DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Denies Florida Death Row Appeal
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Supreme Court denying stay.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday denied a last-minute appeal by a man scheduled to die Friday in Florida's electric chair for killing two police officers 14 years ago. The high court, in an order released at 11:12 p.m. EDT, denied a stay of execution for Jesse Tafero. Justices William Brennan and Thurgood Marshall, who are opposed to any use of the death penalty, dissented. Earlier in the day, the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta turned Tafero down only hours after U.S. District Judge Lenore Nesbitt in Miami refused to issue a writ of habeas corpus in the case. The stay issued by Judge Nesbitt remained in effect until 7 a.m. The Supreme Court had also rejected an appeal by Tafero earlier this week. Mark Olive, appeals attorney for Tafero, refused to comment on the court decisions. Tafero, 43, now on death row at Florida State Prison near Starke, is scheduled to die at 7:01 a.m. Friday for the 1976 slaying of a Florida Highway Patrol trooper and a Canadian constable. He would be the 22nd person executed in Florida and the 124th nationally since the 1976 U.S. Supreme Court ruling allowing states to resume use of the death penalty. The state's last execution occurred exactly one year ago Friday, when former prison guard Aubrey D. Adams was executed for killing a young girl. Tafero, his girlfriend Sonja Jacobs, her two children and traveling companion Walter Rhodes Jr. were sleeping in a a car parked in a rest area on Interstate 95 near Pompano Beach on Feb. 20, 1976, when the two victims approached. Trooper Phillip Black and visiting Canadian constable Donald Irwin of Kitchener, Ontario, were killed when they checked on the car. Black died from gunshot wounds to the head and neck, while Irwin received fatal wounds to his right eye and shoulder. In court, there was a dispute over who did the shooting. Rhodes, who received three concurrent life terms, testified that Tafero and Ms. Jacobs killed the officers. Both were convicted and sentenced to death, but Ms. Jacobs' sentence was commuted to life in prison in 1981. Tafero, a native of Jersey City, N.J., has a long juvenile record and served six years in prison before the killings. His co-defendants remain in Florida prisons.

DOC.HEAD: Singapore Builds More Bomb Shelters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Much of the world plans reductions in military spending, but Singapore, a thriving city-state with no apparent enemies, is building more bomb shelters. About 200 shelters and the same number of air raid sirens will be completed in the next year and Singapore should be ready for its first nationwide drill in 1992, Home Minister Shanmugam Jayakumar said. ``The more shelters, the better,'' he declared. ``This will mean more protection for the public.'' Protection from what? Southeast Asia has been among the world's more stable regions recently, but government leaders insist security remains a problem despite the improvement in U.S.-Soviet relations. That will not change even if the superpowers reduce their military forces in the region, said Lee Hsien Loong, 37, eldest son of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. Lee addressed Parliament as second defense minister. He also has the trade and industry portfolio and is widely viewed as a future prime minister. ``If the United States significantly cuts back its military forces in the region, this will not be a signal for Singapore also to reduce our forces,'' he said. ``It will be reason for concern over a potentially destabilizing change in the regional balance of power.'' Singapore is the only country in the region that openly backs continued U.S. military presence. Officials in several other capitals express private support and public non-alignment. ``Except for Singapore, the nations of Southeast Asia think the American security shield will stand forever, regardless of what they do,'' said Rep. Patricia Schroeder, leader of a House Armed Services Committee delegation that toured the area recently. ``They can boast of their non-aligned purity while reaping the harvest made possible by the American military,'' the Colorado Democrat said. If the United States cannot renew the leases on Philippine bases and is forced to leave, it will need help from friends in the region, she said. Singapore has offered greater access to its air and naval facilities. In his speech to Parliament, Lee said the government would not cut defense spending, reduce the armed forces or end compulsory military training, whatever the United States did. Singapore is about the size of Chicago, with no natural resources except a strategic location between the Pacific and Indian Oceans and the skills of its 2.6 million people, 76 percent of whom are ethnic Chinese. The army, navy and air force have 55,000 regulars and conscripts plus about 200,000 reservists. Analysts rate the Singapore armed forces among the best trained and equipped in the region. Because it is so small, Singapore often holds major military exercises in Brunei, Taiwan or elsewhere. It conducts bilateral maneuvers with other members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations _ Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Brunei and the Philippines _ but ASEAN as a whole does not function as a military alliance. ``No other ASEAN country is slashing its defense expenditures, demobilizing its armed forces or acting on the assumption that it no longer faces any external threats,'' Lee told Parliament. ``It would be foolhardy for Singapore to do so alone.'' Diplomats from ASEAN countries said the countries awaited resolution of two regional problems: the search for a peace formula in Cambodia and negotiations on the U.S. bases. Singapore is in the Five Power Defense Agreement with Australia, Britain, Malaysia and New Zealand. The 1971 pact provides for consultation and cooperation among members if Singapore or Malaysia is attacked or threatened. Defense spending is about 6 percent of Singapore's gross national product, which means the equivalent of $1.9 billion in the current budget. U.S. defense spending in 1988 was 6.1 percent of the gross national product, or $293.1 billion. Some defense funds go to a domestic arms industry that has grown so fast it now seeks export orders and diversification. It was started less than 20 years ago and includes more than 40 companies under the Singapore Technologies umbrella. The government-backed companies evolved from making small arms under license to designing howitzers and upgrading jet fighters. Singapore's ``total defense'' plan was drafted in 1983, while Vietnamese military forces occupied Cambodia, and aims to involve the civilian population with the military in a national emergency. The first air raid drill sent 3,000 volunteers swarming into a new subway station in 1988. Nine underground stations have been fortified to shelter 100,000 people. Shelters also are being built in schools, hospitals and other public facilities. Other civil defense training covers rescue methods, blood donation, mobilization of private motor vehicles and emergency distribution of food and water.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Terri Freeborn tried to spread the word she didn't want to be mayor anymore, but folks didn't listen. She won by four votes. Only 45 of the town's 127 registered voters cast ballots Tuesday, 24 of them for Mrs. Freeborn and 20 for Richard G. Bird, a four-term town council member and Haymarket's vice mayor. One person did not vote in the mayoral contest. Mrs. Freeborn, 38, had decided for personal reasons several weeks ago she did not want to be mayor again of this town of under 500. It was too late to take her name off the ballot, so she tried to spread the word she was out of the race. Mrs. Freeborn, a former interior design specialist who has been mayor since January 1989, said she will ``take it one step at a time'' and serve as long as she is able to balance her family and official obligations. ``I think she's done a very good job to this point and will continue to do so,'' said James T. Shepard, one of two new people elected to the council.

This is one community that's happy a prison is coming to town. Fayette County will hold a parade here Saturday to celebrate construction of a $46.2 million, 926-inmate medium-security prison in nearby Mt. Olive. ``The communities in our region have been devastated by setbacks in the coal industry, and we believe that this correctional facility will provide the first step toward economic recovery,'' said parade chairman Robert Jackson. On hand will be Gov. Gaston Caperton and officials from nearby counties, which also expect to reap economic benefits from the prison. The prison will replace the aging West Virginia Penitentiary in Moundsville, which has been ordered closed by the state Supreme Court by 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Tension High; Governor Rules Out Force to End Indian Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to CORRECT size of reservation to 28,000 acres, sted 14,000, UPDATE with planned meeting in Montreal. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `New York... SUBS 15th graf pvs, `Hubert, like...,' to CORRECT number of people living on reservation.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AB1, XMAS2,XMAS7
DOC.TEXT: Heavily armed police poured into this Mohawk reservation after two people were slain, but Gov. Mario Cuomo on Wednesday ruled out force to put down a 9-month-old dispute over gambling. U.S. and Canadian police sealed off the 28,000-acre reservation that straddles the border. Cuomo said he had ordered the New York Army National Guard to assist state police but would not order guardsmen onto the reservation. ``We will not send military force because of the risk of bloodshed, because of what it would provoke,'' Cuomo told reporter in Albany. ``Before you use military force you should use the force of reason.'' Representatives from six governments were tentatively scheduled to meet Thursday in Montreal to discuss the St. Regis sovereignty issue, according to Micha Menczer, attorney for the Mohawk Council. Officials from Ontario, Quebec and New York, federal officials from the U.S. and Canada, and Indian leaders will be represented at the talks, which will include discussion of the removal of weapons from the reservation and the restoration of law and order, Menczer said. New York State Police carrying shotguns and the Quebec Provincial Force entered the reservation Tuesday night and Wednesday after weeks of violence between pro- and anti-gambling factions culminated in the shooting deaths of two Mohawk men earlier in the day. Cuomo said the National Guard was used to transport troopers and provide equipment at armories in nearby towns. On the Canadian side, Canadian troops provided communications assistance. State troopers denied entry onto the reservation to everyone but residents. They would not divulge the number of troopers on the reservation, but residents said the combined U.S.-Canadian police forces numbered in the hundreds. ``We've got an armed invasion,'' said Diane Lazores, a spokeswoman for the Warrior Society, an armed pro-gambling group. Lazores said state police also were restricting movement of residents within the reservation despite promises made before the action. ``If they want an international incident, they're going to get one,'' she said. The reservation was peaceful Wednesday after nearly a month of nights filled with sporadic gunfire and brawls. Young Mohawk children waited for their school bus beside armed state troopers, while many other Mohawks of all ages stayed at home. ``I'm not venturing out,'' said reservation resident Jack Hubert, a recent retiree. ``I don't want to spend my golden years being shot at.'' Hubert, like the large majority of the approximately 9,000 people living on the reservation, has taken no direct part in the feuding between the two Mohawk factions. ``We're not all looking to get shot, just a few are,'' he said. Up to 600 Mohawks fled to a refugee center in Ontario last week after a week of nightly violence. Junior Edwards, whose body was found near his home in Snye, Quebec, on Tuesday, was described by members of the Warrior Society as pro-gambling. Matthew Pyke was shot to death early Tuesday while walking to the house of a fellow anti-gambling activist. Officials said the deaths prompted state police to break their policy of not setting foot on the reservation unless invited by Mohawk leaders. State police Capt. Richard Garrant said troopers would stay on Mohawk land to ``maintain some type of stability'' until further orders arrived from the governor's office. Fletcher Graves, a mediator from the U.S. Justice Department who has helped the Mohawks resolve other disputes, arrived on the reservation Wednesday afternoon, according to Warriors Society member John Boots. Earlier, Graves said, ``I don't know what my role will be until I get there. We'll talk to every party.'' In Washington, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the Bush administration would not get involved. ``We have no intention to intervene,'' he said. ``It's a matter that needs to be resolved locally.'' Boots said State Police Maj. Robert Leu also arrived to speak with the Mohawks. He said the presence of the state police beyond investigating the two deaths was a ``double-cross,'' and the Warriors have asked the state police to dismantle their roadblocks and leave the reservation. ``I don't want to make a comment on what the reprisal would be when 10,000 Indians get angry,'' Boots said. Barbara Barnes, spokeswoman for the anti-gambling faction, said she was glad that police would be on the reservation. ``People here have no peace of mind. As soon as the police leave, the shots will start again,'' she said. The issue of gambling on the reservation has been at the center of escalating violence since last summer, when an FBI-led gambling raid triggered a 12-day standoff between a pro-gambling group and state police. The FBI claimed the Mohawks had violated federal gaming regulations; the Mohawks claim they are not bound by state or federal gambling laws. Pro-gambling forces say the reservation's six casinos, whose slot machines, craps tables and other games draw busloads of patrons, are an economic boon. Opponents argue they encourage prostitution and drug use and threaten traditional ways. Last summer, a mob of anti-gamblers burned down a casino. Sporadic violence were reported in the fall and winter, but tensions mounted in March when gambling opponents blockaded roads to keep outsiders away from the high-stakes casinos. Last week pro-gamblers tore down the blockades in a hail of gunfire.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Says Parties To Get Access To Secret Police Files
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel says secret police files will be made available to political parties so they may avoid scandal by screening their candidates prior to elections. ``At the request of the political party involved, such screening could be done. Consensus among political parties has been reached in that respect,'' Havel told a news conference on Wednesday. The party would then consider the candidate's fitness to run for office. ``Nobody wants a situation such as we have seen in East Germany where such things (secret police affiliation) were used during and even after the elections as an instrument of political struggle,'' Havel said. ``These things can be done in a more decent way,'' he added, indicating that some potential candidates may indeed have cooperated with the secret police of the Communist regime toppled in last fall's peaceful revolution. Two prominent East German leaders, including former Social Democrat chief Ibrahim Boehme, resigned this year amid allegations they had ties to the secret police of the ousted Communists. Czechoslovakia's first free elections in more than four decades are scheduled for June 8.

DOC.HEAD: New Chairman Maps Kennedy Center Turnaround
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: After barely six weeks on the job, Kennedy Center Chairman James D. Wolfensohn is clear about his goals: give the marble cultural palace a $30 million facelift, fill its stages with arts festivals and lay the welcome mat for inner-city audiences. ``I'm not worried about competition,'' he says. ``I'm worried about my capacity to deliver.'' Wolfensohn, 56, has become a frequent flier aboard the shuttle between Washington and New York _ where he also is chairman of Carnegie Hall and president of a high-powered investment banking firm _ since he took command of the Kennedy Center last month without pay. It didn't take Wolfensohn long to discover that the Kennedy Center is an institution in trouble. He found a deepening financial crisis, generally listless programming _ with a few bright spots _ and nagging confusion over the center's proper artistic role and future direction. When he took the job, Wolfensohn warned the center's trustees that he could spare only two days a week in Washington. Actually, the time has stretched to three or four days, including weekends. ``I'm working very hard,'' he said in an interview. ``But I think now is the time to do it. By the end of the summer, I want to have my arms around the problems. I don't think I will have solved them, but I think I will understand them.'' The most urgent problem was spotted during Wolfensohn's preliminary examination of the Kennedy Center's balance sheets, which showed a cumulative debt of more than $15 million and the desperate need for $30 million in long-delayed renovation and repairs. Wolfensohn said he won a commitment from White House chief of staff John H. Sununu and the center's congressional trustees to find $45 million in federal funds to pay off the debt and refurbish the 18-year-old national center for the performing arts. Wolfensohn agreed to shoulder responsibility for tapping private contributors for the $12 million to $15 million required to finance current levels of programming, after revenues from ticket sales, rentals and other sources. Expanded programming may drive costs to $20 million to $25 million, he estimated. ``Excitement unfortunately comes very expensive today,'' he said. ``And to make this place exciting we're going to need a lot of money.'' Wolfensohn said quality programming is the key to attracting private support and turning the Kennedy Center around. Although built by the government, the center receives no direct federal support for the shows it presents. Wolfensohn wants to build on such innovative but little-recognized Kennedy Center programs as the annual American College Theater Festival and its ``Imagination Celebration'' arts festival for children. He is starting big. He has announced plans for a Texas festival in June 1991, the first of a series intended to showcase the best of performing artists from different states. The same year, he'd like to mount a festival featuring artists from the newly emerging democracies of Eastern Europe. In 1992, he's planning a ``Festival of the Americas,'' with performances by artists from Italy, Spain and North and South America, including native Americans, to mark the 500th anniversary of Columbus' discovery of the New World. Wolfensohn, who grew up in a poor family in Sydney, Australia, has a personal interest in overcoming the Kennedy Center's reputation among local minority residents as an elitist haven for the wealthy. ``You may think I'm naive, but nourishment of the spirit is not a class or financial matter,'' he said. ``I grew up with not a lot of money, and I used to go to free concerts in Sydney. It enriched my life enormously.'' Wolfensohn is mulling a plan to bus 30 or 40 poor families from inner-city neighborhoods to the Kennedy Center every week to introduce them to the performing arts, at little or no cost. ``To bring a child here who then goes home and gets no reinforcement has been a substantial waste of the experience,'' he said. ``Very often it's the parent who's never been here that you make your first and biggest hit with ....'' His goal is to make them ``feel they can come here and enjoy an evening being taken out of themselves, into a new world, into a world of ideas or dreams. If we can give them that, even for a few hours, it can make a difference in their lives.''

DOC.HEAD: Retired Washington Post Advertising Executive Dies
DOC.TEXT: W. Frank Gatewood, retired advertising vice president at The Washington Post, died of pneumonia. He was 88. Gatewood, who retired from the Post in 1969, died on Tuesday in Boca Raton, Fla. He joined the Post in 1954 when it bought the Washington Times-Herald, where he had been business manager. ``He was full of integrity, devotion and ability in the best sense of the word,'' said Katharine Graham, chairman of the board of The Washington Post Co. Gatewood is survived by his wife, Mae, three daughters and seven grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Maine Governor Squares Off With Predecessor in Election Match
DOC.TEXT: Maine voters will re-elect a governor in November. The question is, which one? The choice is between Republican Gov. John R. McKernan and his Democratic predecessor, Rep. Joseph E. Brennan. Brennan has filled McKernan's former seat in Congress since the two exchanged jobs in the 1986 election. The campaign is decidedly issue-oriented _ the economic slump that has gripped the Northeast, environmental pollution and labor relations all loom large. But style may prove as decisive as substance in the outcome of a race many regard as a tossup so far. McKernan, who at 41 is Brennan's junior by 14 years, is the consummate contemporary politician, with boyish good looks, a relaxed public speaking manner and a penchant for staging events tailored for the evening news. Since February 1989, he has been married to Maine's other member of the U.S. House, Republican Rep. Olympia J. Snowe. Brennan comes across as credible and self-confident, and he commands a loyal following that has intensified since he announced in late December that he would take on McKernan. But he is more reserved, almost shy at times, and has never seemed entirely comfortable before TV cameras or large audiences. Running the state government is ``a lot more than style and glitz and photo opportunities and public relations,'' Brennan observed, sizing up his opposition. ``Lackluster'' is a word McKernan uses to sum up his challenger. ``His administration really didn't have a lot of vision, and not a lot of energy, not a lot of creative ideas to try to prepare for the future.'' Brennan was forced out of the governorship by a provision in the state constitution that bars a chief executive who has served two consecutive four-year terms from succeeding himself _ an obstacle that was eliminated by his hiatus in Congress. His decision to give up his seat in southern Maine's 1st Congressional District has opened new opportunities for numerous other players in a political variation of musical chairs. Among the five Democrats competing for the House nomination are state Attorney General James E. Tierney, the party's nominee in the four-way gubernatorial runoff that McKernan won in 1986, and former state housing chief Elizabeth H. Mitchell, who unsuccessfully challenged Republican Sen. William S. Cohen in 1984. The two-way Republican race includes David F. Emery, who held the 1st District seat for eight years prior to McKernan's arrival. In the gubernatorial race, Brennan has taken the early lead in fundraising. In campaign finance reports filed Tuesday, he claimed $354,000 in contributions and more than $285,000 cash on hand through April 24. McKernan, who had $148,000 available out of contributions totaling $273,000, said he put off intensive fundraising until after the legislative session that ended last month. Brennan said McKernan's inferior showing ``reflects a loss of confidence'' in his performance as governor. Each candidate has said he hopes to raise more than $1 million by the general election on Nov. 6. Neither faces opposition in the June 12 primary. McKernan became the first to take his message to the airwaves this week, running a TV campaign commercial touting his skills at managing state government in adverse times. A second ad was to air during the weekend. A prime focus of the commercials, and of the campaign, is McKernan's response to what was once a projected state budget shortfall of $210 million through mid-1991. So far, three of McKernan's New England counterparts _ the governors of Vermont, Massachusetts and Connecticut _ have announced amid similar fiscal problems that they would not seek re-election. McKernan's budget-balancing solution was approved by the Democratic-dominated Legislature with little tampering. ``We've managed this regional problem better than any other state in the same boat, and we did so without raising taxes like so many others,'' McKernan said. But Brennan has hammered away at the issue, questioning why the administration did not recognize the seriousness of the problem sooner. He also charges that the steps taken to balance the budget ultimately will force increases in municipal property taxes. McKernan has challenged Brennan to offer better alternatives and portrays his opponent as a congressman who is ``at the top of the charts in ratings by the special interests'' and has supported ``all sorts of new federal spending.'' ``The message we'll be able to send, thanks to his record, is that he was a lackluster leader for the state, a big spender, and that my re-election is critical to keeping Maine moving forward,'' McKernan said.

DOC.HEAD: 20 Guerrillas Killed in Shootout, Livestock Sperm Bank Blown Up
DOC.TEXT: The army killed 20 Shining Path guerrillas caught trying to blow up a bridge in a northeastern coca producing area, and rebels bombed the country's largest livestock sperm bank, authorities say. Three storage tanks of semen worth several million dollars were destroyed in Wednesday's attack on the government-run sperm bank in Lima, officials said. Four soldiers were wounded in the jungle clash, which occurred Monday as rebels of the Maoist-inspired group were trying to blow up a hanging bridge over the Aguaytia river, a military spokesman said. He said about 30 guerrillas escaped in two trucks after the shootout, which occurred in Ucayali province, a key coca producing area about 240 miles northesast of Lima. Coca leaves are the raw material of cocaine. No people were injured in the attack on the sperm bank, located at the National Agricultural University, but a few stud bulls were slightly hurt when the guerrillas threw two bombs at stables next to the sperm bank. Witnesses said the rebels then fled in a pickup truck. The sperm bank supplies more than 1,000 semen samples a week to Agriculture Ministry breeders. Presidential candidate Alberto Fujimori was rector of the National Agricultural University from 1984 to 1989. Shining Path rebels have attacked numerous agricultural projects throughout Peru in their campaign to cut food supplies in the capital. More than 18,000 people have died in political violence since the Shining Path began its armed insurgency in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Teton-Coal Swap Criticized
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: The Interior Department is pressing ahead with a trade of coal-rich Wyoming land for a pristine view in Grand Teton National Park, despite criticism that the taxpayers will get cheated on the deal. Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., chairman of a House Government Operations subcommittee investigating the swap, said the government is giving away too much coal at the ``fire sale'' price of 2.7 cents a ton. In exchange, the government would receive a ban on development of the largest tract of private land in the Wyoming national park. Both the rights to the coal and the park land were valued at $5.6 million. Synar's environment subcommittee, which was reviewing the exchange at a hearing today, released documents concluding that taxpayers could lose up to $180 million in the transaction because the coal was undervalued. Steve Goldstein, chief spokesman for Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., said he expects the exchange to be finalized in the next few weeks despite the objections. He said the valuation of the coal was correct and based not only on ``real value but the intrinsic value'' of prohibiting development on 1,100 acres on the park. The 207 million tons of coal is under a 2,500-acre tract near Sheridan, Wyo. The park land is the JY Ranch, owned by businessman-conservationist Laurance S. Rockefeller. Rockefeller in 1987 donated the ``conservation easement'' _ basically a scenic view that must remain undeveloped _ to the Sloan-Kettering Memorial Institute for Cancer Research in New York City. The institute would obtain rights to the coal in the trade. Sloan-Kettering ``plans to sell the coal interest and use the proceeds immediately to advance its cancer research programs,'' Bruce A. Bugbee, a representative of the institute, said in written testimony for today's hearing. Rockefeller would retain ownership of the land and the right to construct one additional residence at a specified location. In other testimony submitted for today's hearing, David C. O'Neal, assistant interior secretary for land and minerals management, said the deal ``appears to be an outstanding opportunity to protect Teton National Park from future development while avoiding federal costs associated with acquisition to prevent potential development.'' Synar said Wednesday that it ``strains credulity'' that the department valued the 207 million tons of coal at 2.7 cents a ton. ``At a time of staggering federal deficits, the Department of the Interior should abandon any thought of disposing of publicly owned assets at fire sale prices,'' he said. A major issue in valuing the coal was whether it would be mined or left in the ground. O'Neal said there was ``no expressed interest in the coal'' by mining companies from 1986 until 1989, a period when the department was moving forward with the swap. The initial agreement on the exchange was approved in 1985. But Bugbee made clear in November that by that time, the cancer institute had ``identified parties interested in purchasing the coal who are willing to provide assurances they will proceed immediately ... with the goal of obtaining permits prior to 1995.'' While the Interior Department said its 2.7 cents a ton value is the right amount for undeveloped coal in the ground, Synar said the value should be based on the price that mined coal would have brought the government. When coal is mined on federal land, the government and the state where the vein is located share a royalty of 12.5 percent of the of the selling price. In March 1989, Paul R. Cleary, deputy commissioner of the Wyoming State Land and Farm Loan Office, wrote another state official: ``Assuming a value of $7 per ton and a royalty rate of 12.5 percent, development of the federal coal would generate over $180 million in royalties, of which the state would receive ... some $90 million.'' According to the publication Coal Week, which follows current prices, similar, mined coal in Wyoming sold in mid-April for $4.60 per ton on long term contracts (usually 15 to 25 years) and $3.80 to $4.60 for contracts under a year. At $4.60, the federal-state royalty would be about $119 million. At $3.80 it would total about $98 million.

DOC.HEAD: Atwater's Future Up to Him, GOP Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: Lee Atwater will be the one to decide if his health permits him to continue serving as Republican Party chairman, say GOP officials around the country. ``Until Lee decides what he wants to do, I think we'll defer to Lee before we start speculating,'' said Frank Visco, the California Republican Party chairman. Visco dismissed rumors that Atwater would soon be replaced by Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, a close friend of President Bush. Mosbacher's was one of several names circulating as possible replacements for Atwater. Others included Drew Lewis, a former Pennsylvania GOP chairman who served as transportation secretary during the Reagan administration, and Donald Hodel, twice a member of the Reagan Cabinet as energy and interior secretary. Mary Matalin, chief of staff at the Republican National Committee, said Mosbacher called Atwater to denounce the report as untrue. The White House also said Bush had no intention of making the change. Atwater has received radiation and chemotherapy treatments for a tumor on the right side of his brain. Matalin said Atwater was in George Washington University Hospital, receiving treatment for a blood clot in his left leg. Dr. Stuart Grossman, a neurosurgeon and oncologist at Johns Hopkins University school of medicine in Baltimore, said blood clots are not unusual for brain tumor patients. ``Something predisposes patients with brain tumors to develop clots in the legs,'' he said. ``We don't know why that is.'' ``Patients with clots are treated with a blood thinner and generally do quite well,'' he said. Matalin said she and pollster Robert Teeter visited Atwater at the hospital Sunday and reviewed data on 1990 races. ``This was the best he's been,'' she said. According to Matalin, doctors plan to do another electronic scan of the tumor in the next couple of weeks to assess the effectiveness of the radiation and chemotherapy treatments. ``They're looking for no change,'' she said, an indication that the tumor has stopped growing. ``I was very startled to read that thing about Mosbacher,'' said Jennifer Dunn, the Washington state GOP chairman. ``I called right away to find out what was going on. It turned out it was yet another rumor.'' ``I don't see any change and I can't imagine that George Bush would do that,'' said Anne Ansteine, the Pennsylvania chairman. The RNC meets in Chicago in July. What would otherwise be a routine meeting is certain to be watched closely for signs of whether Atwater will return at some point as a full-time national chairman. ``Lee's going to make that decision,'' said Michele Davis, executive director of the Republican Governors' Association. ``The biggest concern is what's going to happen; is he going to be able to come back?'' said Burton S. Kruglick, the Arizona GOP chairman. He said the July meeting was ``when it's going to have to be decided one way or the other.'' Party officials insisted that Atwater's illness has not disrupted the routine operations of the RNC in this election year. ``We haven't noticed an impact because the programs were in place earlier in the year,'' said Kruglick. ``It's functioning really well,'' said Bruce Benson, the Colorado Republican chairman. Missouri Gov. John Ashcroft, chairman of Republican Governors' Association, said, ``We're going to raise two to three times as much money as has ever been raised before for Republican governors. Lee Atwater's a big part of getting that done.'' ``By March, if we don't have our act together on a state-by-state basis, there's no way we would have made that up,'' said Davis. ``The train had already left the station.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Ted Danson says ``Cheers'' could survive his departure. ``It's a very depressing thought, but it's true. The show has a life of its own,'' said Danson, who will return for a ninth season but isn't sure about a 10th. ``I'm taking the summer off to think about it,'' said Danson, who plays the lothario bartender Sam Malone on the NBC series. Danson is filming ``Three Men and a Lady,'' a sequel to the 1987 box office smash ``Three Men and a Baby.'' He also appeared in the 1989 movies ``Cousins'' and ``Dad.'' ``The question is whether I want to hang around and do a 10th season,'' he said recently. ``I just don't have the legs anymore to run around for eight months doing `Cheers' and then run around three more months doing movies.''

The maker of the Louisville Slugger bat has dropped a breach-of-contract suit against New York Yankees star Don Mattingly. Hillerich & Bradsby, which had sued the first baseman for entering into an endorsement contract with Franklin Sports Industries when he had an agreement with H&B, said Wednesday the alleged breach was not necessarily his fault. ``We think Mattingly is dealing in good faith,'' said H&B lawyer James Milliman. ``We just want a verification from him that our contract's valid.'' H&B said Mattingly is free to endorse other manufacturer's gloves and other baseball products _ but not bats. The company filed an amended complaint alleging Franklin Sports induced Mattingly to violate contracts with H&B. Larry Franklin, president of the Stoughton, Mass., company, had no comment.

A limousine chauffeur served as witness to the weekend marriage of Guns N' Roses lead singer W. Axl Rose and Erin Invicta Everly, daughter of one of the Everly Brothers. Rose, 28, and the 24-year-old daughter of Don Everly were married early Saturday at the Cupid Wedding Chapel. Charles Biondilla, manager of the chapel, said the couple came to the chapel twice before going through with the private five-minute ceremony. ``They were here at midnight first, then they rode around for a few hours in their limousine,'' he said. The band has gained notoriety over its use of racial and sexual slurs on its record ``One in a Million'' and its use of profanity on television.

Men and women should share family responsibilities equally or face family breakdowns, actress Marlo Thomas says. ``I think that unless men start being equal partners in marriage, we're going to have problems with families. Women can't raise families all by themselves, anymore than men can run the world all by themselves,'' she said. ``It's unbalanced. It's like a seesaw sticking up in the air. It has to have the humanity of both partners,'' the wife of talk show host Phil Donahue said at a news conference. Ms. Thomas, the keynote speaker at a Michigan State University conference called ``Kaleidoscope: A Day for Women,'' said responsibilities women carry in the home may be at the root of family problems and violence against women.

Surfer Lance Carson and wave-riding pals like actor Gregory Harrison and surfing champion Tom Curren have recorded an album to save their beloved beaches. Carson, dubbed the Joe DiMaggio of surfing, bemoans what has happened to the ocean since he began riding waves before Gidget was a household name. ``The water is filthy. There are days when you can smell and see miscellaneous waste floating in the water. Sea life is suffering, and we'd better do something now before it's too late,'' Carson said this week. Carson's concern about the ocean led to his participation in the ``Wave Sliders: In a Blue Room,'' an album for the non-profit Surfrider Foundation. The group works to save beaches imperiled by pollution and development. ``Malibu is the crown jewel of surf spots, and now it's a cesspool,'' said Carson, whose 1960s exploits on Malibu beaches were the inspiration for characters in the movies ``Big Wednesday'' and ``Apocalypse Now.''

Plans for a benefit by soul singer James Brown have been nixed by the state Corrections Department. On Monday, a Los Angeles promoter said Brown would hold a concert May 16 in Charleston with Gladys Knight, Little Richard and Jermaine Jackson. A New York concert organizer then said Wednesday that the benefit had been moved Aiken. The department said no to both plans. Brown is serving a six-year sentence for assault and was transferred from prison April 14 to a work-release program. ``As part of being in prison, your liberties are restricted and you're taken away from your commercial life,'' said department spokesman Francis X. Archibald. ``That applies to entertainers, stockbrokers, bankers and anyone else who goes to prison.'' Proceeds from the ``James Brown and Friends'' concert were to have gone to a community group where Brown works as a youth counselor as part of his term.

DOC.HEAD: Two Convicted in Slaying of Milan Police Chief
DOC.TEXT: Two leaders of a leftist revolutionary group have been convicted and sentenced to 22 years in prison for ordering the assassination of Milan's police chief more than a decade ago. The 1972 murder of police chief Luigi Calabresi, one of the longest unsolved cases of political terrorism in Italy, marked the start of more than a decade of leftist and right-wing terrorism in Italy. Leftists considered Calabresi responsible for the death of an anarchist who died after falling from the fourth floor window of a police station, where he was undergoing interrogation. Wednesday's convictions of Adriano Sofri and Giorgio Pietrostefani followed the testimony of one of the assassins, Leonardo Marino. Marino said he and Ovidio Bompressi shot Calabresi outside the police chief's home on orders of Sofri and Pietrostefani, the leaders of Lotta Continua (continuous struggle), an extremist group committed to proletarian revolution. After abandoning the leftist struggle, Pietrostefani became a successful business manager while Sofri, the group's founder, taught at the Florence Fine Arts Academy. Defense lawyers maintainted that the two had nothing to do with the murder and that Marino was falsely accusing them. Sofri and Pietrostefani recieved 22 years, as did Bompressi. Marino was convicted in the assassination and sentenced to an 11-year term.

DOC.HEAD: Amtrak Train Derails, Up to 30 Hurt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with officials now saying up to 27 injured, most not serious, other details. Picks up penultimate graf.
DOC.TEXT: A three-car Amtrak train en route from Chicago to Indianapolis derailed Wednesday night, injuring more than 20 people, authorities said. The accident occurred shortly before 9 p.m. EDT on the eastern edge of Crawfordsville, about 60 miles northwest of Indianapolis, state police said. Amtrak spokeswoman Pat Kelly said 27 people were being taken to a local hospital. David Callecod, spokesman for Culver Union Hospital in Crawfordsville, said 24 people had arrived by early Thursday morning. He said one person was admitted with a concussion and another would be admitted for undetermined injuries, while the others were being treated for minor injuries, such as bumps and bruises. Callecod said earlier that as many as 30 people were to be taken to the hospital. Indiana State Police trooper Mark Cornell, who was at the scene, said the train was switching tracks when it apparently struck the rear end of a stationary freight car and derailed. ``It didn't look like there was an incredible amount of damage,'' he said. Kelley said approximately 35 passengers and crew were aboard the regularily scheduled run from Chicago to Indianapolis. About 25 Crawfordsville firefighters were on the scene, but there were no reports of any fires, said fire department spokesman Bill Myers. The derailment was the second for Amtrak in as many weeks. On April 22, at least 91 people were reported hurt, three seriously, when the national passenger rail line's California Zephyr derailed in Iowa en route to Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Prevents Vertebral Fractures in Elderly Women
DOC.TEXT: A drug can stop and even reverse the loss of bone in the spine and prevent fractures in older women with osteoporosis, a common condition in which the bones become brittle, according to a study today. Danish doctors tested the medicine, called etidronate. Between 15 million and 20 million Americans are estimated to have osteoporosis. The condition is blamed for 1.3 million fractures annually in people over age 45. It is especially common among older women, who develop osteoporosis after menopause when their bodies make less estrogen. The research, directed by Dr. Tommy Storm at Sundby Hospital in Copenhagen, was published in the New England Journal of Medicine. It was financed by Procter & Gamble's Norwich Eaton Pharmaceuticals, which makes etidronate. The doctors performed a three-year comparison study on 66 women, ages 56 to 75. They found that the vertebral bone mineral content of those who got the drug increased 7 percent, while it decreased 3 percent in a comparison group who got dummy pills. The number of vertebral fractures also decreased substantially in the etidronate group. The medicine is approved by the Food and Drug Administration for treatment of Paget's disease, a bone ailment.
EDITORS: Banks, government offices, markets and many businesses are closed in Japan Thursday because of Constitution Day, a national holiday. The AP

DOC.HEAD: America Must Live With Hatred of the Moslems, Scholar Says
DOC.TEXT: America can do little about Islamic rage against the United States except try to understand it and not exacerbate it, says Bernard Lewis, a scholar of the Moslem world. In a prestigious lecture Wednesday night, Lewis tried to explain the ``resentment and anger of the Moslem masses'' toward the West and the United States. ``For vast numbers of Middle Easterners, Western-style economic methods brought poverty, Western-style political institutions brought tyranny, even Western-style warfare brought defeat,'' he said. ``It is hardly surprising that so many were willing to listen to voices telling them that the old Islamic ways were best and that their only salvation was to throw aside the pagan and infidel innovations of the reformers and to return to the True Path which God has prescribed for his people.'' The British-born Lewis, 73, author of 20 books on Islam, is a former history professor at the University of London's School of Oriental and African Studies and at Princeton University until his retirement in 1986. He delivered the 19th annual Jefferson Lecture, an honor bestowed by the National Endowment for the Humanities. The lecture carries a $10,000 stipend. Lewis will repeat the talk tonight at the Hoover Institution and Stanford University in California. In time, Lewis said, more tolerant strands in Islamic tradition may prevail over the forces now dominant. But ``we of the West can do little or nothing'' to affect the outcome, he said. It is an issue ``which Moslems, and only Moslems, must decide among themselves.'' ``And in the meantime, we must take great care, on all sides, to avoid the danger of a new era of religious wars, arising from the exacerbation of differences and the revival of ancient, long-forgotten prejudices.'' The detestation of the West _ as demonstrated by such episodes as the 444-day Tehran embassy hostage crisis that ended in 1981 _ is partly an outgrowth of Moslem ``humiliation,'' Lewis said. In the Islamic world, he said, is ``a growing awareness, among the heirs of an old, proud and for long dominant civilization, of having been overtaken, overborne and overwhelmed by those whom they had long regarded as their inferiors.'' The hatred of America is only the latest outbreak in a battle between the Islamic world and Christendom that already has lasted for 14 centuries, Lewis said, and Islam was winning the battle for the first 1,000 years. The recent resurgence of Islamic fundamentalism, he said, gives shape to the mass anger. ``The instinct of the masses is not false in locating the ultimate source of these cataclysmic changes in the West and in attributing the disruption of their old way of life to the impact of Western domination, Western influence or Western precept and example,'' he said. Since America is the leader of the West, he said, America has become the target. Lewis argued that it was ``crucially important'' that Americans study Islam's heritage and understand the hatred so as not to be provoked ``into an equally historic but also equally irrational reaction against them.''

DOC.HEAD: St. Paul Editor to Head Newhouse in Washington
DOC.TEXT: Deborah Howell, editor of the Saint Paul (Minn.) Pioneer Press, has been named Washington bureau chief for Newhouse newspapers and editor of the Newhouse News Service, according to a company statement. Ms. Howell, 49, succeeds Robert G. Fichenberg, 70, who has been head of the Newhouse bureau in Washington since 1978. Fichenberg will retire in 1991 and in the meantime will serve as senior correspondent, said the statement issued Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Pierce Lawyers Denounce Gilliam
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for former HUD Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. say a former aide who testified that Pierce manipulated federal programs to help friends is ``an admitted cheat and liar'' who can't be believed. DuBois L. Gilliam, who has admitted taking bribes and rigging housing subsidies while Pierce's assistant, finishes a week of testimony Friday before a congressional subcommittee investigating scandals at Department of Housing and Urban Development during the Reagan administration. The panel's chairman, Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., said Pierce should drop his use of Fifth Amendment protections against self-incrimination and agree to appear immediately ``to respond under oath to any of the testimony of Mr. Gilliam.'' After denouncing Lantos' panel for ``an insatiable appetite for publicity,'' Pierce's lawyers attacked Gilliam's credibility Wednesday. ``Mr. Pierce denies all allegations of wrongdoing and improper conduct,'' attorney Paul L. Perito said. ``It is inconceivable that this subcommittee has accepted at face value the unsubstantiated testimony of an admitted cheat and liar who repeatedly violated the public's trust while at HUD.'' He charged that Gilliam admitted to 10 to 12 additional felonies in his first two days of testimony before the panel _ testimony for which he received a court's grant of immunity from further prosecution. Gilliam is in the middle of an 18-month federal prison sentence for abuses of HUD programs. Although Perito said Gilliam's motive in testifying was an early release from prison, Lantos and other members of the House Government Operations subcommittee on housing and employment said they found him a credible witness. Lantos said Gilliam is eligible for parole at any time, and will have served out his sentence by the end of the year. While granted immunity, he risks a perjury conviction if he lies to the panel. ``I have no reason to lie, no reason whatsoever,'' Gilliam said. Pierce himself is under investigation by an independent counsel. Gilliam said he, Pierce and others manipulated programs to direct project grants and lucrative subsidies to friends, sometimes before any formal applications were made. Gilliam said he arranged for more profits for himself after he left HUD by securing subsidies for future business partners. He said he secretly removed incriminating documents from the agency in a medicine bag. He linked President Bush, while vice president, to a 1985 federal grant of $500,000 for a Hispanic trade center in Kansas City, Mo. Gilliam said he took unusual steps to award the grant in 1985 after Hector Barreto, then president of the U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce and a political supporter of Bush and President Reagan, met with the vice president. Gilliam said that after telling Barreto that his proposal for a feasibility study was not eligible for funding by HUD under the secretary's discretion program, Barreto met with Bush. Later the same afternoon, Gilliam said, Pierce's executive assistant, Deborah Gore Dean, ``indicated to me that she had received a call from the vice president's staff people indicating their support and wanted to get the project funded.'' As a result, Gilliam said, he persuaded a Kansas City official to make the grant from the city's Community Development Block Grant funds provided by HUD. In turn, Gilliam said he arranged to have a special grant from the secretary's discretionary fund go to Kansas City to replace that money. ``In other words, let's make a deal _ you do this and I'll do this,'' Gilliam said. Barreto told The Kansas City Star that he met with Bush more than 25 times since 1980 and often discussed various projects that needed funding. He said he specifically discussed the trade center with Bush at least two or three times, but he denied that he used his political connections to receive grant money. ``If that were the case, we would be swimming in money right now,'' he said. ``This is not like we get these grants so we can pay ourselves,'' Barreto said. ``I think it (the trade center) was a project that made sense ....'' He said the project was still in the works. Asked for comment on Gilliam's testimony, Steve Hart, a deputy White House press secretary, said: ``We don't know anything about it.'' Gilliam left the agency in 1987 when HUD's inspector general began investigating him. Despite that cloud, Gilliam said he requested and was given approval from Pierce through an aide to receive grants for low-income housing renovations _ in effect a severance payment worth $1 million or more in resale value to developers. He ultimately did not receive them. But Gilliam said Ms. Dean discussed his request for 400 units of subsidy with Pierce and returned saying, ``I could have 250 ... I couldn't have 400 because I was being greedy.''

DOC.HEAD: Accused Nazi Labor Camp Chief Extradited to West Germany
DOC.TEXT: After losing a 30-month battle against extradition, Joseph Schwammberger was flown to West Germany to face charges he oversaw or took part in the slaughter of thousands of Jews as head of a Nazi labor camp. Schwammberger, 78, was put aboard a Lufthansa commercial flight to Frankfurt on Wednesday accompanied by a doctor, his attorney and West German officials of Interpol, the international police organization. Argentina's Supreme Court late last month upheld the extradition of Schwammberger, who fled to Argentina after escaping from Allied authorities in the late 1940s but was captured at an Argentine ranch in 1987. ``He is charged with provoking the deaths of several thousand Jews, and of personally killing some,'' said Wolfgang Siegel, a spokesman for the West German Embassy. Siegel said that after arriving in Frankfurt, Schwammberger would be taken to Stuttgart, site of the court that had asked for his extradition. Schwammberger is accused of commanding forced labor camps at Przemysl and Mielec in Nazi-occupied Poland at which thousands of inmates, mostly Jews, were executed. Survivors testified he starved prisoners, used dogs to tear them apart, and threw people alive into fires. Rabbi Marvin Hier of the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles, which gathered evidence against Schwammberger, said in a telephone interview: ``Here we are not dealing with an administrator, but with a man who participated directly; a man who rolled up his sleeves and bloodied his hands every day.'' ``This case will be exceptional in the sense that 45 years after the crimes were committed,'' the accused will be brought to trial, Hier said, adding that the center has 73 witnesses who are prepared to testify against Schwammberger. Hier said Schwammberger was arrested by the French army in 1945, but escaped three years later from a train taking him to U.S. military authorities in Austria for trial. Using his own name, Schwammberger eventually settled in Argentina; worked at a petrochemical plant in La Plata, 30 miles south of the Buenos Aires; and obtained Argentine citizenship in 1965, Hier reported. A Stuttgart court ordered his arrest in 1973. At the time, he was believed to be living in Argentina, where there is a sizeable population of German-speaking immigrants. Many Nazis fled to South America following the defeat of Adolf Hitler's Germany. In October 1987, the Simon Wiesenthal Center placed Schwammberger on its most wanted Nazi war criminals list. Argentine newspapers published the list, and police received information about Schwammberger. He was taken into custody on Nov. 13, 1987 at a ranch in Huerta Grande, 500 miles northwest of Buenos Aires. He has been held in jail since. Defense attorneys asked Argentina to reject an extradition request on the ground that Schwammberger was an Argentine citizen, or to hold the trial in Argentina. The Federal Appeals Court in La Plata rejected their argument in August, ruling that the crimes Schwammberger is accused of committing occurred before he was an Argentine citizen. The Supreme Court upheld that ruling on March 23. In 1960, Adolph Eichmann, a major figure in devising the ``final solution'' in which Jews were rounded up and executed, was kidnapped in Buenos Aires by Israeli agents, convicted at a trial in Jerusalem and hanged. Dutch officials have asked Argentine police to look for Abraham Kipp, who was sentenced to death for crimes committed against Jews during the war. In 1953, Kipp was naturalized as an Argentine citizen.

DOC.HEAD: Paleontologist Searching For `Serial Killer' of Dinosaurs
DOC.TEXT: Small land animals _ including the ferocious 6-ounce ``Mutant Ninja Chipmunk'' _ thrived while an environmental crisis killed off most giant dinosaurs more than 100 million years ago, a researcher found. Dr. Robert Bakker, a University of Colorado paleontologist, said fossils recently unearthed from a 130-million-year-old deposit in a rock quarry in Wyoming showed small dinosaurs, mammals, turtles and other animals flourished in the early Cretaceous period a few million years after the giant dinosaurs that lived in the Jurassic period became extinct. ``The new fossils are the remains of animals that lived in a crisis interval during the early Cretaceous Period, and this is the first rock layer that seems to record just what happened and why,'' Bakker said Wednesday. His preliminary findings were published April 15 in the proceedings of the Fourth North American Paleontological Congress. With several colleagues, Bakker, who first identified the fossil beds in the 1970s, unearthed a wide array of ``fossil miniatures'' from the 10- to 12-foot thick deposit known as ``Breakfast Bench'' near the town of Rock River. The specimens date to the earliest part of the Cretaceous period, a transitional period following the demise of long-necked, giant dinosaurs such as brontosaurus, supersaurus and diplodocus. Bakker said the deposit provides evidence of a classic case of ``David and Goliath'' _ a variety of diminutive creatures overshadowed the great dinosaurs for a time. After the dinosaurs evolved into a new line of giants, again eclipsing small animals, the same scenario apparently was played out about 65 million years later at the end of the Cretaceous period, when another catastrophe of some kind killed off all dinosaurs. New species unearthed at the site include a 20-pound herbivorous dinosaur, a pair of fierce rodent-like mammals weighing less than a pound each and a neurologically sophisticated turtle, Bakker said. Numerous crocodilian remains also were found, he said. The sudden appearance of Zofiabaatar, a 6-ounce furry meat-eater that Bakker nicknamed the ``Mutant Ninja Chipmunk,'' illustrates small mammals were taking evolutionary advantage of the swampy environment during the crisis, he said. Scientists have long been puzzled by the mass extinctions at the end of the Jurassic period, and theories focus on such factors as movements of the Earth, starvation, parasites, poisons, changes in climate and meteorites. But according to Bakker, dinosaurs became extinct because of worldwide diseases that turned into an ``epidemiological nightmare.'' ``Dinosaurs didn't go out with a bang, they went out with worldwide diarrhea,'' he said. Big animals travel and are extremely vulnerable to disease, Bakker said. As land bridges formed throughout the globe, the animals spread hundreds of diseases throughout all continents _ eventually killing the lot. ``If you're a species one of the most dangerous things you can do is to invade a continent or have a foreign species move in,'' he said. ``So the stay-at-homes have an automatic immunity to this tourist trap of exotic disease.'' The newly identified creatures apparently thrived in the swampy, fern-choked environment that marked the end of the Jurassic and the beginning of the Cretaceous periods, Bakker said. Since fern-choked swamps also were present at the end of the Cretaceous and during times of other mass die-offs, they may help explain why dinosaurs and other large land animals suffered repeated extinctions. ``Scientists studying mass extinction are like criminologists tracking a serial killer _ the clues that finally catch the killer usually come from the repeated pattern in the way the crimes were committed,'' Bakker said.

DOC.HEAD: Legislators Call for Immediate Action to Cut Pollution
DOC.TEXT: Legislators from 42 nations, disagreeing with President Bush, say the time is now for specific moves to reduce the pollution that is causing global warming. An international conference of lawmakers on the environment concluded Wednesday with a call for specific curbs in so-called ``greenhouse'' gases and development of a ``global Marshall Plan'' to help developing countries deal with environmental problems. ``This conference has given us an agenda for action,'' said James Miruka Owuor, a conference co-chairman from Kenya. The three-day legislative gathering was hosted by the U.S. Congress. The conference goals and resolutions are not binding on any country, but they are expected to be used by environmental activists in legislative bodies as a way to push for new laws to deal with international environmental problems, participants said. Some 200 lawmakers from the 42 nations, including the Soviet Union, most European countries, Japan and many developing nations, took part in the conference. ``We have come to a consensus agreement that the need for action is now, that the need for action is urgent,'' said Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., the conference chairman. Delegates to the Interparliamentary Conference on the Global Environment called for: _Nations to make a specific commitment for a 50 percent reduction in global-warming gases over the next 20 years, including elimination of the use of ozone-depleting chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, and a 20 percent cut in carbon dioxide emissions, largely from the burning of fossil fuels. _Development of a so-called ``global Marshall Plan'' by industrial nations to help developing countries deal with international environmental problems such as global warming, ozone deterioration, loss of forests and other matters. _Greater efforts to deal with population growth so that the world's population could be stabilized at 10 billion people in the next century. The link between population growth and environmental deterioration must be acknowledged, the delegates said. The policy statements and goals provided few specifics on where the money would come to pay for the new programs. Some delegates suggested that money from the ``peace dividend'' derived from improved East-West relations be used to combat environmental problems. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee and a conference delegate, called the conference's closing declaration ``an extraordinary statement of potential legislative strategies.'' But Dingell, whose committee would act on most global-warming legislation, said he doubted any such bills would be approved this year. Nevertheless, the aggressive strategies outlined by the legislators contrasted with the more cautious approach for dealing with environmental problems favored by the Bush administration. For example, the president told an international White House Conference on the environment two weeks ago that more research was needed before any commitments are made for specific pollution controls on global warming. ``I think this is a message to the executive branch here in the United States'' and in other countries as well, Gore said of the resolutions approved by the legislators. ``For any prime minister or president who says delay, we are saying ... the time is now to act.'' On global warming, the conference agreed, declaring: ``Delay exposes us, our children and their children to calamities which we will have made irrevocable by inaction in the present.'' The delegates called for setting a timetable for specific cuts in global-warming pollutants by the year 2010, including a 20 percent reduction in carbon dioxide emissions, a product of burning fossil fuels; elimination of CFCs and a variety of other ozone-depleting chemicals; and a 10 percent reduction in methane emissions. Altogether, that would amount to about a 50 percent reduction in global-warming pollutants by 2010, conference organizers said.

DOC.HEAD: No Ethics Committee Decision Yet in Barney Frank Case
DOC.TEXT: The House ethics committee is struggling to reach a consensus in the investigation of Rep. Barney Frank, a case that involves the Massachusetts Democrat's private homosexual life. After the committee ended its latest meeting Wednesday without any announcement, Chairman Julian C. Dixon, D-Calif., said he was too hasty last week in predicting a decision was near. He acknowledged it was difficult to interpret House rules in the Frank case. He did not immediately schedule a new meeting of the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. Dixon wouldn't provide details on the roadblock, but sources insisting on anonymity said some Republican members are urging a united front that could withstand a promised challenge to their report on the House floor. Prevailing on the floor could require some tough language in a report on Frank's behavior, even if there's no punishment. The committee has declined to file charges of rulebreaking in recent investigations of House Republican Whip New Gingrich of Georgia and Gus Savage, D-Ill. But it warned them not to repeat certain conduct. Rep. William E. Dannemeyer, a conservative California Republican, has said that after the committee makes a report, he would move on the floor to expel Frank. The committee is not expected to recommend a severe punishment for Frank, and based on past experience, would not consider expulsion in a case like this. ``They want to make sure all the bases are covered,'' one source said of the Republican members. ``They don't want something that will be overturned.'' Rep. Louis Stokes, D-Ohio, who is sitting on the panel just for the Frank case, said ``everybody's aware of what he (Dannemeyer) wants to do.'' The panel's ranking Republican, Rep. John T. Myers of Indiana, denied that the deliberations are partisan, or that Dannemeyer's threat is driving the deliberations. ``We're still examining facts,'' Myers said. He noted that while some preliminary votes broke down along partisan lines in a investigation of former Speaker Jim Wright last year, the final decision to charge Wright with breaking the rules was unanimous. Wright resigned before the committee made its recommendations to the House. Dixon also denied there was any anger among committee members, saying, ``All the colleagues are in good spirit and there's no cantankerous attitude in there.'' The case centers on Frank's relationship with a male prostitute, Steve Gobie. Frank admitted paying for sex with Gobie and later hiring him with personal money to serve as a housekeeper and aide. Frank, prodded by a May 8 filing deadline, announced April 17 he would seek re-election regardless of the committee's next step. The case formally began Sept. 11, when the committee began a preliminary investigation. Several weeks earlier, the homosexual relationship between Gobie and the five-term House veteran was revealed by The Washington Times. Frank has faced allegations that he knowingly allowed Gobie to operate a prostitution ring out of Frank's Capitol Hill apartment, that the two men had sex in the House gymnasium and that Frank invoked congressional privilege to waive parking tickets incurred by Gobie while using Frank's car to keep appointments for illicit sex. Frank denied each of those allegations. He said he paid Gobie $80 for sex in 1985, then hired him as a housekeeper and driver in hopes of reforming the prostitute's life. Frank said he fired Gobie in August 1987 after learning of Gobie's prostitution operation from the lawmaker's residence. Frank said it was ``absolutely untrue'' that he knew Gobie was selling sex from his apartment and contended there was ``no basis whatsoever'' to the story about sex in the House gym. He said he did ask that parking tickets be waived when the car was used for official business.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Forecasts Ahead?
DOC.TEXT: ``Good evening. Tonight's forecast calls for a 40 percent chance of rain and a 10 percent chance of a big earthquake.'' Californians may be tuning into such bulletins soon as seismologists put their computer models to work to issue warnings after ominous rattles of the Earth. The seismologists have gathered enough data on major fault systems in California to be able to predict, to some degree, the probability of a quake of 6.5 or more on the Richter scale within certain brief periods. After a foreshock of magnitude of 4.0 or greater is registered, the model will go into work, determining whether there is, say, a 5, 10 or 25 percent chance of a quake within the next three days. The developers of the model are ready to put it into use but are discussing with the state how the predictions will be used _ whether they will be released publicly as earthquake warnings or provided to state agencies so they can prepare. The model is a mathematical formula that uses data on fault activity and the probability of major shocks, Lucile M. Jones of the U.S. Geological Survey said at a meeting Wednesday of the Seismological Society of America. Seismologists long have known that big quakes generally are preceded by less powerful shocks, but the new system is more precise, Jones said. Jones said a study of the major faults in California indicates, for example, that in the relatively quiet Carrizo Plain southwest of Fresno the chance that a 5-magnitude quake will be a foreshock to an 8-magnitude quake is 24 percent. Jones, who developed the formula with Duncan C. Agnew of the University of California-San Diego, said scientists will probably never be able to predict with absolute certainty. But the percentages she can deliver are enough to let people take action to prevent damage or injury, Jones said. ``As scientists we feel that sharing information is always better than withholding information,'' she said. The state could use the information to cancel vacations for disaster personnel, Jones said. Fire stations could move trucks outside. Daycare centers could leave gates unlocked in case they need to evacuate quickly. Residents could fill bathtubs with water for drinking, put away dishes and prepare emergency supplies. ``Each individual group can start making those sorts of decisions,'' she said. ``We aren't at a really high level (of accuracy), but people have been trying to get us to make these statements because there are useful things to do. And as we get better, the probabilities are going to head up.'' Geologist Jim Davis of the California Division of Mines and Geology said he is talking with the Office of Emergency Services about whether the agency should announce earthquake warnings. Davis said he didn't think quake forecasts would unduly alarm people or otherwise cause harm. The prediction system has been worked out so far only for California, whose seismic activity has been closely studied by scientists.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Votes To Subpoena, Immunize Milken
DOC.TEXT: A House panel intends to offer convicted junk bond financier Michael Milken immunity from prosecution for testimony he previously refused to give. The Energy and Commerce oversight and investigations subcommittee voted unanimously Wednesday to subpoena Milken, who pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties last week. If Milken receives immunity from the panel, nothing he says at a congressional hearing could be used against him in court. Before Milken is called to testify before Congress _ something he refused to do two years ago _ the subpoena must be approved by the full Energy and Commerce Committee. Milken, once head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s high-risk, high-yield bond department, faces up to 28 years in prison when he is sentenced in New York on Oct. 1. In settling civil and criminal charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department, Milken agreed to testify truthfully before grand juries and at trials or court proceedings stemming from ``any Drexel-related activities.'' If Milken fails to comply with those rules he can be prosecuted for perjury and obstruction of justice and jailed for contempt of court under the settlement. The agreements do not specifically mention congressional testimony. A spokesman for Milken in New York declined to comment on the subcommittee vote. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of both the full committee and subcommittee, announced last week that he intended to recall Milken as a witness now that his four-year battle with the government is drawing to a close. Dingell wants to know about some 400 limited partnerships _ controlled largely by Drexel employees _ that bought significant stakes in junk bond issues underwritten by Drexel before they were made available to the public. Critics say the activity drove up the price of those issues at the expense of Drexel customers, but the transactions' legality has never been resolved. Milken was called to testify before the subcommittee in 1988 but invoked his Fifth Amendment right against possible self-incrimination. A subpoena also was authorized at that time for convicted stock speculator Ivan F. Boesky, who was linked to Milken in a number of illegal deals. ``It had been served, but the subcommittee was holding off on it until the disposition of the Milken to see whether Boesky would testify at a Milken trial,'' said the congressional aide, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Boesky settled SEC insider-trading charges by pleading guilty to one felony count and paying $100 million in fines and restitution. He was freed last month after serving two years of a three-year prison sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Democrats to Include Public Financing in Campaign Bill
DOC.TEXT: Senate Democratic leaders plan to make public financing of Senate campaigns a major portion of a revised election financing package, congressional sources say. One of the sources said the Senate leadership plan, scheduled to be unveiled today, would include full public financing of Senate general elections for candidates who agree to voluntary spending limits. Another source said public financing was a centerpiece of the Democratic plan but declined to give details. Both sources spoke Wednesday on the condition of anonymity. A spokesman for Sen. John F. Kerry, D-Mass., the sponsor of legislation creating public financing of Senate campaigns, declined comment when asked if Kerry's proposal had been accepted by the Democratic leadership. The spokesman, Larry Carpman, referred all questions to the office of Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. Mitchell spokeswoman Diane Dewhurst also refused to comment. ``We will have an announcement of the Democratic package (Thursday) afternoon,'' she said. That proposal will be the starting point for the floor debate and, more importantly, for negotiations with the chamber's Republican leaders. Mitchell said earlier in the week that Democratic support for some kind of public financing was growing, but would not discuss specifics of the revised Democratic plan. The Senate floor debate, would could begin this week, will open with Democrats and Republicans offering starkly different plans. The GOP floor leader, Kentucky Sen. Mitch McConnell, unveiled a Republican plan Tuesday that would ban all political action committee contributions. Many in the Democratic majority oppose an outright ban on PACs, whose donations tend to favor incumbents. Republicans have opposed public financing and the spending limits espoused by Mitchell and Sen. David Boren, D-Okla. Past proposals brought to the floor have shied away from public financing, which under the Kerry plan would be paid for by increasing the voluntary checkoff on tax returns from $1 to $3. There remains considerable opposition to public financing in both parties, but public interest groups seeking campaign finance reform have said its inclusion in the initial Democratic bill at least would help their position in the negotiations. Other incentives for accepting spending limits expected in the Democratic plan include reduced broadcast and mailing rates. Public financing of general elections would leave the door open for PAC involvement in primaries, and the Democrats are expected to propose a limit on PAC spending in those races.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor's Lawyer Seeks Dismissal of Drug Case
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry's attorney says prosecutors jeopardized the mayor's health and went too far in supplying crack cocaine the night he was arrested on a drug charge. Attorney R. Kenneth Mundy, in a motion filed in U.S. District Court, said the eight-count drug possession and perjury case against Barry should be dropped because prosecutors allowed the mayor to use drugs before arresting him. Mundy accused the government of ``prosecutorial overreach'' for supplying the crack cocaine and cocaine pipe Barry used. ``This over-involvement is unprecedented,'' Mundy wrote in the motion released Wednesday. ``There appears to be no case in which such elaborate and dangerous preparations were employed to prove that a suspect was a mere user.'' In earlier filings, U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens argued that prosecutors routinely provide illegal drugs to suspects in undercover drug buys. Mundy had complained that the government's action had been coercive, but Stephens cited a Supreme Court ruling that such procedures were commonly used ``in contraband offenses, which are so difficult to detect in the absence of undercover government involvement.'' Stephens also argued in the earlier filing that ``to require the agent to interrupt the use of the controlled substance likely would compromise the investigation.'' But Mundy, noting that medical technicians were present to examine the mayor after he used the cocaine, argued that the government acted illegally in allowing the mayor to smoke the cocaine. ``The fact that the medical technicians were available does not make the government's conduct any less offensive,'' Mundy said. ``It only corroborates the fact that they knew the plan was potentially life-threatening.'' Mundy concluded by referring to previous cases which were dismissed because prosecutors used ``coercion, violence or brutality.'' Stephens has until Monday to file a response to Mundy's pleading. Barry, 54, faces five misdemeanor cocaine possession charges and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his drug use. The trial is scheduled to start June 4. One of the possession charges stems from his Jan. 18 arrest in the undercover FBI sting operation, while the other four possession charges and the perjury counts come from a 16-month probe into Barry's ties to a convicted drug dealer. Meanwhile, the executive committee of the District of Columbia Democratic State Committee was expected to present a resolution today to the full committee asking Barry not to seek re-election this year, WTTG-TV reported Wednesday. The resolution urged Barry ``to consider the best interests of the citizens ... (and) not seek re-nomination in 1990,'' according to the television station. The mayor, who aides said intends to run for re-election in November, went through seven weeks of substance abuse treatment following his arrest. Barry has said he was suffering from alcoholism, but top aides said he had a cocaine problem as well. Barry has not yet publicly revealed his re-election plans. If convicted of a felony, Barry would be barred from holding office or running for re-election.
