DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Upholds Death Penalty Law in Illinois
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court reversed a judge and upheld the state's death penalty law, opening the way for Illinois' first execution in 28 years. The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in a 3-0 decision, on Wednesday overturned a ruling last year that the 1977 capital punishment law gives prosecutors too much leeway in whether to seek the death penalty. The ruling came in the case of Charles Silagy, convicted of the 1980 murders of his girlfriend and another woman. He is one of 124 inmates on death row in Illinois. No one has been executed in the state since 1962. On Monday, the U.S. Supreme Court cleared the way for the execution of Charles Walker by ruling that five people who challenged his death sentence without his support had no standing in the case. Walker, condemned in 1983 after pleading guilty to killing two people, is closest to being executed of the state's death-row inmates. Walker has said he wants to die and has abandoned all appeals. No execution date has been set, but corrections officials said it could come within 60 to 90 days. Silagy's execution could come this year as well, said Attorney General Neil Hartigan. Hartigan called the Silagy ruling a ``very substantial victory for the people of Illinois.'' Jay Miller, executive director of the Illinois chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, said his organization was unhappy with both rulings. ``We believe it's past the time when the United States should have a death penalty,'' Miller said. ``We're left with the Soviet Union and South Africa among Western nations having the death penalty.'' Wednesday's ruling reversed the decision of U.S. District Judge Harold Baker, who found the death penalty law unconstitutional. Under the law, Illinois prosecutors can wait until after a conviction to say whether they will seek the death penalty. Silagy's lawyers had argued their handling of the case was hampered by not knowing what prosecutors would do. But the appeals court rejected Baker's contention that Illinois law allowed prosecutors to be ``arbitrary and capricious'' or hindered defense attorneys. In fact, the court said, Illinois' law may even ``enhance the quality of prosecutorial decisions'' by permitting the prosecutor to ``weigh all of the evidence ... in his assessment of the propriety of seeking the death penalty.''

DOC.HEAD: DEA Head Denies Agency Involvement in Doctor's Abduction
DOC.TEXT: Drug enforcement chief Terrence M. Burke says his agency was not involved in the kidnapping of a Mexican doctor sent to the United States to face charges in the murder of a drug agent. ``We did not have any agent actively participate in the planning and execution'' of the operation, the acting head of the Drug Enforcement Administration told a Senate hearing Wednesday. Humberto Alvarez Machain was abducted from his Guadalajara office on April 2 and flown by private jet to El Paso, Texas. There he was arrested for allegedly participating in the 1985 torture-killing of DEA agent Enrique Camerena. Mexico's government has strongly protested the way Alvarez Machain was captured and has demanded the extradition of anyone involved. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari complained to Vice President Dan Quayle last week in Mexico City, and Quayle told him no American agents were involved. The DEA has placed a high priority on capturing those suspected of involvement in Camarena's killing. American authorities believe Alvarez Machain monitored Camarena's condition during the torture. Salinas, speaking at The Associated Press annual luncheon April 23 in Los Angeles, said the seizure of Alvarez Machain could jeopardize the war against drugs. ``This runs the risk of creating illegal habits among those who have the obligation of defending the law and could create a problem much larger than the one we are trying to combat,'' he said. But Burke told the Senate Appropriations Committee, ``We broke no United States law that I'm aware of.'' The panel fashions the Justice Department's money bill. Senators noted published reports that a former Mexican police official has been on the DEA payroll and may have participated in planning the Alvarez Machain abduction. They did not press Burke on the point. Four men claiming to be Mexican federal police seized the gynecologist on April 2. Mexican authorities said Saturday that a former Mexican policeman arrested in connection with the abduction said he was told it was a DEA operation. Burke said he met with Mexican officials last week and assured them American agents did not take part in the operation. A long line of U.S. court decisions have held that a fugitive can stand trial in the United States even if the arrest overseas was improper or illegal.

DOC.HEAD: White Supremacists Sentenced in Hate Crimes
DOC.TEXT: Five white supremacist ``skinheads'' accused of plotting to pump cyanide gas into a synagogue drew prison terms ranging from about five to nine years, an outcome a rabbi said showed ``the system worked.'' An all-white jury found the five guilty March 1 of conspiracy to violate the civil rights of minorities in 1988 by defacing a synagogue and Jewish community center and chasing blacks and Hispanics from Robert E. Lee Park. U.S. District Judge Barefoot Sanders sentenced the men Wednesday. ``This should send a warning across the nation that young racists cannot commit crimes of hate,'' said Barry Kowalski, a prosecutor with the U.S. Justice Department's civil rights division. ``They can believe what they want and say what they want, but they better not vandalize or commit acts of violence.'' Defense lawyers charged their clients were tried for their beliefs and said the men merely were exercising their right to free speech. Former members of the Confederate Hammerskins had testified the skinhead gang planned to pump cyanide into Temple Shalom in a reminder of the Holocaust. Defense attorneys said the group intended only to cut the air conditioning. ``It's a good and a bad day,'' said Rabbi Kenneth Roseman of Temple Shalom. ``It's a bad day we have to do this kind of thing. It's a good day the system worked.'' Jon Lance Jordan, 19, of Garland, received nearly 8{ years in prison and Daniel Alvis Wood, 20, of Dallas, got 9{. They were also convicted of weapons violations. Wood was previously sentenced in state court to 10 years in prison and fined $5,000 for spraying swastikas and anti-Semitic slogans on the synagogue. His federal sentence will run concurrently with the state sentence, Sanders said. Sean Christian Tarrant, 20, of Dallas, received nine years; Michael Lewis Lawrence, 22, of Tulsa, Okla., 4} years, and Christopher Barry Greer, 25, of Irving, 6{ years. The men could have faced up to 20 years in prison for the civil rights violations. Some skinheads, characterized by their closely shaven heads, espouse hatred of Jews, blacks, Hispanics and homosexuals.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Commits Suicide, Labor Protests Continue
DOC.TEXT: A 28-year-old worker committed suicide today by dousing himself with paint thinner, setting it ablaze and jumping from a building, the first fatality in a wave of labor unrest, news reports said. Kim Young-il, a worker at the Tongil Industry Co. in the southern town of Changwon, died of burns and head injuries two hours after he jumped from the roof of a two-story building, the reports said. The national new agency Yonhap said Kim left two letters, complaining of a hard life and protesting alleged police suppression of labor activity. ``Why is my life so hard, Mother?'' Kim said in one letter addressed to his family. ``This society is making people who want to live an honest life angry.'' In the other letter, addressed to his company, he worker wrote: ``I want to fight against Tongil managers and their capitalists, Sung Myung Moon and Moon Sung-kun.'' The company is owned by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the founder of the Unification Church. Moon Sung-kun, a son of the minister, is reported to be directly invovled in the company's operation. The company supplies axles and other parts for the Hyundai Motor Co., the nation's largest automaker and the target of a strike by workers seeking greater influence for unions. The nationwide labor unrest, which has paralyzed many export industries, began Saturday when police stormed the strike-bound Hyundai shipyard in Ulsan. Workers at the yard _ the world's largest _ were demanding the release of four union leaders jailed in previous protests. Authorities say about 300 people, including 235 policemen, have been injured in four days of violent street clashes in the southeastern port and in other cities throughout the country. The government has vowed to deal resolutely with the labor protests, saying the nation's slumping economy is at stake. The economy is already beset by shrinking exports and high inflation. Officials are worried that Kim's death might escalate labor unrest, which had eased considerably on Wednesday. In 1987, the death of a shipyard worker sparked violent nationwide protests. Self-immolation and ritual suicide is a form of protests often used by South Korean radicals to dramatize their cause. In Ulsan, which is about 80 miles from Changwon, about 120 workers at the Hyundai shipyard were holding out for a sixth day atop a 240-foot crane. The workers, who climbed the crane during Saturday's police raid, threatened to take ``an extreme action'' unless they are supplied with food and water. The workers have threatened to commit suicide if police try to arrest them. Police spread nets and air mattresses around the base of the crane and had anti-terrorist teams and two helicopters standing by in the shipyard. The city was otherwise quiet as rains fell. A few hundred striking workers shouting insults roamed streets outside the shipyard. The workers confronted squads of riot police but avoided violence, witnesses said. Officials of the giant Hyundai conglomerate in Seoul said nine of their 13 subsidiary plants in the Ulsan area were operating normally today. Four of the company's enterprises, including the nation's largest car assembly plant, remained closed.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Panel Lists Treatments That Poor Likely to Get
DOC.TEXT: Oregon officials have unveiled a list ranking the worthiness of some 3,000 medical procedures _ the first step in an unprecedented attempt to ration government health care to the poor. The computerized list of medical treatments, ranked according to a formula that balances costs against how many people benefit, will be studied and revised by the Oregon Health Care Commission in coming weeks. The Legislature will then draw a line across the list. Below that line, the state won't pay for treating ailments. The program, approved by the Legislature in 1989, is the first in the nation to consider eliminating expensive treatments for Medicaid patients instead of providing total care, as Oregon and most other states do. If approved by the federal government, the program would add an estimated 77,000 Oregonians to Medicaid rolls that now number about 130,000. The 167-page list was compiled by the commission staff and a consulting firm, which held 11 public hearings, 50 community meetings and a telephone survey to find out which illnesses Oregonians considered most critical. Near the bottom of the tentative list released Wednesday, and likely to be dropped from coverage, were treatments for dementia, skin problems, impacted teeth and sex-change operations. Detection and prevention of AIDS is high on the list, but treatment for AIDS, when a patient is close to death, is near the bottom. So are liver and bone marrow transplants, which can run into the hundreds of thousands of dollars. Thumb sucking was 37th, ahead of croup and congenital syphilis. That's because common ailments like thumb sucking are easily treated at a relatively low cost. Malocclusion _ crooked teeth _ fell between two treatments for Hodgkins disease, a lymphatic disorder that is fatal if left untreated. ``That's an orthodontic problem _ I mean, give me a break,'' said Dr. Harvey Klevit, chief of pediatrics and assistant regional medical director of the Kaiser Permanente health care system. Health commission officials said there were many errors on the list, which was tentative and partial. Under the Medicaid system in Oregon and much of the rest of the country, the number of poor people who are eligible depends on the amount of money available to treat them. When money gets tight, the state rewrites its eligibility requirements, and more relatively well-off people are removed from the list. Those who are left enjoy a relatively rich package of benefits. Under the new plan, there would be no limit on the number of people who could receive basic Medicaid benefits _ but patients would be out of luck if their ailments didn't quality. The document contained so many errors that the panel considered withholding it. It decided to release it only on condition it not be considered final. ``It's a ponderous, complicated, almost overwhelming collection of data,'' said commission chairman Bill Gregory. ``But we had to start somewhere.''

DOC.HEAD: House Authorizes Five-Year Plan For Supercollider
DOC.TEXT: The House has voted to authorize the superconducting supercollider but refused to guarantee Texas' investment in the $7.4 billion project. The bill, approved 309-109 Wednesday, allows the Department of Energy to build the particle accelerator near Waxahachie, Texas. Costs above $5 billion would be left to Texas, which has pledged $1 billion, and other sources, including foreign investors. House members by a 256-163 vote approved an amendment calling for the U.S. government to return Texas' investment if the Energy Department cancels the project before October 1995. Rep. Dennis Eckart, D-Ohio, said the vote did not assure Congress would fully fund the project. Spending will have to be approved later during Congress' annual appropriations process. The bill was sent to the Senate, but the supercollider will not likely be authorized by the full chamber. An aide to Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said senators probably will act on the collider during appropriations. The supercollider is a 54-mile underground ring in which streams of protons guided by electromagnets would be hurled at almost the speed of light until they smash together and break into even smaller particles. Scientists say the supercollider would recreate the physical state in the moment after the Big Bang, which some believe was the beginning of the universe.
DOC.HEAD: Administration Wants to Link Pay to Performance
DOC.TEXT: Bush administration officials say a plan to link federal employees' pay to performance would provide extra compensation for workers who live in New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco. The proposal also would let the government ignore salary caps for hiring 400 ``world class'' experts for such fields as nuclear safety and medical research, Constance Newman, director of the Office of Personnel Management, said Wednesday in releasing the administration's pay proposal. ``We're having trouble recruiting and retaining people to run this government,'' Newman said of the plan, which would affect about 1.4 million white-collar workers. Congress in the past has rejected similar pay-for-performance proposals, but Ms. Newman said lawmakers are beginning to realize the government's inability to compete with private industry. The plan was introduced in both the House and the Senate this week. Unions representing federal employees criticized the proposal last month, saying government pay cannot be reformed without additional money. The OPM's plan, which provides an additional $1.5 billion for the 1991 fiscal year, would award raises based on performance rather than tenure. In addition, the OPM, which handles personnel matters for the federal bureaucracy, is asking for congressional authority to eliminate the system that awards annual pay increases. The administration's plan calls for providing geographic differentials to employees in certain cities where the federal government has the most trouble competing with private industry.
DOC.HEAD: `Father of Television' Honored With US Capitol Statue
DOC.TEXT: American inventor Philo T. Farnsworth, a pioneer of television, was honored when a 7-foot bronze likeness of the electronics genius was dedicated in the U.S. Capitol. The deceased inventor was extolled as the father of television as his statue was placed in the pantheon of famous Americans of the Capitol's National Statuary Hall on Wednesday. His 81-year-old widow, Elma Farnsworth, attended the ceremony. ``I think it's an honor long overdue,'' said Bruce Barnson, who headed a commission that raised $250,000 to place Farnsworth near the likeness of a better-known Utah native, Brigham Young. ``I want to thank you all from the bottom of my heart ... for this great honor,'' Mrs. Farnsworth told the audience. The statue by Utah sculptor James Avanti depicts Farnsworth holding an image dissector tube that was the heart of the electronic television system he conceived as a 15-year-old high school student in 1922. Farnsworth is called in an inscription at on the base of the statue the ``Father of Television.'' Farnsworth gained the first patent on his system in 1934 after winning a patent battle with the powerful RCA corporation, which later paid him $1 million to use his many patents.

DOC.HEAD: Broadcast, Public Meetings Emphasize Need to Upgrade U.S. Infrastructure
DOC.TEXT: A nationwide radio broadcast and public meetings across the United States set in motion a campaign to upgrade the nation's deteriorating infrastructure with money saved from the end of the Cold War. The time has come to convert the military-driven U.S. economy to a civilian economy worthy of a first-class industrial nation, sponsor said Wednesday. The National Commission for Economic Conversion and Disarmament, the overall sponsor, said its call to spend the ``peace dividend'' on rebuilding America was voiced at simultaneous town meetings in more than 60 cities Wednesday night. The broadcast over more than 30 radio stations was followed by two hours of call-in discussion. Seymour Melman, chairman of the private advocacy group, urged communities faced with the loss of military bases or defense industries to initiate new activity. He said planning to repair roads, bridges, schools, railways and other deteriorating infrastructure should come from the local level. The effort is gaining momentum and allies, including the U.S. Conference of Mayors, said Melman, a retired Columbia University industrial engineering professor. Melman has said that by the end of the 1970s, the United States was no longer a first-class industrial economy because it invested a smaller proportion of its gross national product in its civilian economy than did European countries or Japan. Author Studs Terkel moderated the program. Those broadcasting from Washington or calling in endorsements included New York City Mayor David Dinkins, Philadelphia Mayor Wilson Goode, Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn, Seattle Mayor Norm Rice and Atlanta Mayor Maynard Jackson. Other supporters included former Democratic presidential nominee George McGovern; the Rev. Jesse Jackson; Rep. Claudine Schneider, R-R.I.; Susan Fox, director of finance for Southwestern Bell Corp.; Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste; Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee; and George Korpius, president of the Machinists Union.

DOC.HEAD: Actor David Rappaport Found Dead of Self-Inflicted Gunshot Wound
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS details on shooting, background on Rappaport. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY17
DOC.TEXT: David Rappaport, a dwarf who played a win-at-any-cost lawyer known as ``Mighty Mouth'' on ``L.A. Law,'' was found dead in a park of an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound, police said. He was 38. Police found his body Wednesday evening at Laurel Canyon Park in the San Fernando Valley, said Sgt. William Davidson. Late Monday his manager, Frankie Leigh, had filed a missing persons report, saying the actor was depressed. Police gave no motive for the apparent suicide. On March 4, the actor had attempted suicide by inhaling automobile exhaust. Police found him, his breathing stopped, in a car in Hollywood and resuscitated him. The 3-foot-11 English-born actor appeared in several episodes of NBC's ``L.A. Law'' since late 1988. He played a devious lawyer who kicked smooth attorney Victor Sifuentes _ played by Jimmy Smits _ all over the courtroom. One episode last year dealt with dwarf-tossing. In it, Rappaport's character argued dwarfs had the right to be tossed in a bar for money if they wanted. ``This show has become a perfect showcase for an actor,'' Rappaport said in November. In addition to ``L.A. Law,'' Rappaport starred in the 1986-87 series ``The Wizard,'' about a scientist who invented high-tech toys and gadgets. He also appeared in ``Time Bandits,'' a 1981 British comedy film featuring John Cleese and Sean Connery. In an interview in 1988, Rappaport said he had been discriminated against because of his height and wanted simply to be treated like ``a regular, boring normal person.'' ``I look at boring people every day and I say, God, I wish I could be like that, but my lot is to be unique, special, so I have to put up with it,'' he said. ``It's a hard life.''

DOC.HEAD: Volcano Destroying the Last of Kalapana
DOC.TEXT: Residents of this vanishing town struggled to hold on to prized possessions as lava from Kilauea Volcano flowed on. Lovenia Kamelamela, who lives in the home built by her great-grandfather in 1886 on Hawaiian homestead land, worried about her coconut trees. She hoped to to remove as many trees as possible before she is ordered to evacuate today. At the heart of the coastal town, the Kalapana Store and Drive-In, owner Walter Yamaguchi has vowed to stay open even though Hawaii County Civil Defense authorities plan to erect a roadblock to keep people away from the store. The volcano, six miles away, has spewed lava to within 250 yards of the store. ``This is my property. I can open if I want,'' Yamaguchi said. ``I am not moving because she will stop.'' Three homes were destroyed Wednesday and five Tuesday, bringing to 129 the number burned down since Kilauea began erupting in January 1983. More than 50 were destroyed in the past month. In this community alone, where 125 homes once stood, only 30 remain. Others burned along the path to Kalapana. About a dozen families were to evacuate this afternoon. Workers got ready to pick up and move the Star of the Sea Church. The Roman Catholic ``painted church,'' so called because of the brightly colored murals inside, sits in the direct path of the lava, 350 yards away. Across the street, the Kalapana Mauna Kea Congregational Church awaited its fate. The church, originally built in 1823, was destroyed by an earthquake, lava flow and tidal wave in 1868. Another quake forced the rebuilding of the church at its present site in 1935. ``If God wants to save it, he will,'' Deacon Ed Kahanu said. ``It's his church. He can do what he wants.'' Some people attribute the lava flow to the volcano goddess Pele of Hawaiian folklore. Most kamaainas, native-born or longtime residents of Hawaii, do not substitute the worship of Pele for religion but use it as a way to show appreciation for the beauty around them. ``It's more a respect for the land and the volcano than a religion,'' said Reggie Okamura of the U.S. Geological Survey's National Volcano Observatory. ``I have some belief. It's inherent to anyone born and raised here.'' Even Gov. John Waihee, who toured the area Tuesday, said the fate of Kalapana is in Pele's hands. ``Nobody can tell Madame Pele when it all ends,'' the governor said. ``Nobody can tell her what to do.'' Ed Lorenz has lived in the shadow of Kilauea Volcano most of his 60 years. A true believer in the power of Pele, he said she is as angry as he's ever seen. ``If she wasn't mad, she wouldn't damage any houses,'' Lorenz said. ``I've seen a lot of flows, but this is one of the worst.''

DOC.HEAD: Freed Educator Upset That Other Hostages Not Yet Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS With 4 grafs to UPDATE with more testing and debriefing, Reed to return home Friday. Picks up 5th graf, `Reed was...'
DOC.TEXT: Frank Reed says he is embarrassed to be free when men held hostage far longer _ and with whom he shared the deprivations of captivity _ remain prisoners of Shiite Moslem extremists in Lebanon. The 57-year-old American educator savored his third day in freedom Wednesday with his wife Fahima and their 9-year-old son Tarek. Reed also spoke to reporters for the first time since arriving at the U.S. Air Force hospital on Tuesday. Medical tests and debriefings continued today and officials said he would head home on Friday. ``I tell you, I'm very, very angry that Anderson ... Tom and Terry ... are not free,'' he said Wednesday. Reed was referring to Terry Anderson, The Associated Press chief Middle East correspondent and longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon, and Thomas Sutherland, an American educator. Anderson was kidnapped on March 16, 1985, Sutherland on June 9, 1985. ``I spent the good part of two years with Tom and Terry,'' Reed said. ``For God's sake, it's nearly the sixth year for these men. I'm absolutely embarrassed I'm out before they are.'' The founder of a private school in Beirut, Reed was abducted on Sept. 9, 1986 and spent a little more than 42 months in captivity. He was the second American hostage to be freed in nine days and thanks to the intercession of Syria and Iran. Robert Polhill, freed April 22, went through the same battery of medical tests and questioning last week. Reed said that he had been held since October in the same house as hostages John McCarthy and Brian Keenan and that both are ``well and alive.'' Keenan, a dual Anglo-Irish citizen, was abducted on April 11, 1986 and McCarthy, a Briton, was kidnapped six days later. ``Those were the only people I knew'' in captivity, Reed said of the four hostages. Reed lost 60 pounds in captivity and says he was kept blindfolded and bound nearly all the time. He said he was no longer angry with the U.S. administration that hostages are still being held: ``On the basis of information I have received ... it appears to me perhaps we are on the right track to getting these people out.'' Earlier Wednesday, Reed's Syrian-born wife told reporters that her husband was ``angry with everybody,'' including officials in Washington, that the hostage crisis has not been solved. Sixteen Westerners, including six Americans, are believed still held captive by Pro-Iranian Shiite groups in Lebanon. The boisterous, lanky Reed was cheered by dozens of awaiting journalists as he appeared on the balcony for what was originally to be a no-questions photo opportunity. The smiling former hostage affectionately tousled his son's hair, saying it is ``just great'' to be reunited with his family. Reed said he was ``feeling good'' but tired. ``I'd like to stay another week or two, but they want me out of here on Friday,'' he joked. Mrs. Reed earlier in the day that she expected the whole family would return to the United States on Friday. Asked what he wants to do when he gets back to his home in Massachusetts, Reed said in a deadpan manner: ``Hide.'' Then he added: ``I'd like to have a big Maine lobster, about three pounds.'' Mrs. Reed said she has only been able to see her husband in half-hour shifts for a total of three hours since she and son Tarek first saw him in Wiesbaden on Tuesday. But she said that didn't really bother her. ``We're going to be spending a hell of a lot of time together,'' she said. ``He looks much better than I thought he would,'' she said. ``His memory is terrific, he remembers names, I mean, everything in very minute detail.'' However, she mentioned his tremendous loss of weight and said she found he had ``aged a lot.'' She also said she noticed lapses in his concentration, and that he jumped from topic to topic, characteristics typical of other former hostages who had not wanted or been able to speak at length during their captivity.

DOC.HEAD: Tornado, Rain, Hail Kill Two, Injure More Than 700
DOC.TEXT: A tornado and storm lashed the eastern city of Anqing with hail and heavy rain, killing two people and injuring 742, a Shanghai newspaper reported. Hail the size of goose eggs ``split the heavens and covered the earth'' and one tractor was thrown more than 50 feet by the wind during Saturday's storm, reported the Liberation Daily. Two other people were missing and economic damage was estimated at $8.5 million in Anqing and surrounding area about 650 miles southeast of Beijing. The disaster was reported in the Wednesday edition of the Liberation Daily, seen in Beijing today. The report said 3,100 acres of cropland was damaged around Anqing, located about 280 miles southwest of Shanghai.

DOC.HEAD: Parkinson's Patient Shows Progress From Fetal Tissue Transplant
DOC.TEXT: The first Parkinson's disease patient in the United States to be treated with transplanted brain tissue from an aborted fetus said the operation has made it easier for him to talk and move about. And a researcher who wrote a paper on the case said Wednesday the transplant could benefit many Parkinson's sufferers. The Bush administration has banned use of federal funds for medical research involving fetal tissue, which abortion opponents say creates an incentive for abortion. Don Nelson's operation was paid for privately. ``I'm walking better. I don't use crutches or a cane any more when I'm walking in the house,'' Nelson, 53, said in a telephone interview from the Denver area. ``My speech has improved. The volume of my voice is better.'' Nelson said he probably has 30 percent to 35 percent more ability to move than before the operation 1{ years ago, but he still has spells of ``freezing,'' when he is virtually unable to walk. ``I'm hoping that ... I'll continue to get better,'' he said. Nelson also has regained normal functioning of his hands, said Dr. Curt R. Freed, professor of medicine and pharmacology at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center. The November 1988 operation was the first on a Parkinson's victim in the United States, according to Freed's report in the May issue of Archives of Neurology, a publication of the American Medical Association. ``I think it's very exciting to be able to take a chronic disease of the nervous system ... and reverse aspects of it,'' Freed said in a telephone interview. Parkinson's disease, afflicting an estimated 500,000 Americans, develops when areas of the brain degenerate and stop producing dopamine, a brain chemical essential for normal muscle movements. Experiments with rats and monkeys have shown that fetal cells transplanted into adult brains can grow and produce dopamine. About 40 operations on humans have been performed worldwide, including some others in the United States since Nelson's, Freed said. A patient in Sweden improved markedly five months after an operation there, according to the February issue of Science magazine. In Nelson's operation, tissue from the part of the brain that produces dopamine was transplanted from a 7-week-old aborted fetus into the right side of Nelson's brain. A needle was used to make 10 tiny injections _ with the total fetal material amounting to about a sixth of a drop, Freed said. Eugene Redmond Jr., a Yale School of Medicine psychiatry professor, has said that fetal cell implant therapy could become ``the best hope for many people.'' But he has cautioned that a study of a single patient cannot yield final conclusions.

DOC.HEAD: Mexicans Seek Extradition of Man Who Abducted Alleged Drug Doctor
DOC.TEXT: Mexico wants the United States to extradite a man who claims he organized the kidnapping and arrest of a Mexican doctor charged in the slaying of a U.S. drug agent. Mexican Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo said Wednesday that extradition papers are being prepared for Antonio Garate Bustamante, a self-described Drug Enforcement Agency informant who claims to have organized the abduction of Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain in Guadalajara on April 2. Alvarez Machain, a gynecologist, is charged in the 1985 murder of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena. Prosecutors say he gave Camarena drugs to revive him for additional torture before his slaying. The abduction, which Garate claims to have performed at the bidding of DEA agents, has strained relations between the two countries. Mexico has threatened to stop cooperating in the fight against drug trafficking. U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh met with Alvarez del Castillo on Wednesday before a conference of border-state attorneys general. Thornburgh refused to say whether Alvarez del Castillo had asked for Garate's extradition. He said such requests would be made through the U.S. State Department. Garate lives in Los Angeles. The legality of Alvarez Machain's arrest will be dealt with during a May 25 federal court hearing in Los Angeles, Thornburgh said. Thornburgh reiterated that no DEA agent was present when Alvarez Machain was kidnapped nor until he was arrested in El Paso, Texas. Alvarez del Castillo's spokesdman, Fernando Arias Perez, said Mexico wants an agreement that would allow Mexican drug agents to operate in the United States the same way DEA agents work in Mexico. He said there are 41 DEA agents in Mexico. A U.S. law enforcement source who spoke on condition of anonymity said Thornburgh had ``serious misgivings'' about such a proposal. Garate, a former Mexican police officer, told the Los Angeles Times last week that the DEA promised 10 Mexicans $100,000 for Alvarez Machain's capture in Guadalajara and delivery to El Paso.

DOC.HEAD: Ministers Praying For Rain In North Dakota
With PM-Torrential Texas, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ministers are praying for rain and struggling to keep their parishioners from giving way to despair as North Dakota endures its third year of drought. ``In the last two or three months, the amount of stress and anxiety coming out is just amazing,'' said the Rev. Paul Schauer, pastor of the Grace Lutheran Church in Driscoll. ``I've noticed more marital stress in our community, and a lot of public meetings have been very angry meetings.'' While north-central Texas recovers from record downpours this spring after two years of drought, North Dakota residents are going to church to appeal for a little more rain in their lives. Lt. Gov. Lloyd Omdahl was scheduled to attend a service today on the Capitol steps, and Indians plan a rain dance next week at Fort Abraham Lincoln State Park near Mandan. The North Dakota Conference of Churches last week held a prayer crusade appealing for an end to the drought. ``Every Mass we pray for rain. We make a special effort,'' said the Rev. Gerald Ruelle, pastor of Roman Catholic churches in Killdeer and Halliday. ``For any kind of happiness in our area, it seems that rain is a vital part of that.'' Parishioners of the Word of Life Baptist Church of New Salem have pored through the Bible, searching out verses dealing with drought, said pastor Ruger Winchester. ``God says he'll supply our needs and we believe that, even if it doesn't rain,'' Winchester said. Moisture amounts throughout the state have ranged from about half an inch to more than an inch below normal since the growing season began March 25, the federal Agricultural Statistics Service said. Subsoil moisture _ crucial to crops during the growing season _ remains short over 90 percent of North Dakota after two straight years of drought and what state officials say was the driest winter since statehood 101 years ago. Church members are keeping the faith, but it is difficult, said Schauer's father, Allen, pastor of the First Lutheran Church of Tioga. ``There's a lot of trust in God,'' he said, ``but out of the corners of their eyes, they look up and say, `We could use some rain.'''

DOC.HEAD: Scarfo Gets Life in Prison On Top of Current Sentence
DOC.TEXT: Crime boss Nicodemo ``Little Nicky'' Scarfo was sentenced to life in prison for ordering a 1985 hit of a low-level mob figure who did not show him enough respect. ``I'm concerned about the people who follow your direction,'' Common Pleas Court Judge Eugene Clark told Scarfo at the sentencing Wednesday. ``You have made a great part of your life establishing fear in people and you have destroyed many lives.'' Scarfo, 61, was convicted of first-degree murder in the July 1985 slaying of Frank ``Frankie Flowers'' D'Alfonso on a south Philadelphia street. D'Alfonso was a low-level mob figure killed because he did not show proper respect to Scarfo and didn't give the mob a large enough share of a gambling operation, prosecution witnesses said. The government's case was based on the testimony of two reputed mob figures, Thomas DelGiorno, who said he supervised the murder, and Eugene Milano. Both got reduced sentences in exchange for their cooperation. Clark rejected a plea from Scarfo's lawyer, Robert Simone, to make the life sentence concurrent with sentences imposed for federal convictions. The judge directed that the life term should run consecutive to Scarfo's first federal sentence, 14 years for attempting to extort $1 million from a Philadelphia developer. He added additional sentences totaling five to 15 years for conspiracy and weapons offenses. Scarfo also was convicted in November 1988 on federal racketeering charges and received a 55-year sentence. Five other men convicted of first-degree murder in the D'Alfonso hit also were sentenced to life in prison Wednesday. Four of them also were convicted in the 1988 racketeering case. They were Salvatore Merlino, 47, who is serving a 45-year sentence; Phillip Narducci, 27, serving 40 years; Frank Narducci Jr., 32, serving 35 years; and Francis Iannarella, 33, serving 45 years. Joseph Ligambi, 49, also was convicted in the D'Alfonso case. He is serving a 3{-year sentence on a gambling conviction. The prosecution said Ligambi and Phillip Narducci were the gunmen in the murder.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Drug Fails To Relieve Alzheimer's Disease
DOC.TEXT: A drug company plans to seek approval to sell an experimental new medicine for Alzheimer's disease, even though a Canadian study released today suggests it does not work. Tetrahydrominoacridine, or THA, is intended to ease the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease, the leading cause of senility among older Americans. Comparison studies conducted on 39 patients ``fail to demonstrate a significant clinical benefit of THA,'' even though some victims appeared initially to improve, the Canadian researchers concluded. However, at Warner-Lambert, the pharmaceutical company that makes THA, a spokesman said the research should have been limited to the minority of Alzheimer's patients who show an initial response to the medicine. The study, directed by Dr. Serge Gauthier of McGill University in Montreal, was published in today's New England Journal of Medicine. Initially, the doctors gave increasing doses to see how much of the medicine people could tolerate. During this phase of the research, some patients appeared to get somewhat better. Family members said their speech improved, and they were able to do such simple tasks as answer the telephone or set the table. During the next part of the research, patients were randomly assigned to take THA or dummy placebos. This time, the apparent benefits did not return, and there was no important difference between the two groups, according to the study. The researchers speculated that patients might have built up a resistance to the drug or that family members might have imagined the seeming early improvement. At Warner-Lambert, spokesman Barry Cohen said the company believes the drug is useful and plans to ask the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in June for permission to sell it under the brand name Cognex. The company estimates about 40 percent of Alzheimer's patients could benefit from the drug, he said, though it is not a cure. Cohen said the company's own study, being conducted at U.S. hospitals, is encouraging, but he did not disclose details of the findings.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO FIX GARBLE IN HEADER
Dollar and Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in quiet European trading this morning. Gold prices were also mixed. European dollar rates compared to late Wednesday: _1.6823 West German marks, unchanged. _1.4537 Swiss francs, up from 1.4535. _5.6440 French francs, up from 5.6425. _1,233 Italian lire, up from 1,232.25. _1.1660 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1672. The British pound traded at $1.6416 today, compared to $1.6435 late Wednesday. No quotation was available on the Dutch guilder. Markets in Japan were closed today for the Constitution Day holiday. In London, the dollar traded at 157.60 yen, down from 158.55 yen at the close in Tokyo on Wednesday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $369.15 per troy ounce this morning, down from $369.25 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $369 per ounce, up from $368.85 late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped $1.91 an ounce on Thursday, to close at $370.07 per ounce. Silver bullion traded in London at a bid price of $5.02 a troy ounce, unchanged from late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Protest Against Professor's Racial Views Turns Violent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: Angry students tried to storm the auditorium during a speech by a professor who believes blacks are inferior, and nine people were arrested and five police officers injured, authorities said. Michael Levin, a philosophy professor at City College, gave a speech Wednesday at Long Island University's Brooklyn campus defending the argument that white fear of black crime is logical and morally correct, said Frank Post, an LIU spokesman. Police formed a blockade at the auditorium's doors and kept the protesters from entering, Post said. Levin has written in academic journals that on average, blacks are less intelligent than whites. ``The difference in intelligence is inarguable,'' the New York Post quoted Levin as saying. ``There's good evidence that there's a significant genetic contribution'' to that alleged difference. In his speech, Levin said, ``whites have a right to be afraid of blacks. That's reasonable.'' He argued that police have a right to include blacks in suspect profiles used to make drug arrests because ``blacks are so largely involved in crime.'' After Levin had finished speaking, one of the protesters outside yelled that Levin should be removed from the campus, Post said. Of the nine who were arrested, seven were charged with disorderly conduct, one was charged with harassment and one was charged with riot and assaulting a police officer, said police spokesman Fred Weiner. The university, whose student population is 70 percent black, had considered revoking Levin's invitation to its Urban Ethics conference, Post said. A panel of students, faculty and administrators decided that in the interest of free speech and a free exchange of ideas on a university campus, Levin should be allowed to speak. Levin was escorted from the university unharmed.

DOC.HEAD: Clandestine Airstrips Dynamited to Keep Gold Miners Out of Amazon Jungle
DOC.TEXT: In the first phase of an effort to save a primitive Indian tribe in the Amazon jungle, authorities blew up the first of more than 100 airstrips used by gold miners. The miners have brought disease and death to the Yanomami Indians, whose population dropped from 9,000 to 7,500 since the gold rush began three years ago. More than 250 soldiers, air force officials and federal police on Wednesday blew up the first airstrip, a 600-yard runway in the tropical rain forest near the Venezuelan and Guyanan borders. The military used 374 pounds of explosives to blast open 40 holes, each 13 feet in diameter and four feet deep, said Federal Police spokesman Joao Martins. The rest of the airstrips will be destroyed before May 18 to prevent the 40,000 prospectors from returning to Indian lands, Martins said in a telephone interview. He said the work will cost $800,000. President Fernando Collor de Mello ordered the destruction of the airstrips following a visit to the Yanomami reservation soon after he took office on March 15. In addition to evacuating the miners, who first invaded the 1 million-acre reserve in 1987, Collor promised to blow up the illegal landing strips to stop planes from supplying the miners and transporting gold and diamonds. Martins said tw airstrips will be left intact for the National Indian Foundation and the army, which maintains border outposts in the region to combat drug trafficking and smuggling along Brazil's 4,000-mile northern frontier. He said troops seized one small plane loaded with cocaine on the airstrip just before the dynamiting operation began. Police say drug traffickers used the clandestine airstrips as transhipment points between Colombia and Bolivia. The rush to Yanomami territory began three years ago after government studies revealed the presence of gold, diamonds, tin and bauxite in the region. Prospectors flocked to the area, leveling rain forests, chasing off fish and game, polluting rivers with mercury used in gold panning and spreading diseases previously unknown to the isolated tribe. Since 1987, the tribe has dwindled due to malnutrition, venereal diseases and malaria. Others have been killed in clashes with miners. Under international pressure, the government of former President Jose Sarney announced a $4 million campaign in early January to expel the prospectors, by force if necessary. There are about 220,000 native Indians left in Brazil, down from an estimated 5 million when the Portuguese first landed here in 1500. The government has been steadily carving up Indian lands, leaving the Yanomamis 19 scattered reservations totaling 5 million acres in Brazil's northwest Amazon territory.

DOC.HEAD: `Cheers' Actor Fails to Appear in Drug Case; Warrant Issued
DOC.TEXT: A judge issued an arrest warrant for ``Cheers'' actor Kelsey Grammer after he failed to appear in court to give a progress report on a court-ordered drug rehabilitation program he was ordered to attend. Van Nuys Municipal Judge Aviva K. Bobb on Wednesday issued the warrant for Grammer, 35, who plays the brainy psychiatrist Frasier Crane in NBC's television series ``Cheers.'' A police officer at the Van Nuys station jail said early today that Grammer was not in custody. Grammer's attorney, Robert L. Diamond, had said Wednesday his client was out of town and could not be reached. On Oct. 25, Bobb had ordered Grammer to enter the drug program after he was charged with one felony count of cocaine possession. Deputy District Attorney Andrew W. Diamond said Grammer, 35, of Van Nuys, never attended the rehabilitation program. ``He failed to comply, he didn't show up in court and now there is a bench warrant out for his arrest,'' Diamond said. ``Anybody can get busy, but you can't be that busy that you can't sign up for a program for seven months.'' Grammer was arrested on April 14, 1988, after police pulled him over for driving with expired license plates, according to court documents. He was arrested after a packet containing about a quarter of a gram of cocaine worth about $25 allegedly fell from his pocket as he sat in a patrol car on the way to the police station, the documents state. An earlier arrest warrant was issued after Grammer missed a Van Nuys Municipal Court appearance on Feb. 6. He had been scheduled to prove that he had completed an alcohol rehabilitation program and 10 days of community service. According to court documents, Grammer pleaded guilty on July 13, 1988, to a charge of driving under the influence.

DOC.HEAD: OK To Exclude W Through Z From Jury Pool, Court Rules
DOC.TEXT: Blacks, Hispanics and women can't be kept off juries as a group, but it's OK to exclude people whose last names begin with the letters W through Z. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled 3-0 Wednesday that jurors at the end of alphabetical order do not constitute ``a recognizable and distinct class'' covered by court decisions barring discrimination in jury selection. The claim was raised by a man whose last name begins with a W _ William Jefferson Walker. He was convicted of aggravated assault and leaving the scene of an accident in Pima County, Ariz., in September 1983 and sentenced to 10 years in prison. For reasons not explained by the court, the pool from which the jury was chosen included no one with a surname starting with W through Z. Walker cited a psychologist's study, published in 1970, that concluded people whose names started with letters from S to Z were 50 percent more likely than others to develop a condition called ``alphabetic neurosis.'' The court noted that two other appeals courts have rejected similar claims, one of them involving a jury made up entirely of people whose names began with the letters T through Z.

DOC.HEAD: Baltimore Grants Parade Permit To `Skinhead' Group
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: The administration of Mayor Kurt Schmoke has reversed itself and approved a parade permit for a white supremacist ``skinhead'' group rather than face a threatened court challenge. Deputy City Solicitor Ambrose Hartman said the city reluctantly approved the permit Monday, despite objections from community leaders, after concluding it could not win should the group sue on the grounds that its right to free speech was being denied. The group, known as BASH, or Baltimore Area Skin Heads, said it wants to protest the arrival of Soviet Jews in the United States and would march within a month. The Baltimore Sun quoted an unidentified member of the group as saying the group selected a predominately white, working-class area of Baltimore called Hampden because it is ``one of the last white neighborhoods around.'' The group wants Marylanders to take a stand against race-mixing and what they say are other threats to white power, he said. Eleven churches, community organizations and other Hampden civic groups asked the city to deny the permit after learning of the planned rally last month. Referring to two wealthier Baltimore neighborhoods, the Rev. David Rimbach, pastor of the Hampden United Methodist Church, said: ``They're not going to parade though Roland Park or Charles Village, they are going to parade through Hampden, because they think it's a place of hate and violence. ``We don't want to be painted with those kind of colors any more,'' he said Wednesday. Skinheads are known for their shaved heads, heavy boots and Nazi insignia. They have been linked to racial and religious crime in more than two dozen states. ``What we resent more than anything is it adds to the reputation for intolerance we've gotten over the years,'' said Edward R. Jeunette Jr., past president of the Hampden Community Council. He said it ``doesn't represent a majority view of the people who live here.''

DOC.HEAD: Center-Right Leader Named to Form First Non-Communist Government in 40 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Arpad Goencz is pronounced AHR-pahd guntch.
DOC.TEXT: Interim President Arpad Goencz today nominated the leader of the center-right Hungarian Democratic Forum to form the country's first non-Communist government in more than 40 years. Prime Minister-designate Jozsef Antall, the Democratic Forum leader, said he hopes to name a government by mid-May after concluding negotiations with several smaller political parties. The Democratic Forum emerged as the strongest party in the newly elected Parliament, winning 164 of the 394 seats in free elections concluded April 8. Antall has already held coalition talks with the Independent Smallholders Party, with 44 seats, and the Christian Democrats, with 21 seats. Parliament was to appoint members of its committees before ending its largely ceremonial first session later today. It is the first freely elected Parliament to sit in Budapest since the Communists consolidated power in 1948. Goencz, a writer who was jailed for six years after the 1956 anti-Communist uprising, is a leading member of the League of Free Democrats, the leading opposition party in the new Parliament. In nominating Antall to form a new government, Goencz told the deputies, ``I consider him the perfectly suitable person for this task.'' The nomination was Goencz's first task as interim president following his election Wednesday. As interim president, Goencz succeeds Matyas Szueros, a reform Communist who helped Hungary make its gradual transition toward multiparty democracy. Antall accepted the nomination, saying Hungarians can now ``take our fate in our hands.'' ``I will try to lead the country out of this difficult situation,'' he said. ``I ask you for your confidence, so that we can use this historic opportunity.'' Antall said the country could move forward only if his government can gain the cooperation of the opposition Free Democrats, the second largest party in parliament. If he succeeds in building a center-right coalition with the smaller parties, Antall would be able to count on support from 229 deputies. That would give his government a simple majority in Parliament, but not the two-thirds majority required to approve major constitutional changes. The two leading parties did cooperate in selecting candidates for interim president and prime minister. The Democratic Forum agreed to support Goencz, and the interim president in turn nominated Antall. Antall said the Democratic Forum and Free Democrats had also agreed to amend the constitution so that the president would be elected to a regular four-year term by the Parliament rather than by a national election. On Wednesday, Goencz was elected speaker of Parliament, which automatically made him interim president. Goencz is expected to become president, a largely ceremonial post, by June after the new government is formed and the necessary constitutional amendments are enacted, Antall said. The old Communist government of Prime Minister Miklos Nemeth tendered its resignation Wednesday, but will stay on in a caretaker capacity until the new Cabinet takes over. In Hungary, reform Communists cleared the path to democracy, reorganized into a new Socialist Party and gradually liberalized the system over the past two years. But Hungarians showed their anger over decades of Communist rule at the polls, and the Socialists won only 33 seats in the new parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Proposes Foreign Ministers of 35 Nations Meet In New York
With PM-Baker
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III today proposed that 35 foreign ministers from East and West meet in New York in late September to plan a summit meeting by the end of the year. Baker put the proposal to a NATO session meeting in Brussels to discuss security in a changing Europe. The objective of the summit would be the signing of a treaty to sharply reduce troops, tanks, artillery and other non-nuclear arms in Europe. The NATO foreign ministers took no direct action on Baker's proposal for preparations in New York, according to Italian and other European sources. His initiative confirms President Bush's determination to conclude the treaty being negotiated by NATO and the Warsaw Pact by year's end. The accord would set a limit of 195,000 Soviet troops outside Soviet borders and 225,000 U.S. troops in Western and Central Europe. The 35 nations include all the European states except Albania, along with the United States and Canada. In 1975 they signed the Helsinki agreement to lessen tensions in Europe. ``We are all of the opinion that (the summit) must be thoroughly prepared,'' West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher told reporters. He reiterated Bonn's position that the 35-mation grouping, known as Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, must be given more weight in Europe's future. Baker, flying to Brussels on Wednesday from Washington, enthusiastically endorsed the proposition. He said a larger role by the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe was part of the ``new security architecture'' for Europe that he first proposed in a Berlin speech in December. NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner said the alliance had agreed to accept France's invitation to host the conference summit in Paris. At the summit, the 16 NATO and seven Warsaw Pact nations would sign a conventional arms agreement. Negotiations on that agreement are now tangled over limits on aircraft and helicopters, and methods of verifying reductions within the two alliances.

DOC.HEAD: Teacher Robbed at Gunpoint, Slashed In Classroom; Two Others Slashed
DOC.TEXT: A robber entered a grade-school classroom after pupils were dismissed, holding up a teacher at gunpoint and slashing her and two other teachers who came to her aid, police said. The teacher, Judith Deppe, was in her second-floor classroom at a Manhattan public school at 3 p.m. Wednesday after her students had left for the day, a police spokeswoman, Sgt. Mary Wrensen, said today. A gunman entered and forced her to give up her purse containing $30, Wrensen said. Before fleeing, the robber slashed Deppe and two other teachers who came to help, Wrensen said. Another teacher who also tried to help was not injured. Ms. Deppe was slashed on the left arm. Another teacher was cut on the face and the third was cut on the chest.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Proposes Deep Cuts In Short-Range U.S. Nuclear Weapons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to ADD report on summit also from Genscher. Pickup 4th pvs, `According to...'
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III told NATO allies today that the United States has scrapped plans to develop a more powerful Lance short-range nuclear missile for deployment in Europe. Baker also said there would be no further modernization of nuclear artillery, according to West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. In addition, Baker proposed that 35 foreign ministers from East and West meet in New York in late September to plan a summit meeting by the end of the year, Genscher said. The objective would be the signing of a treaty to sharply reduce troops, tanks, artillery and other non-nuclear arms in Europe. NATO foreign ministers took no direct action on the proposed meeting. According to Genscher, Baker raised the possibility that negotiations on reducing short-range nuclear arms would begin immediately after completion of an accord slashing conventional, or non-nuclear, weapons in Europe. In recent weeks, NATO officials have questioned the need to upgrade short-range missiles at the start of 1992, as agreed at a NATO summit last spring, in view of the sharply reduced military threat from the East. Also to be shelved are some 900 non-nuclear Lance II missiles. All the short-range weapons were to have been trained on East Germany, which is moving toward a swift merger with West Germany, a key NATO member. German unification and its impact on security in Europe was to be the focus of today's NATO meeting, with members expected to reiterate calls for a reunified Germany's membership in the alliance. Dutch Foreign Minister Hans van den Broek said on arrival that the issue of German unification was ``far more important today'' than quick action on upgrading the 700 aging nuclear Lance missiles in Europe. The meeting in Brussels comes two days before the beginning of talks in Bonn, West Germany, bringing together the foreign ministers of the World War II Allies _ the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union _ and those of West and East Germany to discuss the future of a united Germany. After his talks at the NATO headquarters, Baker was due to head to the European Community head office for a meeting with the community's 12 foreign ministers. The meeting at NATO comes after some countries _ notably Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Canada _ expressed concern over being shut out of the German unification process although it affects them directly. ``It is very good Baker comes here now as the `two-plus-four' (talks) open two days later,'' said a Dutch official at NATO. ``This is wholly in line with our wishes and those of other allies.'' Other sources, who also asked not to be named, said countries outside the ``two-plus-four'' process see today's meeting as a way of maintaining NATO's role in building a new security order in Europe. The NATO ministers were expected to restate their wish to see a united Germany as member of the alliance. The Soviet Union, which has 380,000 troops in East Germany, opposes such an arrangement. It wants a neutral Germany or a Germany straddling the two military blocs. Also on the agenda of today's meeting were talks in Vienna on reductions in conventional forces and arms in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves AZT for Children With AIDS
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the use of the drug AZT to treat children with AIDS. It is the only drug that has been shown to extend the lives of adults with the deadly disease. New labeling on the drug outlines dosage recommendations for patients aged 6 months to 12 years who have the disease or show symptoms of advanced infection with the virus that causes it. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said the new labeling ``means the drug is now officially considered to be a standard therapy for children with AIDS.'' He said the new status should encourage insurance companies to reimburse patients for pediatric use of the drug. The FDA has been under pressure to approve AZT for treatment of children, particularly from parents of stricken children who have no other recourse. An advisory committee of outside experts voted 7-1 on March 30 to recommend the new pediatric labeling. While AZT has prolonged the lives of people with AIDS, it also has caused significant side effects. The drug can inhibit the production of red blood cells and may reduce white blood cell counts to the point where doses must be discontinued to avoid infections. The FDA said doctors could have prescribed AZT for children without formal approval, but were reluctant to do so because of concerns that side effects might be more severe in children. The agency said clinical trials involving more than 200 children indicate the side effects are similar to those experienced by adults. AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, is a contagious disease that attacks the body's immune system, rendering it incapable of resisting other diseases and infections. The virus most often is spread through close contact with blood, blood products or semen. The chief victims of AIDS have been homosexual men and intravenous drug users. A small percentage of cases are attributed to transfusions of contaminated blood, heterosexual contact and spread from infected pregnant women to their offspring. As of Feb. 28, 1990, AIDS had been diagnosed in 124,984 Americans, of whom 61 percent, or 77,003, have died since June 1, 1981, according to the federal Center for Disease Control. No one is known to have recovered from AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Patriarch of Moscow Dead at 79
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 12 grafs of background at end, and byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Patriarch Pimen, the head of the Russian Orthodox Church who presided over the faith's reawakening after decades of repression, died today at the age of 79, Tass reported. No cause of death was given in the terse announcement. In recent years, Pimen rarely celebrated services because of his increasing frailty. Pimen, as patriarch of Moscow and all Russia, led tens of millions of believers in the officially atheist Soviet Union. After a historic meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in 1988 _ the year the church celebrated the 1,000th anniversary of its founding in Russia _ Pimen praised the Soviet leader's reform efforts toward religion. Under Pimen's leadership, the Russian Orthodox Church supported official Soviet policies, especially the leadership's pronouncements on peace and nuclear disarmament. The church carefully remained in the sphere that was left for it: the spiritual development of individual believers. Recently, however, its leaders have cautiously criticized the laws that restrict church activities. For centuries, Russian Orthodox Church leaders managed close and sometimes difficult relations with the government, but the close contact that Pimen and other top church officials have maintained with the Communist Party angered some activists, who called it collaboration. Born Sergei Izvekov in Moscow, he entered the monastery in October 1927 and took the religious name Pimen. He continued his religious education at a time when authorities violently repressed the church and became a priest in 1931. Until 1946, he was a priest in a cathedral in Murom, a city 140 miles east of Moscow. Pimen moved rapidly to posts in Odessa, Rostov-on-Don and Pskov, being handed more and more responsibility. In 1960, he became a member of the church's Holy Synod, and three years later was named metropolitan of Krutitsky and Kolomenskoye. He was chosen church leader in 1971. In the era of Gorbachev's social and political reforms, Pimen even was elected to the Soviet Parliament in March 1989. He was a member of the World Peace Committee and traveled extensively. In 1982, he addressed a U.N. disarmament conference in New York, and in 1986 he issued a message titled ``On War and Peace in the Nuclear Age.'' He was awarded the officially sponsored Soviet Peace Committee's gold medal and the government's Order of the People's Friendship. A memorial service was planned for Friday at Bogoyavlensky Cathedral i Moscow. No funeral plans were announced.

DOC.HEAD: Hospital Believes Crate with Radiation Sent to Netherlands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: new material throughout with crate thought to have been sent back to Netherlands.
DOC.TEXT: Officials at Georgetown University Hospital believe missing radioactive material taken from the hospital was sent back to the Netherlands, a spokeswoman said today. The hospital had been trying to locate a crate containing a potentially fatal dose of radioactive iridium it believed was accidentally taken from the hospital. But hospital spokeswoman Carol Fox said today that officials found some documents on Wednesday that indicated the missing radioactive material was picked up by the manufacturer on April 20. She said the paperwork indicated that the iridium had been sent back to the Netherlands where it was supposed to have been returned. The hospital will be in contact with the manufacturer and hopes to be able to confirm later today that the shipment is safe and on track, King said. The radioactive iridium was protected by a blue, steel-jacketed lead shield and is braced to keep it in the center of the crate. ``Assuming the source is still contained in the lead shield and still packaged inside the crate, radiation exposure rates should be minimal,'' said a hospital statement released Wednesday. ``If, however, the source has been removed from the shielding, it presents a potentially serious, possibly fatal, risk to anyone who may handle it.''. The hospital said earlier the iridium was believed taken by a courier on April 20 and a Georgetown radiation control officer discovered what was believed to be a mistake 10 days later. The hospital notified the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that a search for the crate failed. The square 18-inch crate bears a shipping label to Georgetown University Hospital. The label on the crate also reads, ``Caution: Radioactive. Handle Carefully, Iridium 192, 10 Curies, Transportation Index: .6.''

DOC.HEAD: Sex Priestess Asked For Proof of Faith _ in Cash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `She told...', to fix `did' to `but.'
DOC.TEXT: A self-proclaimed sex priestess who bedded down with her followers says she first asked for proof _ in cash or other ``tokens of sacrifice'' _ that they viewed sex as a religious experience. Mary Ellen Tracy, known to her flock as Sabrina Aset, testified in federal court Wednesday in her lawsuit accusing city officials of violating her religious freedom in pursuing prostitution charges against her. Mrs. Tracy and her husband, Wilbur, have been convicted of prostitution and running a brothel. Assistant City Attorney Bryon R. Boeckman said the couple used their Church of the Most High Goddess as a front for prostitution. ``This is not a true religion,'' Boeckman said. Advertised in sexually explicit magazines, the church boasted of services by a priestess wearing a strapless red-sequined gown, high-heeled shoes and fishnet stockings. The sparsely furnished church had no pews or pulpit. The few wall hangings included posters of movie stars and a framed nude photograph of Mrs. Tracy. The couple claim divine inspiration prompted them to revive an ancient Egyptian religion in which man justifies his sins by having sex with church priestesses. Ms. Tracy said initiates needed to confess and perform oral sex on her before they could be considered for purification. Before intercourse, sacrifices of cash or other valuables were required to show dedication to the church, she said. ``It's up to a person to decide if it's an acceptable sacrifice,'' she said. During her criminal trial, testimony included allegations she demanded at least $150. She told Judge William Byrne on Tuesday that she collected about $50,000 in donations in three years but kept no records on followers beyond their first names and telephone numbers. The woman, who claims to have had sex with thousands of men, said she told followers their donations were tax deductible, but no receipts were issued. She acknowledged that about half the men paid only one visit to the church and never returned. ``I don't think that's very unusual for any religion,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Four Charged in Attempt To Hang Young Black Man
DOC.TEXT: Four white men have been charged with kidnapping and attempted murder in the near-lynching of a black man after an assault on the 78-year-old grandfather of one of the suspects. The incident began Monday morning when a 78-year-old Nesbit man was beaten at his home and hospitalized. Several hours later, his grandson and three other men abducted a 22-year-old man and brought him to the grandfather's house, said Danny Sowell, chief investigator for the DeSoto County Sheriff's Department. Sowell said the men beat their victim, then forced him out of the house and under a tree. They swung a rope over a limb, placed it around his neck and tried to hang him in an apparent attempt to force him to confess to the assault or identify the attacker, Sowell said. When the man cried out a name, the four removed the rope and took him back to the grandfather's house. Relatives called the sheriff's office, Sowell said. Gerald Pettit, 40, of Lake Cormorant, and Vernon Brinson, 39, David Whitman, 32, and Randy Battles, 29, of Nesbit were jailed on $75,000 bond each. Authorities did not identify the 22-year-old, who was treated at a hospital and released, or the 78-year-old, who was said to be in stable condition at a Memphis, Tenn., hospital. Sowell said he did not know why the men chose the young black, and no one had been charged in the beating of the grandfather.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Invites Congressional Leaders to Budget Meeting
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 7 grafs Bush discussing budget talks; picks up 6th graf pvs, On Capitol...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that he has invited congressional leaders to the White House on Sunday to begin the search for a compromise on the 1991 federal budget. ``What we have to do is start talking process and how we go forward,'' the president said at a White House news conference. ``I'm not going to sit here and do nothing.'' After a slow start, the House approved a $1.2 trillion budget Tuesday for next year, and the Senate Budget Committee approved one of its own on Wednesday. Both spending plans were written by Democrats and impose cuts of about $10 billion in the defense programs Bush wants. The president said he decided to ask for the meeting because of the recent budget movement in Congress. ``Now there seems to be more action, so it seemed to me to be a good time to sit down and talk process, and see where we go now,'' he said. Bush denied that the meeting would be a bargaining session, saying, ``We're not into a negotiation. We're talking process.'' White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush will meet with Sens. George Mitchell, D-Maine, the majority leader, Bob Dole, R-Kan., the minority leader, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley and Rep. Robert Michel, R-Ill., the House minority leader. On Capitol Hill, both liberal and conservative lawmakers are likely to challenge the Senate Budget Committee's decision to slash defense spending next year by $9.9 billion below the level Bush wants. The budget panel on Wednesday adopted a Democratic-written, $1.2 trillion spending plan that sets defense spending at $293.9 billion in fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. In a year that has seen congressional Democrats trying to reduce Pentagon coffers, that would be the deepest cut yet in Bush's defense plans. Sen. Charles Grassley of Iowa was the only Republican to join the panel's majority Democrats in the 14-9 vote for final passage. Democrats touted the plan, which claims to shrink the deficit by $43 billion, as a response to the Cold War thaw. ``This is a clear shift in priorities, a shift away from massive spending on defense and a greater concentration on the domestic needs of this country,'' said committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. ``I don't believe it's anywhere close to being right or prudent, nor will it permit a proper build-down of our defenses,'' countered Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, the panel's ranking Republican. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said defense spending should be set at no less than $297 billion. ``These cuts are deeper than I believe can be justified by the changes in the threat,'' Nunn said. On the other hand, Sasser said he expects liberal legislators to try to transfer money from defense to social programs when the full Senate debates the budget, probably within 10 days. He said he would ``look sympathetically'' on such efforts. Bush has proposed spending $303.8 billion for defense next year. It would take $306.9 billion to allow military programs to stay even with inflation. This year's spending is estimated at $296.3 billion. The House approved its own Democratic-written budget on Tuesday that cuts defense spending to $295.5 billion. Besides saving $13 billion from defense, the Senate panel's plan would chop $3.6 billion from domestic and foreign aid programs. Bush proposed only a $400 million cut. Sasser said that to achieve those savings, he would recommend cutting eight to 10 programs, including foreign aid, the superconducting super collider and grants and loans to rehabilitate housing. ``We have to think in terms of getting rid of the old to make room for the new,'' Sasser said. The package also limits the growth of benefit programs by $5.6 billion, raises $6.2 billion in user fees, and collects $13.9 billion in new tax receipts _ the same figure Bush proposed. In opposing the plan, Republicans argued that the only way to reduce the deficit was for congressional leaders and the White House to hold negotiations. The Washington Post today quoted a White House official as saying the president and congressional leaders planned to meet Sunday to discuss the budget. ``I believe we're going to end up with minimal deficit reduction in spite of this budget, unless there are major negotiating sessions with the president and the congressional leadership,'' said Domenici. Like most Democrats, Sasser refused to commit himself to budget talks. But he said the committee-passed plan could be ``a benchmark from which we would operate'' if there are talks. The president does not have to sign the budget, which lays out federal fiscal plans. But his agreement will be needed for enactment of later spending and tax bills. Stephen Hart, a deputy White House press secretary, said Wednesday evening of the committee's action: ``We are not prepared to respond to specifics. We still feel the president's budget is the best proposal up there. It will continue to be the basis of any discussions we have.''

Here is the text of President Bush's press conference:
BUSH: Let me just open with a statement, and then I'll be glad to take some questions. The revolutionary changes transforming Europe are moving us from the postwar era to a new era in history beyond containment. The revolutions of '89 _ 1989 _ that have brought democracy to Eastern Europe, the prospect of German unification, and my hope for rapid conclusion of a CFE agreement bring us close to a peaceful and more stable Europe whole and free. And I'll be speaking tomorrow at commencement ceremonies in Oklahoma State University about my conception of America's place in the new Europe. And I want to use this press conference today as an opportunity to highlight for you a few of the ideas I plan to discuss at greater length tomorrow. We have arrived at this historic point by maintaining a strong partnership with our European allies. NATO will remain vital to America's place in Europe. It is a proven structure upon which to base our security, and from which to promote a stable, cooperative European order. The alliance is now ready to take on new challenges. And in order to set a new Western strategy for these times, and after consulting personally with my allied colleagues, a consultation completed by Secretary Baker in Brussels today, I am calling for a NATO summit in early _ in early summer _ late June or early July probably. A fundamental purpose of this summit should be to launch a wide-ranging NATO strategy review for the transformed Europe of the 1990s. To provide direction for this, I suggest that this summit should address, first, the future political mission of the alliance, reaffirming its crucial role in managing and stabilizing the transformation of Europe.
