DOC.HEAD: Second Day of Talks Begin, ANC Predicts Talks Will Succeed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with talks resuming, comment from second ANC leader. Pickup 7th graf pvs, `In a...'
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leaders began a second day of talks with the government today, and officials said both sides were committed to finding a way to bring blacks into the political process. The white-led government and the ANC, the country's most powerful opposition group, are seeking to clear the way for future negotiations on a constitution that would give the black majority the vote. This first round of talks, which opened Wednesday, are the first ever between the government and ANC. They are to end Friday. ``When all of us departed (Wednesday's talks), the general feeling was that not only is movement forward necessary, but that it is possible,'' said Thabo Mbeki, the head of the ANC's foreign affairs department. ``We had people sitting in that room who are perfectly reasonable and we are all committed to finding a solution,'' Mbeki told more than 200 people at the Cape Town Press Club. ANC spokesman Patrick ``Terror'' Lekota wrote in an article published today in several newspapers: ``Black South Africans have done every possible thing under the sun to get whites to negotiate a democratic constitution. Now it seems clear that we shall negotiate that kind of constitution in the near future.'' Following Wednesday's talks, the two sides issued a joint statement saying the discussions were characterized by ``openness and straightforwardness.'' Before opening the talks, President F.W. de Klerk and ANC leader Nelson Mandela stood side by side and called for the swift abolition of apartheid. In a bid to calm white fears about a black government, Mandela gave part of his statement in Afrikaans, the language of the Dutch-descended Afrikaners who make up 3 million of the country's 5 million whites and dominate the government. De Klerk said South Africans of all races wanted rapid change. All political parties must work together to find a peaceful solution to the country's racial and political divisions, he said. Under the apartheid system of racial segregation, the country's 28 million blacks have no voice in national affairs while the whites control the government and the economy. The ANC says that before constitutional negotiations can begin the government must lift the state of emergency, allow exiled activists to return and release activists convicted of politically motivated crimes. The government wants the ANC to renounce its largely ineffective armed struggle. All these matters are on the agenda, the two parties said. The government has said that constitutional negotiations will include several opposition groups in addition to the ANC. However, right-wing whites and radical black groups oppose any negotiated power-sharing agreement between whites and blacks. The pro-apartheid Conservative Party marched out of a debate in Parliament on Wednesday to protest the talks between the government and the ANC. The leader of the Conservatives, Andries Treurnicht, said the government had no right to negotiate with an organization that has carried out guerrilla attacks and still was committed to an armed struggle. Meanwhile, the militant Pan Africanist Congress has accused the ANC of ``appeasement'' for agreeing to meet with the government. The Pan Africanists say the only matter they will negotiate is the direct transfer of power from whites to blacks. De Klerk has promised to end white rule but opposes a one-person, one-vote system. He says such a system would replace white domination with black domination. The ANC says it is committed to a full democratic system with no special rights for minorities. The ANC also wants a radical restructuring of the economy that could include government control of banks, gold mines and other leading industries. The talks are the first between a white government and an ANC delegation since the organization was founded in 1912. The discussions are being held at the Groote Schuur estate, once the official home of South African presidents.

DOC.HEAD: `Cluster Suicide' Phenomenon Rocks Small Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs, `Two days...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with another teen-ager threatening suicide, is eventually subdued. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `I sure...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LR2
DOC.TEXT: The pines are tall, lines at cash registers are short and a phone call is still only a dime in this country town. People live here to get away from city and suburban pressures. But today, after a cluster of teen-age suicides, residents are mourning the dead, and, in a sense, the town's loss of innocence. ``It's terrible for a small town like this to have to wake up like this,'' said resident Carolyn Talbert. The high school is flooded with psychiatrists, psychologists and counselors. Police track down absent students if phone calls home aren't answered. Students try to make sense of the senseless. Joe Wise Jr., mayor of the town of 3,230, said, ``We're just getting a taste of some of the things that go on in larger towns.'' On Monday, 17-year-old Thomas Smith went to the front of his fifth-period American history class, professed his love for a girl, and shot himself with a .22-caliber gun as 23 horrified classmates watched. About nine hours later, Thomas M. Chidester, 19, a close friend of Smith's, was found dead with a gunshot wound to the head and a note saying, ``I can't go on any longer.'' A third schoolmate, 17-year-old Jerry Paul McCool, killed himself Tuesday, authorities said. McCool knew Smith and Chidester but was not a close friend. A 19-year-old dropout held authorities at bay with a loaded gun Wednesday night and threatened to kill himself, saying his three former classmates ``saw the way'' out of their problems, Sheriff Cary Clark said. The depressed young man was subdued after about four hours of negotiations, when he lost his hold on his gun and dropped it. He was taken to a hospital for psychiatric evaluation. There were few answers to the loss of three lives in two days. ``I sure can't make any sense out of it,'' said Lisa Deal, 18, president of the student council at Sheridan's high school. ``Even in a tragedy of this nature we must go on. We're all pulling together and trying to get over this disaster.'' School officials immediately began summoning mental health help Monday from across Arkansas and contacted national crisis and grief experts. But Sheridan is different from some of the other ``cluster suicide'' communities. Residents say the 770-student school isn't a high-pressure college preparatory factory full of upper middle-class achievers from fast-growing communities. Forty percent of Sheridan's seniors go on to college, principal Eddie Hauhee said. Smith and Chidester, for example, both planned to enter the military. Like many small towns, Sheridan turns out for its Yellowjackets on Friday nights during football season. Even though many commute to jobs in Little Rock or Pine Bluff up to 30 miles away, and the school has grown recently, Sheridan tries to stay strictly country. ``Obviously there have been changes over the last few years, but this is not Plano, Texas, or Germantown, Tenn.,'' Hauhee said, referring to other communities that have wrestled with cluster suicides. Still, in case of another suicide, a private jet was standing by to pick up a San Francisco-based grief and trauma expert. The community was tense, as well as sad. Police and school officials don't suspect drug or alcohol problems had a role in the suicides. All suicide victims had access to guns because ``this is a hunting community,'' Police Chief David Hooks said. ``I'd like to find something like drugs to blame all the deaths on, but I can't,'' he said. What authorities do suspect is that all three boys, and a fourth classmate who took his life March 28, suffered from a lack of self-esteem. ``School has to be more personal. Lives of children have to become paramount,'' said Sheridan Schools Superintendent David Robinson. ``We don't think we're any different. But we obviously have to ... make an effort to improve self-esteem.'' Tuesday night, some 1,200 parents turned out for a town meeting with school officials and suicide prevention experts. At the high school Wednesday morning, first period was devoted to sessions that allowed teachers and students to discuss their feelings, with assistance from some 60 mental health professionals and clergy who reviewed stages of grief and depression. Counselors and psychologists were placed in each classroom during the day and mingled throughout the school. ``It's still gloomy, and it's going to be that way for awhile,'' said senior Angela Turley, 18. Today, school officials planned to cut back the number of counselors but keep some on call. In the future, counseling programs in the high school that had targeted drugs and alcohol may be shifted to deal with suicide, Robinson said. Student support groups also will be formed. And Sheridan, once just a sawmill town but now a growing bedroom community with several new manufacturing plants, an unemployment rate of only 3.2 percent and a high school dropout rate of just 3 percent, will pray it doesn't happen again. ``I'm scared as a parent,'' said Hooks, father of a 14-year-old junior high school student. At Smith's funeral Wednesday at the Landmark Baptist Church, the Rev. Dennis Moon urged 250 mourners to stop asking the ``unanswerable question'' of why the teen-ager killed himself. ``Bringing back Tommy is beyond our control, but going with him ... is still our choice,'' Moon said.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Scott McCartney is the AP's Southwest regional reporter, based in Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Meet With Lithuanian Prime Minister
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout with Bush quotes.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, preparing to meet with the prime minister of Lithuania, said today he saw no role for the United States as a mediator in the conflict between the breakaway republic and the Soviet Union. Shortly before he was to meet at the White House with Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene, Bush told a news conference that ``if there was a constructive role for the United States, of course, we should fulfill that, but there's not.'' The president also welcomed statements from Lithuanian President Vytautis Landsbergis indicating a willingness to comprmise with the Soviets. Meeting with members of the House Foreign Affairs Commmittee and in a television appearance, Mrs. Prunskiene said Lithuania ``is prepared for compromises'' in those negotiations but ``cannot and will not revoke our declaration of independence.'' ``We also hope for international guarantees of this declaration of independence which we have made,'' she said. ``I wish to emphasize that we believe that only with these international guarantees ... the Soviets will begin negotiations.'' She said she hopes her talks with Bush and senior U.S. officials ``will expedite the process of a peaceful and useful resolution'' of Lithuania's independence crisis. Bush declared that his desire for the freedom and self-determination of the Lithuanians was ``just as strong as anybody else's.'' ``There's a lot at stake in all of this,'' he said. ``There are complications in all of this. Poland, Eastern Europe, I want those (Soviet) troops out and I want to see the firming up of the democracies in Eastern Europe and I want to see us keep this process going forward.'' Mrs. Prunskiene expanded on her call for guarantees in testimony for the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, the Helsinki Commission. ``We could temporarily suspend the quick and unilateral execution'' of legislation implementing the independence declaration, she said, ``if there were international guarantees.'' ``In no way does this mean a repeal of the acts ... or a renunciation of independence,'' she said. ``In such a case, Lithuania would have to be guaranteed on the basis of international law: the continuity of Lithuanian independence, the continuation of her government and her territorial integrity,'' she said. Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla. the committee chairman, said later that Mrs. Prunskiene was closely questioned during a closed session of the breakfast meeting. ``The guarantee she is seeking is the kind of international assurance that the rest of the world would not back away,'' Fascell said. ``She wanted to be certain that internationally there is no change in support for what the Lithuanians are trying to do.'' Fascell said, ``I hope the Soviets quickly respond. I'm not happy with the appearance of doing business as usual at the summit while the screws are being put to the Lithuanian people.'' President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev have scheduled a summit meeting in Washington May 30. Speaking hours before a scheduled meeting with Bush, she also said ``I don't necessarily have to hear any concrete suggestions'' from the president. ``I think a solution is possible,'' Mrs. Prunskiene said on the NBC ``Today'' show. ``Lithuania is ready for negotiations. It is prepared for compromises ... and I think the time has come now for Lithuania to define its position more clearly and to invite the Kremlin once again to engage in negotiations.'' It will be Bush's first direct contact with a ranking Lithuanian official since the Baltic republic declared independence on March 11, setting off a fierce tug of war with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The talks with the president and other high-ranking U.S. officials represent a symbolic foot in the White House door, placed there in part by the demands of conservatives upset by Bush's refusal to recognize Lithuanian independence or retaliate against Gorbachev for imposing a punishing trade embargo. Mrs. Prunskiene, 47, an economist and former Communist Party official, is described by many observers as a tough, accomplished politician. Her Oval Office meeting with Bush was being held in an atmosphere charged by the planned Bush-Gorbachev summit. The White House regards the prime minister's visit as unofficial. Spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush is not meeting with Mrs. Prunskiene as prime minister of an independent Lithuania but rather as ``an acknowledged and freely elected representative of the Lithuanian people.'' Since the beginning of the crisis, the administration has sought the opening of a dialogue between Moscow and Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital. Gorbachev has said a dialogue cannot occur until Lithuania rescinds its independence declaration and moves to pursue its secession goals under the terms of the Soviet constitution and law. Lithuanians maintain their independence is non-negotiable and that to pursue it under Soviet terms would be to accept the legitimacy of the forced incorporation of the country into the Soviet Union in 1940. Mrs. Prunskiene and Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis both have indicated a willingness to accept a proposal by the French and West German governments that they suspend laws passed to implement independence in exchange for talks and an easing of the Soviet embargo.

WASHN: of Europe.
Second, the alliance's conventional defenses for the future and next steps for conventional arms control. While we're still in a period of transition as Soviet forces leave Eastern Europe and our arms control works move forward, we need to develop a new strategy for the period ahead. And third, the role of U.S. nuclear forces in Europe. As democracy comes to Eastern Europe and Soviet troops return home, there is less need for nuclear systems of the shortest range. And in response to these new conditions, I have decided to terminate the follow-on to Lance program and cancel any further modernization of U.S. nuclear artillery shells deployed in Europe. The NATO summit should agree on broad objectives for future negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union on the current short-range nuclear missile forces in Europe, which should begin shortly after a CFE treaty has been signed. Fourth, the future of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, CSCE, to give it and especially its Eastern European member states a more active part in shaping Europe's future. The CSCE can help to build free societies and provide a forum for political dialogue in a united Europe. My allied colleagues and I should agree to take up these _ these ideas at the CSCE summit this fall, to be held around the signing of a CFE treaty. The future of the United States cannot be separated from the future of Europe, and so along with our allies, we must prepare for the magnificent opportunities that lie ahead. In these times of uncertainty and hope, NATO will continue to be vital to America's place in Europe, and a bulwark of democratic values and security. So, this is what I'll be talking about tomorrow and it has been discussed by Jim Baker with our allies in Brussels yesterday and today. And I don't know who has the first question but _ Helen?
Q: Mr. President, you said that things were moving on the hostage front, and can I ask you what are the prospects of getting all the hostages out? They may sometimes feel like sacrificial lambs as the U.S. stands and waits. What goodwill gesture do you have in mind to facilitate this and expedite their release? A: I would have in mind any gesture that wouldn't be perceived as negotiating for the release of hostages. We have a policy. I am going to stay with that policy. But, let me give you an example, Helen. One of the things that the Iranians are interested in is the fate of _ I believe it was four _ four Iranians that were taken, I think, back in '82. Now, if there's some way that we can go back and get any information that would relieve the anxieties of the loved ones of those four people, we ought to do that. And it is our view and I have said this _ told _ made this clear, that it is the best information we have that these people are not alive. But, just as we would like a full accounting for Higgins, our heroic Marine that apparently has been killed, I can understand the Iranians wanting a full accounting, even though they know we have nothing to do with this. So, here's an area where they have said they'd like some information, and if we can get it, I think we ought to get it, and we're trying. So, if that is goodwill, so be it. I hope it is. It's the way I would intend it. And there may be other things we can do. But, look, I understand the anxiety of the hostage families, and I can understand the broken hearts, and that's why I'm not going to shift.

DOC.HEAD: Latvia's Parliament To Consider Independence Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Latvian legislature opening meeting, supporters and foes of independence gathering with signs, quotes from Latvian president, CORRECTS to People's Front, sted Popular Front. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Latvia's legislature opened a session today to begin discussing whether to join Baltic neighbors Lithuania and Estonia in asserting its independence from Moscow. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis attended the opening session ``to be with my brothers,'' and pro- and anti-independence protesters stood aside as the deputies entered the parliament building. About 50 Soviet army officers who live in Latvia gathered with signs proclaiming, ``The People and the Army are United,'' and ``We Won't Go the Way of Lithuania.'' A few steps away, pro-independence protesters carried banners saying, ``The Soviet Army Must Go Home,'' and ``Independence for Latvia.'' Protesters carried Soviet flags or the red-and-white Latvian flag. The legislature, or Supreme Soviet, discussed procedural questions and a vote on independence was likely Friday. Deputies from the pro-independence People's Front said they believe they can muster the needed two-thirds majority. The Soviet news agency Tass said the People's Front and its supporters had 131 of 201 seats in the legislature. A two-thirds majority would require 135 votes, and People's Front activists believe they can find the extra votes. Anatoly Gorbunov, Latvia's president, backed independence in a speech after being nominated to a new term. ``I believe that the renewal of a legally sovereign nation must be accomplished,'' he said, declaring it a ``normal way of life for all the residents of Latvia.'' Gorbunov was expected to win election to continue as president. But he said the republic could not expect help from the West. ``The world, on account of 5 million Baltic people, is not going to risk what has been done in the area of arms control and by Mikhail Gorbachev,'' he said. Landsbergis told Latvian Radio in an interview: ``I see and feel that Latvia won't retreat from the principle of independence.'' He told the Latvian deputies to ``be strong and have courage.'' In his own republic, officials of Landsbergis' government said today that shortages were beginning to touch medical supplies. Lithuania declared independence from the Soviet Union on March 11. In response, the Kremlin imposed harsh economic sanctions, including a sharp reduction in oil and gas supplies, about two weeks ago. The republic of 3.8 million people has been struggling economically ever since the embargo was imposed, with plant closings forcing thousands to stop work and food and fuel being rationed. A similar independence measue was adopted March 30 by Estonia, which with fellow Baltic states Latvia and Lithuania was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. The measure being debated in Latvia would, unlike Lithuania's declaration, take effect only after an indefinite transition period. Lawmakers also were expected to vote on dropping the ``Soviet Socialist'' from Latvia's name, leaving it simply ``The Republic of Latvia.'' Deputies belonging to the Latvian People's Front pro-independence movement said they agreed to the go-slow plan on secession after watching Lithuania struggle unsuccessfully to persuade Moscow to begin negotiations. ``We didn't slam the door and then start to knock,'' said Romans Apsitis, a law professor. ``We're leaving the door open and still moving toward independence.'' The proposal would leave most of the republic's Soviet-era constitution intact, but it would also assert Latvia's claim to independence and its right to re-establish its traditional Parliament. Although the Latvian measure would be less drastic than Lithuania's, it also would not be within the secession procedure outlined in a Soviet law passed in March. The law obliges any republic seeking independence to gain approval through a referendum and wait up to five years while negotiating terms of divorce with Moscow. Opponents say the law effectively prevents any republic from seceding. Apsitis said that at most Latvia would consider a role in a reconfigured Soviet confederation _ but only after gaining independence. Because of Latvia's delicate ethnic balance, a declaration of independence would likely be less radical than Lithuania's declaration. In contrast to Lithuania, where 80 percent of the people are ethnic Lithuanian, only about 54 percent of Latvia's population of 2.7 million people is ethnic Latvian. Most of the rest are ethnic Russians, many of whom oppose independence. ``It will pit Russians and Latvians against each other,'' said Soviet Army Major Alexander Skryachev. In the past year, Latvia has copied Lithuania's daring political moves. In December, it abolished the Communist Party's guarantee on power; in February it condemned the 1940 act that formalized its annexation by the Soviet Union; and last month a large segment of its Communist Party broke off from its Moscow-based parent party. All the moves came within months, sometimes weeks, of similar Lithuanian actions.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Reached on Environmental Studies for Use of Dolphins as Guards
DOC.TEXT: Animal rights advocates and the Navy have agreed on environmental studies on the use of dolphins as security guards at the Trident nuclear submarine base at Bangor. In addition, the Navy has agreed in a separate document to stop capturing the marine mammals until an environmental impact statement on the taking of dolphins from the wild is completed. Both sides said the agreement would delay for months the arrival of trained dolphins at the base on Hood Canal, where they would be deployed to protect the Tridents from underwater intruders. The agreement announced Wednesday, negotiated to resolve a 13-month-old federal lawsuit, was hailed by John T. Costo, a lawyer for the Progressive Animal Welfare Society and 14 other groups. ``I think it's a great settlement,'' Costo said. ``And it's great that the Navy has acknowledged that it has obligations under federal environmental laws.'' Congress gave the Navy permission in 1987 to capture as many as 25 dolphins a year without supervision under animal-protection laws. Costo said the Navy could decide to make either an environmental study or a less extensive environmental assessment of the dolphin guard project, with no timetable established. Only after the decision is announced can dolphin guards be deployed at Bangor, and if the decision is challenged the Navy must provide a schedule for deployment plans, the animal rights lawyer said. The more extensive study would require public hearings at which opponents could present evidence on what they say are the dangers of introducing dolphins to colder water than the animals are normally used to. Critics had also raised other objections to the program, including alleged mistreatment of the animals during training. But as part of the settlement, animal-rights groups agreed that Navy environmental review ``need not publicly discuss operational aspects of the program.'' Before the settlement, some opponents said the Navy was planning to move dolphins to the base within 10 weeks. ``The Navy has no intention to deploy the animals to Bangor in June,'' said Tom LaPuzza of the Naval Ocean Systems Center in San Diego. ``It is not within the cards at all for us to bring that system to Bangor this summer.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Bush Cancels New Missile and Artillery Modernization. Editing to tighten and update; adds 5 grafs dash matter with S&L, Mexico, Budget, Barbara Bush.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today scrapped U.S. plans for modernizing battlefield nuclear weapons in West Germany and called upon the western alliance to conduct a wholesale strategy review to fit ``the transformed Europe of the 1990s.'' With NATO foreign ministers wrapping up their meeting in Brussels, Bush said a NATO summit will convene in late June or early July. Responding to the lessening threat from a shrinking Eastern bloc, he said the United States would not modernize nuclear-tipped battlefield artillery in Europe and would ``terminate'' plans to deploy a newer and more-powerful Lance missile. Bush also told a White House news conference he isn't trying to force out the man who now oversees the nation's troubled savings and loan industry, Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. chief L. William Seidman. He said Seidman had decided not to complete his full term, which expires late next year. Bush said Seidman had called him earlier today to urge the nomination of William Taylor, now acting director of the Resolution Trust Corp., as his successor. Bush did not announce the pull back of any current missile deployments but said the NATO summit would authorize negotiations with the Soviet Union on short-range missiles in Europe _ to begin after agreement on the reduction of conventional forces in Europe. On the subject of U.S. hostages held in Lebanon, Bush said he was cheered by the release of two American hostages but was not willing to make any conciliatory gestures toward Iran at this time. He said he was not certain that the recent releases would lead to quick freedom for other hostages. Bush said he wanted to meet with U.S. allies after his May 30-June 3 superpower summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He was asked about the jeering directed toward Gorbachev during the May Day parade in Red Square, and said such vocal opposition comes with democracy. ``That's the fruits of democracy,'' said Bush. ``He's just learning.'' He was asked about a report out of Europe about a possible military coup, which did not occur. Bush said he'd seen no intelligence about such a threat to Gorbachev, but he added, ``I do from time to time worry about a takeover that will set back the whole process'' of change. Bush characterized as ``very, very positive'' a statement on Wednesday by Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis in response to a call from the leaders of Franch and West Germany urging restraint from the rebellious Baltic republic. Earlier, in an opening statement, Bush signalled his hopes for the new era in Europe. ``As democracy comes to Eastern Europe and Soviet troops return home, there is less need for nuclear systems of a shorter range,'' Bush said in announcing the dramatic military changes. Although Britain has sought a U.S. modernization of 700 aging Lance missiles in Europe, Bush's decision not to upgrade them goes along with the views of most NATO members. The decision not to modernize nuclear-tipped artillary will be particularily popular in West Germany, where most are deployed. Bush said he'd issued the call for a summit of leaders from the 16 members of the North Atlantic Treaty Alliance ``after consulting personally with my NATO colleagues.'' The session would ``launch a wide-ranging strategy review for the transformed Europe of the 1990s.'' Bush said the intelligence community was trying to determine now whether the releases of former hostages Robert Polhill and Frank Reed were part of a process that would lead to freedom for the remaining six Americans in captivity. Bush said he was prepared to ``do anything that wouldn't be perceived as negotiating for the release of hostages.'' He said he was willing to try to determine the fate of four Iranians kidnapped in Beirut in 1982 but said they were believed dead. ``I've tried hard not to raise the hopes'' of the hostage families ``and then have them dashed,'' he said. Bush reiterated the U.S. position that the United States wanted to see ``all hostages'' released but sidestepped commenting on whether this should also include 400 Shiites being held by Israel. Iran has demanded that these prisoners be released, including Moslem leader Sheik Obeid. ``I want to see all hostages released ... in all countries,'' Bush said. But he said there were ``definitional problems'' concerning those held by Israel because ``some people view people they hold as having broken laws and some people don't.'' Bush was to meet later in the day with Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene. He embraced the statement from Lithuanian President Landsbergis that seemed to lessen chances of a confrontation between Lithuanian leaders and Moscow. ``Whatever facilitates dialogue is good,'' Bush said. At the same time, Bush indicated there was no change in U.S. position toward Moscow over the crisis in Lithuania. He denied that his administration's proposal the day before for relaxing export controls on western high-tech products sent to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe had been any form of reward for Moscow's restraint. Bush made the NATO announcements as Secretary of State James A. Baker III met in Brussels with NATO allies. Baker proposed that 35 foreign ministers from East and West meet in New York in late September to pave the way for a summit by the end of the year to formally sign agreements to reduce conventional forces throughout Europe. On other subjects: _ Bush said that ``I didn't tell you I'm anxious to see Bill Seidman leave'' as head of the FDIC, but neither did he urge Seidman to stay. ``I think his decision is a personal one and I support him and he's entitled to make it,'' Bush said. There was no discussion of timing on Seidman's retirement. _ He conceded a difference of opinion existed with Mexican officials over the U.S. role in the abduction of a Mexican doctor now awaiting trial in Los Angeles in the 1985 slaying of a U.S. drug enforcement agent. The United States has denied Mexican charges that it had the doctor kidnapped. ``We don't want a misunderstanding with Mexico, we don't need it,'' Bush said. _ The president acknowledged that nobody is enthusiastic about the fiscal 1991 budget he sent to Congress last winter, but added that the same is true about Democratic budgets. He said he'll meet with Democratic congressional leaders Sunday to decide what to do next. ``We're not into a negotiation, we're talking process,'' he said. _ Bush said that the Wellsley College students who object to Barbara Bush's commeencement address on their suburban Boston campus Massachusetts ``can learn a lot'' from the first lady. The students object on grounds that her prominence stems only from her husband. ``The American people love her because...she stands for something,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgaria and Israel Restore Diplomatic Relations
DOC.TEXT: Israel and Bulgaria restored diplomatic relations today after a 23-year break and signed an economic cooperation agreement. Bulgaria and other East bloc countries broke relations with Israel after the 1967 Six-Day War, and only Moscow has not restored diplomatic ties following the democratic reforms that have swept Eastern Europe. Foreign ministers Moshe Arens of Israel and Boiko Dimitrov of Bulgaria signed a formal agreement to resume relations, then held a news conference at the Palace of Culture. About 100 Palestinian students demonstrated outside to protest Israel's policy in the Middle East. The PLO mission issued a statement acknowledging Bulgaria's right to restore relations with Israel and expressed hope that friendly relations between Palestinians and Bulgaria would continue. Repeating comments made upon his arrival Wednesday, Arens said: ``Bulgaria is almost a neighbor of Israel and many Jews of Bulgarian origin are an integral part of Israeli society,'' he said. Arens said Israel's image is better now because some socialist countries recognize the Jewish state and no longer give unconditional support to Arab nations. Dimitrov and Arens also signed a protocol on economic cooperation that covers air transportation, telecommunications, tourism, agriculture, mutual protection of investments and dealings between the countries' national banks.

DOC.HEAD: Rafsanjani Calls U.S. `Stubborn, Frustrated Child' Over Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 24th graf, `Reed also ...' with Thatcher quotes today; Picks up 25th graf pvs, `The Most ...'
DOC.TEXT: Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani today branded the U.S. administration a ``stubborn, frustrated child'' for refusing to make a goodwill gesture in reponse to the release of two American hostages in Lebanon. He also declared in a speech broadcast by Tehran radio, monitored in Nicosia: ``Iran does not want relations with the United States, and we welcomed severing ties. ... We are not prepared to talk to America.'' Rafsanjani's comments, made in an address to a group of teachers in Tehran, appeared to rule out the possibility of a dialogue with the United States after 11 years of hostility. But they also indicated that Rafsanjani, leader of Iran's so-called pragmatists, was under mounting pressure from anti-Western radicals angered at Iran's role in the release of the two Americans held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militants in Lebanon. Robert Polhill, 55, of New York, was freed April 22. Eight days later, Frank Reed, 57, of Malden, Mass., was released. Sixteen other Westerners, six of them Americans, remain missing in Lebanon. Most are believed held by factions linked to the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God. Rafsanjani admitted that the Lebanese groups who freed Polhill and Reed had done so ``at our suggestion. They could have ... rejected our advice. But they accepted our advice.'' Rafsanjani's comments echoed remarks on Wednesday by Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, that Tehran is against talks with the United States. Khamenei said that ``the Islamic Republic government would not possibly do so without my consent.'' President Bush said today he was cheered by the release of two American hostages but was unwilling to make any conciliatory gestures toward Iran at this time. He said he was prepared to ``do anything that wouldn't be perceived as negotiating for the release of hostages.'' Tehran radio, reporting other parts of Rafsanjani's speech, said Rafsanjani likened Washington's no-deal response to the hostage releases to that of ``a stubborn, frustrated child.'' ``Someone should have taken the first step to solve the hostage issue,'' Rafsanjani declared. ``The expectation was that a government like the United States, which is a big government, would step in and solve the issue. But here the Lebanese warriors seized the initiative and released the hostages without conditions.'' He added: ``Instead of giving an appropriate reward for this initiative, the U.S. reacted by saying it will not negotiate with kidnappers, as if Israel and the (Lebanese) Phalangists are not kidnappers.'' That was a reference to hundreds of Arabs held by Israel, including Hezbollah leader Sheik Abdul-Karim Obeid, seized in Lebanon July 28, and four Iranians seized by Lebanese Christian militiamen in July 1982. Referring to Polhill's release, Rafsanjani said that ``an angry, revolutionary, enraged group, after it released one hostage without pre-conditions, and was confronted with America's irresponsible reaction, should reasonably have taken revenge. ``But they still showed decency and showed their extreme goodwill'' by freeing Reed as well, he said. Referring to Bush's public thanks to Iran and Syria for their role in last month's releases, Rafsanjani said that ``on the one hand the United States thanked Iran and Syria for their efforts in releasing the hostages. ``On the other hand, it started a vile propaganda move, stating `we will not normalize ties until Iran releases all hostages.''' Meanwhile, American hostage Thomas Sutherland turned 59 today and spent his fifth birthday in captivity. His wife sent him birthday greetings in a message published by a leftist Beirut newspaper. Jean Sutherland's message, carried by As-Safir in Arabic and English, said: ``I send you the best gift I have, my dear _ `a red, red rose' of love. May it touch your heart and spirit in a special way on this your special day.'' Mrs. Sutherland lives on the campus of the American University of Beirut where she teaches English. Sutherland was acting dean of agriculture at the school when he was kidnapped on June 9, 1985. Sutherland, of Fort Collins, Colo., is the second longest-held hostage in Lebanon. A pro-Iranian group calling itself Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, has claimed responsibility for Sutherland's abduction. The group also holds American journalist Terry Anderson, 42, of Lorain, Ohio. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Reed, who said he was held with Sutherland and Anderson up until a year ago, was freed Monday after being held for 3{ years by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militants. Reed also said he had been kept in a house in Beirut with two other hostages, Brian Keenan and John McCarthy, both British citizens. In London today, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher welcomed help by Syria and Iran in securing the two American hostages' freedom and said her government was using diplomatic contacts to seek the release of British captives. But she reiterated that the British government would make no deals with the hostage takers. ``We note that America has done no deals, but it is in fact through quiet contacts, that her hostages have been released,'' she told the House of Commons. The Most Rev. Robert Runcie, spiritual leader of the Church of England and the worldwide Anglican communion, said today he had no quarrel with his government's policy of making no deals that would reward the kidnappers. ``Over the past 10 days the Iranian government have demonstrated that, with Syrian support, they can use their influence to bring about the release of hostages,'' said Runcie, whose personal envoy Terry Waite is among the captives. The time has come, Runcie said, for direct talks. ``That, of course, is a two-sided matter. It needs willingness on both sides to talk,'' he said. Keenan's sister, Elaine Spence, talked by telephone with Reed and said he ``condemned very strongly, very bitterly, the British government, for not doing anything at all.'' ``He can't believe that this prime minister (Mrs. Thatcher) can take such a stand. As he said, the irony of it. But words after that to describe Mrs. Thatcher, I wouldn't repeat, what Frank Reed said.'' Mrs. Spence told BBC Radio from her home in Belfast, Northern Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Atheist, Agnostic Knock Boy Scouts For Requiring Religious Oath
DOC.TEXT: The Boy Scouts of America organization has asked a federal judge to dismiss a lawsuit filed by an agnostic who said he and his 6-year-old son were rejected from a Scout chapter for refusing to profess faith in God. Elliott Welsh of suburban Hinsdale filed the lawsuit last fall, saying the organization practiced religious discrimination. The Boy Scouts, based in Irving, Texas, has required its members, now numbering about 4.3 million, ``to do my duty to God and my country'' since its founding 80 years ago, said Scouts spokesman Lee Sneath. Walsh and his son Mark, now 7, were rejected when they noted on Cub Scout membership applications they would not agree to religious stipulations because they were agnostic. The Cub Scouts is a branch of the Boy Scouts for younger boys. When the Scouts refused to change the policy, Walsh filed suit, charging that it violated the part of the 1964 Civil Rights Act that bans religious discrimination in public accommodations. The Scouts contend their units are more like private clubs, which are excluded from that provision of the civil rights law. Scouts attorney Thomas D. Allen asked U.S. District Judge Ilana Rovner on Wednesday to dismiss the lawsuit. Rovner delayed the request for further consideration after Welsh's attorney, Richard Grossman, said the Scouts are a public body because they invite all boys to join. ``If they're going to give a flier to every kid in the 1st grade inviting him to join, then they've got to accept the consequences of having their organization subject to the same laws as a McDonald's or a movie theater,'' Grossman argued. Also Wednesday, Robert L. Sherman, national spokesman for American Atheists Inc., held a news conference to demand that the United Way cut off its annual support to the Boy Scouts in the Chicago area after his 8-year-old son was rejected from the club for the same reason. He said the United Way should cut off about $1.5 million to Chicago chapters of the Boy Scouts, because of the United Way policy prohibiting gifts to organizations that discriminate on the basis of religion. The United Way will appoint a committee to look into the charges, said spokeswoman Julia Hess. Sneath said the Scouts will not change the policy, even if the United Way organizations cut off their donations, which make up about 13 percent of the organization's $350 million annual operating budget. ``As a private membership organization, we have a right to set our own standards for membership and leadership,'' he said. ``We do not discriminate on the basis of religion. And I don't know that anyone has ever proved that having no belief is a religion.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He Can't `Rejoice' Until All Hostages Freed
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that while he welcomes the recent release of two Americans hostages in Lebanon, he can't rejoice ``as long as six others are held hostage.'' Asked whether the release of Frank Reed and Robert Polhill might fortell the release of all Americans, Bush said, ``I can't say that our actions facilitated the release of Reed and Polhill. ``I hope that the affirmation and reaffirmation of our policy contributed, but there were no behind-the-scenes actions that pulled this off,'' Bush said at a morning news conference. The president said he welcomed the release of Reed and Polhill, ``but I can't rejoice and say my heart is full of hope and goodwill as long as six others are held hostages.'' The six include Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped in March 1985 and is the longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon. Bush said he would be willing to make goodwill gestures to Iran ``that wouldn't be perceived as negotiating for the release of hostages.'' Asked what those gestures might be, the president mentioned that Iran was anxious to learn about four Iranian diplomats kidnapped in Lebanon in 1982. ``If we could go back and get any information that would relieve the anxiety of the loved ones of those people we ought to do that,'' Bush said. ``I can understand the Iranians wanting the full accounting. Here they've said, `here is an area where we can get information.''' He said the United States does not think the four diplomats are still alive but added, ``my point is that if Iran feels that way, this is something we should use to disperse the lack of information to bring them the facts, if we can. ... ``Here is something we can do without violating our policy and I think they would consider this good will. There is a human equation here,'' Bush said. The president was asked about the 400 Moslems, mostly Shiites held in Israeli prison camps, whose release is demanded by Iran. ``I have stated my position that hostage holding is unproductive towards any political change and I want to see all hostages released,'' the president said. ``There are definitional problems because some people view the people that they hold as having broken their laws. ... It is not for the United States to make those determinations.''

DOC.HEAD: West German President Honors Jews Slaughtered By Nazis
DOC.TEXT: West German President Richard von Weizsaecker paid homage to the victims of the Nazi Holocaust today, retracing their path from the Warsaw Ghetto to the Treblinka death camp. At Treblinka, accompanied by President Wojciech Jaruzelski, Weizsaecker laid a wreath of flowers at the monument commemorating the more than 800,000 Jews who died there. They both stood silently and bowed their heads at the foot of the 25-foot stone memorial, which is surrounded by hundreds of small rocks _ some bearing names of the hometowns and villages of the victims. Later, Weizsaecker laid flowers at a stone dedicated to Jewish educator Janusz Korczak and the children from the orphanage he ran in the Warsaw Ghetto who died with him at Treblinka. Neither Weizsaecker nor Jaruzelski spoke during the solemn ceremony in front of the monument, which is inscribed with the words ``Never again'' in six languages. Weizsaecker's trip to Poland ``has a big moral and emotional dimension, the proof of which is that we are here together today,'' Jaruzelski told reporters before leaving Treblinka. ``In relations between Poles and Germans ... Moral problems and moral values are important,'' he said. ``And this visit, it seems to me, has created conditions for mutual understanding and trust and this leads to reconciliation.'' Weizsaecker, the first West German head of state to visit Poland, later was to have a second meeting with Prime Minister Tadesuz Mazoweicki. He arrived in Poland on Wednesday. In Warsaw, the West German president visited a monument to the doomed Jewish insurgents who staged the 1943 Ghetto uprising against the Nazis. Then he went to Umschlagplatz, the station where Jews were loaded onto death trains en route to Treblinka, 50 miles northeast. Treblinka was built to carry out Hitler's ``Final Solution.'' An estimated 56,000 Jews were gassed to death after the 1943 uprising alone. Hundreds of thousands more from Poland and other countries died, most within a half-hour of their arrival. In all, 6 million Poles died in the war, including 3 million Jews. Much of the country, including Warsaw, was left in rubble. Weizsaecker's visit to Treblinka has taken on added significance because of the mixed feelings with which Poles view German unification. He has taken pains to assure Poles they have nothing to fear from a united Germany next door. ``If the Germans and the Poles are to find a common future, this will only be possible by taking honest account of the past ... Inexpressible suffering has been inflicted on you by Germans, and today this weighs heavily on us,'' Weizsaecker said Wednesday at a dinner given by Jaruzelski. He reiterated that Poland's chief concern, the permanence of its postwar western border, will be resolved. ``Poland may be unreservedly confident that the border questions between us are irrevocably cleared in their essence and that in the process of forming German unity, they will receive a proper, legally and internationally binding ... treaty,'' he said. On Wednesday, West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher met Wednesday with Polish Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski to discuss a Polish draft of a border treaty. In addition to a border treaty, Poland is seeking a seat at unification talks held by the four World War II allies and the two Germanys.

Now, if the man has done something good and surprised everybody in this room, including me, about the acceptance of freedom and democracy in Eastern Europe, and he has, give credit for that. But on Lithuania, there's an enormously complicated problem. And I must say, I'm looking forward to visiting with the prime minister, in a little bit, of Lithuania. But I must convince the Lithuanian-Americans that my desire for their freedom and their self-determine is just as strong as anybody else's. And I also must convince those here and around the world that we want to see the peaceful evolution that's taking place towards democracy continue. So when Terry asked his question about _ about dialogue, that is our policy. And I'm delighted to see that Landsbergis now feels there may be some merits in this policy. But Lesley, we can't place this on a ``you have to choose between Gorbachev or Landsbergis.'' That's not the policy of the United States government, nor it should be _ nor should it be.
Q: And I have a follow-up. The May Day parade, Mr. Gorbachev was heckled. Your defense decretary says that he doesn't think that Mr. Gorbachev can succeed with his reforms. Do you? A: The May Day parade? He ought to come join some of the parades I go to around here, and this goes for your horse, too. I mean, it's _ (laughter) _ you ought to see some of the _ some of the expression of _ you know, I mean _ look, that's the fruits of democracy _ (laughter). He's just learning. He's just learning, so I wouldn't read too much into that. Yes, there's some discontent, and a lot of it relates to the economy, and some of it relates by _ to _ the Lithuanians inside the Soviet Union to the handling of Lithuania. But that's what's _ there's a good side to all of this. I sometimes ask myself if that's true, but it is _ (scattered laughter) _ because that's the way, you know, fledgling democracies are beginning to work, and that's the way our system has worked. And I don't suppose if everybody _ anytime anyone points to a demonstration that gets rambunctious in the United States and points to ``that means instability in the United States system,'' there's got to be something crazy, because that isn't the way it works. John?
Q: You seem to be getting serious about the budget now. You've invited congressional leaders to the White House Sunday night to talk about the budget. No one in Congress believes your budget projections, partly because interest rates have risen since you released your budget. A: (That's _ that's the key?)

DOC.HEAD: Mediator Called in to Stop Mohawk Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with meeting under way outside Montreal but closed to reporters; add comments from Canadian solicitor general. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Basically, we're...'. INSERTS new penultimate graf with casino owner arrested, reporters stopped.
DOC.TEXT: The Canadian army mobilized assault vehicles at the border and a federal mediator was called in after two Indians were slain in a dispute over casino gambling on the reservation. U.S. and Canadian authorities kept the 28,000-acre reservation straddling the border sealed off as federal, state and provincial representatives met with Indian leaders today near Montreal for talks on restoring order. The morning meeting was closed to reporters. Hundreds of heavily armed state police, Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Canadian provincial police moved in Tuesday after two men were shot to death in a dispute among Mohawks over whether to allow gambling on the reservation. The first fatalities in the 9-month-old dispute prompted state police to break their policy of not setting foot on the reservation unless invited. Mohawks consider the reservation sovereign territory. No shots had been heard for more than a day. Still, many of the Mohawks living on the reservation remained in their homes. ``I'm not venturing out,'' said Jack Hubert, a retiree. ``I don't want to spend my golden years being shot at.'' The Canadian army moved 80 vehicles to Cornwall, Ontario, including 14 amphibious assault vehicles, two helicopters and four armored personnel carriers. Canada's Solicitor General Pierre Cadieux said the police would take away any illegal arms they found. The Canadian military were offering only equipment and engineering support and that no infantry had been summoned to the reservation, he said. ``Basically, we're giving a non-lethal support role,'' said Capt. Cliff Collison of the First Battalion of Royal Canadian Regiment. ``If anybody's going to do any shooting, it will be the police.'' Gov. Mario Cuomo ordered the National Guard to assist state police by transporting troopers and providing equipment but said he would not send guardsmen onto the reservation because it might provoke more violence. ``Before you use military force you should use the force of reason,'' Cuomo said. Fletcher Graves, a mediator from the U.S. Justice Department who has helped the Mohawks resolve other disputes, arrived on the reservation Wednesday afternoon, said John Boots, a member of the pro-gambling Warrior Society. ``I don't know what my role will be until I get there. We'll talk to every party,'' Graves said after being dispatched to the reservation. The issue of gambling has been at the center of escalating violence since last summer. The dispute has been marked by gunfire, arson and blockades, and up to 600 Mohawks fled to Ontario last week after a week of nightly violence. Pro-gambling forces say the reservation's six casinos, where slot machines, craps, bingo and other games draw busloads of patrons from the Northeast, are an economic boon. Opponents argue they encourage prostitution and drug use and threaten traditional ways. Early Tuesday, 22-year-old Matthew Pyke, a casino opponent, was slain while walking in the reservation in Snye, Quebec. Not far away, J.R. Edwards, 30, a proponent of gambling, was found dead next to his house. More than 600 police and soldiers in and around the reservation Wednesday night turned back anyone but residents and searched vehicles for guns at a dozen roadblocks. Earlier, Mohawk children waited for school buses beside troopers. The owner of the reservation's largest casino, Tony Laughing, was arrested Wednesday after police found a canister of tear gas in his car, authorities said. Police also caught three reporters from the Ottawa Citizen trying to cross the St. Lawrence River in a boat to get onto the American side of the reservation, authorities said. The reporters were sent back to Canada. New York troopers will be on the reservation through the weekend while Quebec police investigate the killings, State Police said.

DOC.HEAD: Fire in Government Building, Third in Three Weeks
DOC.TEXT: A fire caused major damage to a government office building Thursday, officials said. It was the third fire in a government building in the capital in less than three weeks. The blaze destroyed one floor of offices used by the Agriculture Ministry. The only casualty was a firefighter who was injured when he fell from the second floor, where the fire started, said R.K. Nyogi, a police commissioner. Nyogi said an investigation was under way into the cause of the fire. ``We can't rule out anything,'' he said when asked if arson was a possibility. It has not been determined what caused the two previous fires. The first, on April 16, destroyed the interior of the capital's main conference center. A few days later, fire broke out in Nirman Bhavan, where the Housing Ministry is located. There were no casualties in either incident. Nriter= NEW YORK (AP) _ Retail sales generally rebounded in April as consumers returned to stores to shop for Easter and spring items, several of the nation's biggest retailers reported today. Many retailers who had a dismal March posted better results last month. Woolworth Corp., whose sales fell in March compared to a year earlier, had an 18.2 percent sales gain in April at stores open at least a year, and a 21.1 percent increase overall. Results from stores open a year or longer _ known as same- or comparable-store sales _ give a more accurate reading of a retailer's performance. Industry analysts therefore give them more weight than overall sales figures. Changes in the calendar _ such as Easter falling on April 9 this year and on March 26 last year _ often have an impact on retail sales and affect year-to-year comparisons. But after accounting for the shift, the industry's overall results were generally favorable, said Jeffrey Feiner, a retail analyst with Merrill Lynch & Co. Analysts consider March and April sales together in assessing how well a store has performed. Shoppers again spent most of their money on apparel and lower-priced items while generally shying away from more expensive purchases. Consumers remained burdened by high installment debt and were again cautious about major expenditures. Analysts expect this trend, which has been in place for several years, to continue. Retail sales are closely watched not only as a gauge of the industry's health, but also as an economic barometer. Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the gross national product. Sears, Roebuck and Co., the nation's largest retailer, reported a 3.1 percent increase over April 1989 results in same-store sales, and a 1.6 percent sales gain overall. Wal-Mart Stores Inc. again outdistanced other retailers, reporting a 7 percent increase in same-store sales, while overall results were up 20 percent. J.C. Penney Co. Inc. had a disappointing month after a much stronger March. Penney's same-store sales fell 2.8 percent, while overall sales were off 1.7 percent. Melville Corp., which runs specialty chains including Thom McAn, Kay-bee and CVS, said its overall sales rose 21.9 percent. Melville did not release same-store figures. Other major retailers, including Dayton Hudson Corp. and May Department Stores Co., are expected to announce their sales figures next Thursday. Analysts said it appeared these companies _ which own some of the country's biggest department store chains _ would report favorable results. The results announced today differ from the federal government's monthly retail sales report. Besides stores, the government's figures include sales at a range of establishments from auto dealerships and supermarkets to restaurants and movie theaters.

DOC.HEAD: Search Called Off for Survivors of Korean Fishing Ship
DOC.TEXT: Rescue workers abandoned their search Thursday for survivors after a Korean fishing boat sank in heavy seas off the New Zealand coast, killing at least 11 crew members, officials said. Only three of the 17 crew members were rescued, officials said. Eleven others were confirmed dead, and three were missing and presumed drowned. The National Rescue Coordination Center called off the search at 3 p.m. Thursday, 36 hours after the first distress call was received from the squid boat Sam Seung 35. The boat sank early Wednesday about 140 miles west of Auckland. ``We must assume at this stage it is bodies we are looking for,'' search coordinator Bud Mills said in a statement. He said the already bad weather conditions were getting worse. The survivors were recovering in New Plymouth. They were identified as the boat's captain, bosun and first engineer. The men spent 12 hours clinging to debris before being picked up by a Soviet fishing trawler. Two Soviet fishing boats helped the Royal New Zealand Air Force in the rescue effort.

DOC.HEAD: Curfew in Nablus to Prevent Clashes Over Seminary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with ceremony, quotes. Pick up 5th pvs, `Palestinians believe ...'
DOC.TEXT: The army imposed a curfew today on the West Bank city of Nablus to prevent demonstrations against a Jewish seminary that Palestinians fear will become the core of the city's first Israeli settlement. Tension was high in Nablus after 10 right-wing Parliament members, including former Defense Minster Ariel Sharon, said they planned to attend a religious ceremony today at the seminary, or yeshiva. However, only Rehovoam Zeevi, a parliament member who advocates expulsion of Palestinians from the occupied territories, and Geulah Cohen, head of the nationalist Tehiya party, arrived in Nablus, the army radio said. The army also permitted only 100 settlers to take part, thwarting the settlers' plans to bring in 17 busloads of supporters. The military also permitted a small group from the leftist Peace Now movement to stage a protest at the site, the legendary burial place of the son of the biblical patriarch Jacob. The Palestinians regard the ceremony as a symbolic increase of the Jewish presence in the city that comes amidst the government's stepped up settlement drive. Daniella Weiss, a settlement leader, said the ceremony was purely religious. ``Maybe it looks like there is a political purpose, but it is only religious,'' she said. ``I do not think that we should cancel or postpone our celebration because of political implications.'' The ceremony came a few days after a top aide to hard-line Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir announced he wanted to build sleeping quarters for the yeshiva students. Under current army orders, the students must leave Nablus at night to avoid clashes with the 120,000 Arab residents. Palestinians believe building a dormitory will constitute a permanent settlement in Nablus, a focus of anti-Israeli violence during the nearly 29-month-old Palestinian rebellion against Israeli occupation. Recent settlement activity has strained relations between Israel and the United States, which considers Jewish settlement in occupied lands an obstacle to peace. Since March 15, when the coalition of Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc and the left-leaning Labor Party fell apart and left Shamir as caretaker prime minister, ground has been broken on two new settlements. Fourteen other sites are reportedly under consideration. Several hours before the ceremony at the yeshiva was to begin, roadblocks were erected at entrances to Nablus to keep out non-residents, soldiers searched Palestinian homes nearby and about a dozen observation posts were erected on rooftops overlooking the building, Arab witnesses said. An army spokesman said the curfew imposed on the city and its surrounding refugee camps confined about 160,000 people to their homes. The measures were aimed at preventing confrontations between Palestinians and settlers. The Moslem fundamentalist Hamas movement had called on Palestinians to attack soldiers and settlers in protest. ``A settlement in Nablus will create a new wave of confrontations with the settlers,'' Ghassan Shakaa, a pro-PLO Nablus lawyer, said in a phone interview. ``This proves how the radicals in Israel are working against peace.'' Left-wing Israelis joined the outcry. Legislator Dedi Zucker of the Citizens' Rights Movement said the Nablus ceremony was ``part of a much larger picture'' of Shamir's drive to create more settlements in the occupied lands. Noam Livnat, a spokesman for the seminary, said the ceremony would be an assertion of Jewish claims of sovereignty over ``Eretz Israel,'' a Hebrew phrase for the biblical land of Israel that includes the West Bank. ``We are not just talking about bringing a Torah to the seminary, but (about) a declaration that Eretz Israel is ours, all of it, only ours,'' Livnat said on Israel radio. Students of the Jospeh's Tomb seminary have been involved in several clashes with Palestinians that have led to bloodshed. In June 1989, about 30 yeshiva students rampaged through the West Bank village of Kifl Harith, burning trees, smashing windows and firing guns at random. A 13-year-old girl was shot and killed, and four seminary students were subsequently indicted in the case. The yeshiva's rabbi, Yitzhak Ginzburg, created a furor in Israel when he said after the incident that ``one must recognize the fact that Jewish blood and a goy's (non-Jew's) blood are not equal, God forbid. Any trial based (on the assumption) that Jews and goyim are equal is a total travesty of justice.'' Several weeks after the Kifl Harith incident, a yehsiva student ambushed a group of Arabs standing at an intersection near Tel Aviv, killing one of the men. He was later arrested.

WASHN: Seidman leave.
Q: Aren't you saying that you wouldn't be unhappy to see him leave? A: Bill Seidman asked to see me a while back _ came to see me _ said he was not going to fulfill his _ rest of his term, and we discussed that. He asked to see me to tell me that. Today, he called me and _ with the name of a successor that he enthusiastically supports. And he's done a good job. We have a significant project that he's in the middle of handling _ we call it the June 30th project _ to get a lot more done with a lot of these savings and loan in a short period of time. And he's agreed to enthusiastically tackle that. So _ and he also said, ``Look, I understand if you might want to put your own person in there.'' But he _ it's his initiative with me and today he suggested the name of a Bill Taylor who we're very high on to take over his responsibilities. So, it's one where everyone wants to have winners and losers and I don't think there are any. I think Seidman has conducted himself with extraordinary grace and great ability. And I've known him for years, worked with him in _ way back when. Yeah?
Q: Mr. President, the costs _ how to deal with the increased costs? A: Well, we've got to work with the Congress on how to deal with the cost and right now there's a significant review going forward to see what the costs are. The figures change all the time on you. Yeah?
Q: Mr. President, you talked a minute ago about fledgling democracies in Eastern Europe. Why _ or has your administration given any thought to a wholesale re-evaluation of the _ America's foreign aid requirements now that the Warsaw Pact is collapsing? And two, what's your response to those who say that we ought to take some money from the military and spend it on foreign aid for these fledgling democracies? A: Well, my response to the latter part is everybody wants to take money for defense to do something else. And the defense secretary and I want to provide adequately for the defense in a changing world, and I think Dick Cheney's done a good job up there trying to hold the line against a Congress that says, any time there's a need for anything, please take it out of defense. And so we're in a problem of my trying to hold the line, ably supported by, in some instances led by, Dick Cheney, who's up there really fighting this battle. What was the first part _ excuse me?
Q: About the full-scale review of America's foreign aid requirements. Are you interested in doing one of those, or not? A: Well, I'd be interested in a full-scale review. I mean, we've heard a lot of _ you know, a lot of our percentage of aid goes to a handful of countries. And here we have a man coming in here today, prime minister of Jamaica, Mr. Manley, who has just done a first class job in trying to move Jamaica forward in many, many ways. And I salute him for that. But his aid was a small amount, and I believe it's been just lined out because of insufficient resources, or failure to reallocate. I've suggested that the president be given a discretionary fund out of all this foreign aid so we can accommodate a person that is trying to take his small country and firm up its democracy. So I think a review of the nature you're talking about might be helpful, but I remember my days in Congress. Foreign aid doesn't have the constituency out there that domestic programs do. Yes, Maureen and then Charles.
Q: Mr. President, have you done an analysis of these hostage releases such that you conclude whether or not this is the beginning of a process that's likely to reach all the releases? And what is the United States doing behind the scenes that might have contributed to these releases? We know you're talking to Iran through third countries, but can you give us _ A: I can't say that our actions facilitated the relief of _ release of Reed and _ and Polhill. I hope that the affirmation and reaffirmation of our policy might have contributed to it, but there was no behind-the-scenes negotiations that will come out that show that we pulled this off. I wish I could _ well, I don't _ I was going to say ``I wish I could say that was true,'' but it would have to be true within these confines I've spelled out here earlier on. But we're _ we will continue to stay with the policy, trying to show goodwill where we can do it without violating the policy.
Q: And have you concluded, sir, whether this is the beginning of a process? A: Oh. Intelligence community is looking at that right now. The debrief of Reed and the debrief of Polhill might contribute to that. But you can rest assured that I have asked for that answer _ Will this lead to _ inevitably to the release of others? But I can't say that there's _ I've gotten any feeling that this process is destined to go forward in a short period of time. I wish it were different, I so wish it were different. Yeah, Charles?
Q: Mr. President, there's a report in Europe today citing Western intelligence sources that on February 25th, the day of the large demonstrations in Moscow, Mr. Gorbachev was perilously close to being overthrown. The Soviet army troops were mobilized. Is it your assessment that he has come that close to facing a coup of some sort within the Soviet Union? A: I was not advised of that by the intelligence community.
