DOC.HEAD: Record Rains Wreak Havoc in Texas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT by deleting reference to Badlands, SUBS 6th graf, `Some areas...' to CORRECT injury total to eight sted seven. INSERTS two grafs after 20th graf, `Water covered...' to UPDATE with flooding this morning in Dallas-Fort Worth. Picks up 21st graf pvs, `Fire crews...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DN1
DOC.TEXT: After two years of drought, the Lone Star State was badly parched. But when it finally rained, it poured. Record downpours this spring in north-central Texas have caused flooding, claimed nine lives, damaged crops and sent residents scrambling from their homes. Drenching rain, 60 mph wind and tornadoes continued today. ``Not since 1922 have we had rain like this,'' said Ed Delgado, spokesman for the National Weather Service in Fort Worth. ``We have seen some lakes rise in water level by four feet overnight, and there is more rain in the forecast.'' Rain today caused or threatened flooding from San Antonio northward and eastward into Oklahoma and Arkansas. In addition to the lives lost in Texas, a 9-year-old Oklahoma City boy drowned Wednesday in a rain-swollen creek, authorities said. North-central Texas _ which includes Dallas and Fort Worth _ is closing in on its average yearly rainfall total _ and the year is not even halfway over. Some areas have had up to 7 inches in 24 hours. Twisters occasionally zapped the area, including one early today that touched down in Paris, damaging 18 homes and businesses and injuring eight people. Amid sheets of gray rain, cars floated through neighborhoods, bumping into each other. Muck settled on living room floors. While police evacuated flooded houses, looters prowled abandoned neighborhoods _ in boats. ``It's a sad situation,'' said Lana Brueggemeyer, a Grand Prairie homeowner whose home has been flooded twice this year. ``But it's the elements of nature. You just don't guess. I would prefer not to go back.'' Two elderly men became the seventh and eighth fatalities of the weather Wednesday morning in Fort Worth, after they apparently ditched their car and tried to cross the street in rushing water, police said. Their bodies were found two miles away. The body of a woman, apparently swept away in her car, was found in Fort Worth. Delgado said 22.05 inches of rain fell in north-central Texas during the first four months of the year, more than double the average of 9.63. The yearly average is 29.46 inches. Only a 22.84-inch total in 1922 surpasses this year's four-month total, Delgado said. And there was heavy rain the first two days of May. Ron Ruffennach, spokesman for the Army Corps of Engineers in Fort Worth, said even with extra workers, his staff is overextended. ``We have got people monitoring just about every lake in the central part of the state,'' he said. ``We have helped evacuate people and even closed down one lake because police said looters were getting into boats and vandalizing abandoned homes.'' The Trinity River, which flows south of Dallas, crested Wednesday, forcing Army engineers to release water into a spillway, he said. ``Once the waters are loose, they can create a deadly current,'' Ruffennach said. Bill Colbert, spokesman for the Texas Water Commission, said the only good news was that one of Texas' major water supplies was being replenished. The Edwards Aquifer, which runs through southwestern Texas, was in dire need of rainfall after well-below average rainfall from 1986 to 1988, Colbert said. Agriculture officials say the rains are wreaking havoc with winter wheat. Flooding saturates the ground and cuts off the plants' supply of oxygen. ``Fields are starting to turn white, which indicates the wheat is dying,'' said Dr. Ken Stokes, an economist for the Texas Agricultural Extension Service. Water covered roads in almost every county in the path of the storm today, including U.S. 175, a major Dallas freeway. The heaviest rainfall moved out of the Dallas-Fort Worth area before dawn today and into counties east and northeast of Dallas. But the west fork of the Trinity River, which flows through Fort Worth and Dallas, remained 6 feet over flood stage and rising at 9 a.m. Floodwaters drove dozens from their homes, and some had to be rescued by boat and helicopter. ``Right now, we're getting people off of rooftops and people who refused to leave earlier,'' Dallas Fire Department spokeswoman Carolyn Garcia said. Fire crews evacuated 143 people from a nursing home in Haltom City, north of Fort Worth, and housed them in a church overnight after two creeks overflowed and the water reached the doors of the hospital. The patients ``become disoriented in foreign surroundings but their staff is with them and people from the church are helping,'' Fire Chief Kerry King said. ``Everyone seems pretty calm.'' In Oklahoma, where widespread flooding also occurred, rain-swollen Comanche Lake was pressing against its dam in Stephens County. Authorities evacuated about 200 people for fear it would burst. Problems were also reported in northwestern Arkansas, where flood warnings were posted in 10 counties, several highways were closed, and Benton County sheriff's deputies had to use boats to evacuate some people. There were no reports of injuries.

DOC.HEAD: West Virginia Primary: Familiar Faces in the 4th
DOC.TEXT: A World War II historian is making his third attempt to recapture his old congressional seat and this time he's making morality the cornerstone of his campaign. Ken Hechler, 75, has been West Virginia's Secretary of State since 1985. He also has been political science professor and wrote ``The Bridge at Remagen,'' about the Army's dash across the Rhine River during World War II. A congressman for 18 years, he lost the Democratic nomination for governor to Jay Rockefeller in 1976 while his party endorsed Nick Joe Rahall II for his congressional seat. Rahall survived Hechler's write-in campaign in November 1976 and beat Hechler in the 1978 primary. ``Had he not chosen to give up the seat, I'm sure he'd still be the congressman from this district,'' Rahall said. The district includes eight, mostly poverty-stricken counties south of Charleston that produce a large chunk of the nation's bituminous coal. Hechler said he is running because Congress has ``deteriorated'' since he left. ``It is now dominated by political action groups. I'd like to take it by the scruff of the neck and shake it up a bit,'' Hechler said. Rahall, chairman of the House mining subcommittee, has been endorsed by the state's major labor unions. The 40-year-old Rahall also amassed more than $479,000 for his campaign by March 30, according to financial reports. Hechler has raised about $3,000 and loaned his campaign more than $100,000. Using radio commercials, Hechler's strategy has been to focus on morality. His campaign jingle, which he wrote and set to a folksy tune, urges voters to elect him so they'll have ``a congressman with high moral standards again.'' Hechler denies taking a dig at Rahall, who was plagued in the last election by drunken driving charges in California in 1988 and was sued in 1984 by a Las Vegas casino for $60,000 in gambling debts. Rahall has interpreted Hechler's commercials differently, accusing Hechler of running a ``gutter-style campaign.'' He said he is tired of having his past exhumed every two years. ``Those are personal items,'' he said. ``There has been nothing in my record to question my honesty and integrity when it comes to my public responsibilities.'' Both candidates agree that West Virginians' outrage at former Republican Gov. Arch Moore following his indictment last month on extortion, fraud and obstruction of justice charges, could spark a rush to expel incumbents. ``The higher the turnout, the more chance I have,'' Hechler said. Rahall said the Moore indictment ``comes at a bad time.'' ``Incumbents are as angered as their constituents,'' Rahall said. ``There are hard-working, honest incumbents who shouldn't be thrown out. I believe the people are going to be fair.'' The Rahall-Hechler scrap is the only contested race for Congress in Tuesday's primary election. Reps. Alan B. Mollohan, Harley O. Staggers Jr. and Robert E. Wise Jr., all fourth-term Democrats, are running unopposed for renomination. Republicans, outnumbered 2-to-1 in West Virginia, have uncontested races in three of the four districts. And no Republican primary is being held in the fourth.

DOC.HEAD: Local Elections Seen as Test of Thatcher's Waning Popularity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with high turnout reported. Pickup 6th pvs, `A rout...'
DOC.TEXT: Britons voting in nationwide elections today were expected to hand Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher the worst electoral drubbing of her 11 years in power and register strong opposition to her economic policies. Officials reported a brisk turnout during the daylong balloting in brilliant sunshine across most of the country. In Britain, votes are counted by hand and most results were to be declared in the early hours Friday, several hours after the polls closed. The ballot for 201 local councils was the Conservative Party prime minister's biggest electoral test since her popularity began dropping a year ago to a now record low due in part to higher interest rates and inflation. The opposition socialist Labor Party held a huge lead of more than 20 points, recent opinion polls indicated. Today's polling is the first time the Conservatives have faced voters since the imposition April 1 of the so-called poll tax, an unpopular per capita assessment by local governments that replaced a property-based levy. At stake are some 5,000 seats on local councils ranging from big regional cities to English country districts. A rout would increase speculation that the party may try to dump Mrs. Thatcher this autumn, the last realistic chance before the next general election in 1991 or 1992. ``In midterm, the government aims to hold what it has. This we shall do,'' Conservative Party chairman Kenneth Baker said Wednesday night. But computer forecasts based on opinion polls showed the Conservatives on course to lose up to 350 seats _ about one-fourth of the seats they are defending. Among the 5,000 seats being contested, Labor holds about 2,500, the Tories 1,500 and centrists or independents the rest. Labor runs 97 of the 201 local councils, the Conservatives 60 and the centrist Social and Liberal Democratic Party 18. In the others, no party has overall control. The economy plays a big role in the election. Inflation is nearly 9 percent and interest rates at 15 percent have sent home loans soaring. A computer forecast based on a Market Opinion and Research International sounding for London's pro-Thatcher Sunday Times showed Labor on course to wrest control of 24 local councils, including nine from the Tories. The poll of a sample of 1,887 voters gave Labor 53 percent support, the Conservatives 31 percent and the fading centrists 6 percent. A poll for The Independent on Sunday showed Labor on 51 percent, compared to the Tories' 37 and 7 percent for the centrists. As the bad news piled up, Thatcher aides hinted this week the poll tax may be amended. ``The poll tax will never be fair,'' commented Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock. ``It cannot be amended. It must be got rid of even if it means the prime minister going down with her own flagship.'' Critics call the tax inherently unfair because the country's richest man pays the same as his gardener. Under the old local tax system, only the country's 17 million homeowners paid a property tax. The new tax is levied against every adult _ some 38 million people, with rebates for the 9.5 million poorest. Like the property taxes, the new tax is supposed to raise nearly $10 billion to pay a portion of the cost of local services including education, the police, garbage collection and subsidized housing.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Committee Sets Hearings For Durenberger
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Ethics Committee announced today it will hold two weeks of public hearings next month to determine whether Sen. Dave Durenberger, R-Minn., violated Senate rules and federal law in his financial dealings. The committee decided in February that there was ``substantial credible evidence'' of such violations by Durenberger.. It voted Wednesday to begin trial-like public hearings on the matter June 12, the committee said in a press release today. In the meantime, the panel will continue investigating Senate reimbursement Durenberger received for stays in a condominium he partly owned, according to the three-paragraph release. ``We have received the ethics committee's release and look forward to a final resolution of the issues before the committee, including those involving the condominium,'' Durenberger's administrative assistant, Bert McKasy, said in a statement. ``We share with the committee an interest in getting these matters resolved in a timely fashion.'' Durenberger's press secretary, Lois West, said the hearing date amounted to a deadline for settling the case. She said attorneys for the senator had been talking to the committee about ``how to resolve the issues and how to come to closure.'' Most of the allegations involve a $100,000 deal under which Durenberger made speeches and accepted fees to promote two books he wrote. The committee said Durenberger may have: _ Violated outside income limits by accepting payments for speeches in 1985 and 1986. Durenberger made numerous appearances during that time which he characterized as book promotion speeches for his publisher, Piranha Press Inc. of Minneapolis. _ Failed to report on his financial disclosure forms for 1985 and 1986 ``the acceptance of reimbursement'' for travel undertaken in connection with the book-publishing deal. _ Violated a rule by converting a campaign contribution to personal use, and violated federal election law by failing to report and deposit the contribution, which he transferred to his publisher. The check of $5,000 was made out to ``Durenberger for U.S. Senate.'' _ Violated federal law and a Senate Rules Committee regulation prohibiting the commercial use of Senate space. The committee said he was paid an honorarium or other fee for six appearances in Senate-controlled areas. _ Broke the Senate's gift rule when he accepted limousine service in the Boston area during 1985 and 1986, in connection with personal travel to Concord, Mass. Durenberger made a number of trips to the Boston area in which he combined trips to a marriage counselor with official appearances. The committee will decide whether to recommend disciplinary action to the full Senate. The possible punishments range from a reprimand to expulsion.

DOC.HEAD: London's Number Is Up
DOC.TEXT: If you need to check the latest program at London's Royal Opera House or just want to natter a bit with cousin George, your fingers will have to do a little more walking beginning Sunday. U.S. callers must add a ``7'' or an ``8'' to the string of numbers it takes to complete such trans-Atlantic calls. That means a call or fax to the American Embassy in London will require dialing 011 (the international code) 44 (United Kingdom country code) 71 or 81 (the new London area codes), plus the seven-digit number. A call to the embassy would look like this: 011-44-71-499-9000. Previously, U.S. callers dialed 011-44-1-499-9000. British Telecom says the 71 area code will be assigned to inner London, including Trafalgar Square and the financial district, while the 81 area code will be used for numbers in outer London such as Heathrow and Wimbley. If you're in London, you'll have to dial either 071 or 081 if you call from one area code to another. British Telecom said the change will double to 10 million London's supply of phone numbers. Without the new area codes, the number pool would have been exhausted within the year. The United Kingdom is the most frequently called overseas destination from the United States, with 71.3 million calls in 1988 _ or 195,433 calls per day, the Federal Communication Commission said. West Germany was second with 40 million calls, followed by Japan with 32.6 million. The demand for additional numbers is due to increased use of fax machines, London's growing role as a communications center and the fact that each extension at a business is given a direct-dial number, British Telecom said.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Rather than sit home on prom night or settle for some geek she didn't even like, Twyla Blankenship of Thorne Bay, Alaska, found a date 1,000 miles away. One of six graduates in the Class of '90 in her village of 450 residents, she advertised through her advanced English class, using a satellite educational network that links students in 30 school systems nationwide. She said she wanted a date with a sense of humor who also looked good in a tuxedo. Out of several responses, she picked Dustin Wambeke, a senior and football star in Freeman, about 15 miles southeast of Spokane. ``The funny thing was that all this started out as a joke,'' she said. ``Now that it's going to happen, well, I'm getting kind of nervous.'' Blankenship has spent $300 on a round-trip ticket for Wambeke, who on Friday will drive to Seattle, fly by jet to Ketchikan, then take a 25-minute ride by float plane to Thorne Bay on the southeastern coast of Prince of Wales Island. ``This is out of my own money, too,'' she said. ``I may have to starve at college, but this is something I wanted to do.'' ``I guess I'm kind of adventurous,'' Wambeke said. ``I'm looking at this as an excellent opportunity to meet a nice person and see another part of the country.'' What made the date possible was ``School in the Sky,'' an educational program established four years ago in Spokane. It uses a satellite telecommunications to beam advanced course work to students in remote schools. The courses, broadcast Mondays through Thursdays, include college-level Japanese, Spanish, calculus and English. Homework is sent by mail or fax to Spokane. ``Kids from small schools tend to think that they're from the smallest and hickiest places on Earth,'' said Penny Cooper, who teaches advanced English on the network. ``This gives them a chance to talk with others from small towns and discover that maybe they're not so bad off after all.'' Said Thorn Bay School Principal Mike Walker: ``Little did we know that when we agreed to offer the satellite courses for kids that it could be used as a dating service.''

Students who needed $800 to finance a trip to a national science contest couldn't get the money from the Lafayette Parish School Board. But passing the hat at the meeting netted $500. The remaining $300 was pledged Thursday morning, letting Edgar Martin Middle School meet its deadline for the National Science Olympiad in Clarion, Pa., said Assistant Principal Cindy Bobbitt. The school won the state competition last weekend, and the deadline for notifying the national competition organizers whether they were going was Tuesday. ``They extended it two days for us to raise the money and let them know. ... We made it under the wire,'' Bobbitt said. She said businesses and residents had donated $6,200 since the Lafayette newspaper published an article Tuesday about the deadline, but students needed $7,000 to let organizers know they would compete. The 15-student team, wearing medals won in New Orleans, went to Wednesday night's board meeting to ask for help. Board members gave them a standing ovation, but balked at chipping in $800. A proposal to give the students $300 also was rejected. An argument among board members ended when one member noted that board policy forbids giving student groups money to pay for trips. A proposal to lend the money was shouted down. Finally, a teacher in the audience got up and passed the hat, bringing in $500.

DOC.HEAD: Striker Commits Suicide; Government Warns Against Labor Unrest
DOC.TEXT: A labor activist set himself on fire and leaped to his death from an auto parts plant Thursday, becoming the first fatality in the wave of labor unrest that has swept across South Korea in the past week. The government issued a new warning against violent labor protests, which have paralyzed vital export industries. Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon said South Korea's slumping economy was at stake. ``The government is facing the worst crisis since the inauguration'' of President Roh Tae-woo in 1988, Kang said. Roh's inauguration followed months of violent protests against his authoritarian predecessor. Government officials are alarmed by mounting public discontent with the Roh administration, whose popularity hit an all-time low of 12 percent in a recent public poll conducted by the ruling Democratic Liberal Party. Kim Young-il, 28, doused himself with paint thinner, set it ablaze and jumped from the roof of a two-story building at his plant in the southern industrial town of Changwon. Kim, a union activist at the Tongil Industry Co., died of burns and head injuries at a hospital two hours later. News reports said Kim left two letters complaining of a hard life and protesting alleged police surveillance of his labor activity. ``Why is my life so hard, Mother?'' reports quoted Kim as saying in a letter addressed to his family. In a letter addressed to his company, owned by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, founder of the Unification Church, Kim reportedly wrote: ``I want to fight against Tongil managers and their capitalists, Sun Myung Moon and Moon Sung-kun.'' Moon Sung-kun, a son of the unification minister, is reported to be directly involved in the company's operation. The company supplies axles and other auto parts for the Hyundai Motor Co., the nation's largest auto maker, where workers are on strike. Police said they were investigating the authenticity of the letters because in one of them, Kim described his father, who died in 1986, as being alive at his hometown. Government officials were worried Kim's death might escalate labor unrest. The unrest turned violent Saturday after police stormed a strike-bound shipyard in Ulsan, an industrial port about 200 miles southeast of Seoul. Authorities said about 300 people, including 235 policemen, were injured in four days of ensuing street clashes in Ulsan and other cities. In 1987, the death of a shipyard worker sparked violent nationwide protests. Self-immolation and ritual suicide are forms of protest often used by South Korean radicals to dramatize their causes. The unrest eased considerably Wednesday, and there were no reports of fighting between workers and riot police. The labor union of the Hyundai Motor Co. voted Thursday to end a weeklong strike and reopen assembly lines Monday. At the strike-bound Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. shipyard in Ulsan, about 120 shipyard workers held out on top of a 240-foot crane for the sixth straight day Thursday. The workers, who climbed the crane during the police raid on their shipyard Saturday, threatened to take ``extreme action'' unless they were given food and water. Police spread nets and air mattresses around the base of the crane and had anti-terrorist teams and two helicopters standing by.

DOC.HEAD: 65 Pound Ovarian Tumor Removed
DOC.TEXT: A 65-pound tumor has been removed from the abdomen of a woman who was admitted to the hospital after suffering chest pains. Sandy Caron, 47, thinking she might be having a heart attack, asked her daughter to take her to the emergency room at St. Vincent's Medical Center last week. An electrocardiogram showed no problems and the pain subsided. ``But the doctor wouldn't let me go home,'' she said. ``He kept looking at my stomach and then my arms, then at my stomach and then my arms, then said, `I don't think your stomach should be that big.''' A CAT scan showed that Mrs. Caron had an ovarian tumor, said Dr. William J. Garoni Jr., her surgeon. After a 3{-hour operation April 25, Garoni removed the benign tumor. ``I've seen ovarian tumors that were 30 to 40 pounds. But in 28 years of doing surgery, I've never seen anything like this,'' the doctor said. The largest tumor recorded, according to the Guinness Book of World Records, weighed 328 pounds and was removed from a Texas woman in 1905. After Mrs. Caron's surgery, the 5-foot-6 Jacksonville woman weighed 205 pounds, Garoni said. ``I can see my feet. To lay in bed and see my feet is really neat,'' she said Wednesday from her hospital bed. Mrs. Caron said she had put on weight with each of her six pregnancies and had never been able to trim her abdomen, even following a diet in which she lost 75 pounds. ``I thought I was just fat,'' said Mrs. Caron, who will be released from the hospital this week.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Protesting Students Can Learn from His Wife
With AM-Bush Rdp
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday that protesting students may be right that his wife's recognition comes from his success, but declared ``these young women can have a lot to learn from Barbara Bush.'' ``She herself said, `Look, I know why I'm privileged to be able to serve in this visible fashion.' She's not trying to be something she's not. The American people love her because she's something she is and stands for something,'' Bush said at a news conference. Bush said he and the first lady do not object to the protest of Wellesley College students who oppose her as a June 1 graduation speaker on the grounds that her recognition is due to her marriage. The president said Mrs. Bush herself acknowledges her ability to serve in a number of areas ``stems from the fact that she's married to the president of the United States.'' ``But I think these young women can have a lot to learn from Barbara Bush and from her unselfishness and from her advocacy of literacy and being a good mother and a lot of other things,'' he said. Asked whether there is merit in the Wellesley students' argument that her accomplishments are related largely to being his wife, Bush drew groans from reporters when he quipped, ``I can't have an argument with that.'' But he said in a serious vein: ``She isn't concerned that 125 students feel that way and I think they'll learn a lot from her.'' A petition at the women's college said Mrs. Bush should not be honored at commencement because she ``has gained recognition through the achievements of her husband, which contradicts what we have been taught over our years at Wellesley.'' In an interview with a group of newspapers Wednesday, Mrs. Bush said, ``They're 21 years old, and they're looking at life from that perspective ... I don't disagree with what they're looking at.'' Mrs. Bush dropped out of Smith College in 1944 to marry Bush. But for a part-time job as a newlywed, Mrs. Bush has never had a salaried job, devoting her life instead to raising their five children and to community volunteerism. For many years she has been an outspoken proponent of literacy programs and as first lady has spoken out for such causes as the homeless and AIDS programs. ``They may change their minds a little bit,'' she said Wednesday of the students. ``I hope they won't opt not to have families, and I hope they won't opt not to be great parents. I don't care who you are, the best job you do in life is raise your children,'' Mrs. Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: `City of New Orleans' Train Derails In Mississippi
With PM-Indiana Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with more than 20 people taken to hospital; quote from scene, other detail. No pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: An Amtrak passenger train crashed into a truck this morning, derailing three engines and three cars and injuring the truck driver and at 21 other people, authorities said. Amtrak officials say the accident occurred about 9:30 a.m. when the train the ``City of New Orleans,'' en route from Chicago to New Orleans, struck a log truck at a railroad crossing just inside the Durant city limits. It was the second Amtrak crash in as many days. An incorrectly set switch sent a Chicago-to-Indianapolis train crashing into freight cars Wednesday night near Crawfordsville, Ind., and at least 26 people were injured. District Two Community Hospital in Durant reported at least 22 people were brought in from the scene of this morning's accident. A spokeswoman who did not give her name said that except for the truck driver, most of the people did not appear to be seriously injured. The truck driver, whose name was not immediately released, was transferred from the Durant hospital by helicopter to the University Medical Center in Jackson. He was in serious condition. ``It was a big jolt,'' said passenger Melissa Mitchell. ``Everybody woke up.'' She said she saw no one injured in her car, the second from the front. ``We got outside and saw that we were majorly off the track, but upright,'' she said. The driver of the truck was trapped in the the wreckage more than two hours after the accident. The log truck had left a nearby lumber yard shortly before the crash occurred. State Highway Patrolman L.C. Clark said three engines ran off the tracks and were lying on their sides next to the rails. Three passenger cars also derailed but remained upright. There was lumber all over the roadway and scattered up and down the rail line, Ms. Mitchell said. Amtrak officials could not immediately say how many passengers and crew were on the train but said it can carry up to 163 passengers and crew. Ms. Mitchell said it was fairly full. Fire trucks and ambulances were on the scene, Clark said. Durant is located about 45 miles north of Jackson in Holmes County.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves AZT for Children With AIDS
DOC.TEXT: AZT, the only drug that has extended the lives of adults with AIDS, has been approved as a treatment for children with the disease, the Food and Drug Administration said Thursday. New labeling outlines dosage recommendations for patients 3 months to 12 years old who have AIDS or show symptoms of advanced infection with the virus that causes it. ``The drug is now officially considered to be a standard therapy for children with AIDS,'' Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said in a statement. That, he said, should encourage insurance companies to make reimbursements for pediatric use of AZT. A total of 2,192 children have been diagnosed with AIDS and 1,182 have died, according to the Centers for Disease Control. The FDA has been under pressure to approve AZT for children, especially from parents of sick children for whom there has been virtually no other effective treatment. An advisory committee of outside experts voted 7-1 March 30 to recommend the pediatric labeling. While AZT has extended the lives of people with AIDS, it also has caused significant side effects. The drug can inhibit the production of red blood cells and may reduce white blood cell counts to the point where doses must be discontinued to avoid infections. The FDA said physicians could have prescribed AZT for children without formal approval, but were reluctant to do so because of concerns that side effects might be more severe in young patients. Clinical trials involving more than 200 children indicate the side effects are similar to those experienced by adults, the agency said. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is a contagious disease that attacks the body's immune system, rendering it incapable of resisting other diseases and infections. The virus most often is spread through close contact with blood, blood products or semen. As of March 31, AIDS had been diagnosed in 128,319 Americans, of whom 61 percent, or 78,341, have died since June 1, 1981, according to the CDC. No one is known to have recovered from AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: French Parliament Approves Bill Barring Racists From Public Office
DOC.TEXT: The National Assembly today approved a bill that would bar anyone who provokes racial hatred or violence from holding elected office and government jobs for five years. The legislation, aimed at the extreme-right National Front party, was passed by the Assembly 307-265 after an all-night debate and now goes to the Senate, where it can be revised before being returned to the lower house. It must be signed by President Francois Mitterand to become law. Jean-Marie Le Pen, the leader of the National Front, said the bill was ``without precedence in a Western democracy.'' Le Pen watched from the public gallery as the sole National Front deputy struggled without success to introduce 80 amendments to block or water down the measure. An alliance between the Socialist and Communist parties, which control a majority of seats in the Assembly, pushed the bill through, while most of the conservative opposition voted against it. The bill bans those found guilty by a court of racial discrimination or inciting racial hatred or violence from running for office, holding a government post or sitting on a jury for five years. The bill also makes it a misdemeanor to deny the existence of crimes against humanity committed by the Nazis during World War II. Le Pen won global notoriety in 1987 by terming the deaths of 6 million Jews in the World War II death camps ``a detail of history.'' ``Because we are all democrats, Le Pen has never been denied his freedom of expression,'' Prime Minister Michel Rocard said before opening the debate. ``But for the same reason, we can't accept that he can hold out these racist and anti-Semitic proposals without penalty.'' The proposal also requires that magazines, newspapers and broadcasting outlets provide right-of-reply space to victims of racially defamatory stories. Conservative deputies argued that the measure unnecessarily tampered with an 1881 law guaranteeing freedom of the press and accused the Communists of opportunism. At a news conference before the debate, Le Pen said the law violated democratic traditions. ``The French Parliament is being called on to institute a new penalty _ the civil and political death of citizens guilty of opposing immigration and defending the French identity,'' he said. The bill's approval comes after a government commission in March said that racism, particularly against North African immigrants, is spreading in France. Le Pen, a former paratrooper, founded the National Front in 1972. It has built its following by opposing immigration, the country's most explosive social issue. Le Pen advocates expelling the 3.4 million Moslem immigrants living in France. The Front's support is strongest among white voters in areas where there are large numbers of North African and black immigrants. The party once held 35 seats in the Assembly and captured 14 percent of the vote in the 1988 presidential elections. It lost most of its seats due to electoral reforms.

DOC.HEAD: `A Chorus Line' on the Auction Block
DOC.TEXT: One last time, fans and performers showed up at the Shubert Theater out of their love for ``A Chorus Line.'' This time, it was to take away mementoes from the longest-running show in Broadway history. After Saturday's performance _ the 6,137th and last for the show _ the set of ``A Chorus Line'' was struck, priced and put up for sale. The theater became the site of a tag sale and auction Wednesday, a cornucopia of 14 years worth of props, costumes and memorabilia. The stage itself was auctioned off _ a 12-inch by 24-inch chunk was priced at $200. Eleanor Reissa, whose husband, Allen Herman, was the show's original drummer, was floored by her purchase. ``It's like the Berlin Wall,'' she said. ``It will be worth something someday.''

DOC.HEAD: Mother Teresa to Set Up Mission in Romania
DOC.TEXT: Mother Teresa, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979 for her care of the derelict in India, said Thursday she will open a mission in Bucharest. The 79-year-old missionary, who arrived Monday from Rome accompanied by four other nuns, told reporters she came to Romania ``to spread tender, loving care.'' The house of the Sisters of Charity will be established in Bucharest under the supervision of Roman Catholic Archbishop Ioan Robu, Mother Teresa said. Mother Teresa said she felt much better after heart surgery last fall ``because the whole world prayed for me.'' She said she planned to visit several orphanages during her stay. Orphans, like disabled people, were neglected under the 24-year tenure of Romania's former Communist dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu. He was overthrown and executed in December.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He Sometimes Worries About Soviet Military Takeover
With AM-Bush Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday that he sometimes worries about the possibility of a military takeover in the Soviet Union that would unseat Mikhail Gorbachev and set back the East Bloc's stride toward freedom. He saluted Gorbachev as ``the architect of perestroika'' and for exercising ``great restraint'' as Poland, East Germany and other Warsaw Pact countries shifted toward democracy. However, he said at a news conference, ``our foreign policy is not based on just Mr. Gorbachev.'' Bush denied he was withholding support for Lithuanian independence because of a desire to see Gorbachev and his reforms succeed. ``I salute the man for what he has done. I think he's under extraordinary pressure at home, particularly on the economy,'' Bush said. ``I do, from time to time, worry about a takeover that will set back the whole process.'' The president said reports that Gorbachev was under pressure from his military to backpedal from possible arms concessions on long-range nuclear missiles and submarine-launched cruise missiles were ``a matter of some concern.'' Bush announced he was canceling a planned modernization of short-range Lance nuclear missiles aimed at the Warsaw Pact from Western Europe and scrapping plans to modernize U.S. nuclear artillery shells in Europe. ``I'm not doing these things ... just to put at ease the Soviet military,'' he said. ``But I must tell you, I sometimes do worry about the military resurgence of some kind inside the Soviet Union.'' One reporter asked about a report that Gorbachev was close to being overthrown Feb. 25 when large demonstrations were staged in Moscow. ``I was not advised of that by the intelligence community,'' Bush said. On the Lithuanian secession crisis, Bush said, ``we can't place this on a you-have-to-choose-between-Gorbachev-or-Landsbergis,'' referring to the Baltic republic's president, Vytautas Landsbergis. ``I've expressed my keen interest in seeing perestroika suceed. Gorbachev is the architect of perestroika,'' Bush said. ``Gorbachev conducted the affairs of the Soviet Union with great restraint as Poland and Czechoslovakia and (East Germany) and other countries achieved their independence. ``But you can't build a foreign policy of a country on the presence of an individual. You can build it on ideas.'' On a lighter note, Bush said Gorbachev shouldn't be too concerned about the jeers he heard at Tuesday's May Day parade in Red Square. ``He ought to come join some of the parades I go to around here,'' Bush said. ``Look, that's the fruits of democracy. He's just learning.''

DOC.HEAD: ANC, Government Negotiators Express Optimism About Talks
LaserPhoto CPN2
DOC.TEXT: Optimistic government and African National Congress leaders said Thursday they were making progress in clearing the way for full-scale negotiations on ending white-minority rule. The two sides issued a joint communique after a second day of talks and said ``both leaders expressed satisfaction with the progress achieved thus far'' and would ``continue tomorrow to work toward bridging ... differences.'' The delegations, led by President F.W. de Klerk and ANC Deputy President Nelson Mandela, met amid tight security at a suburban estate. They are the first formal talks between the government and ANC since the black nationalist group was founded 78 years ago. The first day of talks Wednesday concentrated on a general discussion of the issues each side regards as obstacles, the communique said. Thursday's meeting ``was devoted to a wider-ranging discussion and penetrating analysis of these specific issues in an attempt to identify the differences more clearly in the hope that proposals could emerge on how to bridge these differences,'' said the communique. The talks were scheduled to end Friday evening. But the Argus newspaper in Cape Town said they were likely to be continued at a later date because agreement probably would not be reached on all issues by Friday. The delegations are seeking to remove obstacles to formal negotiations on a new constitution that would give the country's black majority a voice in national affairs. Thabo Mbeki, a senior member of the ANC delegation, expressed optimism when he spoke to reporters during a lunch break Thursday. ``When all of us departed (Wednesday's talks), the general feeling was that not only is movement forward necessary, but that it is possible,'' said Mbeki. ``We had people sitting in that room who are perfectly reasonable and we are all committed to finding a solution,'' he said. Sources of the governing National Party, who refused to be identified, said the government also was confident the talks would lead to full-scale negotiations on changing the constitution. As a precondition to those talks, the ANC is demanding the government end a nearly 4-year-old state of emergency, release all political prisoners, and allow anti-government activists to return from exile. The government has countered with demands that the ANC renounce its ``armed struggle'' and help stop a wave of violence that has claimed hundreds of lives in recent months. In an outline of the ANC's position carried by newspapers Thursday, ANC spokesman Patrick Lekota stressed that the group, which was legalized by de Klerk in February, was making every effort to clear the way for constitutional negotiations. He said the majority of South Africans were looking to the talks to find a peaceful solution to the country's racial divisions. ``While holding grimly to our views, we shall do everything short of selling out to help the government remove the obstacles to a political settlement,'' he wrote. Both the ANC and government have come under fire for the talks. Radical black groups that say only force can end apartheid are angry at the ANC for talking to the government, and white extremist groups oppose the government meeting with blacks. The National Party stressed the government was negotiating from a position of strength. The government, party officials said, would insist on a wide range of guarantees to safeguard the interests of the country's 5 million whites and other minorities. These guarantees would include a parliamentary chamber where whites would have a legislative veto, and retention of Afrikaans as an official language, the party officials said. The ANC has demanded a one-person, one-vote democratic system with no special rights for any racial group. It also wants a redistribution of wealth to aid millions of impoverished blacks.

DOC.HEAD: 26 Hurt in Indiana Train Crash; Mississippi Derailment Also Reported
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `This morning...'; to UPDATE injury total in Mississippi crash. SUBS 10th graf, `Five passengers...', with 2 grafs to CORRECT that those admitted to hospital were four passengers and two crew, sted five and one, and to UPDATE with two people released today. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `It felt...'. SUBS penultimate graf to update situation in Mississippi.
DOC.TEXT: A misplaced switch threw an Amtrak train into a row of freight cars on a siding, injuring at least 26 people, police said today. The locomotive and two cars on a run from Chicago to Indianapolis with 30 to 35 people aboard derailed Wednesday night after striking five freight cars parked on an outside track 40 miles from Indianapolis, said Lt. Harvey Martin. This morning, another Amtrak train out of Chicago stuck a truck in Mississippi, derailing three engines and three cars. The truck driver was seriously injured and more than 30 passengers and crew suffered minor injuries. ``Nobody screamed. Most people just hit the seat in front of them,'' said Mary Vogt, a passenger on the Indianapolis-bound train from Bloomington. ``I knew something had happened but I didn't know what.'' The derailed cars remained upright. ``It didn't look like there was an incredible amount of damage,'' said state Trooper Mark Cornell. Martin blamed the accident on human error, saying a switch that should have been closed was open, diverting the train from its proper track. Amtrak officials said they had no word on what caused the crash. The train derailed in an industrial sector 2{ miles from the Crawfordville depot. It had made a stop there and was on its final leg to Indianapolis. ``It's a good thing it wasn't going faster than it was,'' said Dr. Richard Miller, Culver Union Hospital emergency room director. ``The engineer said it was going about 20 to 30 when he could have been going 60.'' The train's engineer, his assistant and four passengers were admitted to the hospital with injuries ranging from a concussion to severe back pain, a spokesman said. Two of the passengers were released from the hospital today; the four remaining patients were listed in stable condition. An additional 20 to 25 people were treated and released and were bused this morning to Indianapolis, authorities said. ``It felt like somebody hit my head with a hammer,'' said passenger Donald Pope, 60, of New Paris, Ohio, who suffered a cut above his eye. Crawfordsville Police Chief Dave Johnson said today the switch that allowed the freight cars to move off the main track apparently wasn't thrown back before the passenger train came through. ``It's a switch that has to be thrown by hand,'' he said. The train's crew underwent routine drug tests after the accident, but results will not be available for a few days, Johnson said. The train was moved today from the siding to Amtrak's shop in Beech Grove, leaving the track's main line clear, said Amtrak spokeswoman Deborah Hare in Chicago. The accident caused $200,000 damage to Amtrak's cars. In the Mississippi crash, the southbound ``City of New Orleans'' from Chicago to New Orleans slammed into a log truck in the town of Durant, 45 miles north of Jackson, this morning. Twenty-five people were taken to a hospital, including the truck driver who was trapped in the wreckage for two hours, and about 10 others were treated for minor injuries at the scene. Three engines derailed and toppled over and three cars left the track but remained upright, said State Highway Patrolman L.C. Clark.

DOC.HEAD: NFL Considers Suing Over Capital's Planned Sports Lottery
DOC.TEXT: The National Football League criticized the District of Columbia on Thursday for a planned lottery that would allow residents to bet on professional teams and said it will consider suing the city. NFL spokesman Joe Browne said the league opposes gambling ``legalized or otherwise'' and would review the lottery and explore its options, including litigation. ``With increased betting on sports, the nature of fans would change and they would become more concerned about winning bets than seeing their team win a game,'' said Browne. The city's Lottery and Charitable Games Control Board tentatively approved the plan Wednesday night. It would have to be approved by city lawyers and passed again by the lottery board, following a 30-day comment period, before it could be started. Although a similar sports lottery is under suit in Oregon, the district's would be the first in the nation to allow wagering by residents of an area on their region's home teams. The NFL say such legalized gambling would make it easier to fix games, unlawfully makes money from their private enterprise and could turn fans against their home teams. Browne said, for example, Washington Redskins fans may jeer the football team as it protects a three-point lead in a game in which the team is favored by four points. ``We don't want to create a situation where ... people are more concerned about how much a team wins by rather than if they win,'' he said. ``Our players are straight and they play hard,'' said Abe Pollin, owner of hockey's Washington Capitals and basketball's Washington Bullets. ``But what would happen if fans started booing them because even though they were playing well, they didn't cover a point spread? The whole thing is very negative.'' Under the district's proposed game, a bettor would wager on a minimum of four games on each betting card. The bettor could choose up to 14 games on each of four cards. Point spreads would be used, just as in illegal gambling. Prizes would range from $1 to $4,000, depending on the number of selections and correct picks. The Redskins, Capitals, Bullets and nearby Baltimore Orioles would be included in the district's planned betting. The National Basketball Association is suing the ports betting lottery in Oregon, which allows wagering on professional football and basketball games. Oregon has no professional football team and its NBA franchise _ the Portland Trailblazers _ are exempt from the game. The NFL lost a suit to block a similar game in Delaware in the 1970s. The state later dropped the game due to a lack of interest. Pollin said he would talk with NBA Commissioner David Stern and National Hockey League President John Ziegler about to prevent the game from getting started. ``I think it's absolutely horrible and it sends a terrible, terrible signal to people involved in sports,'' said Pollin. ``The idea of that money could be legally wagered on professional sports is a terrible thing.'' ``We're trying to teach our young people to lead very straight lives and then this sort of thing comes along,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: American Marching Band Bringing Sousa Style to Soviet Victory Day Parade
DOC.TEXT: Dot Hill's American Legion marching band has the kind of John Philip Sousa style that would make any American hometown proud. But planning their musical peace tour of the Soviet Union took something more: perseverance. ``And a very special woman,'' said the Rev. Nicholas Ciccone, a Roman Catholic priest who plays the cymbals. Dorothy Hill, the 74-year-old bandleader everyone calls Dot, is that woman. She's the heart of the 70-member, all-male band and the hustle behind its 10-day trip to the Soviet Union, where they've been invited to march in Moscow's annual Victory Day parade. The May 9 parade commorates the Soviet victory over Nazi Germany. The band leaves Friday for Moscow and will go to Leningrad before returning home May 12. ``The fact that the Soviets were willing to permit us to come on such an important day says to me they're ready for peace,'' said Mrs. Hill. She has been told by Soviet officials that her band will be the first American band to march in the parade through Red Square. ``And when we do we'll be playing `God Bless America' and singing `PEACE,' in capital letters,'' she said. ``I've seen three wars in my lifetime and I just don't want another generation going through it,'' said Mrs. Hill, a World War II Coast Guard veteran. ``I wanted to make a peace move now.'' Since everyone loves a parade, she reasoned, how better to promote peace than through music? It took nearly three years, but Mrs. Hill got her wish. She says officials at the Soviet Peace Committee, which oversees national parades, were a bit skeptical when she contacted them. ``They'd ask: `You government?' and I'd say `No. I'm just Dot from the Waltham band.'' She called out of the blue, having dialed up operator after operator before finding one that spoke enough English to help her find out how to reach the people who could help her pull off the mission. The Peace Committee officials ``kept telling me they were trying to get rid of the image of tanks and power and come up with a happy image,'' Mrs. Hill said at the band's final rehearsal this week, which drew about 150 boosters. ``They kept reminding me that our bands are happy bands,'' she said. The Joseph P. Hill American Legion Band, named for Mrs. Hill's late husband, has that big, bold, brassy sound you want to hear on the Fourth of July. Ranging from ages 17 to 82, the band members are fathers and sons, doctors and lawyers, engineers, cooks and landscapers. They are veterans of wars in Europe, Japan, Korea and Vietnam. ``But we've all got Dot, and she's got the perseverance and faith,'' said Ciccone, who everyone in this working-class Boston suburb knows as Father Nick. Band members who have watched reform roll through the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe said the time was right for their peace move. ``This is our chance to show our two governments that people are the same everywhere,'' said Brian Mulcahy, who is as excited about the trip to Moscow as he was during a 1984 St. Patrick's Day march in his ancestral Ireland. Even John Dow, the resident curmudgeon who is bringing his wheelchair and alto horn to Moscow, let a little smile slip. ``I don't think it's going to change the world,'' the feisty septuagenarian said. ``But it can't hurt to see the sights and make a few friends.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Invites Congressional Leaders for Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday that he has invited congressional leaders to weekend talks to discuss how to avoid a looming political standoff over the 1991 federal budget. Congress' two top Democrats showed little enthusiasm for the Sunday session, while the reactions of other lawmakers ranged from enthusiasm to rejection. ``We've got to move forward, and I've got to find a way to do that,'' Bush said of the budget process, which has crept slowly until recently. Bush extended the invitations during a week in which the House and the Senate Budget Committee have approved separate, Democratic-written budgets that would slash the president's defense programs by about $10 billion. His own budget, proposed in January, has not even been put to a vote on Capitol Hill. ``Now there seems to be some action, so it seemed to me to be a good time to sit down and talk process and see where we go now,'' Bush said at a news conference. Congress has long since missed the April 15 deadline the law sets for completion of next year's budget. The 1991 fiscal year begins Oct. 1. But the president said the talks would not address ``any substance'' and that bargaining would not take place. ``We're not into a negotiation,'' said Bush. ``We're talking process.'' Lawmakers and congressional aides speculated that Sunday's session would focus on the basic question of whether serious budget negotiations could proceed in the future. ``The first step is whether further discussions can be initiated, and whether or not they can be fruitful,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. The invitation follows administration warnings that the economy's poor performance in past months means more budget-cutting will be needed next year. The administration now predicts $45 billion to $57 billion in savings will have to be found in the 1991 budget. Bush's budget said in January that $37 billion in cuts would be needed. The Gramm-Rudman law requires next year's deficit to not surpass $64 billion. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., would say little about what the meeting might accomplish. ``There's obviously going to be a willingness to hear what the president has to say,'' he said. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, was even more tight-lipped, declining to even acknowledge that he has been invited to the session. The administration and congressional Republicans have been saying for months that only negotiations between the White House and Congress will truly reduce the deficit next year. But Democrats have been split. Mitchell and Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., have been cool toward the idea of talks. Foley and Panetta have said budget talks with the administration will be necessary. Panetta called the Sunday meeting ``the beginning of a process of discussions with the White House.'' But he said Bush must agree to negotiate on possible tax increases for talks to succeed. Bush promised during his presidential campaign to not raise taxes, but in recent months administration officials have said they are willing to discuss all options for reducing the deficit. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, said he thought the talks are ``a great idea.'' ``I think they could give us more direction about what the president wants to do about the deficit,'' he said. Others, however, expressed disdain for the idea. Many members of Congress have resented the budget negotiations of the past few years, arguing that they end up freezing most lawmakers out of the fiscal process. ``It eliminates many of the cumbersome, clumsy aspects of democracy and replaces them with the efficiency of an edict,'' said Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., a member of the House Budget Committee. ``King George III would have loved it.''

DOC.HEAD: Audit Says VA Failing to Collect Insurance Money
DOC.TEXT: The Veterans Affairs Department lost as much as $392 million in one year by failing to collect from private insurance companies for health care, according to the General Accounting Office. The report, released this week by the congressional auditing agency, says the VA missed collecting from $55 million to $392 million in so-called third party reimbursements in 1988. The department spends about $10 billion a year on health care for veterans, including those with private insurance. Congress in 1986 gave the government the right to collect from private insurers as a means of cutting the deficit. The report did note, however, collections have greatly exceeded the costs of collecting the money. In the 1988 fiscal year, the report said, the VA spent $8 million to collect about $100 million from insurers. The report said VA centers could increase collections significantly if they used better methods to identify insured veterans and bill insurers, and committed more people and time to collections. ``Even when centers identified insured veterans, they did not always bill insurers,'' the report said, citing inadequate controls and manual billing systems. The report said many veterans are ``confused or afraid that disclosures about insurance would jeopardize their admittance to the centers.'' The veterans department operates 172 hospitals, 233 outpatient clinics and 119 nursing homes. The hospitals recorded 1.1 million admissions and 20 million outpatient visits. The report was based on collections at six VA medical centers: Albany, N.Y.; Bay Pines, Fla.; Martinsburg, W.Va.; Minneapolis; Seattle; and West Los Angeles, Calif. The report was requested by Sen. Frank H. Murkowski, R-Ala., the ranking minority member on the Senate Veterans Affairs Committee. The VA, in its response, acknowledged problems and said it was taking a number of steps to address them. In its 1991 budget proposal, the department said it would introduce legislation to improve and expand its third-party collection activities.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Scraps Plans for Newer, Bigger Nuclear Weapons in Europe
DOC.TEXT: President Bush scrapped plans Thursday for newer and more powerful battlefield nuclear weapons in Europe and called for a NATO summit to rewrite political and military strategy for ``a new era in history.'' ``As democracy comes to Eastern Europe and Soviet troops return home, there is less need for nuclear systems of the shortest range,'' Bush said. His decision, canceling modernization of the Lance missile, amounted to a recognition of political realities both in Europe and in Congress. West Germany, where most of the new weapons would be based, had fiercely opposed the deployment since the warheads would be targeted on their countrymen in East Germany. Congress, doubting that the new missiles would ever be installed, had balked at Bush's request for $112 million for modernization. Bush made his announcement at a wide-ranging news conference during which he also said ``I sometimes do worry'' that military hardliners in the Soviet Union might oust President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and try to reverse democratic reforms in Eastern Europe. It was Bush's most direct statement ever about Gorbachev's grip on power. Bush said Gorbachev is under ``extraordinary pressure'' at home because of unrest over Lithuania's drive for independence and the ailing Soviet economy. In a lighter moment, Bush defended his wife Barbara against complaints by Wellesley College students who oppose her as their graduation speaker. He said the students may be right in saying her recognition comes from his success, but declared ``these young women can have a lot to learn from Barbara Bush'' anyway. Bush welcomed statements from Lithuanian President Vytautis Landsbergis indicating a willingness to compromise with the Soviets. ``I think that is very, very positive andlet's hope it goes forward,'' Bush said. Later, he met with Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene at the White House. On other subjects: _ Responding to questions about the freeing of two American hostages in Lebanon, Bush said the United States could not claim credit for their release. ``There were no behind-the-scenes negotiations that will come out that show that we pulled this off,'' said Bush, who previously has applauded Syria and Iran for their roles. The president said he would be willing to make any gesture of appreciation to Iran that would not be viewed as negotiating for the release of hostages. _ Bush announced he had invited top congressional leaders to a meeting Sunday in an effort to ``move forward'' the budget process. The full House and the Senate Budget Committee have passed Democratic budget versions that cut defense spending far more than Bush sought. ``I'm not going to sit here and do nothing,'' Bush said. But he added, ``We're not into a negotiation. We're talking process.'' _ He said he was not trying to oust the man who oversees the nation's beleaguered savings and loan industry, L. William Seidman, chief of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. He said Seidman did not want to complete his term, and had urged Bush to replace him with William Taylor, acting director of the Resolution Trust Corp. As for weapons in Europe, the cancellation of modernization plans has been in the works for months following the collapse of the Berlin Wall and the sweep of democracy throughout Eastern Europe. ``The revolutionary changes transforming Europe are moving us from the postwar era to a new era in history beyond containment'' of Warsaw Pact forces, Bush said. He said the 16-member NATO alliance should meet in late June or early July ``to launch a wide-ranging NATO strategy review for the transformed Europe of the 1990s.'' The president is to meet with Gorbachev in Washington May 30-June 3. Specifically, Bush announced he was dropping plans to deploy a more powerful short-range Lance missile to replace launchers for 700 aging warheads, based mostly in West Germany. All of the new weapons would have been targeted on East Germany, which is moving toward a swift merger with West Germany. The new missiles would have had a range of about 250 miles, compared with about 75 miles for the existing Lance. Bush also said he was canceling further modernization of U.S. nuclear artillery shells in Europe. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services Committee, called Bush's announcement a ``very important step ... and I agree with him.'' Echoing those comments, Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said, ``The primary target of weapons of this range was East Germany, now about to be part of a united Germany, and it had become intolerable to maintain them for their original purpose or to pursue plans for costly and pointless replacements.''

DOC.HEAD: The Lithuanian Flag _ But No Umbrella _ Is Unfurled
With AM-US-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: It drizzled when Kazimiera Prunskiene came to visit President Bush on Thursday, but she unfurled no umbrella _ a symbol since Munich of shame and appeasement. Her leader back home had already invoked that imagery. Last week, after Bush backed away from plans to impose economic sanctions on the Soviet Union for its failure to respect Lithuania's secession, Vytautas Landsbergis, president of the break-away Baltic republic, said the decision amounted to appeasement. Landsbergis said it reminded him of the 1938 meeting in Munich at which Neville Chamberlain, the British prime minister famous for carrying a black umbrella, met with Adolph Hitler and agreed to let Hitler take over Czechoslovkia in the interest of ``peace in our time.'' Munich has been a symbol of sellout ever since; Munich and umbrellas. The prime minister of the besieged, newly declared republic of Lithuania made it clear, wherever she went, that she had come to put Mikhail Gorbachev on the spot, not George Bush. Mrs. Prunskiene said she had no intention of telling a big power like America how to conduct its affairs. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., called her statement ``artful.'' She sat at a table covered in red felt reading a handwritten statement in a firm voice to the U.S. Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a human rights watchdog panel of members of Congress and low-level administration officials. Her message: Gorbachev would be strengthened by the achievement of a democratic Lithuania. It would help him ``overcome the reactionary forces which oppose not only independence for the Baltic states'' but his reforms as well. ``You do not have to choose between Lithuania and Gorbachev,'' she said. But there was iron in her message, too. ``Even the world's darling,'' she said of Gorbachev, ``does not have the monopolistic right to decide the fate of other nations.'' Lithuania, she said, would be free with his consent, or without it; with his economic embargo, or without it. She spoke facing the American flag and the green, gold and red stripes of the old Lithuanian flag. An American woman of Lithuanian extraction, sensing the need, had telephoned the commission and volunteered to provide the flag. It had not been unfurled in official halls in Washington in some time. Mrs. Prunskiene made the most of a visit to Washington and with Bush that the White House stressed was private and unofficial. She went on early morning television. She breakfasted with the House Foreign Affairs Committee and lunched with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. She scheduled a meeting with the editors of The Washington Post and the leaders of the conservative Heritage Foundation and dinner with a group of newspaper columnists. Before leaving Capitol Hill for her meeting with Bush, she stepped onto the floor of the Senate, which suspended business and applauded her. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-S.C., took her by the hand and introduced her to seven Senate pages in their blue suits and white shirts. She shook their hands. An economist and teacher, she once had been a rising communist _ member of the USSR Supreme Soviet. In February, she quit the party. The next month, Lithuania declared itself free and she joined the secessionist government. It fell to a liberal Democrat, Rep. Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts, to disagree with Mrs. Prunskiene at the commission hearing and support the Bush policy of caution. His was the only dissent heard. Tight-lipped, he said much more than Lithuania was at stake. Gorbachev, he said, should not be punished for the sins of Stalin. He said under Gorbachev the Berlin Wall has fallen, thousands of Jews have left the Soviet Union, free governments have taken root in the old satellite nations. ``It ill behooves us to lecture you on the subject of independence,'' Markey told Mrs. Prunskiene. ``By the same token, it ill behooves Lithuania to declare its independence and then charge the West with appeasement and another Munich.''

DOC.HEAD: `Today' Ratings Slump Continues; All 3 Morning Shows Going on the Road
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITS to correct cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: NBC's slumping ``Today'' Show, trying to recover during the important May ratings ``sweeps,'' will go camping in Pennsylvania's Pocono Mountains on May 21-22. Co-hosts Bryant Gumbel and Deborah Norville, and weatherman Willard Scott will do the show from a campsite at the Delaware Water Gap National Recreational Area near Shawnee, Pa. NBC earlier announced that ``Today'' would broadcast from Boston on Monday and Tuesday, and from outdoor New York locations the rest of the week. ABC's top-rated ``Good Morning America'' plans to broadcast from England, Scotland and Ireland for the next two weeks, and ``CBS This Morning'' will originate next week from Europe, starting Monday in Florence, Italy. The ``Today'' camping announcement on Thursday came as the show, which two weeks ago week suffered its lowest ratings in seven years, got slightly lower ratings in the week ended April 27, according to A.C. Nielsen Co. audience estimates. ABC's ``Good Morning America'' won the morning ratings race for the 17th consecutive week, averaging a 4.3 rating. ``Today'' was again in second, averaging as 3.2 rating, one-tenth of a point lower than the previous week. ``CBS This Morning'' remained in third place with a 2.6 rating. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Mubarak Says Egypt Wants to Help Syria Make Peace With Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak said Thursday he wants to help end the feud between Syria and Iraq and persuade Syria's president to attend an Arab summit in the Iraqi capital. Mubarak also said President Hafez Assad of Syria was willing to meet with his main foe, PLO leader Yasser Arafat. Mubarak spoke to foreign reporters before his final meeting with Assad. It was the first trip to Syria by an Egyptian head of state in 12 years. In Baghdad, Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz said Iraq's president will invite Assad to attend the Arab summit. But Assad said in an interview with Egyptian journalists he was surprised that holding the summit in Baghdad appeared to be a foregone conclusion without more discussion among Arab leaders. Assad said the meeting should be held in a location that is not disputed, Egypt's Middle East News Agency reported. The feud between Syria and Iraq, one of the most bitter in the Arab world, has been partly responsible for delays in convening a summit to discuss Soviet Jewish emigration to Israel. ``We had a lot of discussion yesterday but still there are so many points which need efforts, not only from Egypt, but from all the friends in the whole region so as to narrow the gap between Syria and Iraq,'' Mubarak said. The Egyptian news agency quoted Assad as saying: ``President Mubarak assured us more than once about his concern about good relations between Syria and Iraq. But he and many other Arab brothers appreciate that the gap is still wide between the two countries and may need more time and effort. Maybe time will help things improve.'' Arab diplomatic sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Mubarak brought a ``paper'' to Damascus suggesting a meeting of the Syrian and Iraqi foreign ministers in Cairo. Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi foreign minister, said in Baghdad that Saddam would dispatch personal envoys with invitations to all the Arab leaders next week, even though no date has been fixed for the summit. A presidential envoy will visit Damascus to hand Assad the invitation, Aziz said. There were few other indications, however, that the gulf between Assad and Saddam was really narrowing. Their countries are ruled by rival wings of the Arab Baath Socialist Party. Assad supported Persian Iran in its eight-year war with Arab Iraq. Saddam provided weapons to Lebanon's Christian Gen. Michel Aoun in his failed ``war of liberation'' against Syria and its allies. Another major rift in the Arab world involves Assad and Arafat. Mubarak said the Syrian president was ready to meet the PLO leader. ``He has no good relations with Yasser Arafat, yet he will welcome Arafat if he comes here, he's not against that,'' Mubarak said. Assad and Arafat have been feuding for years. A major source of animosity is the Palestinian leader's recognition of Israel's right to exist. Syria is the only Arab state not to have recognized the independent Palestinian state announced at the Palestinian National Council in November 1988. Palestinian sources in Damascus have said previously that Arafat has set three conditions for traveling to Damascus: recognition of a Palestinian state, the release of thousands of pro-Arafat guerrillas in Syrian jails and a pledge not to interfere in Palestinian affairs. Assad also is the most formidable foe of the Jewish state and he has said he will build up his armed forces until they reach ``strategic parity'' with Israel. Syria's involvement in any peace process would be necessary for durable peace in the region. Asked whether he thought Assad would participate in peace efforts in concert with Egypt, Mubarak said: ``The crux of the whole problem is the Palestinian problem. If there is an active role for the Palestinians, President Hafez Assad ill never miss the train,'' Mubarak said. Cairo and Damascus resumed diplomatic ties in December after a 12-year break. Syria broke relations with Egypt shortly after then-Egyptian President Anwar Sadat visited Jerusalem in November 1977. Sixteen other Arab countries also broke relations to protest against Egypt's peace with Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Most Hospital Closings in Rural Communities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf to restore number of closings in five states.
DOC.TEXT: Fifty of the 88 hospitals that closed in 1988 were in rural communities, the government said Thursday. Texas had the most closings, 29, the Department of Health and Human Services said. Alabama was second, with seven. California, Illinois, Louisiana, Missouri and West Virginia had five each. In four of the communities that lost their only hospital, resident had to travel more than 30 miles for inpatient care: Cuba, N.M., 80 miles; Metaline Falls, Wash., and Kearny, Ariz., 50 miles; and Ekalaka, Mont., 36 miles. The report, by the department's inspector general, said that the reasons hospitals gave for closing were the same as in 1987, when 69 facilities closed. Those reasons included loss of revenue due to declining admissions; reduced insurance and government reimbursement rates; more uncompensated care for the indigent and the uninsured; and rising costs due to demands for new technology, more skilled personnel, repairs and renovation. Across the board, hospitals that shut their doors were significantly smaller and had lower occupancy rates than the national average, said Inspector General Richard P. Kusserow. On the plus side, the report said four new hospitals opened in 1988 and eight that had closed earlier reopened in 1988. In a related report, the American Hospital Association said fewer people were admitted to community hospitals in 1989 than in any year since 1973, while outpatient visits rose to a record 308 million. Total admissions in 1989 were 33.2 million, the association said. The average occupancy rate was 64.9 percent. The association said that as hospitals adapted to the outpatient-treatment trend, they eliminated 70,000 beds, 7.3 percent of their capacity, from 1983 through 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Endorses Bank Overseer to Replace Seidman as Bailout Boss
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday endorsed William Taylor, a low-key Federal Reserve veteran, to take over what many consider the toughest financial job in government _ boss of the savings and loan bailout. Bush told a news conference he is ``very high on'' Taylor, 50 years old and director of bank supervision for the Federal Reserve Board, to replace L. William Seidman as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp. The president said Seidman ``enthusiastically supports'' Taylor as his successor. Seidman ``suggested the name of Bill Taylor, who we're very high on, to take his responsibilities,'' Bush said. The FDIC manages deposit insurance funds for banks and S&Ls. The RTC conducts the administration's thrift cleanup. The president said newspaper reports earlier in the week that he had suggested Seidman leave were incorrect. ``It's his initiative,'' Bush said. ``I think Seidman has conducted himself with extraordinary grace and great ability.'' Neither Bush nor Seidman has said when the chairman will leave, but FDIC officials expect he'll go by late summer or early fall. That would allow time to prepare a transition and complete an ambitious program, announced last month, to close or sell 140 insolvent S&Ls by June 30. ``The transition will take place in a very friendly manner when I think it's the appropriate time,'' Seidman said in a telephone interview. He said he's backing Taylor because ``he's a very capable guy. He's familiar with the situation and I have a lot of confidence in him.'' Seidman, 69, had said for some time that he did not plan to stay until his term ends in October 1991. But he had not indicated his resignation was imminent. On Tuesday, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the administration would not resist Seidman's departure. Congressional Democrats said Bush should press Seidman to stay. Seidman had scored points, particularly among Democrats, for his bluntness in revealing the bailout's soaring cost estimates and for his willingness to take positions at odds with the administration. Administration officials, notably White House Chief of Staff John Sununu and Deputy Treasury Secretary John Robson, were irked by his independence. On the other hand, Taylor reportedly is well-regarded by Treasury officials for his low-key, out-of-the-limelight style. Since mid-February, he has been on leave from the Fed, serving as chief staff officer of a Treasury Department-led policy panel overseeing the RTC. Taylor has a reputation as a conservative regulator and was one of the most vigorous advocates of toughening capital standards in the thrift industry. He is not expected to match Seidman's talent for dealing with Congress and the public. ``I think Bill Taylor is going into one of the most difficult jobs in Washington,'' said Kenneth Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America. ``I think he's a very bright, able man, but no one can match Seidman's ties with the Hill and the press.'' Beyond the enormous task of directing the disposal of more than $300 billion in real estate, loans and other assets of failed S&Ls, Taylor will find himself at the center of a clash next year between the administration and Congress when the two sides try to come up with a way to fund a second installment of the bailout. He also should be an important player in next year's debate over the reform of federal deposit insurance and the expansion of commercial banking into securities underwriting and other financial services. Taylor did not immediately respond to a request for comment Thursday. Government sources, asking not to be named, said Taylor wants the FDIC-RTC chairmanship, considered the nation's pre-eminent bank regulatory post. The thrift office director serves under the Treasury secretary but the FDIC chairman, once appointed, serves independently and cannot be removed by the president.

DOC.HEAD: Children's Group Fights ``Infomercials'' for Kids
DOC.TEXT: A children's advocacy group asked federal regulators on Thursday to move against TV producers who violate stringent rules on advertising in kids' programs. Action for Children's Television, in a filing with the Federal Communications Commission, said it was prompted by a report that an upcoming show, ``Video Power,'' planned to splice ads into the program so seamlessly that kids may not know where the program ends and the ads begin.
