The Wall Street Journal reported on Monday that ``Video Power,'' a half-hour syndicated show, would be hosted by a 14-year-old named ``Johnny Arcade.'' Johnny, the Journal said, ``will rattle off `news' items, such as countdowns of top hits in video games. Sandwiched in the minute-long countdowns will be 10-second or 20-second commercials, without so much as a pause between the news and the commercial.'' A video-game maker, Acclaim Entertainment, has purchased 20 percent of the show's advertising time, the Journal said. Anthony Williams, an Acclaim executive, told the newspaper, ``Children change channels during commercials. For one thing, their concentration span is shorter than that of adults. ... This, we think, is a good way for both producer and advertiser to sidestep that problem.'' Attempts to reach Acclaim Entertainment or t of Congressional Budget Office forecasts and $65 billion below the administration estimate. However, the new law is still bringing in about as much money as predicted because the share paid by individuals has risen slightly because of higher than expected wages. Rosen said corporate income taxes accounted for 10.5 percent of all federal receipts last year. By 1995, he said, corporate receipts are expected to account for 11.4 percent of receipts. Even so, CBO Director Robert D. Reischauer said corporate taxes have failed to keep pace with economic growth. ``Corporate taxes measured 4 percent of gross national product in 1960; by 1986, the amount had declined to 1.5 percent,'' Reischauer said. CBO projects corporate receipts of $111 billion for 1991, which would be 1.9 percent of GNP.

DOC.HEAD: Britons Vote For Local Councils; Test For Thatcher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Early results expected by 7:30 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Britons voted Thursday for local councils in the first comprehensive opinion test since Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, now in deep trouble, won a third term in 1987. Voters turned out in relatively large numbers during the daylong ballot for 201 councils, spurred by a national controversy over an unpopular new local tax known as the poll tax. Officials said the turnout among the 25 million voters registered in the 201 councils contested appeared higher than the usual 30 percent to 40 percent in local elections. Opinion polls showed Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative Party, which has plunged to a record low of more than 20 points behind the Labor Party, headed for a drubbing. According to forecasts from two weekend opinion polls, the socialists were poised to snatch up to 300 seats from the Tories _ or one-fourth of the total defended by the governing party. Prime targets for Labor included two London boroughs, Wandsworth and Westminster, where Conservative administrations with slender majorities have set the lowest poll tax rates in the country. Mrs. Thatcher has hailed Wandsworth, charging $243 per adult, and Westminster, with a $320 tax, as epitomizing good Conservative government as opposed to high-spending Labor-run authorities. The average poll tax levied by local authorities is $580, one-third above government targets. Defeat in the two narrowly held boroughs would be widely seen as a personal humiliation for her. An overall rout would increase speculation that the 64-year-old prime minister will stand down, or be dumped by the party, before the next election in 1991 or 1992. Another key Labor target is the north England industrial city of Bradford where a right-wing Tory administration with a two-seat majority on the 66-member council has imposed stringent economies. Problems began a year ago as inflation started rising and the government's attempt to curb it by hiking interest rates began hurting millions of new homeowners. Inflation is now headed toward 10 percent while interest rates are a high 15 percent. The new tax was imposed April 1. Mrs. Thatcher hoped it would turn voters against high-spending Labor-controlled authorities. But instead, most families are paying more and blaming the government. The tax is also perceived as unfair because everyone in a district pays the same, regardless of income. The government argues the fuss is largely because under the old system of property taxes, only the 17 million homeowners paid. Now all 38 million adult Britons have to pay, with rebates for the 9.5 million poorest. At stake in Thursday's elections were some 5,000 seats on regional authorities ranging from remote islands off northern Scotland to big cities, such as Birmingham, through English rural districts and the 36 boroughs of London. The authorities run services ranging from education, through welfare and subsidized housing to street cleaning and garbage removal. They are funded through a combination of the poll tax, business taxes and central government grants. Before voting, Labor held about 2,500 of the seats, the Tories 1,500 and centrists or independents the rest. Labor ran 97 councils, the Conservatives 60 and the centrist Social and Liberal Democratic Party 18. In the others, no party had overall control. Except in London and 12 Scottish districts, only one-third of the council seats were up for election. The seats being contested Thursday were last up for election in 1986, when Labor did well. In the House of Commons on Thursday, Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock said losers outnumbered gainers 3-1 under the new tax. ``If that is so, the enemy is not the community charge. It is high-spending Labor councils,'' Mrs. Thatcher retorted.

DOC.HEAD: Legislature Declares Support For Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: Hungary's new freely elected parliament Thursday declared its support for Lithuania, and the leader of a center-right party began trying to form the first non-Communist government in four decades. At a historic session of parliament, Interim President Arpad Goencz nominated Jozsef Antall, who heads the largest faction in parliament, as premier-designate and asked him to form a government. Antall said he hoped to forge a coalition before the end of the month. ``I will try to lead the country out of this difficult situation,'' he said. The new government will be saddled with a $21 billion foreign debt _ the largest per capita debt in Eastern Europe _ double-digit inflation, rising unemployment and resultant growing social tensions. ``I appeal for confidence so that we can form Hungary's first coalition government,'' Antall said. If Antall succeeds in building a center-right coalition, it will have a simple majority of 229 seats. But it would lack the two-thirds majority needed for major constitutional changes. The government of Premier Miklos Nemeth offered its resignation Wednesday but will stay on as a caretaker government until the new Cabinet takes charge. Goencz, who was jailed for six years after the 1956 anti-Communist uprising, was elected interim president by the house Wednesday. The new government would be Hungary's first non-Communist government in 43 years. Deputies from half a dozen parties fill the legislature, and the former Communists have been relegated to a minor opposition role with only 33 seats in the 394-seat body. Antall's party, the Hungarian Democratic Forum, had been conducting coalition talks with the like-minded Independent Smallholders and the Christian Democrats. They have 44 and 21 seats respectively. Antall told a news conference after his nomination that the first task of his government would be to strengthen international ties, to better relations with the United States and Western Europe and to keep ``correct'' relations with the Soviet Union. He said he also hoped to accelerate the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Hungarian territory. The two countries have agreed on the complete withdrawal of the Red Army by June of next year. The Soviet presence in Hungary is largely associated with Soviet tanks that crushed the 1956 anti-Communist uprising. On Wednesday, the house adopted a motion formally declaring the revolt a revolution and freedom fight. The Communists for decades had condemned it as a ``counterrevolution.'' The motion on Lithuania was added to the agenda just before the session ended. Ever since Moscow began imposing economic sanctions against Lithuania, Hungarians have compared it to 1956, when other countries stood by as their revolution was crushed. ``We deem unacceptable the use of coercive measures and all steps that can hinder the realization of the right of the Lithuanian people to self-determination,'' the text said. ``We hereby express our solidarity with the Lithuanian people and its endeavors to attain self-determination.'' The resolution urged the Kremlin to begin negotiations with Lithuanian leaders to ensure their right to self-determination and ``preservation of political stability of the Soviet Union and of international security.''

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Hails U.S. Decision On Short-Range Rockets
With AM-Bush Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher on Thursday welcomed the U.S. decision not to modernize its short-range missiles based on German soil, saying it shows NATO knows how to change with the times. Genscher made the remark while attending the NATO meeting in Brussels, where the missile announcement was made. ``This shows the alliance takes into account the changed conditions'' of East-West relations, the Foreign Ministry quoted him as saying. There was no immediate comment from the opposition Social Democrats, who have been pressing hard for removal of U.S. short-range nuclear weapons in West Germany. They were sure to welcome the announcement. In Brussels, British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said, ``It's an updating of the alliance's stance.'' West German television proclaimed: ``A new disarmament initiative has come out of Washington.'' ``There is no doubt that NATO does not want to be caught running behind developments in Eastern and Central Europe,'' said a ZDF television commentator. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the United States will cancel development of more powerful short-range nuclear missiles for Europe and will not upgrade its nuclear artillery shells. Baker also said President Bush wants to accelerate negotiations with the Soviet Union on reducing existing short-range nuclear arms. Last year, under intense pressure from Genscher and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, NATO agreed to postpone a decision on modernizing the short-range nuclear arms. Kohl and Genscher called for such a delay because of the growing West German view that a time of improved East-West relations was also a time for increased disarmament. West Germans are also especially sensitive to the short-range nuclear arsenals, since they would land on German soil if they were ever used in combat. A saying coined during debate at the time was, ``The shorter the range, the deader the German.'' ZDF said it appeared Washington made the arms decisions to try to overcome Soviet resistance to having a united Germany in NATO. ``This should sweeten the bitter pill,'' it said. The Soviet Union, fearing the strategic implications, has said it cannot accept NATO membership for a united Germany. East Germany has long been Moscow's most important military ally. Just after the U.S. announcement, East Germany said that, as planned, it had returned to the Soviet Union last month the Scud B shorter-range nuclear arsenals on East German soil. East Germany's news agency, ADN, said the action was in line with a decision by the East German government in January. According to the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, 28 Scud B launchers were stationed in East Germany. The Scud B is not considered the same type of weapon that the United States announced it would not be modernizing. It has a range of up to 186 miles, a distance greater than the Lance rockets Washington has decided against upgrading. Short-range nuclear missiles similar to the Lance, with a range of up to 93 miles, remain in East Germany. According to NATO, the Soviets have hundreds of short-range nuclear missiles spread across the Warsaw Pact countries and thousands of nuclear artillery pieces.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Peggy Lipton, who rose to fame on ``Mod Squad,'' quit show biz 17 years ago to become a wife and mother. Now she's on the comeback trail, starring in ``Twin Peaks.'' ``It was great, but I was scared,'' Lipton, 42, said of her return to work. ``It's true for any woman because your sense of yourself has changed so much.'' ``My whole energy has changed. But you have a great advantage: you know yourself better. I had no idea who I was at that age. None,'' Lipton said in the May 4-6 issue of USA Weekend. When ``Mod Squad'' went off the air, Lipton ditched her bell-bottoms to marry producer Quincy Jones and raise their daughters, Rashida, 14, and Kidada, 16. The couple split up in 1986, but they're still close. ``I think you remain friends when you have children,'' she said. ``I love Quincy. He was everything to me.'' Lipton plays a diner owner on ``Twin Peaks,'' an avant-garde ABC-TV series by director David Lynch. ``I love working and I get upset now when I don't do enough,'' she said. ``But it was a conscious choice to be a wife and mother. Right now I don't have any mother-work conflicts because I stayed home with my kids and I wouldn't trade that experience for being the biggest star.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Eddie Murphy may be one of Hollywood's biggest stars, but fellow black actor Danny Glover says he's unimpressed by what Murphy has done with his clout. Pointing to last year's ``Harlem Nights,'' which Murphy wrote, directed and starred in, Glover said: ``Once again blacks are portrayed as foul-mouthed, crap-shooting gangsters having a good time in Harlem. ``These are acceptable conditions to most audiences, since we've been seen often enough in these circumstances.'' Glover, who rocketed to stardom as Mel Gibson's partner in ``Lethal Weapon,'' said he tries to take roles that challenge attitudes and stereotypes. ``I'm doing `Predator II' instead of (Arnold) Schwarzenegger!'' he said in the May 6 issue of Parade magazine. ``It's not a black or white part, it's just a good role.''

Zsa Zsa Gabor got a slap in the face Thursday when Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream announced it has discontinued airing a commercial featuring her. The commercial, portraying Gabor as an ``Unbelievable Spokesperson For An Unbelievable Product,'' was part of a campaign to promote the Oakland-based company's Grand Light product. On Tuesday, Gabor was given an extra 60 hours of community service by an angry judge who said fund-raising in her Bel-Air mansion was not the way to serve time for a sentence. Gabor, 72, was sentenced last year to 120 hours of community service on her conviction of slapping a Beverly Hills motorcycle policeman who had stopped her Rolls-Royce. Dreyer's received more than 300 complaints, and Steven Schickler, the company's vice president of marketing, said: ``Several of our spokespersons have been somewhat controversial. Although we intended Ms. Gabor's ad to be humorous, some of our customers have expressed strong dissatisfaction with the commercial so we've decided to stop airing it.''

Pop music stars of the '60s, B.J. Thomas, Gene Pitney and the Shirelles, will share in a court award of some $850,000, based on unpaid royalties. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Higgins assessed the award Wednesday against a defunct record company. Thomas, whose hits include ``Raindrops Keep Falling on My Head'' is to receive $177,299. Pitney, known for teen heartthrob songs such as ``Town Without Pity,'' is owed $187,762. Members of the Shirelles, an all-female group whose recordings included ``Soldier Boy,'' were awarded $119,537 each. Three members of the Shirelles _ Beverly Lee, Shirley Owens Alston and Doris Coley Jackson _ are still living. A share is also to go to Vernon McFadden, widower of the late Addie Harris McFadden. The singers had filed suit in 1987, claiming that Gusto Records Inc. and GML Inc. had improperly seized master recordings that had passed through several owners over the years. Attorneys for Gusto and GML had countered that the artists never had rights to the royalties in the first place or sold them to other record companies years ago. Grant Smith, a lawyer who represented Gusto Records, said Thursday he will appeal the decision but said Gusto would pay if the appeal fails.

Rock 'n' roll legend Chuck Berry has gone to court to get back videotapes that brought him unwanted attention in a lawsuit. A suit filed in December by a former cook at Berry's Southern Air Restaurant in nearby Wentzville charged that Berry had made videotapes of her and other women while changing clothes and using the women's restroom. The ex-cook, Hosana A. Huck, 48, alleged that Berry had placed concealed cameras in the ceilings _ an action she called ``patently and highly offensive.'' Now Berry, 63, filed suit last week in St. Charles County Circuit Court to demand the return of the tapes, which he says were stolen from his home on Sept. 9, 1989. Berry's lawyer, Wayne Schoeneberg, said they believe Huck and her lawyer have the tapes. Berry's lawsuit charges that his privacy was invaded because Huck ``publicly disclosed private matters'' concerning Berry without his permission.

DOC.HEAD: `Bonfire' Filmmaker Tries to Appease Bronx With Disclaimer
DOC.TEXT: Warner Bros., responding to accusations of Bronx-bashing in its film adaptation of ``The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' has agreed to tack on a standard disclaimer at the end of the movie. The company confirmed Thursday that an agreement had been reached to run a two-sentence statement assuring moviegoers that the story is fictional. ``It's the kind of thing you see in most movies and a lot of books,'' said a Warner official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``It's not anything special.'' The movie, based on Tom Wolfes' best-selling novel about a Wall Street bond salesman who gets enmeshed in the Bronx court system, infuriated Borough President Fernando Ferrer. Ferrer got a glimpse of the script last month when several scenes were shot on location in the Bronx and on Wall Street. He criticized the movie's negative depiction of the borough and sought a disclaimer detailing the Bronx's cultural institutions. He didn't quite get that in the agreement reached earlier this week. The full disclaimer reads: ``This motion picture is a work of fiction, and is not intended to reflect actual events or conditions in the localities portrayed. Warner Bros. wishes to thank the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting and the people of the city of New York for their cooperation during the filming.'' Ferrer said in a statement that Warner Bros. had missed the point of his objection. ``The real issue here was to give voice to people who do not have access to Warner Bros., or the media, who feel their positive contributions should be acknowledged,'' Ferrer said. ``When I expressed my indignation over the filming ... it was already evident that Warner Bros. never intended to give the Bronx that small gesture of acknowledgement.'' Filming for the movie has moved to Los Angeles, which so far has not requested a disclaimer.

DOC.HEAD: House Bill Proposes Ten-Fold Increase in Fines for Child Labor Violators
DOC.TEXT: The $1,000 fine for violations of child labor laws is failing to deter employers, lawmakers said Thursday as they proposed increasing the federal fine to $10,000. Businesses that repeatedly hire children for dangerous jobs or work youngsters for too many hours would face fines of up to $100,000 and year-long jail terms for their executives under the measure. The legislation was introduced in Congress along with the release of a study that reports such violations jumped 150 percent in a recent six-year period. Under the bill, the Labor Department would have to keep nationwide statistics on workplace fatalities, injuries and illnesses involving workers under age 18. House members who introduced the measure said the size of the nation's child labor problem is unknown because of poor record-keeping and detection. ``We have grabbed onto the large tail of an unseen beast,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. The Labor Department, which has recently cracked down on child labor violators, is reviewing changes in such laws. Though the agency has not taken a stand on raising the penalty for each infraction to $10,000, it has made administrative changes to increase the fine structure. Previously, the Labor Department fined businesses $1,000 for each child involved; it has now started fining employers $1,000 for each infraction. Rep. Don Pease, D-Ohio, another sponsor, said the fines are often reduced by the Labor Department and ``don't even amount to a slap on the wrist.'' The measure would also impose stiff penalties for willful violations that result in a child's death or injury. If a worker under 18 suffered serious bodily injury from a willful violation, the employer would face a fine of up to $250,000 and a seven-year jail term. Violations involving a death would carry the same fine and 14 years in jail. A General Accounting Office study said information provided by 26 states showed that in 1988, children under age 18 suffered more than 31,500 work-related injuries and illnesses. The GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, said the huge increase in detected child labor violations may be due to a tight labor market and increased enforcement by the Labor Department. The number of child labor violations uncovered by the Labor Department grew from about 10,000 in fiscal year 1983 to nearly 25,000 in fiscal 1989, the study said. Last month, the Labor Department uncovered about 12,000 violations during a three-day nationwide sweep. Those violations are expected to result in fines of nearly $4 million to employers.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Allies Set Swirl of Summits to Keep Pace With Changing Europe
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUB lead and 13th graf, `The decision...' to correct that one treaty involved, and add West German reax to Lance decision. Pickup 14th graf, `In May...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BRU6
DOC.TEXT: Spurred by the historic changes sweeping Europe, the United States and its 15 Western allies agreed Thursday to hold NATO and East-West summits this year to reach a treaty reducing troops and non-nuclear arms. The decision was announced after Secretary of State James A. Baker III briefed NATO foreign ministers on a new U.S. nuclear missile cutback and on the need to adapt the alliance to a lessened Soviet military threat. NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner reported the alliance's consensus to have a summit in London in early summer and an East-West summit in Paris by year's end. ``NATO is preparing for the future,'' he said. ``The Atlantic alliance is taking advantage of the historic opportunity to move from confrontation to cooperation.'' The sole sour note was an accusation by Woerner, the former West German defense minister, that the Soviets were ``foot-dragging'' in negotiations to reduce troops, tanks, artillery and other non-nuclear forces. Baker stressed that holding the 35-nation summit depends on completing the Conventional Forces in Europe (CFE) treaty. ``Unless we conclude a CFE agreement we should postpone a CSCE summit,'' he told reporters. The CSCE, or Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, is comprised of all the nations of Europe except Albania, along with the United States and Canada. Baker said the negotiations to limit Soviet troops in Europe to 195,000 and U.S. forces to 225,000 ``have not proceeded as rapidly as we would have thought.'' He said he would have a better grasp of the situation after meeting with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Bonn Friday and Saturday, and again in the Soviet Union in two weeks. He also announced, as President Bush did in Washington, that the United States would shelve plans to deploy more powerful Lance short-range nuclear missiles in West Germany and would not upgrade nuclear artillery shells in Europe. In addition, he offered to accelerate negotiations with the Soviets to make cuts in the current stockpile of 1,600 missiles with ranges of up to 300 miles once the CFE treaty is wrapped up. The decision to shelve development of a new Lance missile underscores the rapid pace of change in East-West relations. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher welcomed the decision, saying it shows NATO knows how to change with the times. In May 1989, the NATO allies agreed to upgrade the aging Lance missiles. With those plans now canceled, the Lance will become obsolete by 1995. In 1975, the CSCE set a course for lessening East-West tensions by promoting human rights and reducing military frictions. Now, with NATO's military mission rapidly diminishing, the United States and its allies seek to expand the role of the 35-nation organization. ``We need a more ambitious agenda for the CSCE,'' Baker said. He suggested such missions as monitoring ``unusual military activity'' and managing disputes between members. To prepare for the 35-nation summit, Baker announced he would host a meeting of all CSCE foreign ministers in New York in late September. He apppealed to the Soviets to speed up the negotiations on a treaty and said he was confident Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ``will overcome this period'' of slow progress. The main obstacles to a treaty are disputes over limiting airplanes and helicopters and how to monitor cutbacks. Woerner said the allies agreed that a unified Germany would be a member of the NATO alliance and have no chemical or nuclear weapons. In a concession to Moscow, he said, Soviet troops could remain in what is now East Germany for a number of years. ``We have no intention of shifting the balance to the detriment of the Soviet Union,'' he said. Gorbachev reiterated only last week his opposition to NATO membership for a unified Germany, and Shevardnadze said last month the new Germany should be ``nonaligned'' or possibly belong to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact. The issue will confront Baker in both his sessions with Shevardnadze and at a meeting of the two Germanys and the four victorious World War II allies _ the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union. The so-called two-plus-four talks will focus mainly on allaying the concerns of Germany's neighbors during German reunification.

DOC.HEAD: Settlers Hold Ceremony at Jewish Ceremony, Curfew on Nablus
DOC.TEXT: Dancing and singing Israeli settlers held a religious ceremony Thursday at a Jewish seminary in the heart of the West Bank city of Nablus, and the army clamped a curfew on the city to thwart Palestinian protests. Arabs fear that the seminary, Joseph's Tomb Yeshiva, will become the core of Nablus' first settlement. In an effort to avoid friction, the army barred settlers from bringing in 17 busloads of supporters for the ceremony, in which a new Torah scroll was brought into the seminary. Only 100 settlers were allowed to take part. Dozens of soldiers stood guard as the settlers, some sitting on each others' shoulders, danced with the scroll. The Torah was carried under a violet embroidered canopy. Several right-wing members of parliament, including parliament speaker Dov Shilansky of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud bloc, attended at the invitation of the settlers. The military permitted a small group from the leftist Peace Now movement to stage a protest at the site, the legendary burial place of the son of the biblical patriarch Jacob. The leftists, in a futile attempt to drown out the settlers' singing, stood in line and sang ``The Song of Peace'' _ a famous Israeli anti-war song. Yossi Sarid, a left-wing lawmaker who led the protests, said the ceremony was a political provocation. ``This has nothing religious in it,'' he said. ``We are familiar with these people's political views. They want to cause provocations on every hill, near every tree and every tomb.'' ``They have nothing sacred, no God in their hearts, and they are ready to exploit the Torah for political purposes,'' he said. Settlement leader Benny Katzover said the ceremony was purely religious and that Peace Now was wrong to intervene. ``They stick to us like leeches,'' Katzover said. ``They are wrong and we will continue our actions.'' However, Noam Livnat, a spokesman for the seminary, acknowledged the political element to the ceremony, saying it was an assertion of Jewish claims to the biblical Land of Israel, which includes the West Bank. Israel captured the West Bank from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East War. ``We're not just talking about bringing a Torah to the seminary, but (about) a declaration that the Land of Israel is ours, all of it, only ours,'' Livnat said on Israel radio. The seminary has been a source of controversy. A top Shamir aide recently announced he wanted to build sleeping quarters for the yeshiva students, who at present have to leave Nablus at night in accordance with army orders. Palestinians believe that establishing a dormitory would constitute a permanent settlement in Nablus. The city has been a major hotbed of violence during the nearly 29-month Arab rebellion against Israeli occupation. An army spokesman said Thursday's curfew on the city and surrounding refugee camps confined about 160,000 people to their homes. Several hours before the ceremony, soldiers searched Palestinian homes and erected observation posts on rooftops near the seminary, Arab witnesses said. A helicopter hovered above and roadblocks were erected around the city to keep out non-residents. The army said the measures were aimed at preventing clashes between Palestinians and settlers. The Moslem fundamentalist Hamas movement had called on Palestinians to attack soldiers and settlers in protest. Ghassan Shakaa, a pro-PLO Nablus lawyer, warned in a telephone interview that ``a settlement in Nablus will create a new wave of confrontations with the settlers.'' Since the March 15 collapse of Israel's coalition government, ground has been broken on two new settlements and it has been revealed that the government secretly funded another settlement. The developments have strained relations between Israel and the United States, which considers Jewish settlement in occupied lands an obstacle to peace. Students of the Joseph's Tomb seminary have been involved in several bloody clashes with Palestinians. Last June, about 30 students rampaged through the West Bank village of Kifl Harith, burning trees, smashing windows and firing at random. A 13-year-old girl was shot and killed. Four seminary students were indicted in the case. The yeshiva's rabbi, Yitzhak Ginzburg, created a furor in Israel when he said after the incident that Jewish blood and the blood of non-Jews ``are not equal, God forbid.'' Several weeks later, a yehsiva student ambushed a group of Arab workers near Tel Aviv, killing one of the men. He was arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Dies of Apparent Self-Inflicted Gunshot Wound
LaserPhoto NY17
DOC.TEXT: Actor David Rappaport, a dwarf who appeared as an attorney defending little people on TV's ``L.A. Law,'' apparently shot himself to death two months after a previous attempt. He was 38. The 3-foot, 11-inch actor's body was found Wednesday night in shrubbery at a San Fernando Valley park, said Detective James Edwards. ``The investigation hasn't been completed but it appears to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound,'' coroner's office spokesman Bob Dambacher said Thursday. Rappaport suffered a gunshot wound in the chest. A .38-caliber pistol was found. No suicide note was located, but his manager said the actor had been tormented by depression for months. A suicide attempt by the actor March 4 was thwarted by police who found him unconscious in a car with the motor running. He was hospitalized with carbon monoxide poisoning. Frankie Leigh, Rappaport's cousin and business manager, filed a missing person report with police Tuesday, saying the actor was depressed when he left his Hollywood home. ``This is a shock to everyone,'' Ms. Leigh said. ``He went out to walk the dog, a Labrador named Rickie after singer Rickie Lee Jones, and he took the car. When he didn't come back we knew something was wrong.'' The dog was found inside the car near Rappaport's body, she said. ``Everybody kept saying he was coming along and he was fine. This is a shock,'' said actor Billy Barty, who founded the Little People of America support group for dwarfs and midgets. ``There is depression in the world period. It doesn't matter whether you are big or small,'' Barty said. ``I don't know why he took this step.'' ``He was in incredibly charming guy, very bright and very articulate,'' said attorney Paul Miller, a dwarf friend of Rappaport. ``He had his feet on the floor, so to speak, and wasn't one of those crazy Hollywood types.'' Rappaport portrayed Simon McKay, a Good Samaritan inventor on ``The Wizard'' from 1986 to 1987 on CBS-TV. He also starred with John Cleese and Sean Connery in the 1981 film ``Time Bandits.'' Rappaport had most recently appeared in several episodes of NBC's ``L.A. Law,'' playing a scheming, win-at-any cost lawyer, Hamilton Skylar, who became the nemesis of attorney Victor Sifuentes, played by Jimmy Smits. In one episode, Skylar defended dwarf-tossing, arguing that little people had the right to be tossed in a bar for money if they wanted to. ``This show has become a perfect showcase for an actor,'' Rappaport said. ``It is such a quality show _ from the writing to the acting to the wardrobe _ it is the Rolls-Royce of television. And believe me, I've done the whole range of TV, so I know a Rolls when I see one.'' In an Associated Press interview two years ago, the English-born Rappaport said he had suffered discrimination because of his height. His wish: to be treated like ``a regular boring normal person.'' ``I look at boring people every day and I say, God, I wish I could be like that, but my lot is to be unique, special, so I have to put up with it. It's a hard life,'' he said. About his size, Rappaport said: ``A very good journalist in England years ago said to me, `There's hundreds of actors out of work, but there's only two good actors in the world who are 4-foot tall. Try and corner the market.' ``And basically that's what I've tried to do, and it seems to be working.'' Ms. Leigh said Rappaport had no surviving family. A funeral and burial was planned next week in London, Ms. Leigh said.

DOC.HEAD: Blood Agencies To Test All Donations For Hepatitis C
DOC.TEXT: Blood bank agencies announced plans Thursday to screen all blood donations for hepatitis C, the most common serious infection spread by blood transfusion. The American Association of Blood Banks, the American Red Cross and the Council of Community Blood Centers said in a joint statement that the donated blood will be screened using a new test licensed on Tuesday by the Food and Drug Administration. By some estimates, about 7,500 to 20,000 of the 4 million Americans receiving blood transfusions annually develop acute hepatitis C. Officials said the new test may cut that number of infections by about 50 percent. Jon MacPherson, executive director of the Council of Community Blood Centers, said the groups also were suggesting that patients who have received blood transfusions within the last 20 years should consider being tested for hepatitis C. ``Hundreds of thousands of people have been infected in the past and may not know it,'' he said. ``They should call their physician and ask about being evaluated.'' Hepatitis C, formerly called hepatitis non-A, non-B, is thought to be caused by a virus called HCV. It infects from 150,000 to 200,000 Americans annually. Only 5 to 10 percent of these cases are attributed to blood transfusions. Other sources are thought to be shared drug needles and, some studies suggest, sexual relations. The source of at least half of the hepatitis C infections, however, is unknown. Symptoms of hepatitis C for most patients are mild and the disease usually is not diagnosed. There is no generally available treatment for the disease, but some experimental studies are underway. For 10 to 20 percent of the patients, hepatitis C can be serious, leading to life-threatening liver disease, or cirrhosis. It is estimated by the blood agencies that the new testing will prevent 500 to 5,000 new cases of transfusion-associated cirrhosis. The new hepatitis C test, marketed by Ortho Diagnostic Systems Inc., tests blood samples for antibodies to the hepatitis C virus. Earlier tests for hepatitis C used indirect measures that were less precise. A joint study by the blood agencies said up to 1 percent of all U.S. blood donors are expected to test positive for HCV, but between 40 and 70 percent of this number will be false positives. Blood donations will not be accepted from those who test positive for HCV, the statement said, even though ``we do not know whether they are truly infected'' because of the high false positive ratio.

DOC.HEAD: Security, Safety Lapses Found at Nuclear Amrs Plants
DOC.TEXT: Once-secret government reports on nuclear arms plants reveal illegal drug use, major safety lapses, theft and other security breaches within the last nine months. The troubles are catalogued in a six-inch stack of internal documents made public by the Energy Department this week, a month after a department contractor revealed their existence by mistakenly sending copies of one report to governors' offices. The department initially tried to keep a lid on the revelations. Failing that, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins announced he was making the reports publicly available ``to show that I am serious about changing the way DOE does business.'' The release of the papers, called daily operations reports and written from the department's regional field offices, marks a significant, if limited, opening in the wall of secrecy behind which the nuclear weapons industry has operated for nearly a half-century. The weapons plants are owned by the Energy Department and operated by private contractors. The reports, covering the period of Aug. 24, 1989, to present, describe problems ranging in seriousness from safety lapses at the Savannah River, S.C., nuclear reactors to worries about ``media noise'' over environmental problems at the Rocky Flats arms plant near Denver. Much of the information was presented in a shorthand form with little or no detail, but it unveiled several episodes not previously acknowledged to the public. Among the more serious cases: _A backup system for pumping water to cool one of the Savannah River nuclear reactors may have been unusable for the past five years because of missing wiring. Engineers discovered the problem only last December. _Significant uranium releases at the Hanford weapons plant in Washington state were not reported for several months. The reason: the releases occurred after the Energy Department standard for radiation protection was inadvertently canceled in January 1989, but before it was reinstated in July 1989. _A faulty circuit breaker started two fires in a powerhouse at Savannah River last August, forcing two nuclear materials processing operations to be shut down for several days. No one was reported injured; damage was estimated at $50,000. _Security guards at several weapons plants were dismissed or resigned after being arrested for theft of government-owned guns and other property. A guard at the Nevada Test Site, where warheads are detonated in underground tests, resigned in February after he was arrested for holding stolen property, including two rifles, one shotgun and five handguns he carried in his personal vehicle. _In April, a security guard at Savannah River was accused of sleeping on duty after a supervisor at one of the reactor buildings walked into his locked and darkened office to find the guard ``getting up from the floor.'' A later report said that wasn't evidence enough to make the charge stick. _Illegal drug use was reported throughout the weapons complex. In one nine-day period in November, nine cases of illegal drug use were reported at five plants or laboratories. In September an operator of one of the Savannah River nuclear reactors was suspended after testing positive for unspecified drug use. Other reports described incidents that, viewed in isolation, may have been minor, but taken together formed a pattern of violations that could lead to serious accidents in one of the most potentially hazardous working environments on Earth. For example: _Operations involving the metal beryllium at the Oak Ridge plant in Tennessee were suspended for more than a month last fall to improve hygiene practices and tighten operating procedures and engineering controls. Exposure to airborne beryllium dust has been associated with an incurable lung disease, berylliosis. _An unspecified violation of safety limits for nuclear materials at Rocky Flats was not reported to plant managers until four days after it was discovered. _A worker at the Argonne nuclear laboratory in Illinois was seen sawing through a pipe that had been specially painted to indicate it was radioactive.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Drama Desk Nominations Each for `Grand Hotel' and `City of Angels'
DOC.TEXT: ``Grand Hotel'' and ``City of Angels,'' two big Broadway musicals, each received 12 Drama Desk nominations Thursday for outstanding achievement during the 1989-90 New York theater season. Both shows were nominated for best musical, as was Andrew Lloyd Webber's ``Aspects of Love.'' Five productions were nominated for best play: ``The Lisbon Traviata'' by Terrence McNally, ``The Piano Lesson'' by August Wilson, ``Prelude to a Kiss'' by Craig Lucas, ``The Secret Rapture'' by David Hare and ``Some Americans Abroad'' by Richard Nelson. Several big name stars were snubbed in the acting categories. Not nominated were Maggie Smith of ``Lettice and Lovage,'' Kathleen Turner of ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' Rex Harrison of ``The Circle'' and Vanessa Redgrave of ``Orphesus Descending.'' Dustin Hoffman, who played Shylock in a revival of ``The Merchant of Venice'' was nominated in the featured actor category. Nominated for best actor in a play were Alec Baldwin, ``Prelude to a Kiss''; Charles S. Dutton, ``The Piano Lesson''; Nathan Lane, ``The Lisbon Traviata''; Gary Sinise, ``The Grapes of Wrath''; and Colin Stinton, ``Some Americans Abroad.'' The nominees for best actress in a play went to Geraldine James, ``The Merchant of Venice''; Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio, ``Twelfth Night''; S. Epatha Merkerson, ``The Piano Lesson''; and Mary-Louise Parker, ``Prelude to a Kiss.'' Actor in a musical nominations went to Mike Burstyn, ``The Rothschilds''; David Carroll, ``Grand Hotel''; Philip Casnoff, ``Up Against It''; and James Naughton, ``City of Angels.'' The nominees for best actress in a musical were Debby Boone, ``The Sound of Music''; Tyne Daly, ``Gypsy''; and Lynne Wintersteller, ``Closer Than Ever.'' The Drama Desk, an association of New York drama critics, writers and editors, includes both Broadway and off-Broadway shows in awards consideration.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Says Government Needs to Do More to Educate Teens About AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Federal efforts to help schools educate teen-agers about AIDS haven't caught up with the need posed by the epidemic, a congressional study said Thursday. Two-thirds of the nation's public school districts reported providing formal education about AIDS during the last school year, the General Accounting Office said. The education was not in all grades and tended to drop off in the 11th and 12th grades, when students are at an age when sexual activity that could expose them to the AIDS virus tends to increase, according to GAO, the investigative arm of Congress. ``Most American teen-agers have received essential information on the causes of AIDS and how to minimize the risks of becoming infected with HIV (the AIDS-causing virus),'' said Mark V. Nadel, associate director of GAO's human resources division. ``However, there still are gaps in the provision of AIDS education.'' Students in smaller school districts are less likely to receive any AIDS education, Nadel said. AIDS education efforts ``are most clearly deficient where they are most clearly needed _ in the high-risk out-of-school population, which includes runaway and homeless youth,'' he said. Nadel spoke at a Senate Governmental Affairs Committee hearing on prevention of acquired immune deficiency syndrome. ``As much as people may want to get AIDS behind them, the epidemic among youth may be only just beginning,'' said the chairman, Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio. ``Since education is still the most potent weapon we have to control this epidemic, we need education programs that provide the facts about this disease.'' The federal Centers for Disease Control, which handles federal AIDS education efforts, should be required to take a stronger leadership role in developing ways to extend education efforts in the upper grades, GAO said. ``CDC-led nationwide education efforts are not yet commensurate with the epidemic's potential for disaster,'' the report said. One in five teachers providing AIDS-related instruction have no training in the area, and those who do often got too little, the report said. The GAO recommended the Health and Human Services Department work with state education agencies to assist smaller school districts overcome community barriers to AIDS education, and ensure that districts taking federal money collect adequate information from students. An accompanying report on out-of-school youth said CDC ``has accomplished relatively little'' in providing education about the virus outside of schools. Dr. Gary R. Noble, assistant surgeon general and deputy director of the CDC, defended the agency's education efforts. AIDS instruction drops off in the upper grades because it's usually offered in health classes not offered to upperclassmen or are elective courses in the upper grades, he said. The CDC, he said, is recommending organized program of instruction in all grade levels.

DOC.HEAD: Most Kidnapped Children Taken by Relatives
DOC.TEXT: The disappearance of 5-year-old Melissa Brannen from a Christmas party in Virginia and the kidnapping by a masked gunman of 11-year-old Jacob Wetterling in Minnesota terrorized their communities. But they are the exception, not the rule, for abducted children, according to a Justice Department study released Thursday. The overwhelming majority of the 359,000 children kidnapped each year are taken by relatives, the study said. Nevertheless, 200 to 300 kidnappings a year are dramatic enough to prompt headlines and are what the public generally perceives when it hears about an abduction _ a stranger forcibly taking a child for a long period of time and possibly killing the victim. The Brannen and Wetterling cases last year fit this definition of the stereotypical abduction created by he researchers who compiled the study, ``Missing, Abducted, Runaway, and Thrownaway Children in America.'' Neither child has been found. As many as 4,600 children are kidnapped by people who are not relatives in abductions that can include rapes and assaults. Many of these kidnappings never attract the public's attention, according to the researchers, David Finkelhor of the University of New Hampshire, Gerald Hotaling of the University of Lowell in Massachusetts, and Andrea Sedlak of Westat Inc. The fact that only 1.4 percent of all abductions of children are committed by strangers should ease parents' fears of strangers, said Ernie Allen, president of the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. ``We don't want parents to be paralyzed by fear,'' he said, adding, however, ``If there are 300 Melissa Brannens a year, that's 10 elementary school classrooms full. That's a tremendous concern.'' The study says the estimate of 4,600 abductions ``may be low. A number of these ... abductions may never be reported to the police because the victims of these assaults or rapes are ashamed or intimidated,'' the study said. The study was required by the 1984 Missing Children Act. Overall, the researchers estimated that in 1988 there were 354,100 children abducted by relatives, up to 4,600 kidnapped by non-family members, 450,700 who ran away, 127,100 who were thrown away _ abandoned or deserted, told to leave the home or told to stay out after leaving voluntarily _ and 438,200 who were lost or were otherwise missing. The study said 114,600 children may have been involved in attempted kidnappings, with the majority involving strangers unsuccessfully trying to lure the children into automobiles. The study said many children thought to be missing actually were not: ``Caretakers did know where they were. The problem was in recovering them.'' The report also said that at least 22 percent of the children previously considered runaways should be treated as throwaways.

DOC.HEAD: Poles Celebrate National Holiday Long Banned by Communists
LaserPhoto WAR54
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in more than half a century, Poland officially celebrated its national day on the third of May, honoring the nation's democratic traditions and breaking with its Communist past. Unlike recent years, when the day was marked by violent clashes between police and anti-government demonstrators, Poles observed the holiday Thursday by returning to a tradition of parades, church services and family outings. The holiday marks the anniversary of Poland's 1791 democratic constitution, Europe's first written constitution. ``I'm very happy that this day has come back,'' said a smiling Dariusz Chmielewski, joined by his wife and 8-year-old son on Warsaw's Victory Square, where an army band dressed in red, white and blue 17th-century uniforms performed before about 2,000 people. ``We have been waiting for this for a long time and it has finally come true,'' he said. The May 3 holiday commemorates Poland's short-lived attempt in 1791 to avoid Russian domination by establishing a government based on a liberal constitution. Four years later, the country was swallowed up by its powerful neighbors _ Russia, Austria and Prussia _ and disappeared from the map of Europe for 123 years. After Poland regained its independence in 1918, May 3 became the country's national day, equivalent to the American Fourth of July. But observances were banned after the 1939 Nazi invasion. After the war, Poland's Communist government abolished the holiday and changed the national day to July 22, the anniversary of the 1944 proclamation of a pro-Moscow government. In recent years, Communist authorities organized some official observances in an effort to coopt the holiday, but these were overshadowed by the anti-government protests. But last month, the new Solidarity-led government sponsored legislation to abolish July 22 as the national day and restore May 3 to its official status. Parliament approved the bill, and President Wojciech Jaruzelski signed it into law one week ago. The hasty enactment of the new official holiday caught many Poles unaware, giving them an unexpected day off just after the May 1 workers holiday, which is fast losing significance with the demise of Communism. Thursday's observances began with a flag-raising ceremony at Warsaw's Royal Castle attended by Jaruzelski, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and other officials. Later at Victory Square, the military band entertained the crowd by performing military and church music as well as cabaret songs and even a bit of swing. For Poles long used to ponderous official Communist ceremonies, the light-hearted music brought smiles and cheers. They cheered again when Mazowiecki _ the former Solidarity adviser and political prisoner who formed Eastern Europe's first non-Communist government last August _ suddenly appeared on a small platform in their midst. The prime minister, normally sad-faced, smiled and waved as he urged people to sing along to the music. A Mass for the nation's leaders was held Thursday evening at Warsaw's St. John's Cathedral. In past years, police would forcibly break up anti-government protests after May 3 services at the cathedral. Elsewhere in Poland, tens of thousands of people took part in an outdoor Mass in the southern shrine city of Czestochowa attended by Cardinal Jozef Glemp, the Catholic primate. In recent years, the Roman Catholic Church has observed May 3 as a feast day honoring the Virgin Mary. At Victory Square, 76-year-old Janina Lebenstein recalled past May 3 celebrations before World War II when there were parades, little bars and buffets and dancing in the square. ``We are happy to live to see this day,'' she said. ``It's not yet like it should be, but maybe next year it is going to be beautiful.''

DOC.HEAD: Latvian President: From Apparatchik to Champion of Independence
With AM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A local journalist summed up Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov, who was re-elected Thursday, in one phrase: ``He's come a long way, baby.'' Gorbunov, 48, belongs to a breed of Baltic politicians who, swept along by popular reforms, turned from a Communist Party functionary into a champion of independence. Along the way, he gained the expertise in two arenas _ Moscow and Riga _ that makes him a capable go-between in the tough negotiations with the Kremlin that are just beginning. ``Thanks to you, personally, Latvia has very strong and elastic political contacts in Moscow,'' a Latvian deputy said Thursday as the parliament questioned Gorbunov before his election. Questioners Thursday did not focus on Gorbunov's past, but several activists recalled with irony that he went on record about three years ago calling pro-independence protesters ``traitors of the people.'' On Thursday, Gorbunov declared: ``I believe the renewal of a legally sovereign nation must be done.'' ``So he's come a long way, baby,'' said Karl Streips, an American of Latvian descent who writes for the Popular Front newspaper Atmoda. Despite Gorbunov's former party orthodoxy, ``It's become very evident he's extremely popular. And he was elected on the People's Front slate. And he has been saying the right things,'' Streips said. Gorbunov's popularity in the republic _ he is considered its best-liked politician _ was reflected in Thursday's vote. Of 196 deputies, 153 backed him. Gorbunov, a trim man with thick, dark hair and black-framed glasses that give him a Clark Kent look, appeared authoritative and at ease fielding questions. He stood up against nationalists who want tough requirements for citizenship in independent Latvia, saying they should ``consider the realistic situation.'' Almost half of Latvia's population is not ethnic Latvian, and many of the Russians and Ukrainians migrated to the republic after it was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Many Latvian nationalists want only those who resided in the republic before 1940 and their children eligible for citizenship. Gorbunov acknowledged he had recently jumped ship from a lofty party position in the Central Committee to join the Latvian Communist Party that broke away from its Moscow parent party. But this latest twist in Gorbunov's career, like the earlier changes, incited little criticism at the Latvian Supreme Soviet. ``Only idiots don't change their minds,'' said Nikolai Neilands, a deputy foreign minister. Neilands said Gorbunov could be compared to Algirdas Brazauskas, Lithuania's Communist Party chief who is also extremely popular at home and well-respected in Moscow as well. In Lithuania, however, Brazauskas lost the race for the presidency to Vytautas Landsbergis, who was far more radical in his drive for independence. That Latvia's parliament elected a Gorbunov-type instead reflected the republic's tactic of seeking independence more gradually and with more consideration for the Kremlin's desires.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Promises to Help Iran Get Accounting of Missing Diplomats
With AM-Bush Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday promised to help Iran get details on the fate of four kidnapped diplomats, calling it a goodwill gesture and not an attempt to bargain for U.S. hostages. ``This is something they feel very strongly about,'' Bush told a news conference. ``They've mentioned it to us several different times.'' In his most conciliatory remarks toward Iran to date, Bush said: ``It's something I'd like to do. And I think they would consider this a gesture of goodwill.'' Bush said that ``the best information we have'' is that the Iranians, kidnapped in Beirut in 1982, are dead. But, he said, ``If there's some way that we can go back and get any information that would relieve the anxieties of the loved ones of those four people, we ought to do that.'' At the same time, Bush insisted that the United States would do nothing that would entail bargaining for the release of the remaining six American hostages in Lebanon. He said that while he welcomed the release of Robert Polhill and Frank Reed, ``I can't rejoice and say that my heart is full of great goodwill as long as six others are held hostage.'' Iran's charge d'affairs, Mohsen Muscavi, and three aides have been missing from Iran's embassy in Beirut since the early days of the 1982 Israeli invasion of Lebanon. Bush cited the case when he was asked if he were prepared to make any goodwill gestures toward Iran for its help in obtaining the release of Polhill and Reed. ``I would have in mind any gesture that wouldn't be perceived as negotiating for the release of hostages,'' Bush said. ``Let me give you an example,'' Bush continued. ``One of the things the Iranians are interested in is the fate of'' the four diplomats. Just as the United States wants to learn more about the fate of Marine Col. William R. Higgins, presumed to be dead, ``I can understand the Iranians wanting a full accounting'' of their diplomats, Bush said. He said he was not suggesting that Iran believes the United States had anything to do with the seizure. ``So here's an area where they have said they'd like some information, and if we can get it, I think we ought to get it,'' Bush said. ``And we're trying. So if that is goodwill, so be it. I hope it is.'' Bush also said that there might be other things that the United States could do along the same lines. However, he sidestepped taking a position on one Iranian demand _ that the United States pressure Israel for the release of 400 Moslem Shiites held in Israel, including cleric leader Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid. ``I want to see all hostages released,'' Bush said. But he said there were ``definitional problems'' in relation to the issue of hostages held in Israel. Asked to elaborate, Bush said: ``Because some people view people that they hold as having broken their laws, and some don't. And it's not for the U.S. to make these determinations.'' The president, who previously has thanked both Iran and Syria for helping to free the two U.S. hostages, said he didn't think anything the United States done had any bearing on the two releases. Meanwhile, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., urged U.S. officials to press for more information about Higgins, whose captors in Lebanon said last October that they had executed him. Dole noted that Higgins' body was never recovered and ``no one knows for sure'' what happened to him. Higgins' captors released a videotape showing the American hanging from a noose; FBI experts concluded it was authentic. Higgins was head of the U.N. peacekeeping force in Lebanon when he was kidnapped. Bush said the United States will stand by its policy of not bartering for hostages. ``We will continue to stay with the policy, trying to show goodwill where we can do it without violating the policy.'' He said there were ``no behind-the-scenes negotiations'' involving the United States that led to the release of Polhill on April 22 or Reed on April 3. The longest-held hostage is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. raum

DOC.HEAD: Two Men Appear in Court in `Super Gun' Case
DOC.TEXT: The managing director of a company that manufactured parts for a suspected Iraqi ``super gun'' project appeared in court Thursday on charges of violating a British arms embargo. A former executive of a Belgian company that contracted for the parts also appeared before Magistrate Jane Hayward. Both men were released on $40,000 bond, and their cases were adjourned until Aug. 22. Peter V. Mitchell, managing director of Walter Somers Ltd., was charged with knowingly exporting unspecified equipment between June 17, 1988, and Monday at Manchester Airport and elsewhere in Britain in violation of a ban against the sale of military hardware to Iraq. He was arrested Wednesday. Christopher Cowley, a former executive of Space Research Corp. of Brussels, also appeared. Space Research, founded by ballistics expert Gerald Bull, contracted for the suspect parts with Walter Somers and with Sheffield Forgemasters. Customs officers seized eight sections of tube manufactured by Sheffield Forgemasters on April 12, after determining they could be used as a gun barrel. Walter Somers supplied Iraq in October with equipment its engineers now believe may have been part of a hydraulic recoil mechanism for the gun project. Scholar Calls For Cutoff Of Weapons Shipments To Afghanistan
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union should stop sending weapons to Afghanistan and encourage elections, an Asian scholar told Congress Thursday. The remarks of Barnett Rubin, a fellow at the U.S. Institute of Peace, came amid a report that Washington and Moscow are taking a new tack in the effort to end the war in Afghanistan. The New York Times reported that both sides have shown flexibility on the issue. The Soviets have indicated their willingness to accept elections for a new government while the United States has said it would allow Najibullah, the current Soviet-installed leader, to run for president if he first resigns, unidentified officials said. Secretary of State James Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze will discuss Afghanistan at their meeting later this month, the State Department said in a statement Thursday. The statement also confirmed that Robert Kimmitt, the under secretary of State, has said, ``We do not object to Najibullah or his associates participating in the elections; that is for the Afghans not us to decide.'' The future of Afghanistan was discussed at a meeting of the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, known at the Helsinki Commission. Members of Congress have raised questions recently about the purpose of the estimated $600 million in secret aid that the United States channels annually to the Afghan guerrillas. There have been allegations that the money has not been fairly distributed to the rebels. The rebels have been divided particularly since the withdrawal of Soviet troops in February 1989. Despite the withdrawal, the Soviets have contined to provide millions of dollars in military hardware the Najibullah government. Rubin said it was pointless for Moscow and Washington to continue the weapons drain. ``A military solution cannot work not only because neither side can defeat the other, but, more fundamentally, because there are not two sides. ... A victory of any of the many contending forces would provoke a civil war on the part of those who are excluded,'' he said. He said the goal should be a ``political settlement in which the Afghans choose their own leaders without any conditions set by outsiders; Afghanistan becomes a neutral buffer state and all foreign powers cease to supply weapons or engage in covert operations.'' Pre-election talks should include all elements of Afghan society, including representatives of major commanders, religious and tribal dignitaries, ethnic and religious minorities, former government officials and former King Zaher Shah. Such talks could be held under the auspices of the United States, perhaps acting in conjunction with the Organization of the Islamic Conference, he said. Rubin said he felt confident the Soviets and Najibullah would adhere to their pledge to support the result of election in Afghanistan because of their performance in Nicaragua and Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Lost Liszt Concerto Makes its Debut
LaserPhoto CX6
DOC.TEXT: A piano concerto written 150 years ago by Franz Liszt was being performed Thursday night for the first time, and the soloist says the honor of playing the long-lost composition was ``a gift from God.'' ``All I have to say is, there are 50 million pianists out there right now that would like to be me,'' pianist Janina Fialkowska said hours before the debut of the concerto for piano and orchestra before a sellout crowd at the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. Fialkowska acknowledged some nervousness and a tremendous sense of responsibility in performing the work, discovered by a doctoral student from the University of Chicago doing archival research in Europe. ``I was much more careful with this,'' said Fialkowska, a Canadian who now lives in Connecticut. ``I had to approach every note of the piece and choose a way that would satisfy myself, the public and Liszt. ``I have grown to love the piece,'' she said. ``I want the piece to be a success ... I want the piece to be loved. ``It's a gift from God,'' she said of being asked to perform the concerto. Liszt, a Hungarian who lived from 1811 until 1886, was a virtuoso pianist and a prolific composer who performed and taught across Europe. ``He divided his household in so many cities that he invariably lost track of some materials,'' said Rena Mueller, a Liszt scholar who teaches at New York University. ``Also, he gave sections away as gifts sometimes.'' It took the work of an enterprising scholar, Jay Rosenblatt, to piece together sections of Liszt's work found in the german cities Nuremberg and Weimar and Budapest, Hungary, to form the one-movement, 15-minute piece, now called Concerto Opus Posthumous. ``The materials had been located before and had been seen by other scholars,'' said Mueller. ``Mr. Rosenblatt was able to put them together ... into a single coherent piece.'' The result, she said, is ``a large original composition.'' ``It probably dates to the late 1830s, at a point when he was touring the cultural world, demonstrating just what could be done on this relatively young instrument, the piano,'' she said. ``It is one of the major works (of) Liszt that has been discovered since the Second World War _ major in terms of scale and in terms of its overall importance to the repertory,'' she said. Rosenblatt, who is working on his dissertation at the University of Chicago, said Thursday he would be on hand for the world premiere of the piece at Orchestra Hall. Alan Walker, chairman of the music department at McMaster University in Ontario and a Liszt scholar, said the piece demonstrates Liszt's comfort in orchestrating while he was still in his early 20s. ``The prevailing wisdom is that he didn't learn to handle the orchestra until 10 or 15 years later,'' Walker said. Despite the fanfare for Thursday's premiere, the performance of the piece was sure to provoke some controversy, Walker said. ``When we say that it was lost, it's not strictly true, because several people including Liszt himself always knew where the piece was,'' Walker said. ``But Liszt didn't publish it, so this raises an ethical question as to whether or not a piece that Liszt never bothered to publish in his lifetime should be published at all.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises One-Time Foe's ``First Class Job'' in Jamaica
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday praised Jamaican Prime Minister Michael Manley for a ``first class job'' in promoting economic progress and promised to seek ways to help the country despite U.S. spending constraints. Bush told Manley his administration would look into ways to relieve Jamaica's massive international debt and would try to provide more flexibility in a program that provides development loans through private banks, U.S. officials said. Manley ``has done a first class job in trying to move Jamaica forward in many, many ways,'' Bush said at a news conference before he met with Manley. He told Manley at the start of their meeting, ``We have great respect for what you're doing, trying to do.'' U.S. officials say they are pleased that Manley has abandoned the socialist path he had taken when he was prime minister in the 1970s for more free-market philosophy. He has cut government price supports and relaxed the ban on foreign investments to deal with Jamaica's foreign debt. ``The United States wants to help these efforts,'' Bush told Manley. But he added, ``I cried on his shoulder a little bit about budget limitations we face here in the United States.'' Still, Bush said, ``we will continue to support development and growth in Jamaica.'' Manley said Bush had shown ``a real interest in a different approach'' to helping Jamaica with its $4.3 billion foreign debt. ``What was very good from our point of view was his open mindedness ... and his desire to search with us for solution,'' Manley said in a telephone interview after the Bush meeting. Bush said he directed Treasury Secretary Nick Brady and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleberger to ``see how much flexibility the United States can have in helping Jamaica in the ways that would benefit their move towards more privatization, more economic growth and more to the benefit of all Jamaican people.'' U.S. officials said Bush agreed to look into concerns Manley raised. Specifically, Manley wants the International Monetary Fund and World Bank to allow Third World debt to be rescheduled. He also wants eased restrictions on funds in Puerto Rico banks that are deposited in lieu of taxes by U.S. companies that do business there. Those funds are to be used for loans for development projects in the Caribbean, and Manley wants the United States to expand the types of projects eligible for the funds into economic and technical assistance areas. The United States recently rescheduled the $813 million debt Jamaica owes the United States. Bush wants Congress to give him more freedom to allocate foreign aid so that currently earmarked funds can be used to accomodate the needs of small nations such as Jamaica. The administration cut $25 million in aid from Jamaica last year to help the new democracy in Poland, but is seeking that amount in its new budget request for Jamaica. ``We have been concerned that some of us who have been in the trenches of democracy all along might get forgotten in the new excitement,'' Manley said. ``But I am very confident from things we have observed in President Bush's administration and from our talks today that you do not intend to divert from our immense needs, but rather to seek new ways to help new ... members of the family of democracy,'' he said. Manley embraced Cuba's Fidel Castro and hewed to socialist principles when he held office during the 1970s. But he has worked on closer relations with the United States since returning to office. Manley's views ``have evolved in ways that obviously we respect and support,'' said a U.S. official who briefed reporters about the visit on condition of anonymity. ``I think our relations have never been better.''

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Looks For Way to Convert Property to Private Hands
DOC.TEXT: East Germany, under pressure from the West, tried Thursday to find a way to quickly shift its vast quantities of state-owned land and businesses into the private sector. Under the ousted socialist system that ruled for four decades, the state owned all property. West Germany has said a quick conversion to private property must follow the agreement the two nations reached Wednesday on merging their economies. That agreement came under heavy fire Thursday from critics who said it will speed the collapse of many East German factories and hurt poor and handicapped people by taking away social subsidies. Thousands of shoe and leather workers at factories staged brief warning strikes to demand their jobs be protected. Employees halted work in East Berlin, Erfurt, Gera, Lauchhammer, Karl-Marx-Stadt and Weissenfels, the government news agency ADN said. East Germany's finance and foreign ministers also criticized the plan, causing the first major cracks in the broad coalition government of East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere. De Maiziere answered critics by promising to block the ``uncontrolled'' acquisition of state-owned assets by West Germans and foreigners. West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann said a quick privatization of property and industry was crucial to creating a market economy that would spawn jobs and incomes necessary to offset the loss of huge social subsidies. He said many details have to be worked out, but quick privatization is needed to cope with the widespread joblessness in East Germany as the country is forced to compete in the free market. ``From July onward every company that's active in West Germany can also become active in East Germany,'' Haussmann said in Bonn. Otto Graf Lambsdorff, head of West Germany's Free Democrats, said a conversion to private property must quickly follow the decision to convert East German marks to West German marks. Otherwise, it will be money thrown ``out the window,'' he said. Teams of experts from the two governments began talks on the key aspects of unification in East Berlin on Thursday. The talks followed agreement on an economic proposal that was billed as a basic plan for merging the economies by July 2. Social Democrats who have joined the government of de Maiziere, who leads the conservative Christian Democrats, sharply criticized the plan. East German Finance Minister Walter Romberg said the agreement still does not give adequate protection to people earning low incomes and fails to include a mechanism to protect people when rents and livings costs rise in the free market. East Germans now are dependent on subsidized food, housing and jobs. ``A law that adjusts for social shortcomings in East Germany ... is of essential significance,'' Romberg said in Bonn, where he met with West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel. East German Foreign Minister Markus Meckel, head of the Social Democrats, also criticized the agreement. Some East Germans want guarantees that prices and rents will not rise at a vastly sharper rate than their wages. The government of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said the influx of new Western businesses will raise living standards in East Germany. The agreement would convert East German wages, pensions and small savings accounts at a 1-1 exchange to the West German mark. It also would convert debts owned by East German factories _ estimated at 200 billion East German marks _ at a 2-1 rate. Those debts now will be worth 100 billion West German marks ($60 billion), but with Western interest rates. Some economists have said that the debts should be forgiven entirely to allow the factories to get a fresh start in the free market. The economic agreement rate would allow elderly people to convert up to 6,000 marks ($3,500) at a 1-1 rate, but people 14 and under could only exchange 2,000 marks ($1,180). All others would have a 4,000 mark ($2,360) limit.

DOC.HEAD: Poland, Mexico Get U.S. Commodities
DOC.TEXT: Poland and Mexico will get U.S. donations of farm commodities, the Agriculture Department announced Thursday. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager of the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said Poland will receive 77,000 metric tons of soybean meal to ``help meet the livestock feed needs of Polish farmers'' this year. The meal, worth around $15 million based on prices this spring at processing plants, will be part of the $100 million aid package announced earlier by President Bush, he said. Dickerson said the meal will be bought by USDA through a bidding process among suppliers. Mexico will get about 45,000 tons of sorghum grain valued at $3.8 million. The grain will be sold to the private sector in Mexico and the proceeds used for food aid to needy people, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Nazi War Criminal Returns to Face Charges of Mass Murders
DOC.TEXT: Four decades after fleeing to Argentina, alleged Nazi war criminal Joseph Schwammberger returned to Germany as a feeble old man Thursday to face charges in the deaths of thousands of Jews. Schwammberger, a former Nazi SS lieutenant accused of commanding two labor camps in Poland, was extradited from Argentina after losing a 30-month fight against being returned to Germany. Schwammberger, 78, had to be supported by a plainclothes security man as he walked down the steps from the Lufthansa plane, which flew him from Buenos Aires to Frankfurt. He was accompanied on the flight by a doctor, his attorney and West German officials of Interpol, the international police organization. Schwammberger, wearing a tan sweater and checkered shirt, glanced briefly toward news photographers waiting on the airport tarmac, but made no comments. He was led away to a police van and taken to the southern city of Stuttgart, which is the site of the Baden-Wuerttemberg state court that asked for his extradition. Officials said he could face trial by the end of the year. If convicted, he faces a maximum sentence of life in prison. West German has no death penalty. Argentina's Supreme Court last month upheld the extradition of Schwammberger, who fled to South America after escaping from Allied authorities following World War II. The Stuttgart court ordered Schwammberger's arrest in 1973. At the time, he was believed to be in Argentina, where there is a sizable population of German-speaking immigrants. Many Nazis fled to South America following the defeat of Nazi Germany. Argentine officials captured Schwammberger without incident in November 1987 at a ranch about 500 miles northwest of Buenos Aires. Schwammberger variously claim heart and health ailments during his incarceration in Argentina. As a naturalized Argentine citizen, he fought his extradition to the Supreme Court, which finally revoked his citizenship. The high court upheld a lower court ruling that the crimes Schwammberger is accused of committing occurred before he became an Argentine citizen. A native of Austria, Schwammberger is accused of commanding forced labor camps from 1942 to 1944 at Przemysl and Mielec in Nazi-occupied Poland at which an estimated 5,000 inmates, mostly Jews, were executed or deported to death camps. Survivors testified he starved prisoners, used dogs to tear them apart, and threw people alive into fires. Rabbi Marvin Hier of the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles, which gathered evidence against Schwammberger, said in a telephone interview: ``Here we are not dealing with an administrator, but with a man who participated directly; a man who rolled up his sleeves and bloodied his hands every day.'' Hier said the center has 73 witnesses who plan to testify against Schwammberger. Hier said Schwammberger was arrested by the French army in 1945, but escaped three years later from a train taking him to U.S. military authorities in Austria for trial. He fled to Argentina in 1949, where he lived under his own name and obtained citizenship in 1965. For years he worked at a petrochemical plant in La Plata, 30 miles south of Buenos Aires. In October 1987, the Wiesenthal Center placed Schwammberger on its list of most wanted Nazi war criminals. Argentine newspapers published the list, and police received information of Schwammberger's whereabouts. In an interview Thursday with West Germany's Saarland state radio, Simon Wiesenthal said Schwammberger's extradition after so many years ``is a warning to future murderers, who perhaps are being born today.''
