Wiesenthal runs a Nazi-hunting center in Vienna, Austria, that is still tracking hundreds of suspected Nazi war criminals in the United States, Canada, South America and elsewhere.

DOC.HEAD: Mohawks Warriors Continue to Bear Arms in Deadly Gambling War
DOC.TEXT: Militant Mohawk Indians on Thursday defied calls from officials to lay down their weapons and negotiate an end to a 9-month-old gambling battle that has killed two Indians. A federal mediator said Thursday afternoon he planned to meet with at least one Indian chief on the St. Regis Indian Reservation in northern New York, where the fight over casino gambling erupted in gunfire that killed two people Tuesday. ``There was never a death before and now there are two,'' said Fletcher Graves, a U.S. Justice Department mediator who has helped resolved past disputes on the reservation, which straddles the U.S.-Canadian border. Also Thursday, about 30 U.S. and Canadian officials met in Montreal to discuss the problem, said Eddie Brown, assistant secretary for Indian affairs at the U.S. Interior Department. The meeting was closed to reporters. Mohawk representatives were not invited to the meeting, said Leaman Long, spokesman for Canada's Indian Affairs Department. About 100 New York state troopers continued to man roadblocks and patrol the U.S. side of the reservation. Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Ontario and Quebec provincial police patrolled the Canadian side. Members of the pro-gambling Warrior Society, a self-proclaimed Mohawk security force, carried automatic weapons as they maintained their own patrols on the Indian land. ``It's something that's well beyond our control,'' said state police Sgt. Richard Jones. ``It's going to take a political solution. We're just maintaining the peace until they negotiate an agreement.'' The reservation was quiet Thursday, as it was Wednesday. Before state police moved in late Tuesday, gunfire could be heard nightly throughout the reservation, prompting hundreds of Mohawks to flee. St. Regis resident Margaret Peters said she had to lie on her stomach behind a barricade to avoid bullets as she and her family fled the reservation a week ago. She said as the bullets were flying, she thought, ```I'm going to die tonight.''' She said she left because she didn't want her kids ``to grow up thinking it's OK to hear gunshots every night.'' Gov. Mario Cuomo and state police have called on the Indian factions to put down their weapons and negotiate. Warriors claim they are a legitimate police force protecting the rights of those who live on the reservation. ``Can the New York state police tell the (Ontario police) to lay down arms?'' said Warrior Society spokesman John Boots. ``Can Ontario police tell New York state police to lay down their arms?'' The warriors say Cuomo and state police betrayed them after troopers moved onto the reservation. Boots said state officials promised that troopers were entering the reservation only to escort Canadian police to the scene of the shootings, which occurred in Canada. Once on the reservation, troopers stayed to maintain order, said state police Capt. Richard Garrant. ``Cuomo and state police doubled-crossed us,'' Boots said. Cuomo said state officials would begin negotiating next week with the Mohawks to resolve the gambling issue as long as the ``Indians meet the conditions, which are no violence, close the casinos and no roadblocks.'' Most of the reservation's six casinos have been closed since last week, and all have been closed since troopers occupied the reservation. Boots said the warriors would not negotiate until state troopers leave. The warriors and many other Indians say state and federal laws do not apply on the 28,000-acre reservation, where about 9,000 Mohawks live. About 2,000 Mohawks have fled the reservation in the last week. State police, who generally had stayed off the Indian land since an FBI-led gambling raid there in July, moved in after the killings. Since the summer raid on the Mohawk casinos, the reservation has been the scene of arson, beatings and random gunfire. The violence had escalated since March, when gambling opponents set up roadblocks to keep outsiders off the reservation. Opponents of the casinos say they encourage prostitution and drug use and threaten traditional ways. Supporters say they the casinos, which attract busloads of tourists, are an economic boon.

DOC.HEAD: Jerusalem Mayor Meets With Bush
DOC.TEXT: Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek said a meeting Thursday with President Bush left him convinced that Bush has no objection to Jews living anywhere in that city. But the White House quickly tempered that by saying the United States maintains its opposition to Israeli settlement in occupied territories. Kollek said he explained to Bush that his city of 430,000, home to about 12 percent of Israel's population, would like to get its proportional share of immigrants from the Soviet Union or elsewhere. ``I assured him that ... we had not changed the frontier of Jerusalem since '67 by a single inch,'' said Kollek. Speaking with reporters on the White House driveway, Kollek said, ``I have no doubt that the president has no objection to Jews settling all over Jerusalem without any exception.'' ``We hope to receive a fair amount of the immigration. ... I think he and the people around him were satisfied with these replies,'' the mayor said. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said later in a written statement: ``The president believes Jews and non-Jews ought to act in a manner that does not threaten the city's comity or in any way prejudice prospects for the peace process. ``As recent events in the Christian quarter have demonstrated, the real question is not an abstract one of the rights of Jews and others, but rather how these rights are implemented,'' the spokesman said. ``The long-standing opposition of the United States to settlement activity in the territories occupied by Israel in 1967 is well known. So, too, is the position of the United States supporting a united Jerusalem whose final status is determined by negotiations.'' Kollek said the Arab population of Jerusalem doubled in the past 20 years, and the Jewish population grew by 80 percent to 85 percent. He said the Jewish-Arab ratio would be ``roughly preserved'' in the future because there is room to build 25,000 more Jewish dwellings and 20,000 to 25,000 Arab homes. Bush stirred a controversy in early March by saying the United States objected to ``new settlements in the West Bank or in East Jerusalem.'' That remark was blamed by some for helping bring about the fall of the Shamir government. Bush later exchanged letters with Kollek, who said he is satisfied with Bush's explanations of U.S. policy. Kollek said that immigrants who settle in Jerusalem ``do not get any special benefits that the people in the occupied territories get.'' Kollek told Bush in the Oval Office that the move by Jewish settlers into a Greek Orthodox Church-owned building in the Christian Quarter ``was one of the most silly and more destructive actions in our recent life.'' The Supreme Court of Israel upheld an eviction order against the settlers last week, and most have left. ``While every citizen in Israel and Jerusalem has the right to live wherever he likes, one has to use a little bit of common sense and sensitivity in such an occasion. And that wasn't used on that occasion,'' the mayor said. Kollek has helped get 500,000 signatures on a petition demanding electoral reforms following the parliamentary deadlock that has left the country without a new government for weeks. ``It's an impossible situation,'' he said of the system that guarantees tiny parties a Knesset seat no matter how small their share of the vote.

DOC.HEAD: Pimen, Patriarch of Moscow and All Russia, Dead at 79
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts graf after 13th, `Metropolitan Pitirim...' to update with church officials meeting. Recasts lead to mention added tolerance in Soviet Union.
DOC.TEXT: Patriarch Pimen, who headed the Russian Orthodox Church through years of repression and a recent renewal in a more tolerant Soviet Union, died Thursday at the age of 79. Pimen died at his Moscow residence after a long illness, the official Soviet news agency Tass said. It did not elaborate. In recent years, Pimen became increasingly frail and rarely celebrated services. When he did appear in public, he needed help to stand or move. As patriarch of Moscow and All Russia since 1971, Pimen led tens of millions of believers in the officially atheist Soviet Union. Some critics accused him of collaboration because he operated within strict limits imposed by the Kremlin. ``Probably the way he will be remembered is as a pious monk rather than as a dynamic church leader,'' said Jane Ellis, a scholar at Keston College Center for the Study of Religion and Communism, based in Britain. After a historic meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in 1988 _ the year Christianity celebrated the 1,000th anniversary of its founding in Russia _ Pimen praised the Soviet leader's reforms affecting religion. In the early years of Pimen's leadership, the Russian Orthodox Church supported official Soviet policies, especially the leadership's pronouncements on peace and nuclear disarmament that were critical of the United States. The state rewarded Pimen for his loyalty. He was a member of the government-sponsored World Peace Committee and traveled extensively. In 1982, he addressed a U.N. disarmament conference in New York. He was awarded the officially sponsored Soviet Peace Committee's gold medal. On his 70th birthday, he received the government's Order of the People's Friendship. For centuries before the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution, Russian czars imposed political controls on the church, but in the 1920s and 1930s, the Communist Party went further, razing churches and imprisoning and sometimes executing clerics. That repression eased in recent decades. Nevertheless, top church officials felt compelled to maintain close ties with Communist authorities, and that angered some religious activists. As more and more Soviets have been drawn to the faith and worshiped openly, there have been more challenges for the Russian Orthodox Church. Many activists have questioned whether Pimen had the strength and the inclination to lead the church into a new era. Ellis said Pimen was not a strong advocate for the church. ``He was one of those, like other leaders of the church, who really was put in the position where, in order to keep any church life alive at all ... had to acquiesce and do what the government tells them to do, and he was one of those who quite clearly did that,'' she said in an interview Thursday. Metropolitan Pitirim, head of the Russian Orthodox Church's printing department and reportedly close to Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, is regarded as a possible successor to Pimen. Ellis said about a half-dozen bishops could be seen as contenders for the post and there was no clear front-runner. Church officials gathered in Moscow on Thursday night to elect an acting patriarch and resolve other matters concerning Pimen's death, Tass reported, but there was no immediate word on who was chosen. By tradition, the church's top leadership body _ known as the Local Council and made up of all metropolitans, archbishops, bishops, and representatives of the clergy and laymen _ will gather within six months to elect a permanent successor. Born June 23, 1910 into a white-collar family, Sergei Izvekov entered the monastery in October 1927 and took the religious name Pimen. He continued his religious education at a time when authorities violently repressed the church, and he became a priest in 1931. Until 1946, he was a priest in a cathedral in Murom, a city about 140 miles east of Moscow. Pimen advanced rapidly into more responsible posts in Odessa, Rostov-on-Don and Pskov. In 1960, he was named archbishop and became a member of the Holy Synod, the administrative organ of the Russian Orthodox Church. Three years later he was named metropolitan of Krutitsky and Kolomenskoye. He was chosen patriarch in 1971, succeeding Patriarch Alexei, who had led the church 25 years. Pimen was elected to the Soviet parliament in March 1989. ``We church people ardently pray for the success of the restructuring process (perestroika), and strive to do everything possible for its development,'' Tass quoted Pimen as saying in 1988. A memorial service was planned Friday at Bogoyavlensky Cathedral in Moscow. No funeral plans were announced.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Mileage Requirements Could Be Dangerous, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Highway deaths are virtually certain to rise if automakers are forced to significantly improve fuel efficiency by the end of the decade, the government's top traffic safety official said Thursday. ``Injuries will be more severe; deaths will increase'' because automakers would be forced to build smaller cars, said Jerry R. Curry, administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. In a speech to the Society of Automotive Engineers, Curry criticized ``special interest groups that want to become the high priests'' of gasoline mileage standards, which his agency sets. Under current law, new fleets _ all the cars an automaker produces in one model year _ must have an overall average of 27.5 miles per gallon. That means some models may fall short of the minimum if others exceed it. For light trucks, the minimum is 20 mpg. A bill in the Senate would require automakers to improve their fleet averages 20 percent by the 1995 model year and 40 percent by 2001. The minimum for the typical fleet would rise to 34.4 mpg in 1995 and 40.2 mpg by 2001. Environmentalists support the bill, saying major improvement in fuel economy should be the centerpiece of efforts to curb global warming. But automakers say the measure would wreak havoc in their industry and force them to stop making all but the smallest cars. Curry said it ``seems inevitable'' that a big increase in the standards would drastically reduce car sizes. He said in an interview his agency was studying the impact increased standards would have on highway deaths. ``It's very clear from the preliminary data that while we can't tell you specifically what it is, there is a very definite increase in the number of deaths as you downsize cars,'' Curry said. ``There's no question that smaller cars are more dangerous than larger cars. It's a matter of physics.'' Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., sponsor of the fuel economy legislation, said automakers had issued equally dire warnings in the mid-1970s when the current 27.5 mpg standard was proposed. ``These are the same people who said catalytic converters could never be done, who said we couldn't reach the 27 mpg standard, who fought air bags, side-impact standards. Their track record on this issue has not been impressive,'' Bryan said. Highway fatalities have decreased steadily despite reduced car weight in the past two decades, he said. Curry also supported automakers' contention that the proposed increase would restrict consumer choice. ``Forcing products on the public against consumer wishes is what the Soviets call centralized economic planning,'' Curry said. ``Mr. Gorbachev says it does not work in Russia. Can we expect it to work here?''

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Claims $1.00 Valuation Shrank to $0.027
DOC.TEXT: The Interior Department once valued coal at $1 per ton that it now says is worth 2.7 cents in a proposal to swap the coal for a protected scenic view, a congressman charges. Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., released a National Park Service memo Thursday with the higher estimate as he argued that the ``public's coal is being given away at 2.7 cents a ton.'' The park service is part of the Interior Department. Another Interior agency, the Bureau of Land Management, said the memo was mistaken, because the $1-a-ton estimate was made for a different coal tract by a private consultant. The Interior Department wants to trade rights to the 2,500-acre Youngs Creek coal tract, near Sheridan, Wyo., for a permanent development ban on a ranch owned by businessman-conservationist Laurance S. Rockefeller in Grand Teton National Park. The department, which hopes to complete the deal this month, now values the coal and the ``conservation easement'' _ the power to keep the tract from being developed, thus protecting the view _ at an equal $5.6 million. Since the tract contains an estimated 207 million tons of coal, the value comes to 2.7 cents a ton. A Wyoming official estimated a year ago that the state and federal governments each could have received up to $90 million in royalties by keeping the federal tract _ and allowing it to be mined. Interior Department officials defended the deal Wednesday at a hearing of the House Government Operations environment subcommittee, chaired by Synar. They said the 2.7 cent valuation was correct, insisting there was little interest by mining companies in the tract until 1989 _ a statement disputed by a mining firm which said it sought mining rights for years. The officials also argued the coal was difficult to mine compared to other coal in the region, and said there might be no actual mining for three decades _ although Synar produced documents saying mining could begin by 1995. Rep. Craig Thomas, R-Wyo., who supports the exchange, argued that coal values are ``somewhat abstract and hard to determine'' but the Grand Teton vista is valuable to everyone. ``I'm almost astounded,'' he said, ``that anyone would criticize the preservation of Teton Park.'' Under the deal, the public would not have access to Rockefeller's JY ranch. Rockefeller would not personally benefit from the exchange, because in 1987 he donated the conservation easement to the Sloan-Kettering Memorial Institute for Cancer Research of New York City. The institute would gain rights to the coal tract, and plans to sell the coal interest to obtain money for its cancer research. Synar released a May 14, 1986 memo written by Richard Young, chief of the land resources division of the National Park Service for the Rocky Mountain region. The memo described a meeting the previous day in Casper, Wyo. of representatives of the National Park Service, the Bureau of Land Management and Rockefeller. ``Values were discussed briefly,'' Young wrote. ``For the Youngs Creek tract, considering the type of coal, the mineability and the current market, BLM estimates the value of about $1 per ton in the ground.'' Roy Allen, chief of the Northwest Regional Evaluation Team of the Bureau of Land Management, said Young was mistaken that the $1 per ton was a BLM estimate. He said that was the figure supplied by a private consultant as the value of a nearby coal tract that was involved in a lawsuit. At that point, he said, ``BLM had never estimated the value'' of the Youngs Creek tract. David C. O'Neal, assistant secretary for land and minterals management for the Interior Department, said the deal ``appears to be an outstanding oportunity to protect Teton National Park from future development while avoiding federal costs associated with acquisition to prevent potential development.''

DOC.HEAD: Exiled Nagaland Nationalist Leader Dead at Age 83
DOC.TEXT: Angami Zapu Phizo, who fought for independence for the northeast Indian state of Nagaland and was condemned to death in absentia, has died in exile at age 83, sources at the Indian High Commission said Thursday. He died Monday, the sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The cause of death was not disclosed. Phizo, a Christian and chief of Nagaland's Angami tribe, had been in exile since 1960 when he fled Indian troops sent to the mountainous state on the Burmese border. Phizo cooperated with the Japanese during World War II in their failed bid to overthrow British colonial rule in India. Later, he petitioned Indian political and spiritual leader Mahatma Gandhi to support the Naga claim for independence but failed to gain Gandhi's support. After India gained independence from British rule in 1947, Nagaland was made a part of the Indian state of Assam. In response, Phizo founded the Naga National Council, and was its president. It demanded a separate Naga homeland and organized armed resistance against Indian forces. The government of independent India's first prime minister, Jawaharal Nehru, initially held talks with Phizo. But later it sent Indian soldiers to Nagaland to fight the guerrillas and Phizo was condemned to death in absentia for murder and declaring war on the Indian state. Phizo fled to Zurich and in 1960 with the help of a Church of England missionary, the Rev. Michael Scott, came to London. Nagaland is about 160 miles long and 70 miles at its widest point. Its population of 775,000 is descended from fierce tribal headhunters. The British in days of colonial rule sent 18 military expeditions from 1832 until 1887 to try to subdue them. Nagaland, formerly the Naga Hills district of Assam and the former Tuensang Frontier division of the Northeast Frontier Agency, was officially inaugurated as a separate state of the Indian Union in 1963. But many Nagas remained dissatisfied. Fighting between Naga guerrillas and Indian forces resumed in 1972 and still continues. The Indian government has banned all foreigners from visiting Nagaland and the other six northeast Indian states without a special permit. The sources at the Indian High Commission said Phizo's son had made inquiries about the possibility of taking his father's body back to Nagaland. A delegation from Nagaland was traveling to London to make the arrangements, they said.

DOC.HEAD: `Cheers' Actor Sought on Arrest Warrant
DOC.TEXT: ``Cheers'' actor Kelsey Grammer was being sought on an arrest warrant Thursday after failing to appear in court for a progress check on a drug counseling program. Van Nuys Municipal Judge Aviva K. Bobb issued the warrant Wednesday for Grammer, 35, who plays the brainy psychiatrist Frasier Crane in NBC's television series ``Cheers.'' It is the second outstanding arrest warrant against the actor. Bobb had ordered Grammer on Oct. 25 to enter the drug program after he was charged with one felony count of cocaine possession. The actor's attorney, Robert L. Diamond, said Thursday he had not heard from his client and was told only that Grammer was out of town. ``I would tell him, `Get back here right away, before they have to pick you up,''' said Diamond. ``I thought he was attending (the program). I told him if he had any problems, get in touch with me.'' If Grammer doesn't surrender, he could be arrested on the warrant issued by Bobb. It has a $7,500 bail attached. ``Then he'll be taken to court and either the diversion program will be reinstituted, or criminal proceedings will be renewed, depending on what kind of reasons he gives for failing to appear,'' said District Attorney spokeswoman Sandi Gibbons. Deputy District Attorney Andrew W. Diamond said Grammer ``had not paid a fee, not made an application, and not attended any of the rehabilitation classes.'' He said if Grammer is tried on the cocaine charge and convicted, the maximum penalty is three years in state prison and a $10,000 fine. ``Anybody can get busy, but you can't be that busy that you can't sign up for a program for seven months,'' he said. Grammer was arrested on April 14, 1988, after police pulled him over for driving with expired license plates. A packet containing about a quarter of a gram of cocaine worth about $25 allegedly fell from his pocket as he sat in a patrol car, according to court documents. An earlier arrest warrant was issued after Grammer missed a court appearance on Feb. 6 concerning a drunken driving arrest. He had been scheduled to prove that he had completed an alcohol rehabilitation program and 10 days of community service. According to court documents, Grammer pleaded guilty on July 13, 1988, to a charge of driving under the influence.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Committee Sets June Date for Durenberger Hearings
DOC.TEXT: Public hearings on Sen. Dave Durenberger's financial dealings will begin next month, the Senate Ethics Committee said Thursday. The panel said in February there was ``substantial credible evidence'' of rules violations involving a $100,000 book promotion deal and free limousine service accepted by the Minnesota Republican. Durenberger has admitted to lapses in judgment but denied any willful wrongdoing. The proceedings could be canceled if Durenberger and the panel negotiated an agreement to settle the case, and the senator said Thursday, ``Whether the hearing is going to be necessary we'll have to wait until early June to make a decision.'' ``It's a matter of wanting to bring this to a head,'' he said. Durenberger said his attorney had been talking informally with the committee's special counsel but he declined to discuss the talks. Two weeks of hearings, beginning June 12, are scheduled on the allegations. The committee said it would continue its investigation into Senate reimbursement Durenberger received for a condominium of which he was a co-owner. He said he expected that deal to be added ot the possible violation the panel would pursue at the June hearings. The committee could recommend that Durenberger be censured, expelled or lose seniority or responsibility. The case also could be referred to the Justice Department for a criminal investigation. The committee has said it's investigating 113 paid appearances by Durenberger in 1985 and 1986 at which he arranged to charge fees for speeches and split the proceeds with Piranha Press of Minneapolis, the publisher of two books he wrote. The deal may have broken federal law as well as Senate rules, the committee said. Some of the organizations that invited Durenberger to speak said they considered the appearances standard paid speeches and that his books were never mentioned. Paid speeches count toward the outside earnings limits for members of Congress. The committee said Durenberger may have exceeded limits on receipts of gifts by accepting nearly $5,000 in limousine trips for personal travel in 1985 and 1986. The committee has been investigating the condo deal since December, when a newspaper disclosed that Durenberger charged the Senate rent when he stayed in his Minneapolis condominium from 1983 to 1989. Durenberger repaid the Senate $11,005 in January when the Rules Committee decided he was not entitled those expenses.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Balk at Job Bias Safeguards for Their Employees
DOC.TEXT: Several lawmakers called Thursday for swift action on a bill to curb job discrimination but refused to apply the safeguards to their own staffs. ``Some say the last plantation is here on Capitol Hill,'' said Rep. Charles Hayes, D-Ill., who all the same voted with the majority as the House Education and Labor Committee voted 21-9 against applying the bill to congressional staff members. The bill is designed to overturn six 1989 Supreme Court decisions that civil rights forces call severe setbacks. Provisions of the legislation range from a ban on employee harassment in the workplace to tightened safeguards against discriminatory hiring practices. Its provisions would have been applied to House employees under an amendment offered by Rep. Steve Bartlett, R-Texas. The provision found support among Republicans who are critics of the overall bill while Democrats who are trying to speed action on the bill were the chief opponents of the amendment. The debate came as Hayes and other lawmakers called for speedy action on the legislation. The chairman, Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., is hoping for final action by the education and labor panel Tuesday. The bill then goes to the House Judiciary Committee. Senators and House members traditionally have guarded their patronage powers and have exempted their offices from fair-hiring bills. Rep. William Clay, D-Mo., suggested that Bartlett had something ``mischievous'' in mind when he offered the amendment. ``I think it's a question of motivation,'' Clay said. ``I doubt it's the gentleman's intention to modify the bill to the point where he will cast a vote for it.'' ``If he were sincere, he would include the Senate in this as well,'' Clay said. That brought Rep. William F. Goodling, R-Pa., the panel's ranking Republican, to his feet to demand that Clay strike his words from the record. ``I don't think I want to sit in a situation where we are questioning each other's motives,'' he said. He said such questioning violated a House rule. Clay, however, refused to recant. ``Let's go, I'm leaving,'' said Goodling, walking out. But within a few minutes Clay asked to have his words stricken from the record and Goodling was back at his place in the committee room.

DOC.HEAD: ROTC Program Seeks Volunteer Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The Army and Air Force ROTC want students to voluntarily withdraw from the military training programs to help pare the future officer corps, a Pentagon spokesman said Thursday. So far, 216 students in the Army program and 103 in the Air Force program have accepted the offer, said Air Force Maj. Doug Hart. The offer, he said, is being made only to those students not in the ROTC scholarship program. ``The Army and Air Force are saying if you don't want to be in military after you graduate, we won't hold you to your contract,'' Hart said. The Navy did not join in the offer. The plan has been in effect this school year for students scheduled to graduate in 1990. The services, Hart said, decided to implement the program after it became apparent the size of the active duty force would be shrinking in coming years as a result of the lessening Soviet threat and budget concerns. About 8,000 students graduate each year from the Reserve Officer Training Corps and begin their military careers as commissioned officers.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says American, Soviet Missile Destruction On Schedule
DOC.TEXT: Destruction of intermediate-range nuclear missiles by the United States and the Soviet Union is proceeding on schedule and should be completed in a year, arms control officials said Thursday. The officials told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that two years into the three-year process, the Soviets have destroyed 1,615 missiles, or 86 percent of the total called for in the 1987 Intermediate Range Nuclear Forces treaty. The United States has destroyed 486 missiles, about 57 percent of the number that must be eliminated by June 1, 1991 under the agreement, said Gen. Roland Lajoie, director of the Pentagon's On-Site Inspection Agency. Because the Soviets have more multiple-warhead missiles, they still have about twice as many warheads deployed as the United States, Lajoie said. ``All indications are that all missiles ... will have been destroyed by both sides'' by the treaty deadline, he told the committee. Ronald F. Lehman II, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said the United States is also still trying to find out how some Soviet SS-23 intermediate-range missiles were transferred to Warsaw Pact countries and eluded initial detection by U.S. treaty negotiators. ``We have to establish ownership _ whose are they?'' Lehman said. ``And are there warheads for these missiles controlled by the Soviet Union? There's not an obvious picture yet.'' East Germany has invited U.S. inspectors to inspect the missiles in question, and information also has been received from Bulgaria, he said. Although the missiles are capable of carrying nuclear warheads, the countries involved have said they carry only conventional armaments, Lehman said. Lehman also acknowledged that satellite photos have picked up ``SS-4-related equipment at an undeclared site'' which could violate the missile treaty. ``It depends what was operationally deployed at the time of the treaty,'' Lehman said. ``We can't say that in and of itself it is inconsistent with the treaty. We have to find out the facts.''

DOC.HEAD: Iran's President Assails U.S. Response in Hostages' Release
LaserPhoto BX8
DOC.TEXT: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran said Thursday the groups holding hostages in Lebanon released two Americans at Iran's prodding, but that the United States was still acting like a spoiled child. He also said Iran is not restoring diplomatic ties with the United States. Robert Polhill, 55, of New York, was freed April 22 and eight days later a second U.S. educator held hostage, Frank Reed, 57, of Malden, Mass., was freed. Rafsanjani said the kidnappers released the two ``at our suggestion. They could have ... rejected our advice. But they accepted our advice.'' In his speech to a group of teachers in Tehran, Iran's capital, Rafsanjani compared the U.S. response to that of ``a stubborn, frustrated child.'' The speech was carried by Tehran Radio and monitored in Nicosia. President Bush told a news conference in Washington Thursday he was cheered by the release of Polhill and Reed, but was unwilling to make any conciliatory gestures toward Iran at this time. Bush has repeatedly declared he will not negotiate with Iran or the Lebanese Shiite Moslem kidnappers for the release of hostages. But he did promise to help Iran get details on the fate of four Iranian diplomats kidnapped in Lebanon in 1982, calling it a goodwill gesture and not an attempt to bargain for U.S. hostages. ``This is something they feel very strongly about,'' Bush said. ``They've mentioned it to us several different times.'' Sixteen Westerners, including six Americans, are missing in Lebanon. Most are believed held by groups controlled by Hezbollah, the Iranian-financed Party of God. Longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, kidnapped March 16, 1985. In London, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Thursday welcomed Syria's and Iran's role in gaining freedom for Polhill and Reed, but said Britain will not deal with hostage-takers. She is under pressure to secure the release of British hostages in Lebanon. Three Britons and an Irishman with dual British and Irish citizenship are held, including Terry Waite, special envoy of Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie. Rafsanjani said Thursday that ``an angry, revolutionary, enraged group, after it released one hostage without pre-conditions, and was confronted with America's irresponsible reaction, should reasonably have taken revenge. ``But they still showed decency and showed their extreme goodwill'' by freeing Reed as well. ``American bullies, instead of being impressed by the move, reiterated their previous stance.'' Rafsanjani acknowledged that Bush expressed appreciation publicly to Iran and Syria for their role, but said his administration ``on the other hand ... started a vile propaganda move, stating `We will not normalize ties until Iran releases all hostages.''' Rafsanjani said Iran was not interested in restoring relations and denied Western press reports that Tehran helped secure the two recent releases because it needs to resume diplomatic ties with the United States. ``Iran does not want relations with the United States, and we welcomed severing ties,'' he said. ``We are not prepared to talk to America.'' A dispatch Thursday from Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said arbitration talks between America and Iran in the Netherlands were focusing only on legal issues. The two sides have been working for nine years to settle financial disputes stemming from the 1979 Islamic revolution. IRNA said a statement from the delegation stressed that ``no other topics, either political or economic, have been or will be discussed.'' Rafsanjani's comments Thursday appeared to rule out a possible dialogue with the United States to end 11 years of hostility. But they also indicated that Rafsanjani, leader of those seeking broader contacts for Iran, was under mounting pressure from anti-Westerners angered at Iran's role in the release of the two Americans. Rafsanjani praised the groups in Lebanon for taking the initiative on the releases and castigated Washington, saying, ``Instead of giving an appropriate reward for this initiative, the U.S. reacted by saying it will not negotiate with kidnappers, as if Israel and the (Lebanese) Phalangists are not kidnappers.'' He was referring to Arabs held by Israel, including Hezbollah leader Sheik Abdul-Karim Obeid, who was seized in Lebanon on July 28. Lebanese Christian militiamen, the armed wing of the Phalangist Party, seized the four missing Iranians in July 1982. In Wiesbaden, West Germany, U.S. military officials said Reed will head home Friday after spending Thursday undergoing further debriefings by a special team seeking clues about other Westerner hostages. Reed's daughter by an earlier marriage, Marilyn Langston, said in Malden Thursday that during his 43 months in captivity, Reed was told his mother had died and did not learn she was alive until he was released this week. Reed's mother, 91-year-old Leota Sprague, shares an apartment in Malden with Reed's wife, Fahima, and the couple's 9-year-old son, Tarek.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Health Costs Up by 10 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The nation spent nearly $540 billion on health in 1988, a 10.4 percent increase over 1987, the Department of Health and Human Services said Thursday. The statistics, the most recent available, show a return to a double-digit growth rate after smaller increases in 1986 and 1987, said HHS Secretary Louis Sullivan. Health expenditures, he said, have been growing faster than the economy for many years and will strain the ability of Americans to pay for quality care. The report by the agency's Health Care Financing Administration said the dollar amount spent on health care in 1988 was 117 percent greater than the sum spent in 1980. Per capita spending increased 100 percent from 1980 to 1988. Among the other statistics in the HHS report: _National health expenditures accounted for 11.1 percent of the gross national product in 1988, up from 9.1 percent in 1980. _Personal health expenditures, the lion's share of health spending, increased 10 percent in 1988. _General economic inflation accounted for less than half the increase in personal health spending. Medical price inflation was responsible for about a quarter of the increase. Other factors, including population changes, volume of services and use of high-tech services accounted for the rest of the increase. _The federal government financed 30 percent of personal health spending, mainly through its Medicare and Medicaid programs. State and local governments contributed another 11 percent; private health insurance financed 32 percent; and patients paid directly for 24 percent. _National spending on physician services increased 13.1 percent. Spending on hospital services was up 9.3 percent. _Of each dollar spent on health care, 39 cents went to hospitals and 19 cents went to physicians. Nursing homes received 8 cents per dollar.

DOC.HEAD: Gerald Arpino Resigns From Joffrey Ballet
DOC.TEXT: Gerald Arpino has resigned as artistic director of the Joffrey Ballet, and has withdrawn his works and those of the company's founder from the Joffrey's repertory. However, Arpino will continue as artistic director of the company's ballet school, the school's director said Thursday. ``The resignation of Gerald Arpino as artistic director of the Joffrey Ballet in no way affects the Joffrey Ballet School,'' director Edith D'Addario said. ``The school is an independent organization and Mr. Arpino is still and will remain the artistic director of the Joffrey Ballet School.'' Arpino, who became artistic director of the ballet company in 1988 after the death of founder Robert Joffrey, resigned Tuesday after the Joffrey board of directors voted to set up an operating committee that would run the company in place of both Arpino and the 55-member board. Ten board members resigned in protest at what one called a takeover by businessmen ignorant of artistic matters. Arpino has been a dancer and choreographer with the modern ballet company since its early days in the mid-1950s. However, critics and dance buffs alike have often called his works pedestrian instead of inspired, and without structure, purpose or artistry. With the exception of such works as ``Sea Shadow'' (1962) and ``Viva Vivaldi'' (1965), Arpino is considered a second-rate choreographer who merely moves dancers around a stage. In a statement released when he resigned, Arpino said, ``I refuse to participate in an organization which I believe has lost its moral and ethical foundation.'' He further said the Joffrey may no longer use works that belong to him or to Robert Joffrey's estate. The Joffrey, like many dance companies, has financial problems. Based in New York and Los Angeles, it faces a deficit of about $2 million. David H. Murdock, co-chairman of the Joffrey with Anthony A. Bliss, has agreed to close the deficit with gifts, loans and fund-raising over three years, The New York Times said. The board believed his assistance was conditioned on the new operating committee being established, a board member told the newspaper. Ruth Houghton, a board member for 23 years, was among those who quit in protest. ``These are businessmen who don't know about artistic things,'' she said. ``The thing they don't realize is that with Jerry gone, all the major, big, heavy contributors who kept the company going for years are gone.'' Bliss defended the move, saying the large board paralyzed the company as it grappled with a financial crisis. ``Right now, we've got an emergency, and we've got to put this through to save the company,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bushes Visit Wake for Baptist Minister
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, attended a wake Thursday for the Rev. Henry C. Gregory III, a Washington pastor whom Bush called ``an outstanding leader.'' Gregory, who died Sunday, was a minister at Shiloh Baptist Church. The Bushes spent about 15 minutes with other mourners at the church near the White House. Bush said in a statement that Gregory saw his church as a vehicle to help the unemployed, the hungry and the homeless. ``We commend his spiritual leadership and are proud to have known him. He was an outstanding leader and he will be missed,'' the president said.

DOC.HEAD: Newborn Kidnapped by Woman Posing as Diaper Saleswoman
DOC.TEXT: Police searched Thursday for a 13-day-old baby kidnapped from a shopping center by a woman posing as a saleswoman for a disposable diaper company. ``I want my baby back. I want to know how he is,'' said Migdalia Cortes de Canales, 19, in an interview with The San Juan Star, an English-language daily. ``I'm desperate.'' Her newborn son, Carlos Luis Canales, was abducted Tuesday by a woman posing as a Pampers sales representative at a shopping mall in suburban Carolina, police said. The woman told the couple the children had won a contest to be in a commercial, she said. ``She said they (the Pampers company) would supply diapers, clothing for the children and that they would even pay us for letting them appear in the commercials. We are in financial need,'' the baby's father, Luis Felix Canales, 20, told the newspaper. The couple have two other children, Luann, 3, and Luis, 1. Police spokesman Tony Santiago said Thursday detectives were checking tips from dozens of callers after the FBI circulated a composite sketch of the woman, believed to be in her 40s. The couple said the woman went to their home April 27, took down their names and said their children had won a contest and would be photographed Tuesday at the shopping center. They said the woman drove them to the mall Tuesday and while the parents prepared the children to be photographed, she offered to hold the crying infant in a waiting area. ``After 20 minutes, we realized she had left with the baby,'' the newspaper quoted Mrs. Canales as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Armed Services Committee Seeks to Cut Pentagon Paperwork
DOC.TEXT: Leading members of the House Armed Services Committee introduced legislation Thursday to reduce the number of reports the Pentagon is required to send the panel. ``Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has long complained that Congress makes the Pentagon write too many reports,'' said committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis. ``We found out that what Dick Cheney is saying is right.'' Under the legislation, Aspin and Rep. William Dickinson of Alabama, ranking Republican on the committee, will track the number of one-time and repetitive reports requested by lawmakers on the panel. Aspin and Dickinson would then review and decide on the requests. According to their calculations, the legislation would kill 59 of the 211 recurring reports the department is required to submit to Congress. The committee last year requested 133 reports and the Senate Armed Services Committee asked for 76 reports. After the two panels negotiated on the final defense budget, another 308 reports were requested. The bill ``will drive a stake through the heart of one quarter of all the reports that the Pentagon has been required to send us,'' Aspin said. Joining in support of the legislation were Reps. Nicholas Mavroules, D-Mass., and Larry Hopkins, R-Ky., ranking members of the House Armed Services subcommittee on investigations.

DOC.HEAD: Ceausescu Son to Go on Trial; Demonstrations Continue
DOC.TEXT: Nicu Ceausescu, son of executed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, will go on trial this month on charges that include genocide, the government said Thursday. Meanwhile, the Romanian government said it would not break up 12-day-old demonstrations in the capital, but it also ruled out talks with the protesters. The younger Ceausescu will face a military tribunal May 26, said Teofil Pop, a spokesman for the justice minister. The tribunal was to convene in the central city of Sibiu, in the region where Nicu Ceausescu was Communist Party chief. The charges are ``genocide and violation of arms and munitions regulations,'' Pop said. Nicu Ceausescu will be the second member of his family to go on trial since the December's toppling and execution of the elder Ceausescu and his wife, Elena. The late leader's brother, Lt. Gen. Nicolae Andruta Ceausescu, is being tried in Bucharest for allegedly shooting to death seven demonstrators Dec. 22. He was the commander of the secret police academy. Since April 22, crowds of up to 10,000 have been rallying in Bucharest, focusing their anger on interim President Ion Iliescu, who they accuse of trying to maintain the old totalitarian order. The protest organizers have expressed fears of a police crackdown. But Vice Prime Minister Gelu Voican-Voiculescu told reporters at government headquarters Thursday that no such action would be ordered, even if the protest continues until the May 20 election. By Thursday evening, about 2,500 demonstrators had gathered in University Square in central Bucharest, waving signs demanding Iliescu's resignation. State television showed another anti-Iliescu protest in Timisoara, a revolution flashpoint and about 250 miles west of the capital. At a Wednesday press conference, organizers of the Bucharest rally demanded the government negotiate with them on their call to bar ex-Communists from politics and the election. The demand would affect Iliescu and many others in his National Salvation Front. The Front, which has dominated the government since Ceausescu was overthrown, is generally favored to win the election. Voican-Voiculescu charged that the demonstrators are being funded and fed by ``forces who want to destablize society.'' He singled out the National Peasant Party, one of five opposition parties threatening to boycott the May 20 elections. However, the vice prime minister acknowledged he had no proof of the party's involvement. Voican-Voiculescu, who directed the trial of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu, also disclosed when they were captured late Dec. 22, he argued they should be killed immediately. He said, however, that he was overruled by Iliescu. He also acknowledged that ``mistakes were made'' in the summary trial of the Ceausescus, which was widely criticized internationally. ``In particular, the defense attorney was transformed into a prosecutor,'' Voican-Voiculescu said. The two were executed on Christmas Day for ``grave crimes'' during Ceausescu's authoritarian rule, which began in 1965.

DOC.HEAD: Worst Rain since 1922 Causes Floods, Evacuations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Berneice cq in 19th graf
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic; LaserPhoto XEUF1
DOC.TEXT: The worst rain in decades drenched Texas on Thursday, chasing hundreds from flooded homes around Dallas and Fort Worth, closing highways and sending lakes surging over their dams. Eight people were injured when a tornado ripped through Paris in northeast Texas, demolishing a nightclub, flipping vehicles, uprooting trees and tearing up roofs. Flooding also was widespread in Oklahoma and Arkansas. Three people have been killed by rains that have lashed Texas since Tuesday. The recent storms added to woes that have been mounting for weeks as Texans slopped through the wettest spring since 1922. The rain eased a bit Thursday, but forecasters warned the worst was still ahead as rivers swelled, dams spilled over and rising floodwaters threatened more property damage. Vice President Dan Quayle, in town to stump for Republican state candidates, toured a hard-hit neighborhood in south Dallas and promised distraught residents that federal aid would be expedited. ``I've come by to say hello and let you know that we're trying to pull everything together, to cope with it as best we can,'' Quayle told residents who sought refuge at the Rhoads Terrace Recreation Center. ``It's tough. We're all sad.'' Water covered roads in almost every county in the path of the storm Thursday, including U.S. 175, a major Dallas freeway, which was closed during the morning rush-hour. The west fork of the Trinity River, which flows through Fort Worth and Dallas, remained more than 6 feet over flood stage and rising in the late afternoon. Floodwaters drove scores from their homes in the Trinity River drainage between south Dallas to Grand Prairie, and some had to be rescued by boat and helicopter. Thirty families were left temporarily homeless in Grand Prairie, where water was up to the roofs of houses. ``Right now, we're getting people off of rooftops and people who refused to leave earlier,'' said Dallas Fire Department spokeswoman Carolyn Garcia. Some neighborhoods were awash in up to six feet of water, she said. North-central Texas was drenched with 22.06 inches of rain in the first four months of this year, the worst since the 22.84 inches recorded in 1922, said Ed Delgado of the National Weather Service. Up to seven inches of rain fell in the first few days of May in some spots. Texoma Lake on the Texas-Oklahoma border north of Dallas overflowed its emergency spillway late Wednesday for the first time since 1957 and remained a foot above the spillway level Thursday afternoon. At least 100 people on the Oklahoma side of the state line fled their homes, and 200 were evacuated from below Comanche Dam in Stephens County in south-central Oklahoma. In northwest Arkansas, flood warnings were posted in 10 counties and some people left their homes for high ground. A 5-year-old boy was in critical condition after being rescued from the rain-swollen War Eagle River in the state's northwest corner Thursday, along with two adults who tried unsuccessfully to rescue him. In Paris, five of the eight injured people were in a nightclub destroyed by the twister. Their injuries were minor, said Dick Boots of the Paris emergency office. Tornadoes caused minor damage around Wylie and Denison north of Dallas. About 20 patients were evacuated without harm from the Terrell Care Center east of Dallas after a storm blew part of the roof off about 2:30 a.m., said administrator Berneice Hill. Fire crews evacuated 155 people from a nursing home and hospital in Haltom City north of Fort Worth Wednesday night when the Big Fossil and Little Fossil creeks overflowed their banks and came within inches of entering the hospital. The patients from Haltom Convalescent Center and nearby Twin Oaks Medical Center spent the night at a Baptist church. Ranchers downstream were warned to get their cattle away from the runoff filling the Red River. The clouds had a silver lining for Bill Owens, a construction worker from Forney, who took advantage of the high water to do some fishing. ``It's the best time to catch them,'' Owens said. ``I couldn't work anyway because of the weather.''

DOC.HEAD: NOAA Allows Dolphin-Swimmer Program To Continue On Experimental Basis
DOC.TEXT: Four marine shows that allow human swimmers to frolic with dolphins will be allowed to continue on an experimental basis, a federal agency announced Thursday. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administrations said it would allow the ``Swim-with-the-Dolphin'' program to continue until the end of 1991, but only at the four locations where such programs now exist. ``No new permits, however, will be issued to other locations at this time and no additional dolphins may be captured for use in these programs,'' the announcement said. Federal officials said the programs must follow new conditions and will be closely monitored. The announcement said that the National Marine Fisheries Service, a part of NOAA, investigated the dolphin-swimmer programs. The agency found ``no physical evidence that the dolphins involved in these programs have suffered more health problems than dolphins which are used for public display in aquaria habitats.'' Three of the dolphin programs are in Florida and the fourth is in Hawaii. NOAA made the ruling after environmental groups expressed concern about the health and safety of dolphins in the swim programs. The marine fisheries service said it received hundreds of letters about the dolphin-swimmer program during the last six months. Officials said the swim-with-the-dolphin programs will be allowed to continue on an experimental basis so more information can be obtained on the well-being of dolphins participating. Based on this information, the programs may be extended beyond 1991, or discontinued. The marine fisheries service said it will closely monitor the programs to assure that new conditions imposed are followed. The new conditions include assuring that dolphins are given additional rest periods; provisions for additional security; a means for the dolphins to escape from the swimming public, and that no more than two human swimmers per dolphin will be permitted in the water at the same time. Also, the new conditions require the training for program staff members and forbid any participant to hold, pull or grab the dolphins.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Bid Aloha to Kalapana as Lava Surges Toward Town
DOC.TEXT: People bid aloha to Kalapana on Thursday as the town was sealed off because of imminent danger from Kilauea Volcano's surging sea of lava. Workers were preparing to move the historic Star of the Sea Church to safer ground. The Kalapana Store and Drive-In cleaned off its shelves and stopped serving hot foods after being ordered to close. The lava flow was headed in a direct path toward the center of town, advancing to within 125 yards of the store and within 250 yards of the church. One home burned early Thursday, bringing to 130 the number destroyed since Kilauea Volcano started its present eruption Jan. 3, 1983. Several more were expected to fall Thursday, civil defense officials said. George Hook, owner of the construction company that is relocating the church for free, said two 20-ton hydraulic lifts would be used to hoist the termite-ridden structure onto a flatbed truck. The church will be taken to a clearing where other relocated homes are being stored, said Sister Mary Helen, who was trying to organize a church service somewhere near the church before it's moved. ``We want to bring it to a closure,'' she said. ``Right now it is a community coming to death.'' Across the street, the Kalapana Mauna Kea Congregational Church awaits its fate. Church members voted against moving long before the flow arrived in this lava-prone area. ``If we moved it, it would defeat the whole purpose of our Christian faith,'' said church moderator Bernice McKeague. ``There is a whole history to it, but a church is not a building. It's the people.'' The church had planned a final service for Thursday night, but that was cancelled by the 6 p.m. evacuation order. The church, originally built in 1823, was first destroyed by an earthquake, lava flow and tidal wave in 1868. It used to stand on the site where Star of the Sea Church is, but moved across the road in the early 1900s, McKeague said. Store owner Walter Yamaguchi, 82, who built his drive-in restaurant in 1963 and his grocery store 11 years later, walked around and said he would be back. ``I leave it up to Madame Pele (the volcano goddess),'' he said. ``She will stop.'' Mary Dressler said she had stopped at Yamaguchi's store nearly every day of the 15 years she lived in Kalapana Gardens subdivision to talk with him. ``We shared a lot of good times. It's real sad,'' she said after going up to Yamaguchi and hugging him. ``I love you,'' she said. Jim Halpin, who lived in Kalapana for six years, said he would move back as soon as officials let people return, something that could take years because the lava has to cool. He stopped at Yamaguchi's store to say goodbye, too. ``Walter's like everybody's uncle,'' he said. ``I came to say goodbye and get that last container of chocolate milk.''

DOC.HEAD: Radio Ship May Seek to Dock in Hong Kong Despite Official Bar
DOC.TEXT: Operators of the Goddess of Democracy said Thursday the radio ship may seek on humanitarian grounds to dock in Hong Kong, but officials of the British colony say it is not welcome. The governor of the British colony said the ship, which plans to broadcast news, music and pro-democracy reports to China from international waters off Taiwan, would be refused entry. Christine Dupont, spokeswoman for the Paris-based Boat for China Foundation, said Thursday that the project's directors were discussing their next move. Already rejected by suppliers in Taiwan, the ship was seeking permission from Hong Kong to take on a transmitter, food, fuel and water, organizers said. The converted trawler sailed for Hong Kong on Thursday, and was expected to arrive in two weeks. ``It has been made quite clear to the organizers (of the ship) for a very long time that they would not be welcome in Hong Kong,'' Governor David Wilson told reporters on Thursday. However, Dupont said the ship might seek to dock in Hong Kong anyway. ``It's our understanding that the law of the sea doesn't permit anyone to turn away a ship in need of reprovisioning or fuel,'' she said. ``To refuse assistance goes against international law.'' The vessel left France on March 17 and arrived in Singapore on Wednesday. It is named after a statue erected by pro-democracy students in Beijing's Tiananmen Square last spring before the bloody military suppression of their movement in June, when troops killed hundreds of unarmed civilians. Wilson said he did not want Hong Kong ``used as a battlefield for other people's political battles,'' adding: ``It would be quite inconsistent with that policy to have a ship of that sort coming into Hong Kong.'' Hong Kong reverts to Chinese sovereignty in 1997 and is very sensitive about relations with Beijing, which has issued warnings about helping the 1,200-ton ship. China's Communist leaders, who called in the military for a deadly crackdown on the pro-democracy movement last June, have refused to rule out the use of force to stop the ship's plans to broadcast pro-democracy reports from international waters near Taiwan. Any attempt by the ship to enter the port of Hong Kong could be dangerous because it is surrounded by Chinese territorial waters. If Hong Kong remains closed, it is not clear if the ship would then seek to follow the original plans and dock in the northern Taiwan port of Keelung to take on provisions. Although the Nationalist Chinese government of Taiwan is Beijing's bitter enemy, relations between the two sides have been warming in recent years and some Taiwan officials are reluctant to increase tension by assisting the ship. The Goddess of Democracy is carrying a crew of 10 French as well as several journalists who boarded in Singapore. French journalist Christophe Nick, vice president of the Boat for China Foundation and the ship's spokesman, said the vessel will reach Hong Kong in about 15 days. ``We plan to broadcast from May 23, programs in Tibetan, translated into Chinese language, because the Chinese army entered Tibet on that day in 1951,'' he said. He said funds for the project were obtained from 19 magazines and from Chinese people in Macao, Hong Kong and other areas.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Will Test Stamp Sales at ATMs
DOC.TEXT: Polyester postage stamps will be sold through automatic teller machines at banks in a six-month test beginning May 18 in Seattle, the Postal Service announced Thursday. Spokesman Art Shealy said the stamps will be test-marketed in a joint venture by the Postal Service and Seafirst bank, first at about 15 Seattle locations and then at other Seafirst branches in Washington state. Shealy said the sheets of stamps were designed to be like currency so that they could be dispensed the same way cash is dispensed through the machines. He said the sheets, each with a dozen 25-cent stamps, would cost $3 apiece, debited against the customer's bank account. The stamp is designed to be self-adhesive, requiring no licking, Shealy said. ``We think it answers quite a large portion of the public's request for a more convenient stamp,'' he said. ``It is humidity-resistant so they don't stick together. It is really a stamp of the future.'' If the Seattle test is a success, Shealy said, the stamps will be tried out nationwide in the spring of 1991. The Postal Service already sells stamps through supermarkets and other types of store and Shealy said selling them through automatic teller machines ``basically is an electromechanical version'' of this system. ``We think it is something that our customers want because it will enable them to buy their stamps while they are getting cash for the weekend without needing to stand in line at a Post Office,'' he said. He said some surveys showed as many as half of the people standing in Post Office lines early in the morning, around noon or in the afternoon were there simply to buy stamps. He said the Postal Service had increased the number of its automatic vending machines, and also sells stamps by mail and takes orders for them over the telephone. The automatic teller machines will provide customers with another option, he said. The Postal Service has ordered a run of two million stamps for the test, the spokesman said. He said the stamps are not biodegradable but might be in the future. ``When the stamp comes out for full national distribution we will probably, if the technology exists and if the stamp will hold up, consider a biodegradable product,'' he said. ``In fact, we are looking to the industry and encouraging them to come out with that product.''

DOC.HEAD: Pastors Pray For Rain at State Capitol
With AM-Storms, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A few sprinkles of rain fell shortly after more than 100 people gathered Thursday at the Capitol to pray for an end to the drought. But state officials said North Dakota needs more than that as it braces for a third straight year of parched pastures and shrinking lakes. Gov. George Sinner declared the state a drought disaster area last week. State officials say that even if rain comes soon, it will still take several years for the soil and waterways to regain their normal supply of moisture. Eight pastors took part in Thursday's hourlong interdenominational service of prayer, song and Bible reading. Lt. Gov. Lloyd Omdahl and former Gov. Art Link also spoke. ``We're here with a common faith in God and so we are here to make a request on behalf of our state, on behalf of the people who are suffering under a drought,'' Omdahl said. ``Father, our land is desolate and unproductive in its present condition. It cannot produce an abundant harvest,'' said the Rev. Dom Vetter of the Victory Family Bible Church in Bismarck. ``We are in need of you to heal our land. ``Today we come boldly to your throne of grace. The Word says we can ask you for rain in the springtime. Therefore, Father, we ask you to send the storm clouds, send thunder, send the lightning and the rain upon our state,'' he said. About 45 minutes after the service ended, a light rain began and lasted about 2 minutes, after which the sky cleared. The governor was in Washington to seek federal money for the Garrison Diversion Project, a $1 billion effort to divert Missouri River water for cities and rural water systems. Thursday's gathering is to be followed Sunday by a traditional Indian rain dance at Fort Abraham Lincoln State Park near Mandan.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Says Human Rights Abuses Continue in Kenya
DOC.TEXT: Human rights continue to be restricted in Kenya, the State Department told Congress in an exchange of letters made public Thursday. ``We shall continue to raise these issues with the Kenyan authorities and press for positive action,'' said Assistant Secretary Janet G. Mullins in a letter released by the office of Rep. Gus Yatron, D-Pa., chairman of the House human rights subcommittee. The last year brought to Kenya ``an even further erosion in respect for civil liberties and political rights,'' the department said, quoting from its 1989 report on human rights around the world. At the time Kenyan President Daniel Arap Moi visited Washington three months ago, Yatron had sent letters to the State Department and to Kenyan Ambassador Denis D. Afande expressing concern ``over reports of troubling developments'' in Kenya. He mentioned reported forced repatriation, beatings, attacks and threats against Kenyans of Somali origin, constitutional amendments weakening the tenure of judges, restrictions on the Daily Nation newspaper, other pressures against journalists and a ``shoot to kill'' policy against poachers and bandits. The State Department said it shared Yatron's concern about judicial tenure because ``we hold an independent judiciary central to the definition and protection of human rights.'' Kenya's constitutional amendment ``allowing for two weeks of detention for capital offenses and the actions taken by the government to restrict the press are troubling,'' Ms. Mullins added in her letter to Yatron. ``With regard to the deportation of Somali refugees, a positive development in this crisis has been the Kenyan government's allowal of both the U.N. high commissioner for refugees and the Red Cross to travel in the area,'' it added.

DOC.HEAD: Greater Political Freedom for Federal Workers Advances
DOC.TEXT: The Senate moved Thursday toward allowing the nation's 3 million federal civil service and postal workers to participate more in party politics despite a threatened veto by President Bush. On a 67-30 vote, Democrats defeated an amendment by Senate Republicans aimed at derailing a bill to remove most of the restrictions on political activities by federal employees imposed by the 1939 Hatch Act. The Democratic bill would revise the law to lift prohibitions that bar federal civil service employees from holding office in political parties, working in campaigns or soliciting campaign dollars from fellow workers. However, it would continue prohibitions on federal workers running for public office, soliciting campaign funds from the general public or engaging in political activities while on the job. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called the current restrictions ``illogical and unnecessary.'' ``Federal employees have been denied many of the basic rights of freedom of expressing and action enjoyed by millions of other American citizens,'' he said, citing prohibitions against participating in phone banks and other political operations. The Republican amendment by Sen. William Roth, R-Del., would have substituted the proposed changes with an order directing the Office of Personnel Management to ``simplify and clarify'' what Roth acknowledged are confusing regulations under the law. Roth said the bill would ``risk a return to the spoils system'' because civil service workers would feel compelled in the competition for promotions and pay raises to ``exercise their new political rights ... to please their politically appointed superior.'' The House approved similar but broader legislation on a 297-90 vote more than a year ago. Its bill also would allow federal employees to seek and hold political offices and solicit campaign funds from the public. Congress passed nearly identical legislation in 1976, but it was vetoed by then-President Gerald Ford, who contended it would politicize the civil service because workers would ``inevitably feel compelled to engage in partisan political activities. The Bush administration makes the same contention. Officials in the Justice Department, the Office of Personnel Management and White House Budget Office all said they would urge President Bush to veto any change in the current law, saying it would ``undermine th integrity and independence of the traditionally non-partisan civil service.'' The original Hatch Act was passed during the New Deal era in response to overzealous political appointees of President Franklin D. Roosevelt requiring enrollees in the Works Progress Administration to contribute to the 1938 re-election campaign of then Democratic Sen. Alben Barkley of Kentucky.

DOC.HEAD: Storms Bring Floods to Texas, Hail in Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms lashed Texas and the nation's midsection Thursday with floods, hail and an occasional tornado, and stubborn winter clung to the mountains of eastern Arizona and southern Colorado. Gentler rains fell from New Jersey south to Virginia ahead of a line of thunderstorms advancing northeast from Texas. Flooding continued Thursday in north-central Texas, which has recorded its wettest spring since 1922. Hundreds of people were forced from their homes in Texas, southern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. A tornado injured eight people in Paris, Texas. The storms have killed three Texans since Tuesday. The same storm front reached north and east through Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Ohio and Indiana, where it produced marble-sized hail in Bartholomew and golf-ball-sized hail in Plainville. Among the spots reporting serious flooding Thursday were the Trinity River in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, the Sabine river in east Texas, the Blue River in southern Oklahoma and the Red River along the Texas-Oklahoma line. A flash flood watch was posted Thursday night for all of Arkansas except the extreme southeast portions. The western part of the state has been belted by 7 to 10 inches of rain in the past two days. West Tennessee also was under a flash flood watch overnight for an area between the Mississippi River and the Tennessee River, which includes Memphis. Late winter snow fell Thursday in the White Mountains in eastern Arizona, across the higher spots in southeastern Colorado and into western Kansas. At dawn, snow was a foot deep at La Junta, Rye and Trinidad, Colo. The overnight accumulation in Pueblo, Colo., pushed that city's total to 66 inches for the winter, slightly more than the record set in the 1947-48 season. On Friday the storms that plagued the southern Plains was forecast to shift east along a band reaching from the southern tip of Texas north and east to Lake Erie. Elsewhere, rain was forecast in the Northeast, lighter showers across Michigan, Ohio and Illinois, and partly cloudy weather in the Southeast, Plains and Northwest. Sunny skies and temperatures in the 80s and 90s were forecast for Florida, southern Georgia and the hottest parts of the desert Southwest. Heavier rainfall during the 6 hours ending at 3 p.m. EDT Thursday included 1{ inches Bryan and College Station, Texas, 1 inch at Hill City, Kan., and } inch at Belleview, Ill. The low temperature in the Lower 48 on Thursday 24 degrees at Park Falls, Wis., Pellston, Mich. and Houlton, Maine.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Arrests Two Texans as Drug Traffickers
DOC.TEXT: Mexican agents arrested two Texas men and three Mexicans and seized a light airplane to break a marijuana supply line that ran from the northern state of Chihuahua to Texas, the attorney general's office said Thursday. It said in a statement that Ronald Milanese and John Bannon were arrested on suspicion of drug trafficking in a predawn raid Wednesday at a hotel in Ciudad Juarez, a city of 1 million cross the Rio Grande from El Paso, Texas. Their hometowns and ages were not available. Earlier, two Mexican men held in Chihuahua city for drug trafficking told officials that the Americans promised to buy a load of marijuana from them, the government said. Chihuahua is 225 miles south of El Paso. Federal anti-narcotics police seized a Cessna 206 at Ciudad Juarez Airport, authorities said. They said Milanese and Bannon planned to use the aircraft to haul marijuana from a clandestine airstrip near Jimenez, 125 miles southeast of Chihuahua, to Van Horn, Texas, 125 miles southeast of El Paso. Police found and destroyed the airstrip, seizing 1,100 pounds of marijuana and 52 gallons of airplane fuel stored in a cave nearby, the statement said. It said agents also arrested an armed man who guarded the place. The government said Ismael Segura Prieto and Armando Rodolfo Vargas Buendia were arrested at a gas station in Chihuahua while en route to meet Milanese and Bannon, and that they gave police information leading to the Americans' arrest. Officers seized Segura Prieto's house in Chihuahua and two unlicensed vehicles he had. All five men are in jail in Chihuahua city, the government said.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Returns `Scud' Missiles to Soviets
DOC.TEXT: East Germany said Thursday that it has returned to the Soviet Union the ``Scud B'' shorter-range nuclear arsenals stationed on East German soil. East Germany's news agency, ADN, said the rockets were returned to the Soviet Union last month. ADN said the action was taken in line with a decision made by the East German government in January. According to the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, a total of 28 ``Scud B'' launchers were stationed in East Germany. The ``Scud B'' has about twice the range as the U.S. Lance missile, which the United States on Thursday announced it would not be modernizing as planned. The ``Scud B'' has a range of up to 185 miles. Short-range nuclear missiles similar to the Lance _ with a range of up to 93 miles _ remain in East Germany. According to NATO, the Soviets have hundreds of short-range nuclear missiles spread across the Warsaw Pact countries and thousands of nuclear artillery pieces.

DOC.HEAD: Scary Show, No Go, Decides 3-Year-Old
DOC.TEXT: A Springfield, Ill., pediatrician reports in a medical journal that one of his patients was scared into constipation by a televison commercial that showed a toilet turning into a biting monster. Dr. Virgilio R. Pilapil, writing in the April issue of Pediatrics, said a 3-year-old boy was brought to his office for treatment of constipation after the youngster refused to use the family bathroom at home. The child's functions had all been normal throughout his short life and he had been thoroughly toilet trained for six months, the doctor said. But then the boy started refusing to move his bowels and eventually would do so only in a diaper while standing up. And he refused to say why the sudden change in habits. ``Finally,'' Pilapil writes, ``he gave in to his mother's constant asking and told her that he had seen a television commercial ... in which a toilet bowl was portrayed as turning into a monster, with the seat cover making a chomping movement. ``This image scared him from again sitting on the toilet,'' the doctor wrote. ``He feared it `would get him.' '' Pilapil said the patient is now being encouraged to use the toilet and ``the family is having some success, although not consistently.''

DOC.HEAD: Cartel Agrees To Cut Output, But Prices Fall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Longer version on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: OPEC ministers unanimously agreed Thursday to cut the cartel's total crude output by 1.45 million barrels a day to help maintain oil prices at a minimum of $18 a barrel. But oil prices fell quickly and sharply amid skepticism that the cut would actually materialize. Analysts noted that even if OPEC succeeded, the action wouldn't be enough to solve the current oil glut problem. ``OPEC won't manage to cut production that much,'' said Geoff Pyne, an analyst with the London investment firm UBS Phillips and Drew. ``It might only be between 500,000 and 1 million barrels a day.'' Peter Nicol, an oil analyst with the London investment firm Warburg Securities, noted that although members ``sound serious about trying to cut production to boost oil prices ... they face a difficult task because the market is really awash at the moment.'' North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude oil, fell 55 cents in London late Thursday to $15.90 a barrel. The June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, fell 69 cents to settle at $17.99 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Although all 13 members will reduce their crude production, OPEC President Sadek Boussena said the cartel's chronic quota violators would contribute most to the cutback by returning to their official ceilings for the first half of the year. The United Arab Emirates, which analysts say is a repeated cheater, agreed to cut its output by 200,000 barrels a day, Boussena said. The agreement, reached on the second day of an emergency session, will be in effect until the end of July. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries postponed its regular midyear session for a month to July 25, when it will decide its output and pricing policy for the rest of the year, he said. OPEC pumped 23.5 million barrels a day in April, Boussena said; the cartel's official ceiling is 22.1 million barrels. ``For the time being, we decided to have a freeze-time for three months,'' said Boussena, who also serves as Algeria's oil minister. He did not provide a breakdown of the agreed cutbacks. Analysts have said overproduction by Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates was responsible for the oil glut at a time when demand traditionally eases off in the second quarter. Oil prices will remain under pressure for the next two or three months, the analysts predicted. ``I think we have to wait for winter restocking and winter demand to turn things around,'' Pyne added.

DOC.HEAD: President Replaces Four Ministers in Cabinet Shakeup
DOC.TEXT: President George Vassiliou replaced four of the 10 ministers of his Cabinet on Thursday in a shakeup that had been expected for more than a month. Vassiliou was elected to a 5-year term as president in February 1988. A millionaire business consultant, he ran as an independent candidate supported by both right-wing and left-wing parties. It was his first foray into politics. Labor Minister Takis Christofides, whose resignation last month set in motion the changes, was replaced by Iacovos Aristidou, an economist and career civil servant. Christoforos Christofides, no relation to the former labor minister, takes over the ministry of education from Andreas Philippou. Christofides is a former member of Parliament. Pavlos Savvides, the managing director of a shipping company, replaces Communications and Works Minister Nakos Protopapas.
