Nicos Papaioannou, a lawyer and president of the government Environmental Council, replaces Christodoulos Chrysanthou at the Justice Ministry. Apart from the new education minister, the appointees are considered non-political technocrats, like the six holdover members of Vassiliou's Council of Ministers. Cyprus has been divided into Greek and Turkish sectors since 1975, when an autonomous Turkish Cypriot state was proclaimed following a Turkish invasion in 1974. Greece denounced the proclamation, but Turkey welcomed it.

DOC.HEAD: Mecham Headquarters Target of Arson Again
DOC.TEXT: For the second time in 24 hours, someone tried to burn down the campaign headquarters of former Gov. Evan Mecham, police said Thursday. Investigators said the second attempt took place about 1 a.m. Thursday, when an arsonist threw a burning container onto the roof of the offices. Police Lt. Randy Henderlite said the object resembled a Molotov cocktail, which is a gasoline-filled bottle with a makeshift wick attached. The first attempt _ about 3 a.m. Wednesday _ caused about $30,000 damage, mostly to the roof. Investigators said Thursday's arson caused an additional $5,000 loss. ``I don't feel too good about it,'' said Mecham, who is running for the Republican nomination for governor even though he was impeached and removed from office two years ago. He said the headquarters would remain open. In the past week, three large houses in Phoenix have been firebombed in similar attacks, but police to date have nothing to indicate they were the work of one arsonist or were linked to the attack on Mecham's offices, Henderlite said. Mecham's headquarters faces foreclosure and auction by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. May 18, unless he can work out a deal to repay a $460,000 loan on the property, records show. Among the possibilities being investigated by detectives was whether the threat of foreclosure had anything to do with the fires, Henderlite said.

DOC.HEAD: Connie Chung Program Renewed for Second Season
DOC.TEXT: CBS News' ``Saturday Night With Connie Chung'' has been renewed for a second season even though the program has fared poorly in the ratings since its premiere in September. Chung on Thursday confirmed its renewal during a lunch with TV writers held by CBS News to help promote two specials titled, ``Face To Face With Connie Chung.'' The first will be shown Monday; the second May 14. Monday's show includes interviews with actor Gene Wilder, who discusses the death of his wife, Gilda Radner, from ovarian cancer, and with talk-show star Arsenio Hall. Last fall, Chung's Saturday series drew sharp criticism for its re-creations of news stories. ``We don't have them (re-creations) on very often'' because they take a long time to produce, she said Thursday. But she defended re-creations, calling them ``a great way to tell a story when you couldn't tell it any other way.'' Although she said she didn't know if her one-hour show would return to its Saturday time slot next fall, Andrew Lack, the program's executive producer, said that ``as far as I know, we'll be back Saturday night at 10 p.m.''

DOC.HEAD: Oprah Winfrey Says She Had Premature Baby at 14, Baby Died
DOC.TEXT: Oprah Winfrey says she had a premature baby when she was 14 but that the baby died shortly after birth. In the May 6 issue of Parade magazine, the talk-show host says it greatly saddens her to confirm a published story based on an interview with her ``deeply disturbed'' half-sister, Patricia Lloyd. ``It is true that when I was 14 years old, I became pregnant,'' Winfrey said. ``The baby was born prematurely and died shortly after birth. The experience was the most emotional, confusing and traumatic of my young life. ``I had hoped that this matter could stay private until I was fully able to deal with my own deep emotions and feelings, so that I could share this experience in a way that could best help educate other young girls who are trying to cope with all the ramifications of sexual abuse.'' Winfrey, 36, also said she was distressed that any publication would pay her half-sister for the story. She described Lloyd as ``a drug-dependent, deeply disturbed individual.'' Parade did not identify the publication or when the story appeared. ``My heart goes out to my half-sister, who is obviously in a lot of pain,'' Winfrey said.

DOC.HEAD: Ivory Coast Legalizes Opposition; Togo, Sierra Leone Stay 1-Party
DOC.TEXT: Africa's longest-serving president gave in to demands for democracy Thursday but leaders of two other West African nations _ Togo and Sierra Leone _ said their countries would remain one-party states. Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, in an about-face, ordered the legalization of political parties that have applied for registration. The central committee of the president's Democratic Party had called Tuesday for such a step. Houphouet-Boigny's decision followed March protests against austerity measures and corruption that grew into violent anti-government demonstrations demanding he relinquish his 30-year monopoly on power. The Ivory Coast constitution allows opposition, but those who have tried have been harassed and their groups refused registration on technical grounds. Thursday's announcement did not say how many parties would be legalized. Togo's military government, meanwhile, spoke of ``the necessity to follow the work of nation-building in the atmosphere of union, peace and solidarity found under a single party.'' The statement came Thursday at a meeting of Cabinet ministers and political opponents. The military in Togo has twice had ousted civilian governments since the country's independence from France in 1960. Gen. Gnassingbe Eyadema seized power in 1967 and instituted a one-party state two years later. A similarly negative response to a multiparty system came from another former military man, Sierra Leone's President Joseph Momoh, who cited the constitution's establishment of a single-party system. In an interview published Thursday in the state-owned Daily Mail newspaper, Momoh said ``those who are thinking of a multiparty system have to hasten slowly.'' Another longtime leader, President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, offered reassurances Thursday that he would not reverse his surprise decision to convert the Central African nation to a multiparty system. In a message to the National Assembly, he promised political reforms announced April 24 would proceed, but warned he would not tolerate disorder. The Zairean leader, who has held absolute power since November 24, 1965, surprised the country last month by appointing a transitional government to oversee elections to install a democratic government within a year.

DOC.HEAD: Latvia Opens Legislative Session Aimed at Independence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS name Vytautas in lead graf; INSERTS 2 grafs after 16th graf, Lithuania is ... to UPDATE with rationing reported. SUBS graf 19 `In Lithuania' to CORRECT population of Lithuania to 3.8 million; minor editing thereafter to trim
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOS15
DOC.TEXT: Latvia's legislature on Thursday began debating whether to declare independence from the Soviet Union, exhorted by Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis to ``be strong and have courage.'' Landsbergis said he came to the neighboring Baltic republic ``to be with my brothers.'' He said Latvians, if they moved more slowly than Lithuania on the path to secession, would be ``trudging through a jungle.'' ``I see and feel that Latvia won't retreat from the principle of independence,'' Landsbergis said in separate remarks to Latvian Radio. Pro- and anti-independence protesters surrounded the Latvian deputies as they entered the parliament building. About 50 Soviet army officers who live in Latvia gathered with signs proclaiming, ``The People and the Army are United,'' and ``We Won't Go the Way of Lithuania.'' A few steps away, pro-independence protesters carried banners saying, ``The Soviet Army Must Go Home,'' and ``Independence for Latvia.'' Protesters carried Soviet flags or the red-and-white Latvian flag. The Latvian Supreme Soviet, or legislature, debated procedural questions. A vote on independence was likely Friday. Lawmakers from the separatist People's Front predicted they could muster the two-thirds majority need. There are 201 members of the Latvian Supreme Soviet, but only 197 will vote on independence because of four disputed seats stemming from the March election. A two-thirds majority of 132 votes is needed to pass the independence measure. A spokeswoman for the People's Front said Thursday the measure is supported by more than 140 deputies. Anatoly Gorbunov, who was re-elected president of Latvia at Thursday's session, backed independence in a nomination speech. ``I believe that the renewal of a legally sovereign nation must be accomplished,'' he said, declaring it a ``normal way of life for all the residents of Latvia.'' Gorbunov, a 48-year-old former Communist Party functionary who has shown himself skilled at negotiating with Moscow, won 153 votes out of 196 cast. He warned that the republic could not expect help from the West. ``The world, on account of 5 million Baltic people, is not going to risk what has been done in the area of arms control and by Mikhail Gorbachev,'' he said. In Washington, Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene said before a meeting with President Bush that her republic would be willing to suspend independence measures opposed by Moscow if it had Western guarantees of support for its sovereignty. Lithuania is enduring a Kremlin economic embargo imposed in response to ts independence declaration. Officials of Landsbergis' government said Thursday that shortages were beginning to hit medical supplies. The Soviet government newspaper Izvestia said Thursday that rationing is being introduced in Lithuania, with each person entitled to two kilograms (4.4 pounds) of flour, cereals, butter and sugar a month, and that a monthly limit was set on how much could be taken out of a bank account. Izvestia's report was quoted by the Soviet news agency Tass. Landsbergis told reporters he thought Latvians would eventually achieve independence by a slower, ``more difficult'' path than Lithuania. He said they were agonizing over their relationship with Moscow and appeared to be ``trudging through a jungle.'' Because of Latvia's delicate ethnic balance, the step could be less radical than Lithuania's declaration of independence March 11. In Lithuania, 80 percent of the 3.8 million people are ethnic Lithuanian, but about 54 percent of Latvia's population of 2.7 million people are Latvian. Most of the rest are ethnic Russians, many of whom oppose independence. In the past year, Latvia has followed Lithuania's lead. In December, it abolished the Communist Party's guaranteed monopoly on power; in February it condemned the 1940 act that formalized its annexation by the Soviet Union; and last month a large segment of its Communist Party broke from its Moscow-based parent. The steps followed similar Lithuanian actions. The Latvians are taking a slower approach to independence, however. One proposal calls for an undefined transition of several years before full independence. Estonia also set an undefined transition period in a declaration March 30. The Latvian proposal adopts four articles from the republic's 1922 constitution: establishing an independent and democratic republic; the historic territory of Latvia; giving power to the people; and establishing a sovereign Latvian parliament. It also recognizes the legitimacy of Soviet laws that do not contradict the republic's own law. Gorbunov said the proposal took into account talks that already have begun with Moscow. Latvia's economics minister, Janis Aboltins, told Tass it was essential that Latvia avoid economic sanctions like those brought against Lithuuania. ``The Soviet Union would painlessly do without our 1.5 percent-2 percent of the country's overall output,'' while Latvia could be hurt badly, he said. Svetlana Marushchenko of the anti-independence Interfront movement, who protested at the Supreme Soviet, warned that if Latvia declares independence ``it will doom Latvians to poverty for decades.''

DOC.HEAD: Fire Jumps Canal, Threatens 150,000-Acre Wildlife Area
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE acreage of park fire to 10,500 from 10,000; CLARIFY status of area where largest fire is burning. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `If the...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH3
DOC.TEXT: A 4-mile-wide brush fire raced through bone-dry Everglades sawgrass Thursday, jumping a canal and threatening an ecological buffer zone that protects Everglades National Park. ``We're in big trouble, it jumped a levee 50 feet wide,'' said state ranger Gene Dempsey. ``There's nothing slowing it down _ there's no water holes, no breaks.'' The fire, driven westward by 15 mph winds and fueled by sawgrass parched by Florida's two-year drought, had spread to 24,000 acres, or more than 37 square miles, by early afternoon. By jumping the canal, the blaze moved into the Everglades wildlife management area, an uninhabited, 150,000-acre buffer zone established to protect plants and wildlife in Everglades National Park. It also was headed toward Big Cypress National Preserve. The fire, located about 30 miles northwest of Miami and about 15 miles south of Big Cypress, didn't threaten any inhabited areas. ``Our main hope was to stop it there,'' Dempsey said. ``The next canal is about 12 miles away.'' The wildfire was one of three burning around Miami. A 10,500-acre fire within Everlades National Park itself, southwest of Miami, remained active Thursday, but firefighters from a federal team from Asheville, N.C., were confident they could control it, said park spokeswoman Darlene Koontz. She said they had determined the park fire was man-made _ either by arson or accident. Seminole Indian firefighters were trying to control a smaller blaze on their reservation in Broward County, said Dempsey. So far they did not need state help. Fires are a normal part of the Everglades ecology, said park spokeswoman Pat Tolle said. But this year's big fires worry environmentalists because the drought has left the region so dry, areas that usually would be bypassed by brush fires are threatened. If the smaller park fire to the south spread westward, for instance, it could threaten the nesting sites of the endangered Cape Sable seaside sparrow, a ground-nesting bird, said Ms. Tolle. The fires also could threaten hardwood hammocks _ small forested islands raised slightly above the marshland that are host to rare orchids, as well as certain species of tree snails that could not flee. ``But generally speaking the larger animals, the mobile animals, have already left the drier areas,'' she said. ``When you go in after the fire, there is very little evidence of dead or injured animals.''

DOC.HEAD: Washington Hangman's ID Can be Kept Secret, Court Rules
DOC.TEXT: The identity of Washington's hangman can be kept secret, a judge ruled Thursday. Thurston County Superior Court Judge Daniel Berschauer found that disclosure of the man's identity probably would block execution of convicted triple murderer Charles Rodman Campbell. Prison officials believe the executioner to be the nation's only qualified hangman, and he has made it clear he will perform the job only if his identity and hometown are kept secret, the judge said. ``The undisputed evidence is that the state could not proceed with an execution if disclosure were made,'' he said. The American Civil Liberties Union said it would quickly appeal. The ACLU had filed a request with state prison authorities seeking the name and qualifications of the hangman. The state responded by suing the ACLU and requesting an injunction against releasing the name. Campbell, whose case is on appeal, was sentenced to die for the 1982 stabbing deaths of Barbara Hendrickson, Renae Wicklund and Wicklund's 8-year-old daughter Shannah. The two women testified against Campbell in 1976, when he was convicted of sexually assaulting Wicklund; the killings took place after he was freed from prison. Assistant Attorney General Aaron Owada welcomed the decision. Both Owada and the judge stressed that they support public disclosure as a general principle. But they said state law allows a narrow exemption in cases where disclosure would not be in the public interest and would hamper a ``vital governmental function.'' The judge said he was balancing the public's right to know with the right to have government run properly. ``We are a society of law, and if the Executive Branch is prohibited from enforcing lawful court orders (such as an execution order), then indeed there can be damage to the vital public interest,'' Berschauer said in ruling from the bench. ACLU attorney Stephen Strong told the court the information is in the public interest and that the prison system has issued only hearsay evidence that the executioner might bow out if his identity was released. The state's $1,500 contract with the man says only that the state would try its best to keep his name secret, he said. ``If the state paid enough money, it could find somebody tomorrow, somebody from South Africa, for instance, where they hang people all the time,'' ACLU official Jerry Sheehan said in a later interview. The judge declined to rule on the constitutionality of hanging. Washington also allows a convict to choose death by lethal injection. Campbell has yet to indicate a preference, so the state has to prepare for both styles of execution. Campbell came within hours of execution last year, but won a stay from the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco. A final ruling is pending from the court. Washington's last execution by hanging was in 1963. The last such execution in the nation was in Iowa, in 1965.

DOC.HEAD: Mobutu Lifts Expulsion Order Against Journalist
DOC.TEXT: President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire lifted an expulsion order against a journalist who reported the deaths of two protesters at an anti-government rally, the Agence France-Presse news agency said Thursday. AFP journalists in the French capital confirmed a report from Kinshasa, Zaire that their colleague, Jean-Claude Fiol, had received the presidential pardon. Mobutu personally withdrew the order hours after it was issued Wednesday by Information Minister Ngongo Kamanda, who had summoned Fiol and the French ambassador to protest the report, AFP said. The ministry had demanded proof to back up an AFP dispatch that two people were killed when police broke up an illegal rally Monday by the Union for Democracy and Social Progress. The governor of Kinshasa and the state news agency Azap denied the report. Mobutu, Zaire's leader since 1965, lifted a 20-year ban on opposition parties April 24 and announced multiparty elections would be held next year. The U.S.-backed leader has been under increasing pressure by several U.S. lawmakers, who accuse his administration of authoritarian rule.

DOC.HEAD: Royal Seller Sends Candleholders to Auction
DOC.TEXT: A set of six 18th century silver candleholders, sold by royalty, fetched nearly $1.9 million on Thursday. The auction house Sotheby's said it was a record-setting price for a set of English silver. The candleholders, or sconces, were sold by a member of an unidentified royal family. Sotheby's said it had been asked not to identify the seller, whose father had bought the wall sconces in 1931. They had been auctioned in 1921 by descendants of the original owner for $15,000, Sotheby's said. Rahim Sadat, owner of London silver dealers Armitage Ltd., paid $1.89 million for the 16-inch high candleholders, known as the Dunham Massey sconces. ``It was a lot of money but ... I thought they were cheap at that price,'' Sadat said. The sconces, which each hold a single candle, were were made by Peter Archambo in London in 1730 for George Booth, 2nd Earl of Warrington, a notable silver collector. They bear elaborate figures from classical mythology. The earl kept the sconces in a room known as the great bedchamber at his Dunham Massey mansion in Cheshire, northwest England. ``The sconces are beautiful and unique, with a splendid noble provenance, and are probably the most important set of English silver I have handled in 15 years,'' Sadat said. Sotheby's had put a top estimate of $1.64 million on the sconces. The auction house attributed the price to high quality and the rarity of a set of six pieces surviving together for 260 years. At Christie's, New York, Sadat paid a world record price for a single piece of silver on April 19 when he bought a 17th century Sicilian table fountain for $1.98 million.

DOC.HEAD: Mills College Votes to Accept First Male Undergraduates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with color, quotes from students and college president; pick up 7th graf pvs, `Before the vote...' SUBS 16th graf pvs, `Board Chairman...,' to DELETE redundant first reference to Hellman.
DOC.TEXT: Trustees at Mills College voted Thursday to admit male undergraduates for the first time in the school's 138-year history, triggering cries of ``No, no!'' from hundreds of angry, tearful female students. ``We will not accept this. We have been betrayed,'' said Robyn Fisher, president of the Associated Students of Mills College. The trustees, hoping to avoid dipping heavily into the exclusive school's endowment to offset declining revenues, had been considering the move for some time. ``If Mills is to maintain academic quality and financial strength in the long run, it must increase its undergraduate enrollment to at least 1,000,'' said board chairman Warren F. Hellman, a San Francisco investment banker. He refused to reveal the breakdown of the vote by the 35-member board. Although men have been admitted to Mills' graduate programs for many years, a majority of the faculty had opposed the change, and it's hard to find a student who favors the idea. Several women at the school have even shaved their heads in protest. Hellman's voice was all but drowned out by angry shouts as he made the announcement from a podium in grassy Mills Common, where students had been summoned by chapel bells to hear the news. ``Mills has been the center of strong women and encouraged them to speak out,'' said junior Beckie Albright, who said she won't be returning next year. ``We deal with men in bars and in social situations. We don't want them in our classrooms.'' Dr. Mary S. Metz, the school's president, expects the first men to enroll in the fall of 1991. ``Mills accepts today's vote ... as a challenge to create a new model of coeducation that moves beyond conventional views of women and men and their roles in society,'' she said. Before the vote, Peter Mirijanian, spokesman for the Women's College Coalition in Washington D.C., said male undergraduates would ruin an atmosphere that gives female students leadership roles they have trouble attaining at co-ed colleges. ``The whole environment on a campus changes when men are admitted, no matter how hard the school tries to prevent that,'' Mirijanian said. ``Male students are taken more seriously and women suffer.'' Anita Pampusch, president of the coalition and of St. Catherine's women's college in St. Paul, Minn., added: ``There is so much evidence that women's colleges do something special for women; it would be a great shame if we did away with them. Women have always occupied a somewhat secondary role. At women's colleges they could occupy a primary role.'' The faculty voted 57-26 against the plan, which is intended to increase the undergraduate count from 777 to 1,000 at the quiet, tree-lined campus. Administrators say going co-ed ultimately will save the liberal arts school, one of three women's colleges in California and 94 in the nation. There were 298 all-female colleges 30 years ago. ``It's not a question of immediate death to the college if we don't go co-ed. But the school will decline,'' said Mills spokeswoman Vickie Bates. Enrollment in Mills' 33 undergraduate programs is down 4.2 percent from three years ago, said school economists. That contrasts with nationwide figures. According to the Women's College Coalition, full-time undergraduate enrollment at women's colleges is up this year by 3.5 percent, and part-time enrollments increased by 2.3 percent. Hellman, the board chairman, said the college must go co-ed to avoid relying too heavily on its $70 million endowment fund. Endowment revenues contribute 20 percent of the school's budget compared to 6 percent to 7 percent at most institutions, he said. But Fisher remained unconvinced. ``The institution has made it through financial crunches in the past without going co-ed,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Family's Grandmother Dies
DOC.TEXT: Martha Bridges, grandmother of the Jackson singing clan that includes pop stars Michael and Janet Jackson, was buried Thursday after a private funeral. Mrs. Bridges, 82, died Sunday of heart failure at a San Fernando Valley nursing home, said Bob Jones, spokesman for Michael Jackson's MJJ Productions. No other information was given. The funeral was held early Thursday at the Praisewater Funeral Home chapel in suburban Van Nuys. An undertaker who wouldn't give his name said she was buried afterward at Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Hollywood Hills. The Jackson family attended the funeral and graveside service, but the spokesman wouldn't identify individual family members in attendance or provide any details.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says Drug Fight No Pretext To Violate Law
DOC.TEXT: The United States said Thursday that fighting drug trafficking cannot justify violating national and international law _ an apparent reference to the kidnap of a Mexican doctor linked to a drug murder. U.S. Ambassador Jonathan Moore, representative to the U.N. Economic and Social Council, did not specifically mention the incident involving Dr. Alberto Alvarez Machain, which has strained U.S.-Mexican relations. Moore told delegates the United States believes ``pursuit of the drug menace cannot be used as a justification for violating the fundamental precepts of national and international law.'' Alvarez Machain was captured in Mexico by Mexican bounty hunters on April 2 and turned over to the Drug Enforcement Administration in the United States. He was linked to the torture-murder of DEA agent Enrique Camarena in Mexico in 1985. The United States has admitted no complicity in the cross-border kidnapping. On Wednesday, Mexico's ambassador, Jorge Montano, referred indirectly to the doctor's abduction. Montano called for anti-narcotics efforts to ``respect national sovereignty and territorial integrity and internal legislation.'' He emphasized, ``It is contradictory that certain countries which have a high level of drug consumption and growing internal production, instead of joining the collective fight, instead are acting outside the most elementary norms of international rights.'' Montano said Mexico contends that a U.S. Supreme Court decision of Feb. 28, which supported U.S. agents abroad, ``is an authorization to commit actions violating sovereignty of other countries.'' He said Mexican authorities will keep cooperating in fighting drug trafficking, ``but will not allow anybody _ drug dealers or those prosecuting them _ to violate the rights and laws of Mexico.'' On Thursday, Moore said a recent international session against drug trafficking recognized ``that no country can deal with this scourge alone or isolate itself from its effects.'' The Economic and Social Council is following up the General Assembly in February and a meeting in London on issues arising from the illegal drug trade. Moore urged all nations to ratify the U.N. Convention against Traffic in Illicit Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. He said U.N. drug control agencies have major and growing roles in international narcotics control.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Prime Minister Seeks World Help in Independence Move
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf: ``I don't,'' with 6 grafs new Prunskiene quotes bgng: ``But Mrs.,'' picks up 5th graf pvs: ``White HJouse spokesman,'' now 10th graf; SUBS 16th graf: ``Landsbergis said,'' to CORRECT that all of Czechoslovakia not turned over to Germany at Munich; only Sudentenland, with rest falling to Germany in 1939
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WX10, WX18, WX21
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene appealed to President Bush on Thursday to formally recognize her government's independence from Moscow. ``I think he's going to see how events unfold there and he's going to take decisions which are compatible with U.S., Soviet and Lithuanian interests,'' she said. Bush said at a news conference shortly before the 45-minute Oval Office meeting that he sees no role for the United States as a mediator between Lithuania and Moscow. But Mrs. Prunskiene, speaking at a reception as her long day of top-level meetings and public appeals drew to a close, said that her countrymen expect more than that from Bush. ``I made it clear to President Bush that the Lithuanian nation is awaiting basic support from him,'' she told an audience at the conservative Heritage Foundation. ``I don't think the president is at all indifferent to the Lithuanian cause,'' she said. ``He is, however, concerned with some of the complexities that surround this issue.'' She said that what Lithuania most needs _ if it accepts a proposal made by France and West Germany to slow the implementation of independence _ are international guarantees that talks with Moscow will in fact lead to independence. ``President Bush's involvement in this process would be very helpful,'' she said. Only time will tell whether her White House meeeting was productive, she said, adding: ``I have not lost hope.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush told Mrs. Prunskiene to take back to Lithuania this message: ``I am personally, and the United States government, is committed to the self-determination of the people of Lithuania.'' The White House has said Mrs. Prunskiene's visit was unofficial, but Fitzwater said Bush was pleased to get a first-hand account of the conditions in Lithuania. Bush, Fitzwater said, repeated the 50-year U.S. policy ``of refusing to recognize the forcible incorporation of the Baltic states into the U.S.S.R.'' ``He urged all parties to enter into a good faith dialogue. He stressed our desire to see the situation in Lithuania resolved peacefully and without intimidation. He emphasized the deep commitment of the American people to freedom and democracy around the world and the further progress of reform in the Soviet Union.'' Mrs. Prunskiene was asked if she endorsed a comment by Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis that Bush's refusal to impose sanctions against the Soviet Union was tantamount to ``another Munich.'' Landsbergis said it reminded him of the 1938 meeting in Munich at which Neville Chamberlain, the British prime minister, met with Adolf Hitler and agreed to let Hitler take over German-speaking areas of Czechoslovkia in the interest of ``peace in our time.'' Munich has been a symbol of sellout ever since. ``I don't think that comparing it with Munich was the best choice of words,'' she said. But she added: ``One must understand that what he said was said because Lithuania has a great desire for independence and hopes that the West will support the drive to reach that independence.'' Earlier, Mrs. Prunskiene said the upcoming summit between Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev could be a crucial turning point. ``Fate is giving them the chance to make an admirable mark on history,'' she said. Mrs. Prunskiene had said the independence crisis in Lithuania can be resolved if strong international pressure is brought on Gorbachev to permit genuine democracy in the Soviet Union. ``Even the world's darling does not have the monopolistic right to decide the fate of other nations,'' she said, referring to Gorbachev. Greeted with a standing ovation as she opened public testimony on Capitol Hill, the 47-year-old prime minister acknowledged that Gorbachev would prefer that Lithuania remain within the Soviet federation, ``although not by force.'' However, she said, the United States and the world don't have to choose between the Soviet leader ad the break-away republic. ``The solution is this: Gorbachev and a breakthrough for democracy in the Soviet Union and an independent Lithuania,'' she said. ``These two are compatible and converging sides of the same process, rather than alternatives. ``It is difficult for the West to perceive that pressuring Mr. Gorbachev helps rather than hinders.'' International pressure, Mrs. Prunskiene said, can help Gorbachev become ``a consistent practitioner of democracy'' and overcome reactionary forces inside the Soviet Union. Mrs. Prunskiene delivered her testimony before the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, the so-called Helsinki Commission, formed in 1975 to monitor Soviet compliance with its human rights commitments. Meeting over breakfast with members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Mrs. Prunskiene said Lithuania ``is prepared for compromises'' in those negotiations but ``cannot and will not revoke our declaration of independence.'' ``We also hope for international guarantees of this declaration of independence which we have made,'' she said. ``I wish to emphasize that we believe that only with these international guarantees ... the Soviets will begin negotiations.'' While appearing before the Helsinki Commission she said: ``We could temporarily suspend the quick and unilateral execution'' of legislation implementing the independence declaration, she said, ``if there were international guarantees.'' ``In such a case, Lithuania would have to be guaranteed on the basis of international law: the continuity of Lithuanian independence, the continuation of her government and her territorial integrity.'' Mrs. Prunskiene said Gorbachev's economic blockade has plunged Lithuania into difficult times, but that the coercion will not succeed. ``We intend to hold out and survive, because there is no road back,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Key House Panel Approves Tougher Log Export Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: Efforts to restrict further log exports from government lands won unanimous approval Thursday from a key House committee as backers of the plan predicted it will win passage through Congress. The House Foreign Affairs Committee sent the Export Administration Act to the full House with an amendment that would ban the lucrative export of raw-logs from all state lands in Oregon and three-fourths of such lands in Washington. The export controls are necessary to keep domestic mills operating while setting aside millions of acres to protect old-growth forests needed to save the rare northern spotted owl from extinction, said Rep. John Miller, R-Wash. In the past, panel members have opposed measures that would allow states to ban exports of commodities on the basis that the federal government has the sole power to set U.S. trade policy. But Miller said the proposal approved Thursday gets around that problem by directing the commerce secretary to implement the state bans and preserving President Bush's authority to nulify the bans if they conflict with federal policy. ``I've got to say it went better than we ever expected,'' Miller said after the meeting. ``I expect it will be coming to the floor quickly.'' ``I don't expect there will be any opposition on the floor,'' said Rep. Les AuCoin, D-Ore.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Insists United Germany Remain in Alliance
With AM-Baker, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: NATO foreign ministers insisted Thursday that a united Germany must remain in the Western alliance but sought to reassure Moscow that Soviet security interests would not be hurt as a result. ``Our message is clear: it's not a question of winning or losing at the end, there must be only winners,'' NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner said at the end of a special alliance meeting on German unification. ``The Soviet Union will not lose. It will win in stability and it will win partners in security,'' he told reporters. Secretary of State James A. Baker III agreed, ``A stable, united Germany within secure borders and as part of a free alliance is a loss for no one.'' Woerner said the ministers were unanimous in insisting on NATO membership for a unified Germany. West Germany already is a member of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization, but East Germany belongs to the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. More than 380,000 Red Army troops are stationed on East German soil. Moscow wants the new Central European state to be militarily non-aligned. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze suggests that the new nation belong to both alliances. Woerner ruled out dual-membership, saying it would lead to a ``sort of neutrality.'' ``It is clear that this is not acceptable to us,'' he said. Baker suggested that with a U.S. decision to speed up the timetable for U.S.-Soviet negotiations on slashing tactical nuclear forces in Europe, the Kremlin might ease its opposition to NATO membership for the new Germany. ``There's a recognition on the part of the NATO alliance that circumstances are changing,'' Baker told a news conference. The NATO foreign ministers met two days before the start of the ``two-plus-four'' discussions on a united Germany, which include the four World War II allies _ Britain, France, the United States and the Soviet Union _ and the two Germanys. The special NATO meeting was called after smaller alliance nations, especially Italy, Belgium and the Netherlands, complained about being left out of the ``two-plus-four'' process. Woerner said NATO did not intend to expand its forces into the current territory of East Germany but that the western sector would continue to belong to NATO's joint military structure. He said a united Germany ``will renounce the possession of nuclear and chemical weapons as both present German states have done.'' No discriminatory measures should be applied to the new state, Woerner said, without elaborating. Baker said the ``two-plus-four'' group would discuss various issues about German reunification but that its membership in NATO could only be decided by the alliance and the merged nation. A NATO statement said Thursday that Woerner will meet with President Bush, Baker and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney during a two-day visit to Washington starting next Monday, and would also meet with congressional leaders and National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft. Woerner will proceed to Canada for a May 9-10 meeting of NATO defense ministers near Calgary, Alberta, on nuclear arms policy, the statement added.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Democrats Offer Version of Campaign-Financing Legislation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 6th graf: ``The new,'' to explain how proposed voluntary tax checkoff would work differently from the current presidential campaign checkoff. FYI, we expect this story to stand for AMs
DOC.TEXT: Senate Democrats proposed Thursday that the public finance nearly half the cost of Senate campaigns and that political action committees be prohibited from contributing directly to candidates. The revised campaign reform bill, which party leaders said they will bring to the Senate floor next week, retains spending ceilings vehemently opposed by most Republicans but raises them about 20 percent above what Democrats had first proposed. Democratic leaders unveiled their package just two days after Republicans rushed out a counterproposal endorsed by 34 of the 45 GOP senators. Under the Democratic plan, about 70 percent of a candidate's general election campaign expenses _ but none of the costs for primary races _ would be paid by the government from funds raised through a proposed $3 checkoff on income tax returns. Since the middle 1970s, tax returns have included a checkoff that allows taxpayers to designate $1 of their taxes to a fund for financing presidential campaigns. The new checkoff, in contrast, would require the taxpayer to pay more _ taxpayers could voluntarily give up $3 of their refunds or add $3 to the taxes they owe to go into a special government account to finance congressional campaigns. The new Democratic-proposed ceilings on Senate campaigns would range from $1.9 million in small states to slightly more than $10 million in the largest, California. Sponsors said it would basically cut in half the amount now being spent. The GOP plan would abolish union and corporate PACs entirely and cut the amount that issue-oriented PACs can contribute to campaigns by 80 percent. But Republicans would leave unlimited the aggregate amounts that candidates and the two parties can raise from individual donors and spend on elections. ``The only meaningful way to reform ... is to have limits on campaign spending,'' said Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell of Maine. ``Anything less than that avoids the real issues and simply creates the illusion of reform.'' With revised proposals from both parties now on the table, the door is open for Mitchell, Republican Leader Bob Dole and their representatives to begin serious negotiations. ``We still hope we can reach a bipartisan agreement,'' Mitchell said. ``I hope we can engage in discussions in the very near future.'' Oklahoma Sen. David Boren, the chief author of the Democratic package, said he doesn't expect those talks to begin before the bill is brought to the Senate floor Monday or Tuesday. ``Everything is negotiable from our point of view, except that we have to have some limit on overall spending, or that money will pop up in some other way,'' Boren said. The initial reaction from Republicans was disdain. ``I can't believe this is a serious proposal,'' said Kentucky Sen. Mitch McConnell, the chief author of the GOP measure. ``Including House races, taxpayers would pick up a $400 million tab each election cycle for an incumbent's protection bill.'' While both Democrats and Republicans have retreated from a bipartisan compromise suggested two months ago by a panel of academic experts and professional campaign fund-raisers for both sides, Boren said he still rates the odds at 2-to-1 that the Senate will pass a bill. ``I think we could very well have enough Republican votes'' to prevent a repeat of the successful filibuster GOP senators mounted two years ago against a campaign reform bill, Boren said. ``But that's not enough,'' he added. ``It's not going to be enacted if it's not agreeable to George Bush. The president doesn't want any PACs ... but I don't think he's hung up on the details.'' Currently there is a $10,000 limit on how much union, corporate and issue-oriented PACs can give to a candidate. The Republican bill would outlaw labor and corporate PACs _ which in recent years have overwhelmingly funneled their contributions to incumbent Democratic lawmakers _ and limit donations from ideological PACs to a total of $2,000 per candidate for both primary and general elections. While the new Democratic proposal would ban all PAC contributions to individual candidates, it would still allow PACs to collectively contribute up to $5 million to the Democratic and Republican parties and up to 30 percent of the money raised by Senate party campaign committees. However, Democrats would outlaw so-called leadership PACs organized by senators and congressmen. Democrats also would raise from $25,000 to $30,000 the total of contributions an individual can make to several campaigns or political committees. But the extra $5,000 could go only to state party committees.

DOC.HEAD: Erosion in Credibility of Israeli Army After Uprising
DOC.TEXT: An army-commissioned poll published Thursday in the Israel Defense Forces Weekly indicated about 30 percent of Israelis surveyed lacked full faith in army announcements and the ethical behavior of soldiers. Independent experts said this represented a significant erosion in public support for the army as a result of its handling of the Palestinian uprising, in which 681 Palestinians and 43 Israelis have died. But army spokesman Brig. Gen. Nachman Shai said the poll showed a strong backing for the army. ``I'm not satisfied with 70 percent support ..., '' he said in an interview. ``But after almost 29 months of intefadeh (Arabic for uprising) it does speak for the basic support of the people for the military.'' Shai said he believed the credibility of army announcements had declined in the past two decades, the result mainly of more aggressive and critical Israeli news media. He noted the army opened itself to more coverage and liberalized censorship. ``People recognize it is part of democracy, the price you have to pay,'' he said. The poll found 70 percent of those surveyed believed army statements were reliable; 25 percent felt the army spokesman's office sometimes reliable; four percent described communiques as unreliable. No judgment was forthcoming from the remaining one percent. The independent Dahaf Institute surveyed 1,101 Israeli adults for the poll in March. Ruth Zin of Dahaf said there was a 2.5 percent margin of error. About 70 percent of those polled also thought the army adhered to moral standards. But it found 30 percent felt soldiers only conformed somewhat to ethical guidelines. It found 95 percent believed they could rely on the army's combat ability. Ms. Zin said she could not determine whether the findings represented a significant change in Israeli thinking since the questions had not been asked in previous surveys. However, independent military analysts and pollsters said the results pointed to a significant drop in support in a country where nearly everyone serves in the army and the military has traditionally been held in high esteem.

DOC.HEAD: Capital Democrats Reject Bid to Discourage Barry Candidacy.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with vote; picks up 7th graf pvs, bgng: Anita Bonds...
DOC.TEXT: The local Democratic Party Thursday narrowly rejected a resolution drafted by the party chairman that would have requested Mayor Marion Barry to abandon any plans to run for re-election in November. The proposal was voted down by a 29-23 margin after almost two hours of tumultous debate in which Barry supporters repeatedly shouted insults at committee chairman Josyln Williams, who drafted the resolution, and others who supported it. Following the vote, the mayor's supporters left the District Building hearing room shouting ``Four More Years.'' Barry faces trial next month on five misdemeanor cocaine possession charges and three felony counts of lying to a federal grand jury about his drug use. The unprecedented resolution declared Barry's leadership ``in question'' and concluded with the request that he ``announce that he will not seek renomination in 1990.'' Barry has not publicly disclosed his future political plans. However, he has made numerous campaign-style appearance since his return to the city from seven weeks of treatment for substance abuse, and sources close to the mayor said Barry intends to run for a fourth, four-year term, despite his impending trial. In a letter to Williams, Barry called the resolution ``undemocratic'' because it ``undermines the right of the voter to decide.'' Barry also said the party's action ``would have little influence on my decision about my political future.'' Barry did not attend the meeting, but his sentiments were echoed by many who did. ``It is not this committee's place to tell anyone who is trying to take part in the democratic process that they can't run,'' said Harry Thomas Jr., president of the local Young Democrats chapter. ``It hasn't been done before, and if this party wants to get political ... then we should endorse somebody, not discourage them.'' Others objected on procedural grounds, saying they had not been given enough notice. The 72-member state Democratic committee, so named despite the District of Columbia's lack of statehood, has staunchly backed Barry in the past. Anita Bonds, Barry's political manager, said the mayor attempted to discourage Williams and other members of the committee from drafting the resolution during a private meeting last week. ``The mayor attempted to discourage them from doing this, and told them that it would not be the only factor in his deciding his political plans,'' Bonds said. ``Today, the mayor's position remains the same.'' Five Democrats already are vying for Barry's job. Recent opinion polls show that the mayor still enjoys the support of between 20 percent and 25 percent of the city's electorate. There is no run-off provision under city election law, which means the party's September primary could be won with a fairly small fraction of the vote. Former police chief Maurice T. Turner, the prohibitive favorite to win the Republican nomination, has run even with or ahead of Barry in recent surveys. Democrats outnumber Republicans in the district by almost a nine-to-one margin. Meanwhile, court papers released Thursday showed that Barry declined to answer, invoking his constitutional right against self-incrimination, when a grand jury asked him whether he had used drugs in the past five years. During grand jury appearances on Jan. 19 and Jan. 24, 1989, Barry testified that he had not exchanged drugs with convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis and that he was unaware of Lewis' involvement with narcotics. But in a letter dated Jan. 25, 1989, released by U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens, Barry declined to answer the grand jury's question whether he had ``used within the past five years any illegal drug or substance including cocaine.'' In the papers filed Thursday, Stephens said Barry ``consciously engaged in a course of conduct to corroborate the known lies of others that exonerated him and to remain silent about other matters.'' Barry is now accused of lying on three occasions to the panel: Once each about whether he and Lewis gave each other cocaine and also when asked whether he was aware of Lewis' drug involvement. The letter was released as Stephens sought to block efforts by Barry's attorney to have the perjury charges against the mayor dismissed. A conviction on any of the perjury charges would bar him from holding office or seeking re-election. Neither Barry nor his spokeswoman, Lurma Rackley, were immediately available to comment on the documents.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian TV Crew Studies U.S. Anti-Drug Efforts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `At a...,' to CORRECT youth's age to 13 sted 16.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush gets a lot of attention bashing Colombian cocaine traffickers. Now, Colombian TV crews are touring this country to see what's being done to choke off the demand that drives the drug trade. The South American film crew worked in Connecticut's largest city Thursday after stopping last weekend in Washington, D.C., to interview federal officials. The visitors focused on the seemingly insatiable demand that has made traffickers rich, powerful and feared in their country, said Maria Eugenia Sierra, a journalist with the network news show ``Telenoticiero del Mediodia.'' ``The United States has the problem of the consumption of drugs, whereas there are tremendous consequences in Colombia as a result of this problem _ the narco-traffickers,'' she said. The traffickers have been blamed for more than 200 deaths in Colombia since August, when Colombian President Virgilio Barco declared a crackdown. The Colombian crew, whose show is seen by about 3 million each weekday at noon, came to Bridgeport to talk with people who run anti-drug programs _ and the kids they try to help. At a conference at the Bridgeport Hilton, they interviewed 13-year-old Kisha Rivera, one of 200 student leaders in a drug prevention program. ``She asked me what I have done to stay away from drugs,'' Rivera said. ``I said, `No, I've never tried it.''' Miss Rivera doesn't just say ``no'' when offered drugs. She told the interviewers she has taken the opportunity to try to persuade her drug-using peers to fight their problem. ``I said no and tried to help them,'' Miss Rivera said. ``And if they don't want any help, I don't have a friendly relationship with them. But if they accept, I'll take them to the guidance counselor.'' John Higgins-Biddle, the director of the Regional Youth Substance Abuse Program, explained to the Colombian crew that the program builds self-esteem so youngsters can turn down drugs and alcohol. It also targets students at risk and helps them find counseling. ``We realize there has been a reduction in the use of drugs, and programs have had some effect,'' Sierra said. ``Our intention here is to come to know some of these programs and possibly use them in Colombia.'' In Washington, Sierra interviewed drug czar William Bennett. He took the opportunity to praise Barco's campaign against the cocaine traffickers and to say he hoped Colombians wouldn't see U.S. efforts to help Barco as meddling. Sierra and the crew also stopped in Princeton, N.J., at the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, which gave $27 million in grants this year to fight drug and alcohol abuse. And they interviewed Thomas Hendrick, director of Partnership for a Drug-Free America. That's the campaign that features the bubbling egg in a frying pan and the words, ``This is your brain on drugs.'' Sierra has higher hopes for her show than one from a competing network, which has yet to air the program it taped in Florida and Detroit four months ago. ``The news we hear from the embassy is they are so intimidated by the drug cartel that the chances of (airing) anything are nil,'' said Alan Botto, a director with the U.S. Information Agency. He set up the interviews for both crews. ``You know, every day you arrive at work and you do your job, and there is a general and continuous danger,'' Sierra said. ``But the truth of the matter is, you just get used to it. We must go as far as we can in this battle. We must go as far as the narco-traffickers will allow us.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Sex Church Not Protected by Constition
DOC.TEXT: A couple cannot claim their sex-based Church of the Most High Goddess is a religion protected by constitutional freedoms and thus immune from attempts to enforce vice laws, a federal judge ruled Thursday. Wilbur Tracy, 51, and his wife, Mary Ellen, 47, argued that the church, which promises salvation through sex in exchange for monetary sacrifices, should be protected by the U.S. Constitution. The couple testified the church was based on an ancient Eqyptian religion in which intercourse with Mrs. Tracy, alias priestess Sabrina Aset, cleansed the soul as a purification rite. Proof came in the form of cash or other ``tokens of sacrifice,'' Mrs. Tracy testified Wednesday. Mrs. Tracy said she qualified as a high priestess for the religion in 1986 by sleeping with 1,000 men over a two-year period. But U.S. District Judge W. Matthew Byrne rejected the argument, ruling after a five-day, non-jury trial that they weren't protected from law enforcement prosecution by constitutional religious freedom guarantees. The Tracys filed the lawsuit claiming city officials pursuing prostitution charges violated her First Amendment right to religious freedom. Named in the lawsuit were City Attorney James Hahn and Police Chief Daryl Gates. Assistant City Attorney Bryon R. Boeckman said authorities believe Mrs. Tracy and her husband used the church as a front for prostitution. ``This is not a true religion,'' Boeckman said. Advertised in sexually explicit magazines, the church boasted services run by the priestess wearing a strapless red-sequined gown, high-heeled shoes and fishnet stockings. The sparsely furnished church had no pews or pulpit. The few wall hangings in place included posters of movie stars and a framed nude photograph of Mrs. Tracy. The Tracys filed the lawsuit while their misdemeanor criminal convictions for prostitution and running a brothel are on appeal. They claim divine inspiration prompted them to revive an ancient Egyptian religion in which man justifies his sins by having sex with church priestesses. She said initiates needed to confess and have sex before they could be considered for sin ``negation'' and ``purification,'' Then ``sacrifices'' of cash or other valuables were required to show dedication to the church before having sexual intercourse. ``The rituals would end if there were no sacrifices?'' asked Byrne. ``Correct,'' Mrs. Tracy answered. ``There is no purpose to having your sins negated if you do not wish to emulate God.'' She denied that she sought specific payment amounts. During her criminal trial, testimony included allegations she demanded minimum payments of $150. ``It's up to a person to decide if it's an acceptable sacrifice,'' she said. She testified Tuesday that she collected about $50,000 in donations during a three-year period, but did not keep records regarding followers beyond their first names and telephone numbers. She acknowledged that about 50 percent of the men paid only one visit and never returned. ``I don't think that's very unusual for any religion,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Doe Appeals For Halt To Fighting, Delegation Said Sent To Washington
DOC.TEXT: Embattled President Samuel Doe on Thursday appealed to rebels to lay down their arms and submit proposals for negotiations, and his government said a delegation was traveling to Washington for talks on the insurgency. The announcement appeared to be in response to U.S. government calls for talks to end the fighting. Doe has so far refused to negotiate with rebel leader Charles Taylor. The Doe government said in a statement that the 10-member delegation would meet with members of Congress and State Department officials. The State Department, however, had no comment on any talks that might be planned. ``I don't have anything on that,'' said State Department spokeswoman Nancy Beck said Thursday night. The United States has close ties with this West African nation, which was founded by freed American slaves in 1847. Doe seized power in a bloody April 12, 1980, coup that ended the domination of a small elite of Americos, the descendants of the slaves. In the insurgency, Doe's troops are accused of killing hundreds of civilians since rebels invaded eastern Nimba County from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24. More than 150,000 refugees have fled the fighting to neighboring countries or other parts of Liberia. On Thursday, national media continued to broadcast an appeal from Doe to the rebels, asking them to stop their offensive and present their grievances for negotiation. A U.S. source, reached by telephone from London on Thursday, disputed reports that the rebels were in striking distance of Monrovia. However, Moses Washington, the acting Liberian information minister, said Thursday that troops were continuing to battle rebels in Grand Bassa County, 90 miles east of Monrovia. He said there also has been fighting in the rebel stronghold in central Nimba. A two-pronged rebel advance toward Monrovia and Buchanan, the country's second port, has dangerously stretched rebel supply lines. The rebels initially met indifferent opposition from government troops, many of them conscripted and poorly paid, who often flee the fighting. But much stiffer resistance can be expected nearer to Monrovia, where Doe keeps at least half of the 5,000-man army and his toughest troops.

DOC.HEAD: Interest In Buying PTL Assets Swells After National Ad
DOC.TEXT: After nearly two years' unsuccessful efforts to sell TV evangelist Jim Bakker's old Heritage USA empire, the bankruptcy trustee resorted Thursday to a national newspaper advertisement. Several previous offers for 2,000-acre theme park and residential development have failed to pan out, including one from Bakker himself before he was imprisoned for fraud. A trustee for the U.S. Bankruptcy Court wants to sell the retreat near Fort Mill, complete with water-slide park, hotels and television satellite, to pay off debts incurred by Bakker's PTL ministry. The property has been valued at about $100 million. A full-page ``for sale'' ad appeared in The New York Times on Thursday. Martin W. Taplin, a Miami real-estate expert hired by bankruptcy trustee Dennis Shedd to handle the sale, characterized response to the ad as ``unbelievable.'' But he refused to say how many potential buyers were drawn by the ad, or to name them. Before the ad ran, the sellers had been approached by about 60 prospective buyers, Taplin said. About one-quarter of them appeared to have the money to make the purchase, he said. The ministry declared bankruptcy in June 1987, three months after Bakker resigned from PTL in a sex-for-hush-money scandal involving former church secretary Jessica Hahn. The property has been on the market nearly two years. In addition to the water slide-equipped theme park, the resort has convention areas, an office building, shopping center, condominiums, time share units, campsites, utility plant and a 1,640-acre development of homes, apartments and townhouses. Bakker is serving a 45-year prison sentence in Rochester, Minn., for defrauding his followers of $3.7 million. He was convicted of overselling and misrepresenting time share units at Heritage USA, as well as squeezing pay raises and other perks out of the PTL board when the ministry was headed for financial ruin.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Rises in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold rose $1.35 an ounce on Hong Kong markets on Friday, opening at $372.09. It closed at $370.74 Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Journalist Freed After Being Detained in Letelier Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with release of journalist. Picks up 3rd pvs, `The Letelier...' with minor editing to CONFORM
DOC.TEXT: A military prosecutor on Thursday night freed a local journalist whose overnight detention was criticized by President Patricio Aylwin. A lawyer for the independent Santiago daily newspaper La Epoca, Luis Sandoval, said release of journalist Manuel Salazar was ordered by army Maj. Raul Rozas, the same man who ordered his detention a day earlier. Salazar had uncovered the identity of a former secret police agent linked to the 1976 assassination in Washington of former Foreign Minister Orlando Letelier and an American associate, Ronni Moffitt. Rozas on Wednesday also freed the former police agent. The Letelier case is proving to be a delicate issue for the elected civilian president, who has pledged ``full cooperation'' with U.S. officials on it and investigations into alleged human rights abuses during the 16{-year military dictatorship. Later Thursday, Aylwin met with Gen. Augusto Pinochet for the first time since the right-wing army commander gave up the presidency in March, but neither man disclosed what was discussed. It was widely expected to include rights issues. Upon Pinochet's arrival at the Presidential Palace, a small group of demonstrators booed him and shouted ``Murderer!'' Two people were detained, police said. Pinochet left the 40-minute meeting through an underground exit, avoiding reporters. Letelier was a bitter foe of Pinochet. Three former officials in Pinochet's secret police were indicted in U.S. courts, and one of them admitted his role in the Sept. 21, 1976 car bombing and served a seven-month U.S. prison sentence. Aylwin told reporters he was ``surprised'' by the prosecutor's order. ``I think judges have the obligation to explain the reasons for the decisions they make,'' he said outside his Santiago residence. The prosecutor questioned Salazar for 10 hours Wednesday and ordered he be held incommunicado indefinitely. At the same time, Rozas freed the former secret agent, Monica Luisa Lagos, 38. She had spent five days in jail while undergoing questioning about an alleged accessory role in the assassination of Letelier. Questioned by reporters, Rozas declined to explain why he ordered Salazar's arrest. He cited the secret nature of his investigation. Under Chilean law, military prosecutors can order people arrested during their investigations. Aylwin, however, said an explanation ``would not affect the secrecy of the investigation.'' He said the action ``requires clarification from the proper authority.'' Salazar is national editor of La Epoca and led the newspaper's efforts to uncover the woman's identity. In a front-page editorial under the headline ``Our protest,'' La Epoca on Thursday criticized the prosecutor's decision as an attack on press freedom. The woman admitted she is a former agent of a now-defunct secret police agency, known as DINA. She said she traveled to the United States under the assumed name of Liliana Walker, providing cover for another agent who was an accomplice in the Letelier slaying. Letelier was a prominent foe of Pinochet, who led a 1973 military coup that overthrew the elected leftist government of President Salvador Allende. The other two officers wanted in the Letelier case are still in Chile, and U.S. authorities say they will continue their efforts to bring them to justice. On Wednesday night, the Chilean Senate unanimously approved a bill to posthumously restore Letelier his Chilean citizenship, which the Pinochet government removed 10 days before his death.

DOC.HEAD: MX Project In Trouble, Senator Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs; INSERTS grafs 6-7: ``In another,'' with SDI testimony; SUBS graf 10: ``How can,'' to remove now-redundant identification of Nunn
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon's plans to deploy nuclear missiles on railroad cars is in ``big, big trouble'' in Congress because of a reported proposal by the Air Force to eliminate funds for the system, a senator said Thursday. Air Force officials refused to confirm reports that the service had recommended that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney cut funds to move the multiple-warhead MX missile from fixed silos to railroad cars. ``The Air Force supports the president's budget that's on the hill for the two-missile program,'' Franklin C. Miller, deputy assistant secretary of defense for nuclear forces and arms control policy, told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee. But Sen. James Exon, D-Neb., chairman of the subcommittee on strategic forces and nuclear deterrence, said the committee is aware of what the Air Force recommended and that proposal is undermining support for the system on Capitol Hill. ``The MX rail-garrison proposition is in big, big trouble here since we know what the Air Force recommended and whether or not the secretary overrides that, it's going to have a bearing on what we do here,'' the senator said. In another Senate hearing, Lt. Gen. George L. Monahan Jr., director of the Strategic Defense Initiative Organization, said said a cut of $1 billion from the sum proposed by President Bush for ``Star Wars'' would clearly ``put our deployments further out in the future.'' Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., raised the possibility of such a cut to $3.6 billion in the new budget during discussion in the Senate Appropriations defense subcommittee. Current spending is $3.8 billion, and Armed Services Commitee Chairman Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., has urged that figure for the new budget. President Bush's $303 billion defense budget proposal for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 calls for $2.8 billion for the MX missile project and $202 million for development of the single-warhead Midgetman missile, which could move about overland on special trucks. Members of Congress, however, have questioned the Pentagon's plans to upgrade its strategic force in light of the reduced threat from the Soviet bloc. ``How can we make decisions on strategic modernization without knowing what the targets are?'' said Nunn. Miller said the Pentagon is conducting a special review of those targets but was unable to say when it would be completed. But the apparent Air Force plan on the MX missile caused consternation among the subcommittee members. ``We are pawing around in the dark,'' Exon told the witnesses.

DOC.HEAD: Famed Tenor Conquers Bolshoi Theater
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-8 pvs, `Irina Sukhotsky...' to CORRECT typos of Pavarotti, acquaintance. Pickup 9th pvs, `Among the...'
DOC.TEXT: Luciano Pavarotti took the stage at the Bolshoi Theater on Thursday before an elite crowd, including President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who attended a concert to raise money for victims of the Armenian earthquake. Pavarotti, grinning broadly and extending his arms to the audience, sang four encores to increasingly loud cries of ``Bravo!'' and insistent applause. The Italian star dedicated one of the encores to Raisa Gorbachev, seated in a box just left of the stage. He met briefly with the president and his wife backstage after the sold-out performance. The Gorbachevs joined in warmly applauding Pavarotti on his first trip to the Soviet Union in 15 years. It was the tenor's first performance at the famed Bolshoi. Theater workers said people hoping to buy the few available tickets began lining up at 2 a.m., 10 hours before the box office opened. The theater was surrounded by police. Asked why he was trying to buy a spare ticket across the street from the 2,500-seat theater, engineer Sasha Zlorovsky said, ``Pavarotti is singing. That says it all.'' Irina Sukhotsky, an economist, couldn't get through the police cordon to find an acquaintance she said would have a ticket for her. Olya Pivovarova, a student, managed to slip through but had little luck getting a ticket. The problem was not the price, but the availability. Pavarotti thrilled the crowd inside the red-and-gold trimmed theater with a selection of songs from Bellini, Rossini, Verdi and others. He was accompanied at the piano by Leone Magiera. Among the toughest critics in the hall was usher Yekaterina Vitova, an opera lover who has seen stars come and go during her 30 years at Moscow's most famous theater. ``He has a brilliant voice,'' she said. She praised not only the power of his voice, but his control of it and compared him to Soviet tenor Sergei Lemeshev, a Bolshoi star in the 1950s and 1960s. ``In my mind, he's better than anyone we have here,'' she said. She also was a little concerned about Pavarotti's girth. ``He's hefty, isn't he?'' she asked. ``I guess they have to be in order to sing like that.'' Among those who attended the concert were such Soviet luminaries as poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko, magazine editor Vitaly Korotich, lawyer and newspaper editor Fyodor Burlatsky and Gorbachev adviser Georgy Shakhnazarov. The concert was the first in a series of benefits to raise money to build a $30 million hospital in Spitak, in Armenia. The city was destroyed by an earthquake in December 1988 that killed 25,000 people in northern Armenia. Pavarotti has performed twice before in the Soviet Union, in 1965 and in 1974, when he sang at Tchaikovsky Hall. He will give three more performances in the Soviet Union, two in Moscow and one in Leningrad. He will be accompanied by the Arturo Toscanini Symphony Orchestra.

DOC.HEAD: Grenade Thrown At Presidential Candidate's Office, But No Injuries
DOC.TEXT: Assailants lobbed a hand grenade at the campaign office of a rightist presidential candidate Thursday, but damage from the blast was slight and no one was hurt. Manuel Ayau Cordon, the candidate of the ultra-rightist National Liberation Movement, brushed off the attack in Guatemala City, the capital, and said he was not seeking police protection. Ayau Cordon said the hand grenade was thrown from a speeding car, but he had no details. Police said they had no suspects. This was the second attack on an opposition group this year. Hand grenades were thrown at the office of the conservative National Advancement Party, causing minor damage but no injuries. Elections are scheduled for Nov. 3.

DOC.HEAD: Costa Rica To Reduce Foreign Debt
DOC.TEXT: The Costa Rican government and foreign creditor banks have agreed on a formula to lower the Central American nation's $4.5 billion foreign debt, an official said Thursday. Eduardo Lizano, president of the Central Bank, told a news conference that Costa Rica will repurchase 64 percent of its $1.8 billion commercial foreign debt at 16 cents on the dollar. The deal, to be signed Saturday, will save Costa Rica $110 million a year in debt principal and service payments, he said. The agreement was to be signed by Treasury Secretary Rodrigo Bolanos and representatives of the foreign banks. Once the agreement is signed, Costa Rica will have until May 21 to pay $253 million to bring itself up to date in payments and repurchase the old debt, Lizano said. Government officials said that Costa Rica has fallen behind on debt payments of $145 million a year. However, under the new agreement, it will owe only $35 million annually. Costa Rica was one of the earliest countries to reach agreement in principle on new financing packages under a U.S. plan unveiled in March 1989 by Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. It focuses on enticing commercial banks to write off some of their loans to Third World nations or reduce the interest charged in return for guarantees that the remaining debt will be paid. The strategy, aimed at reducing the burder of 39 debtor countries, emphasizes reducing a borrowing country's debt and the interest it must pay. By contrast, the Reagan administration strategy was to provide new loans in return for economic reforms by the borrowers.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Humberto Ortega Plans to Keep Large Army
With AM-UN-Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Humberto Ortega, the only prominent holdover from the Sandinista regime in Nicaragua, intends to maintain a strong army, he said in a report broadcast Thursday. The general, head of Nicaragua's armed forces, said on the CBS Evening News that a large army was necessary because of military tensions in Central America. Ortega was retained by President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro to retain stability in the army. But he told CBS that he has had trouble keeping the army together. In the two months since his brother, former President Daniel Ortega, and the Sandinistas lost the country's popular election, 30 percent of the draftees in Nicaragua's army have deserted, the general told CBS. Even with the desertions and cutbacks, Ortega said he still plans to keep an army of 40,000. Nicaragua has the largest army in Central America. Mrs. Chamorro won election on Feb. 25. Last week, she succeeded Daniel Ortega after a decade of Sandinista rule and nine years of war with U.S.-backed Contras rebels. The Contras had promised to surrender their weapons and disband by June 10, then balked after Mrs. Chamorro announced that Gen. Ortega would remain military chief.

DOC.HEAD: Study: U.S. Lead in Superconductivity Research Threatened
DOC.TEXT: The United States could lose its leadership in superconductivity research because U.S. companies are investing less in the technology than their overseas competitors, according to a congressional study released Thursday. The Office of Technology Assessment used high-temperature superconductivity as a test of the nation's ability to sustain a long-term research and development effort, said study director Gregory Eyring. ``We have had a large government investment,'' Eyring said. ``But if you look at the industry side, the situation isn't as encouraging. ``The primary interest is whether we're ahead of the Japanese,'' he said. Physicist Paul Chu of the University of Houston, a pioneer in the field, said he agreed to a certain extent with the study's conclusions. ``U.S. industry's involvement is certainly not as great as that in Japan,'' Chu said. ``We'd like to see more.'' ``The commitment from government could be even more long-term,'' Chu said. ``While quantity of that commitment is important, the quality is even more important. Without stability and continuity, we cannot plan our program efficiently.'' The U.S. government spent $130 million on superconductivity research in 1989 while Japan spent less than $70 million, the study said. But Japanese companies in late 1988 and early 1989 invested about $107 million in such research compared with about $73 million by U.S. firms, it said. Superconductors have no resistance to the flow of electricity. If they could be harnessed in ordinary electrical devices, they could avoid the energy lost to heating in the generation and distribution of power. So far, the principal uses of superconductors are in magnets in medical imaging devices and particle accelerators. Superconductivity was discovered in 1911, but for years superconductors were only known to work when cooled by liquid helium to a few degrees above absolute zero, minus 459 degrees Fahrenheit. In 1986, Chu discovered a superconductor that worked at minus 234 degrees Fahrenheit, a temperature reached with cheap liquid nitrogen, and higher temperatures have been reported since. The OTA study said high-temperature superconductivity should receive a higher priority at universities than it does now.

DOC.HEAD: Former LBJ Aides Gather for 25th Reunion
DOC.TEXT: President Lyndon Johnson was an ``awesome engine of a man'' whose personality and deeds cannot be captured in a book, a former aide said Thursday at a 25th anniversary symposium celebrating LBJ's 1965 inaugural. Lady Bird Johnson and daughters Luci Turpin of Toronto and Lynda Robb of McLean, Va., were among several hundred people who attended the symposium of friends and former associates. Jack Valenti, special assistant to Johnson in 1963-66, said, ``Nobody knows better than the people in this room that Lyndon Johnson was many-sided, contradictory, and no one near him, with the exception of his wife, ever took the total measure of the man. ``And so it will be, that none of the written, or yet to be written, volumes will be definitive on the work President Johnson performed, on the deeds that he accomplished and on the flaws he exhibited.'' Valenti referred to the controversy raging over the second volume of a three-volume biography of Johnson. The author, Robert Caro, portrays the former president as a man without scruples who stole his 1948 election to the U.S. Senate. Valenti, now president of the Motion Picture Association of America, said Caro's latest book, ``Means of Ascent,'' and the earlier volume fall short _ ``way short.'' ``Every Caro word is dipped in curare, every Caro page squirmed with loathing. The cards are marked, the deck is stacked,'' he said. ``Almost anything that you could say about LBJ had a tinge of truth except one thing _ you could never say he was dull,'' Valenti said. ``He was an awesome engine of a man, and you and I in this room will never, ever again see his like.'' Former Democratic vice presidential candidate Sargent Shriver, a Johnson assistant in 1965-68, said the United States ``needs desperately the vision of a Kennedy and the political genius of a Johnson and their can-do spirit to get our nation moving again.'' ``Yes, I've read and heard about Kennedy's alleged womanizing, and Johnson's alleged theft of an election,'' Shriver said in a reference to Caro's version of Johnson's narrow 1948 U.S. Senate victory over former Texas Gov. Coke Stevenson, who was lionized in the book as a Texas hero. ``The only perfect man I've ever heard of is Jesus Christ and the only perfect woman was his mother, Mary,'' Shriver said. ``So, I'm not looking for any miraculous reincarnation of virgin birth _ most certainly I'm not looking for a Coke Stevenson.'' The symposium, co-sponsored by the University of Texas at Austin and LBJ Library, continues through Saturday. Johnson, who became president after the Nov. 22, 1963, assassination of John F. Kennedy, won the White House on his own in 1964. He retired to his ranch west of Austin in 1969 and lived there until his death in 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher's Conservatives Lose Heavily in British Local Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with later results, Conservatives say, ``It's the massacre that didn't happen.'' No pickup
