DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party lost heavily in local elections Thursday, and socialists posted their best performance since she won power 11 years ago. But the Conservatives, in deep trouble over the economy and the imposition of an unpopular new local government tax, averted the rout forecast in opinion polls, where Mrs. Thatcher trails by nearly 20 points. ``Not a marvellous result, but certainly not the disaster that was being predicted,'' said Environment Secretary Chris Patten, the Cabinet official in charge of the new so-called poll tax. ``It's the massacre that didn't happen.'' The Labor Party was jubilant. It was the only party to make net gains and easily outstripped its target of 200 new seats. With results declared from 180 of the 201 councils, Labor had made 10 new gains to control 89 concils. The Conservatives lost eight and had control of 36. The third-running centrist Social and Liberal Democratic Party controlled three councils and had lost three. No party had overall control in the rest. About 5,000 seats were at stake. ``We're delighted,'' said Labor campaign manager Bryan Gould. But he said the Tories' not doing as badly as predicted would lessen pressure by some worried Conservatives to try to shed Mrs. Thatcher as leader. ``If so, the Tories will be making a mistake,'' he added. For the first time since Mrs. Thatcher won power in 1979, Laborites made significant gains in the Tory heartlands of the prosperous south. Labor seized control from the Tories of the south England port of Portsmouth and for the first time in nearly 20 years, Laborites won seats in nearby Torbay, previously total Conservative territory. The Tories also lost control of the key northern industrial city of Bradford. But in London, Labor fared badly in what some analysts saw as a continuing legacy of ultraleft Labor councils that captured control of some of the 36 boroughs in the 1980s. In a key result, the Conservatives held with a hugely increased majority London's Wandsworth borough, a focus of national attention after setting the lowest poll tax in the nation. The tax helps fund local council spending. A BBC computer prediction early Friday indicated a swing of 12 percent against the government. ``This is something we can learn from, but there's no reason to panic,'' said Conservative legislator John Biffen, the party's former leader in the House of Commons. BBC analyst Peter Kellner said the Tory performance was the ``worst since modern politics began. The Tories really are in deep trouble.'' The elections were the first comprehensive opinion test since Mrs. Thatcher won a third successive term in 1987. In polls taken in the past month, the Labor lead averaged a huge 19 points, but down from an average 23 points in the previous month. According to forecasts from two weekend opinion polls, the socialists were poised to snatch up to 300 seats from the Tories _ or one-fourth of the total defended by the governing party. Mrs. Thatcher hoped the poll tax, imposed April 1, would turn voters against high-spending Labor-controlled authorities. Instead, most families are paying more and blame the government. The tax is also seen as unfair because everyone in a district pays the same, irrespective of income. Under the old system of property taxes only the 17 million homeowners paid. Now all 38 million adult Britons have to pay, with rebates for the 9.5 million poorest. The seats at stake Thursday were on regional authorities from remote islands off northern Scotland to big cities and English rural districts. The authorities run services ranging from education and subsidized housing to street cleaning and garbage removal. They are funded through a combination of the poll tax, business taxes and central government grants. Before voting, Labor held about 2,500 of the seats, the Tories 1,500 and centrists or independents the rest. Before Thursday, Labor ran 97 of the councils, the Conservatives 60 and the centrist Social and Liberal Democratic Party 18. In the others, no party had overall control.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Concerned About US Attack; US Issues Denial
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS graf 2 to CORRECT spelling of Havana
DOC.TEXT: Cuba announced large-scale defense measures Thursday to guard against what it described as a potential U.S. military attack but the State Department said the Cuban claims were ``totally false.'' A dispatch from Havana of the Cuban government news agency Prensa Latina monitored in Mexico City said Cuba had mounted ``Operation Shield'' which aimed at throwing back any U.S. incursion into Cuban territory from the U.S. naval base at Guantanamo on Cuba's southeastern coast.
DOC.HEAD: The report, 3rd graf
Sutherland's Daughters Talk to Ex-Hostage Frank Reed
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thomas Sutherland was in ``great physical and mental shape'' the last time he was seen by his recently freed fellow hostage, Frank Reed, Sutherland's daughters said on their father's 59th birthday Thursday. Joan and Kit Sutherland said Reed called from Wiesbaden, West Germany, on Wednesday night to send the women their father's love. Reed, who spent Thursday undergoing further debriefings in Wiesbaden by a special team seeking clues about other Western hostages, told the women he had not seen their father since February 1989 but had spent about two years with him. ``He said that Dad was in great physical and mental shape and that he sends all of his love to his family,'' Joan, 25, said as her father spent his fifth birthday in captivity. ``The most important thing was that he was OK, which to us was a dream come true.'' Sutherland was on leave as a Colorado State University professor when he was abducted June 9, 1985, while he was acting dean of agriculture at American University of Beirut in Lebanon. His wife, Jean, is still in Beirut and teaches English at American University. Reed called the women at their Fort Collins home 70 miles north of here and talked about 45 minutes, said Kit, 29, the second of Sutherland's three daughters. The phone call was the best news they've received in two years, Joan Sutherland said. Reed said her father ``hanging in there and waiting to be released,'' she said. ``We're hoping but we're not expecting anything. My mom is feeling real optimistic, too. She has taught us to be that way.'' Mrs. Sutherland sent her husband birthday greetings Thursday via a leftist Beirut newspaper. Her message, carried by As-Safir in Arabic and English, said: ``I send you the best gift I have, my dear _ `a red, red rose' of love. May it touch your heart and spirit in a special way on this your special day.'' The daughters celebrated their father's birthday Wednesday at the First Presbyterian Church in Fort Collins where Sutherland was a member for more than 30 years. The crowd that gathered there sang ``Happy Birthday'' and blew out candles on a large cake while children tied yellow ribbons around trees outside. A pro-Iranian group calling itself Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, has claimed responsibility for Sutherland's abduction. The group also holds Terry Anderson, the longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon. Anderson, 42, the Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Although Islamic Jihad has issued photos of other hostages, it has never issued a picture of Sutherland. Another American, Robert Polhill, was freed in Beirut on April 22. Both were freed with the help of Syria.

DOC.HEAD: Two Amtrak Derailments in 24 Hours Injure 55 People
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS to UPDATE throughout with 30 injured, sted 29; CORRECTS number of passengers in 6th graf pvs, `Officials said...' to 200 passengers, 13 crew; CORRECTS that truck driver in 17th graf, `Boren was...' trapped for more than 1 hour, sted 2; pickup 18th graf, Amtrak officials...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JX3
DOC.TEXT: A passenger train crashed into a truck, injuring 30 people Thursday, less than 24 hours after another Amtrak train smashed into a row of freight cars in Indiana in an accident that injured 26. The latest accident occurred about 9:30 a.m. when the train, ``City of New Orleans,'' en route from Chicago to New Orleans, struck a log truck at a private railroad crossing near the Memphis Hardwood Co., a lumberyard in Durant. Authorities said no flashing lights or signs marked the crossing. ``It looked like a dynamite explosion,'' said state Trooper Jimmie D. Thomas, who witnessed the accident. ``When it hit, it scattered lumber all over creation, and the truck was dragged down the track.'' ``It was a big jolt,'' said passenger Melissa Mitchell. ``Everybody woke up. ... We got outside and saw that we were majorly off the track, but upright.'' Deborah Hare, an Amtrak spokeswoman, said there were 200 passengers and 13 crew members aboard the train. Four crew members were among those injured, she said. Officials earlier said there were from 160 to 170 people, including crew, on the train. It was the second Amtrak crash in two days and the third in two weeks. Authorities said an incorrectly set switch sent a Chicago-to-Indianapolis train crashing into freight cars Wednesday night near Crawfordsville, Ind. On April 22, at least 91 people were reported hurt, three seriously, when the national passenger rail line's California Zephyr derailed in Iowa en route from California to Chicago. The southbound ``Hoosier State'' with 30 to 35 people aboard derailed Wednesday night after striking five freight cars parked on an outside track 40 miles northwest of Indianapolis. A passenger and the train's engineer and assistant engineer remained hospitalized Thursday with minor injuries. The others were treated. ``Thank God we were only going 25 (mph), or him and I would be history,'' said assistant engineer James Neff, 42, referring to himself and Amtrak employee James Ullery, 40. Ullery said that by the time he noticed the train was on the wrong track, it was too late. Officials from Amtrak, Conrail, the National Transportation Safety Board and the Federal Railroad Administration were investigating the cause of the crash, but released no preliminary results. Conrail owns the track where the accident occurred. In the accident at Durant, District Two Community Hospital reported at least 30 people were brought from the scene. A spokeswoman said that except for the truck driver, most of the people were treated for bumps and bruises. The truck driver, Andrew Wilbur Boren, 69, an employee of Memphis Hardwood, was transferred by helicopter to Mississippi Baptist Medical Center in Jackson, 45 miles south of Durant. He was in stable condition. ``I was sound asleep when the train hit, and it was a rather rude and abrupt alarm clock I thought,'' Mitchell said. Boren was trapped more than one hours after the accident. The log truck had left a nearby lumberyard shortly before the crash occurred. Amtrak officials said the remaining passengers were loaded on school buses and driven to Jackson where they would catch chartered buses to New Orleans. State Trooper L.C. Clark said three engines ran off the tracks and were lying on their sides next to the rails. Three passenger cars also derailed but remained upright.

DOC.HEAD: Precede UNITED NATIONS
Contras Insist on Disarming Sandinista Army before Disbanding
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Contras insist army disband at same time as Contras. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Contras insisted Thursday that the Sandinista army must be dismantled at the same time as the rebels, a demand the Chamorro government immediately rejected as dangerous to Nicaragua's fragile peace. Aristides Sanchez, a spokesman for the U.S.-supported Contras, said the rebels will not meet the June 10 deadline to hand in their weapons to U.N. military peacekeepers, as they had pledged to do in an April 19 agreement. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said earlier Thursday he considered the holdup in demobilization ``a matter of grave concern.'' Sanchez, a civilian adviser to the Contra leaders, said Thursday that what the Contras now want ``is the complete dismantling'' of the army, simultaneously with the rebel force. ``That is what the people of Nicaragua ask for, that is what the people want, and we should support that,'' he said. ``One doesn't have to be so airtight about it,'' Sanchez replied when asked if the rebels planned to meet the June 10 deadline. He spoke to reporters shortly after arriving in Managua from a rebel hideout in hill country with Contra military chief Israel Galeano and four members of Galeano's general staff to discuss the problem Friday with officials of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's government. ``After 10 years of fighting ... it's not possible to dismantle an organization in 24 hours,'' Galeano replied when asked why his fighters have not started to demobilize. Roberto Ferrey, a government spokesman and himself a former Contra, was asked if the government would consider acceding to the rebel demand. ``In principle, no,'' he replied ``June 10 is the deadline. It's not possible to change it.'' Leaders of the Sandinista party, which Mrs. Chamorro easily defeated in elections Feb. 25, say Nicaragua could be plunged into chaos if the Contras do not disband on schedule. They add, however, that the army is protected by the constitution from any drastic shakeups. Mrs. Chamorro took office April 25 for a six-year term. She promised to respect the military's professional structure but plans to cut deeply the size of the army to reduce government spending and mend the war-shattered economy. The Contra leaders arrived dressed in fatigues but unarmed, accompanied by observers from the U.N. and the Organization of American States. Perez de Cuellar said he considered it ``a matter of grave concern that the demobilization of the members of the Nicaraguan Resistance did not begin in the afternoon of April 25, as stipulated in the agreements signed at Managua on April 18-19.'' The Security Council, which called for U.N. observers to disarm the Contras, will meet Friday to discuss the demobilization problem. ``Serious efforts must now be made by all concerned in order to get the demobilization process quickly back on track,'' Perez de Cuellar said in his report. ``This can only be done if the solemn commitments contained in the Managua agreements are scrupulously honored.'' On his recommendation, 586 military observers from a Venezuelan battalion and 54 U.N. military observers were deployed in five ``security zones'' in Nicaragua. Ferrey, who represents Mrs. Chamorro in the peace talks with the rebels, said her meeting with the Contra people Friday ``is to discuss security issues and guarantees for their demobilization and disarmament according to the accords.'' Rebel negotiator Oscar Sovalbarro signed the accord on disarmament and demobilization, but Galeano had said earlier he would not disband his troops because Mrs. Chamorro kept a Sandinista as army chief. Mrs. Chamorro has retained Gen. Humberto Ortega, who was defense minister in the Sandinista government, as army chief of staff but says the assignment is temporary. Maj. Jose Luis Garcia, head of intelligence for the U.N. peace keeping forces in Nicaragua, said that as of last week more than 6,000 rebels have gathered in the five security zones though they are still armed.

DOC.HEAD: Government: Noriega Attorney Received `Seven-Figure' Retainer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and grafs 8-9, bgn, `Rubino did...,' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Rubino comments.
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors said Thursday that Manuel Noriega's lead attorney told them he had received a ``seven-figure'' retainer, but defense lawyers said the statement was made in jest and the team has no money left. The issue was raised in response to the defense team's motion to withdraw from the case on grounds the government had frozen all Noriega's bank accounts, leaving them with no financial resources. That motion was scheduled to go before U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler late Friday afternoon. Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan said in papers filed Thursday opposing the withdrawal that the defense team's claims ``are simply untrue and disingenuous.'' According to an affidavit, on or about January 1990, lead Noriega attorney Frank Rubino discussed his retainer with another assistant U.S. attorney, Cynthia Hawkins, during the course of a plea bargain conference on an unrelated case. As it was being typed up, ``Mr. Rubino mentioned that the retainer he had been paid to represent Gen. Noriega was `in seven figures,''' or at least $1 million, according to Ms. Hawkins' signed statement. Rubino then asked ``whether I was going to go into private practice to make more money,'' the affidavit said. Rubino said Thursday he recalled the incident, which he said occurred well after the United States began its invasion of Panama on Dec. 20 but before Noriega arrived in the United States in early January. ``I was in her office, we were all laughing and talking and joking,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``From her lips to God's ears it should be true,'' he said jokingly. ``It's just silly.'' Co-counsel Jon May said the government had ``taken seriously a statement that was made in jest. ... There is no money.'' He added that the defense would give more details at Friday's hearing. May also said the defense would demand that the government show probable cause for contending the frozen funds were drug-related. Should prosecutors fail to do that, the defense would demand the money be turned over to Noriega, he said. The government's response stated it has frozen $20 million in various bank accounts, but only one is in Noriega's name, and investigators do not know if that account contains any money. ``Stripped of its misleading and unsupported allegations, counsels' argument represents an attempt to require the Government to pay defense counsel a higher fee,'' said the U.S. attorney's response, which was also signed by prosecutors Myles Malman and Guy Lewis. The defense motion, filed Monday, said the attorneys had run out of money, and could not hire attorneys, secretaries and investigators to handle the complex case. They said they had received no fees for 10 months, and only a few thousand dollars in expense money. Noriega was indicted here in February 1988 on charges of taking money from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to make Panama into a safe haven for cocaine smuggling. Noriega surrendered to U.S. authorities on Jan. 4, two weeks after U.S. troops invaded Panama, and is being held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Explodes, Kills 4 in Cocaine Center
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded Thursday night in front of a pharmacy in the western city of Cali, killing four people and wounding 20, the radio network RCN reported. The explosion in the cocaine trafficking center was the latest involving the La Rebaja pharmacy chain. Police have blamed previous attacks on the continuing war between the rival Medellin and Cali cocaine cartels. The bomb went off in the crowded Alameda neighborood, destroying the La Rebaja pharmacy and smashing windows and causing other damage in 13 nearby businesses, Col. Jaime Sierra, director of the police in Cali, told the network. The four victims included a 3-year-old boy and a security guard, RCN quoted police as saying. Police said they did not know who set off the explosion, and there was no immediate claim of responsibility. A series of attacks on the pharmacy chain had ended when after Gilberto Rodriguez Orejuela, the reputed leader of the Cali cartel, sold his interest in the chain. It was the second bombing in the city of 1.5 million in the last 24 hours. On Wednesday, two bombs were thrown at a police station, injuring four policemen and severely damaging the building. Traffickers have been blamed for the deaths of nearly 300 people in terrorist attacks since August 1989, when the government declared war on traffickers. U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration sources said the Cali and Medellin cartels account for more than half the cocaine smuggled into the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Choice of General as Premier Sparks Protests
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top general, picked by President Lee Teng-hui to become premier, tried Thursday to win over lawmakers fearful about military intervention in politics. The Yuan, Taiwan's highest lawmaking body, will have to approve the nomination of Defense Minster Hau Pei-tsun when it is formally submitted later this month. Hau would replace Premier Lee Huan. About 100 college students demonstrated Thursday against the choice of the general, and opposition politicians have vowed to paralyze the legislature until the president backs down. Political observers say Lee chose Hau, 71, to shore up support among the governing Nationalist Party's conservative old guard. Hau was one of many senior party officials who fled to Taiwan with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in 1949 after losing a civil war on the Chinese mainland to Communist forces. The aging Nationalists still dream of returning to China to rule. The students shouted ``Hau Pei-tsun, get lost!'' and ``Oppose military intervention in politics,'' as they marched to the Yuan, where they urged lawmakers to reject the nomination. An angry opposition politician, Liu Wen-hsiung, trampled a picture of the president at a legislative meeting. Hau visited the Yuan Thursday to seek support, and the mass-circulation China Times quoted him as saying he supported democracy as long as the opposition agrees that the island is a province of China. He was also quoted as saying the military will not interfere in politics. Hau was appointed defense minister last year after serving as chief of the armed forces for eight years. In recent years, the Nationalists have gradually loosened their tight grip on power, lifting martial law, allowing opposition political parties and giving more government posts to the native Taiwanese, who account for 85 percent of the island's 20 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh, Mexican Attorney General Pledge Cooperation
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Mexico on Thursday pledged cooperation in the war on drugs despite an undercurrent of tension stemming from the abduction of a Mexican citizen wanted by U.S. officials. U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and his Mexican counterpart delivered separate speeches at a conference of attorneys general from states on both sides of the border. Thornburgh praised Mexico's ``priority efforts against drugs and corruption'' and said cooperation between the two nations has never been better. He also referred to the ``problems that inevitably arise among neighbors.'' The kidnapping of a Guadalajara gynecologist wanted in connection with the murder of a U.S. drug agent has strained relations between the United States and Mexico. It was the subject of closed-door talks Wednesday between Thornburgh and Mexican Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo. Mexican officials said Thursday they want proof of U.S. claims that the kidnapping last month of Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain was masterminded by Mexican federal police. Thornburgh told Alvarez del Castillo that Mexican police had hatched the plot, according to a source. But a spokesman for Alvarez del Castillo said U.S. officials did not back up the allegation. ``If the Department of Justice of the United States has proof that demonstrates that the police in Mexico intervened in the abduction of Alvarez Machain, they should prove it,'' said Rene Hernandez, director of information for the Mexican attorney general's office. Machain was abducted April 2 from his office and flown by private jet to El Paso, Texas, where he was arrested by the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. He is to stand trial in Los Angeles for his alleged participation in the 1985 torture death of DEA agent Enrique Camarena. A federal judge has ordered a hearing May 25 into the circumstances of Alvarez's arrival in the U.S. A Mexican who identified himself as a longtime DEA operative told the Los Angeles Times last week that he hatched the plot to kidnap Alvarez and that it had DEA approval. DEA has denied its involvement. Neither Thornburgh nor Alvarez del Castillo mentioned the Machain case specifically in their speeches Thursday. Alvarez del Castillo said the meeting of law enforcement officials was ``testimony of trust, of respect, of hope _ that's what Mexico is offering.'' ``Let us recognize that on some occasions the fight against drug trafficking and drug addiction have generated disagreements,'' Alvarez del Castillo said. ``It often happens that common enemies generate confrontations that in the long run will be beneficial.'' He also, however, made repeated references during his speech to Mexico's sovereignty, which Mexico has complained was violated in the Machain abduction. Mexican officials said they are prepared to ask for the extradition of the self-described DEA operative, Antonio Garate Bustamante.

DOC.HEAD: Three Former Lawmen Convicted of Murdering Black Inmate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix writethru designation. INSERTS 10 grafs after 7th graf pvs, `His mother...' to UPDATE with acquittal and trial summation quotes; CORRECTS sentencing scheduled for Friday sted Thursday in 11th graf, `The three...'; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Three white former lawmen were found guilty Thursday of murder in the death of a black jail inmate in 1987. The all-white jury deliberated for about four hours before finding former Hemphill Police Chief Thomas Ladner and former Sabine County sheriff's deputies Billy Ray Horton and James M. Hyden guilty in the death of Loyal Garner Jr. The 34-year-old Florien, La., resident died of head injuries two days after being arrested on Christmas Day 1987 on drunken driving charges. An estimated 200 people packed the courtroom for Thursday's verdict. ``I want no show of emotion, no outbursts, no crying, no nothing,'' State District Judge Joe Tunnells said before reading the jury's verdict. Garner's widow, Corrinne Garner, cried quietly as the verdict was announced. His mother, Sarah Garner said, ``I'm glad. I hope it's over.'' ``They told us there would never be another trial, but still I didn't given up. There wasn't a day come that I didn't look up to heaven and talk to God about it,'' she said. Johnnie Maxie, one of the two brothers arrested with Garner, said he was surprised by the outcome. He said he had not expected the men to be convicted. The three lawmen had been acquitted by a Sabine County jury in July 1988 of charges that they violated Garner's civil rights by beating him and denying him medical attention. The acquittal drew angry protests from the black community in East Texas. In November 1988, the two deputies filed a $6 million lawsuit claiming two trial witnesses and two lawyers concocted the case against them. The three could be sentenced to a maximum 99 years in prison Friday morning when the punishment phase of the trial is scheduled. Ladner and Horton declined to comment after the verdict. Hyden, asked if he had anything to say, remarked tersely: ``Not yet.'' During his closing arguments Wednesday, Smith County District Attorney Jack Skeen told the jury that the ex-lawmen displayed a total indifference to human life and that the badges they wore did not give them ``a license to murder.'' John Seale, Ladner's lawyer, called the prosecution's case weak because it was based on the dishonest testimony of ``three jailbird witnesses.'' In his rebuttal, Skeen said prosecutors relied on testimony from inmates because the prisoners were the only witnesses who didn't work for the county. A prosecutor told the jurors Wednesday that the officers ``crossed over that line of law enforcement officers to common criminals,'' when they beat Garner. Defense attorneys said the men struck Garner in self-defense.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Chosen for Second McMartin Pre-School Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE with alternates chosen, opening set for Monday.
DOC.TEXT: A jury was selected Thursday for Raymond Buckey's second trial in the McMartin Pre-School child molestation case, the longest and costliest criminal proceeding in U.S. history. The seating of 12 regular jurors and six alternates came less than a month after attorneys began their inquiry to find panelists unbiased by publicity surrounding the first Buckey trial. Opening statements were set for Monday. Buckey, 31, who has been a defendant for nearly seven years, was acquitted of 40 molestation charges Jan. 18, and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, was acquitted of 12 charges. But prosecutors decided to retry Buckey on eight counts on which the jury deadlocked. A total of 13 charges were unresolved by that jury, but the prosecution dropped five of those counts. The first trial lasted nearly three years and cost $13 million. The eight remaining charges being tried involve three children who attended the now defunct McMartin preschool in Manhattan Beach _ a dramatically diminished group compared to the hundreds once described as alleged victims. Buckey and his lawyers, who had hoped for dismissal of all remaining charges, have accused District Attorney Ira Reiner of playing politics with the case. They say he decided to retry Buckey to further his own ambitions to become California attorney general. Reiner has denied any ulterior motives. Parents of McMartin school children campaigned loudly to have Buckey retried in the week after his acquittal on most charges. They conducted a letter-writing campaign, went on national TV talk shows and held press conferences to espouse their views. Deputy District Attorneys Joe Martinez and Pam Ferrero have said they hope the new trial can be concluded in six months. But Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg warned prospective jurors at the outset that the trial could continue into 1991.

The pines are tall, lines at cash registers are short and a phone call is still only a dime in this country town. People live here to get away from city and suburban pressures. But today, after a cluster of teen-age suicides, residents are mourning the dead, and, in a sense, the town's loss of innocence. ``It's terrible for a small town like this to have to wake up like this,'' said resident Carolyn Talbert. The high school is flooded with psychiatrists, psychologists and counselors. Police track down absent students if phone calls home aren't answered. Students try to make sense of the senseless.

After two years of drought, the Lone Star State was badly parched. But when it finally rained, it poured. Record downpours this spring in north-central Texas _ the Badlands _ have caused flooding, claimed nine lives, damaged crops and sent residents scrambling from their homes. Drenching rain, 60 mph wind and tornadoes continued today. ``Not since 1922 have we had rain like this,'' said Ed Delgado, spokesman for the National Weather Service in Fort Worth. ``We have seen some lakes rise in water level by four feet overnight, and there is more rain in the forecast.'' North-central Texas _ which includes Dallas and Fort Worth _ is closing in on its average yearly rainfall total _ and the year is not even halfway over.

After barely six weeks on the job, Kennedy Center Chairman James D. Wolfensohn is clear about his goals: give the marble cultural palace a $30 million facelift, fill its stages with arts festivals and lay the welcome mat for inner-city audiences. ``I'm not worried about competition,'' he says. ``I'm worried about my capacity to deliver.'' Wolfensohn, 56, has become a frequent flier aboard the shuttle between Washington and New York _ where he also is chairman of Carnegie Hall and president of a high-powered investment banking firm _ since he took command of the Kennedy Center last month without pay. It didn't take Wolfensohn long to discover that the Kennedy Center is an institution in trouble. He found a deepening financial crisis, generally listless programming _ with a few bright spots _ and nagging confusion over the center's proper artistic role and future direction.

The Interior Department is pressing ahead with a trade of coal-rich Wyoming land for a pristine view in Grand Teton National Park, despite criticism that the taxpayers will get cheated on the deal. Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., chairman of a House Government Operations subcommittee investigating the swap, said the government is giving away too much coal at the ``fire sale'' price of 2.7 cents a ton. In exchange, the government would receive a ban on development of the largest tract of private land in the Wyoming national park. Both the rights to the coal and the park land were valued at $5.6 million. Synar's environment subcommittee, which was reviewing the exchange at a hearing today, released documents concluding that taxpayers could lose up to $180 million in the transaction because the coal was undervalued.

Bleary-eyed workers of the night, take heart: Scientists have found a way to help you get a decent day's sleep. A simple combination of bright light at night and total darkness during the day can help night-shift workers quickly adapt to their upside-down hours, researchers found. The approach appears to be the first quick, practical cure for the night-shift blues, the on-the-job sleepiness and daytime insomnia that plague many of the nation's 7 million night workers. The principal developer, Dr. Charles A. Czeisler of Boston's Brigham and Women's Hospital, said more testing needs to be done before employers start installing new lights.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv09
For Release PMs Wednesday May 9 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Students Join Study Groups to Become `Politically Mature'
DOC.TEXT: More than 10,000 Beijing teen-agers are giving up their Saturday afternoons, not really through choice, to learn about the Communist Party in political study groups at high schools and universities. Official media hail the grups as proof of revived interest in ideology among youngsters. In fact, many of the students are ``volunteered'' by their schools or youth organizations. Others sign up because showing the right political attitudes can be a shortcut to a leading university or a good job. Classes have different names _ spare-time Communist Party school, Marxism-Leninism study group, communism study group _ but share the goal of teaching students to love the party and fight ``bourgeois liberalism,'' or Western ideas. Chinese authorities are trying to recapture a generation that has harbored deep resentment of the party since the harsh military suppression of the democracy movement a year ago. Young people speak scornfully of the government in private, but go along with the ideological campaign in order to avoid trouble. This is the official story: Young Chinese were shaken by last year's movement, which started among college students in Beijing and spread quickly to other cities. Politically immature students did not fully understand communism or China's national conditions, and became pawns of ``foreign hostile forces.'' A Beijing high school student chosen from thousands of applicants for a 14-week course on the Communist Party was quoted as saying: ``We understand very little about the party. I think this is closely related to why we had the turmoil'' last year. According to the weekly Beijing Review, one college student said ``he knew many of the arguments were wrong'' during the pro-democracy movement felt it ``difficult to produce a correct explanation'' and that ``only by studying Marxism-Leninism could he distinguish right from wrong.'' At Fudan University in Shanghai, one of the most noted liberal arts schools, philosophy major Wang Haifeng and seven classmates started a Marxist philosophy study group in September. Official reports say 57 more groups have been started at Fudan since, involving more than 600 students. On its front page last month, China Youth News published an appeal from Wang and his seven friends that said: ``We students have great need to study Marxist philosophy ... to enhance our political quality and theoretical level. Studying Marxism will help us establish a correct world view and outlook on life.'' Last fall, more than 2,000 students were said to be studying in the Communist Party school at Qinghua University in Beijing, China's foremost technical institution. Xinhua, the official news agency, said the students were so enthusiastic the university library could not meet the demand for such works as Marx's ``Communist Manifesto'' and ``The Selected Works of Mao Tse-tung.'' The Communist Youth League in Beijing has started similar classes for high school students. At Beijing's No. 4 Middle School, more than 800 students fill the auditorium each Saturday afternoon for lectures by college professors and officials of the Youth League Committee. Zhou Shiliang, a professor at the Youth's College of Political Science run by the Communist Youth League, lectured for two hours recently on the meaning and history of communism. Each week's lectures are taped and shown to nearly 10,000 high school students at other party schools in Beijing. Four students from each Beijing high school attended on the day Zhou spoke. Most listened attentively, but a few boys in warmup suits tapped their feet impatiently when an enticing spring breeze entered through the open auditorium doors. One girl was seen reading a tattered novel hidden by her notebook. Zhou urged students to give up selfish ambitions and devote their lives to realizing communism in China. He likened the task to climbing a mountain and declared: ``If you want to be part of the work of communism, you must be prepared spiritually and mentally.'' At one point in his exhortation, Zhou roared at the students: ``Are you for protecting private ownership and exploitation or for wiping out private ownership and wiping out exploitation?'' Almost inaudibly, his listeners muttered the correct response. Xu Fei, a 17-year-old who took copious notes, said afterward: ``We're all here to learn. Even though we live in a socialist country, what is socialism really? We don't know. ``Before, I felt that communism was very distant and vague. Now I know that communism will indeed be achieved.''

$Adv10
For Release PMs Thursday May 10 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Many Non-Socialists Joining Party to Get Elected
DOC.TEXT: There are socialists in Japanese politics today who don't believe in socialism. They believe in their own causes, and in getting elected. To do that, they are joining the Socalist Party and changing it from a radical, heavily ideological party unlikely to win power into a varied group of reformers with a far better chance against the governing Liberal Democrats. The new members are lawyers, physicians, college professors, journalists and housewives. An example is Tomiko Okazaki, a former television broadcaster who is one of 59 rookie Socialist Party members elected to the lower house of Parliament in February. The party increased its strength in the 512-seat chamber, where the power lies, from 83 to 139. ``I was never a socialist and I have no ideological background at all,'' said Ms. Okazaki, 46. ``I joined the party to get elected and to become a politician who can protect women's interests.'' Takako Doi, popular leader of the nation's largest opposition party, told the national convention in early April: ``We need to promote a broad range of reforms now to make our party credible for taking over the government. ``If we fail to do so now, we may end up permanently in the opposition camp.'' For years, internal ideological disputes hampered Socialist efforts to break the hold on power by the conservative, pro-business Liberal Democrats, who have governed Japan since the party was formed in 1955. Since Ms. Doi became the first woman leader of a major Japanese party in 1986, the Socialists have gradually muted intramural disagreements and shifted from ideology to a more populist style. In July 1989, the Socialists nearly doubled their strength in the 252-seat upper house, from 39 to 73, and the Liberal Democrats lost their majority for the first time. The governing party retained control in the February elections for the lower house by winning 275 seats, but the strong Socialist gains demonstrated that the opposition party is a growing challenge. Analysts said the Socialists benefited from Ms. Doi's popularity and a dual Liberal Democratic handicap: an influence-buying scandal that reached the top levels of the establishment and an unpopular sales tax. Tadatoshi Akiba, a former geometry professor at Tufts University in the United States, said Ms. Doi asked him last year to join the party and run for Parliament. ``I never thought about becoming a politician, nor was I ever interested in socialism before,'' the 47-year-old legislator said. ``I decided to run for Parliament because I thought I can change the Socialist Party and Japan's politics from inside.'' Asked what changes he wants in the party, he said it was changing already ``because it endorsed non-socialists like me in the election.'' At its convention in April, the party took the call for a socialist revolution out of its constitution. Some opposition was expressed by leftist factions, but a comfortable majority supported eliminating the clause. ``Our key ... right now is to take control of the government,'' Tsuruo Yamaguchi, the party secretary-general, said in an interview. ``I think most party members are willing to sacrifice their stubborn ideological positions for the sake of gaining control of the government.'' Party leaders say even giving it a new name is possible. Sukio Iwatare, a policy coordinator, said some of the changes were spurred by the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe. ``If the term `revolution' or the name `socialists' projects the wrong image that our party is a bunch of revolutionaries, I don't see why we should not change them,'' he said. Vice chairman Makoto Tanabe said the party would continue a market economy, with no drastic changes, but ``impose certain restrictions on economic activities from the viewpoint of protecting our environment and avoiding unfairness in our society.'' Under the Liberal Democrats, he said, ``only certain groups, such as large companies and landowners, (have) thrived while most people were not awarded the benefits of Japan's economic success.'' Foreign policy has been a problem for the Socialist Party because it advocated disarmament and neutrality for Japan, and abolition of the Japan-U.S. Security Treaty. The new line continues support for unarmed neutrality, Iwatare said, but ``We would not take a drastic approach to our ideal.''

DOC.HEAD: NBC's `Hunter' an Ex-Reporter, Sort Of
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stepfanie in 9th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: It's not widely known, but Fred Dryer played a hard-boiled sports reporter before he became the hard-eyed constable of NBC's ``Hunter.'' The occasion: a Superbowl press conference in January 1975. He and Lance Rentzel wore battered fedoras with hatbrim cards that said PRESS. They technically were employed by the Los Angeles Rams then. But they had press credentials secured by Dick Schaap, then a magazine sports editor. In their non-Rams capacity as newshawks, Dryer recalls, they asked such probing questions as: ``They say this is the Big Game and there's no tomorrow. Will you in fact be disappointed when the sun comes up tomorrow?'' For some reason, this caused grumbling from scribes who took pro football as almost seriously as TV does. Most, however, realized a put-on was under way. Not so some National Football League functionaries. ``They went crazy,'' Dryer said with slight grin. In due course, he said, then-NFL Commissioner Pete Rozelle made inquiries: ``He said, `I understand you guys are reporters. What are you doing?' ``I said, `Well, we're here to cover the news and print the .. . unmentioned. There's a lot of smut that needs to be punched up, and we're just the two guys to do it.''' The light dawned. Rozelle realized it was a spoof. The Superbowl, in which the Rams weren't playing, came and went. Six years later, so did Dryer, at least from pro ball after 13 seasons as a defensive tackle for the Rams and New York Giants. Although he knew that party had to end sometime, he hadn't particularly thought what he'd do after football until 1978, he said. Then, after considering and rejecting life in real estate, he began considering the acting business, then studied it for five years with actress Nina Foch. ``I had to find out what it was, how interested I was in it, and most important, could I make a living at it,'' he says. Small roles here and there followed, including four ``Cheers'' episodes as Ted Danson's old pal from baseball days. Then he read for ``Hunter,'' which some critics would later sneer at as a small-screen edition of ``Dirty Harry.'' Similar sneers greeted his first venture into feature films, a modern Marine shoot-'em-up called ``Death Before Dishonor,'' two years ago. It proved dead on arrival at the box office, for which Dryer blames the producers. But ``Hunter'' has lasted six seasons with Dryer as its lean, blue-jeaned star. NBC has found it a durable Saturday series. The network, which in mid-April shifted ``Hunter'' to Mondays, says a seventh season is likely. If so, Dryer, who says it already has been renewed, will start anew with a new female partner. Stepfanie Kramer is giving up her role as Hunter's sidekick, Sgt. Dee Dee McCall, for films and singing. Her swan song, so to speak, will occur in Monday's episode when she marries an old flame. Dryer, who at 6-foot-6 is the tallest of TV's cops, pondered a visitor's theory. It had nothing to do with Kramer's departure. The theory was that pro football players-turned-actors seem to be more successful and tend to have longer runs in network series if they've played on the defensive line. Two examples: Merlin Olsen and Alex Karras. The former piled up more than seven years in NBC's ``Little House on the Prairie,'' ``Father Murphy'' and the short-lived `Aaron's Way.'' Karras had four ABC years in ``Webster.'' True, former running back Ed Marinaro had five seasons as a co-star of ``Hill Street Blues.'' But the much better-known quarterback, Joe Namath, lasted only one month as the star of NBC's ``The Waverly Wonders.'' Dryer thought about all this. His eyes took on an evil glint. ``Well,'' he said, ``I think the true intelligence is in defense.'' __ Elsewhere in television: ANOTHER REASON TO CONTINUE LIVING: An NBC movie based on the ``Archie'' cartoon strip, will be shown Sunday. In it, Archie, Veronica, Jughead and Betty now are thirtysomething and coping with adult problems like divorce, careers and single parenthood. BERGENS EVERYWHERE: Frances Bergen, mother of the star of CBS' ``Murphy Brown,'' will be the guest star of the show's May 21 episode, in which Corky (Faith Ford) gets married. Mrs. Bergen, who plays the groom's mother, probably will be watching the May 19 edition of NBC's ``Saturday Night Live'' with great interest. Candace Bergen will be the show's host.

DOC.HEAD: Yes, Housing Has A Future
DOC.TEXT: Bonds are not the only junk peddled in the securities markets. There are junk companies too, financed by junk bonds. There is plenty of junk analysis too. Ask the folks who make up the housing and real estate markets, those people who have had to read one brokerage house analysis after another about how it no longer pays to own a home. Junky analysis, they say. As an investment, the Wall Street analysts contend, housing has had it. Prices have run up so far that buyers have been priced out of the market. The demographics are turning; there'll be a slowdown in buying-age population. Many of the analyses, including some from academe, have been the basis of stories about the great housing bust, the coming collapse of housing prices, the ominous recession in real estate, crumbling castles and the like. Such notions so irritated the National Association of Home Builders that it countered with a special report, pointing out that housing is not a security, is not wildly traded, is more than an investment, and has basic, innate value. It has not stopped Wall Street. A brokerage house analysis just issued grows enthusiastic about the demise of the single-family home as the American family's primary investment. Now, it suggests, people will turn to securities. The analyst contends that ``adjusted for quality and price change, the average American homeowner is worse off today than he or she was in 1980.'' ``Really?'' housing people ask. In 1980, the median price of single-family homes was $64,000. By late last year, just before the decade closed, the median was more than $125,000, or close to double, an increase greater than inflation in general. This, after putting up just 10 percent of the price, living in the house for a decade, watching children grow up, enjoying unique income tax deductions, having the use of low-cost equity loans, paying down the mortgage ... ``The reality of home price underperformance in the 1980s has been very slow to sink in. Many people clung (and in some instances still cling) to the expectations of renewed appreciation,'' the analysis continues. Perhaps they do, but meanwhile they have a roof over their heads and a foundation under their feet, which is more than can be said for some of the junk companies that Wall Street recommended in the 1980s. But why, housing industry people ask, should home prices collapse or barely keep pace with inflation? Because, say Wall Street's analysts, housing has been priced beyond the means of buyers. Prices must fall to meet the market. Maybe so, but isn't the market there? Those same analysts have been saying for years that millions of Americans couldn't afford houses, and it is unlikely that they will have disappeared at the very time opportunity arrives. But, the analysts say, the young-family bulge that supported homebuying in the 1980s will flatten in the 1990s. Yes, say the housing people, and that means builders probably won't build as many houses as in the 1980s. Aside from these considerations, the home builders point out other salient considerations that tend to support prices. Buildable land, the biggest single factor in housing costs, is not growing in supply. If anything, building and environmental codes may become even more strict. Labor costs aren't likely to plunge. While people don't necessarily need stocks and bonds, and from time to time foresake the markets in them, they do need homes. Most people wouldn't be caught without one.

DOC.HEAD: Reform Brings Higher Scores, Accountability in Delta Schools
With BC-Children of the Delta II
DOC.TEXT: For nearly a decade, states in the Mississippi Delta region have pursued tough education reforms, and they are starting to get results. Last month, Kentucky Gov. Wallace Wilkinson signed legislation that will overhaul public education. The changes were enacted after the state Supreme Court in June found the public school system inequitable and unconstitutional. Spending per pupil varied district to district from $1,800 to $4,200. Now a state minimum, $2,900, has been established. In addition, the new Kentucky law calls for committees of parents, teachers and principals to make day-to-day school decisions. In Mississippi, Gov. Ray Mabus also signed legislation in April, continuing education reforms begun in the early 1980s that have raised standardized test scores for the last four years and increased accountability by requiring district ``report cards.'' One measure commits $182 million to curriculum improvements in the next three years; another calls for $800 million in bonds to replace aging school buildings and buses. Mabus has said he'll call a special legislative session in June to work out how to finance the plan. Arkansas' education reforms have reduced class sizes, added support personnel and expanded the curriculum, particularly language, science and math courses. A 1-cent sales tax hike and a teacher testing policy were among reforms pushed by Gov. Bill Clinton in 1983. Since then, his office says, 1,400 people who failed the teacher tests are out of the classroom, 17,000 more students are taking foreign-language classes than in 1983, 15 percent more students are attending college, dropout rates have improved and test scores are up. In Tennessee, a draft of Gov. Ned McWherter's 1991 package spells out 12 major goals, from requiring kindergarten to better preparing college freshmen to do college-level work. The plan also calls for ``performance audit teams'' in the state education department. Reforms in Louisiana have included reducing classroom size, rewarding successful schools and raising teachers' pay, though hard times in the state's petroleum industry have cut revenues. One effort Gov. Buddy Roemer is pushing is a $30 million computer-based reading lab. The states still fall behind much of the nation in per pupil spending. According to the National Center for Educational Statistics in Washington, the national average expenditure was $4,243 in 1987-88, the last year for which complete figures were available. The comparable state figures were: Kentucky, $3,011; Mississippi, $2,548; Arkansas, $2,989; Tennessee, $3,068; and Louisiana, $3,138.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran U.S. Senator Seriously Challenged By Ex-KKK Leader
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Bennett Johnston's slide into a fourth term should have been well greased by his $2 million campaign war chest and plenty of pork barrel power after 18 years on Capitol Hill. Instead, the Democratic senator already is embroiled in what he calls a ``rock `em, sock `em'' race with iconoclastic Republican state Rep. David Duke, the leader of the National Association for the Advancement of White People and a former Ku Klux Klansman. With voting still five months off, the charismatic Duke has all but blown away attention for state Sen. Ben Bagert of New Orleans, endorsed by the Louisiana Republican Party to challenge Johnston. Louisiana's Oct. 6 open primary is a candidate free-for-all without regard to party. If Johnston does not get a majority, he could be forced into a runoff in the November general election. ``David Duke attracts attention from everywhere. The kind of free coverage he gets is worth literally millions,'' Johnston said. ``It will be a media circus for David Duke before this thing is over with, plus he's raising a good bit of money.'' Duke, a relentless campaigner, draws huge crowds as he crisscrosses the state and money pours in from all over the country. He said he's raised $800,000 with the formal registration for candidates still three months away. ``Duke should not be written off lightly. He is young, he is intelligent. He handles himself very well. He is not the type of person to be considered a buffoon because he is not,'' said former Gov. Edwin Edwards, a freewheeling Democratic populist who served three terms. Edwards suggested he would enter the Senate race himself if it looked like a Republican would defeat Johnston. Duke, 39, has cloaked himself in the drape of GOP conservatism. A recent statewide mailing touts working for welfare, no new taxes, gun rights and the elimination of affirmative action. In Johnston's hometown of Shreveport, state Rep. Alphonse Jackson, a black Democrat, said Duke's support is mind-boggling. ``I've even heard some blacks say they're voting for Duke because he is for equal rights. I tell them what Duke says and what he means are entirely different. It sounds crazy, but he could get some black vote,'' Jackson said. ``It doesn't surprise me. People are for me,'' Duke said. ``A lot of blacks who pay taxes and work hard, they don't like the welfare system, the cycle of poverty. The welfare system has been the worst enemy of blacks and poor whites in this country.'' Duke as grand wizard unmasked the KKK, ushering the white supremacists from night rides to family picnics and public politics. He left the Klan in 1980, accused of trying to sell a membership list to a rival faction, and formed the NAAWP. Under the glare of international spotlights, he was elected to the Louisiana Legislature from a nearly all-white House district in 1989 _ despite endorsements for his rival from Ronald Reagan and George Bush. Duke says his racism and Nazi sympathy were youthful errors. As a legislator, he claims to be a spokesman for equal rights for everyone. ``I'm not looking for support from someone who wants to put down others, who wants to take away the rights of others,'' Duke said. That message goes a long way with his supporters. ``What David Duke represents is not what people think. I'm not talking about Nazism or the KKK, I'm talking about what I call equality,'' said Ted Andrus, 67, of Mandeville, who contributed $1,000. ``I like the principles which he elucidates _ no special treatment for anybody,'' said Robert Graham, 84, of Escondido, Calif., who contributed $700. Johnston, 57, drew the wrath of some American conservatives in 1987 when he worked to defeat the nomination of Judge Robert Bork to the U.S. Supreme Court. The Louisiana GOP accused Johnston of being a liberal and declared him vulnerable. As chairman of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee and the Appropriations subcommittee on energy and water development, Johnston controls some purse strings vital to oil-, gas- and water-rich Louisiana. Johnston drew no serious opposition in 1984, when he pulled in 86 percent of the vote. This time around, he said, his latest statewide poll gives him 56 percent of the vote to 20 percent for Duke and 13 percent for Bagert. ``I think the vision I have for Louisiana, a new economic base, unity for the state, strong education, environment, that's what people in Louisiana are concerned about more than whether we can put the black man back in the back seat,'' Johnston said. A Shreveport Journal newspaper poll in March showed Johnston with 32 percent, Duke 26 percent and Bagert 17 percent of the vote in Shreveport and Bossier City in northwest Louisiana. More recently, a University of New Orleans poll showed Johnston with 43 percent, Bagert 13 percent and Duke 12 percent of support from New Orleans metropolitan voters. ``This is probably the worst Duke is going to do in any part of the state,'' said pollster Susan Howell. ``Racism sells. He is a good performer. He's a handsome fellow that sounds very non-threatening. He has that populist appeal that everybody's after him and he's just, aw shucks, one of us,'' Johnston said.

DOC.HEAD: Nebraska Senator's Appeal Has Some Looking to 1992 Presidential Race
LaserPhoto WX17 of May 2
DOC.TEXT: Something about Nebraska Sen. Bob Kerrey sends normally cynical Democrats into a swoon. He's a soft-spoken, sensitive-looking war hero who quotes Yeats and dates actress Debra Winger, raises money by the bushel and has a 75 percent-plus approval rating in a conservative Republican state. He's an ambitious man, yet by all accounts a man who could easily walk away from politics. Friends and acquaintances speak admiringly of his daring, his independence, his humility, his curiosity, his depth, his kindness. They compare him to John Kennedy and Gary Hart, Jerry Brown and David Letterman, Mario Cuomo after the 1984 Democratic convention. They talk about his star quality. His Medal of Honor. His blue eyes. He might as well have ``hot presidential prospect'' stamped on his high, pale forehead. ``The guy has made an impression like nobody I've seen in a long time,'' said Dan Payne, a Democratic media consultant based in Boston. ``Everything about him is unusual by any standard,'' said Harrison Hickman, who has done polling for Kerrey since 1982. ``If he decided to run, I think he would be great. I've said since I first met him he could be anything he wants to be.'' Joseph Robert Kerrey, 46, has made his mark in many spheres. He joined the Navy as a SEAL, lost his lower right leg in Vietnam and came home an opponent of the war. He got married, had two children and got divorced; made millions as a restauranteur; served a term as governor and then declined to run for re-election. But two years later, in 1988, he ran for a Senate seat and won, frustrating Nebraska Republicans who had thought they would no longer be up against his charisma and apparent invincibility. ``He's not only been a Teflon governor but he was a Teflon type of candidate for the U.S. Senate,'' said state GOP chairman Norm Riffel. Kerrey was sworn in only 16 months ago, but already many Democrats see in him the inspirational candidate they need to win a national election. Frequent media mentions and network television appearances are signs of what some commentators dismiss as a short-lived Kerrey boomlet. But others believe the attention will translate into something more significant and lasting. He's on a roll, and also on a cusp. As Payne puts it: ``He can either go the way of Jerry Brown and burn out like a comet, or tap the energy and the excitement and the brightness'' that emanate from a new star. Thus far, Kerrey's moves in the direction of national politics are tentative. He hasn't set up a fund-raising operation, bt he has hired Bill Shore, a Hart veteran, as a top aide and traveled to 10 states to give speeches and meet with local officials and political activists. Kerrey says he wants to be a good senator from Nebraska. But he hinted at a broader Kerrey ``vision'' and leadership style at a Texas Democratic Party dinner last February in Houston. ``It is important,'' he said, ``for us simply to reach down inside of ourselves and decide what we think ought to be done and then declare it without fear of what somebody else might say.'' His priorities include universal health care; investment in U.S. roads, water systems and other infrastructure; reducing the national debt; and establishing an educational trust corporation to help schools that are struggling to improve. His primary role so far, however, has been as a combative and knowledgeable protector of the agriculture interests so vital to his state. He also is closely identified with Indochina. He recently returned there on a fact-finding mission, his first visit to the region since a grenade shattered his leg and ended his military service. ``It was hard,'' Kerrey said hesitantly when asked about the trip in one television interview. ``There's an attachment there and at the same time there's part of me that never wants to go back. The way I live anyway is to put that stuff behind me.'' The war experience did leave a legacy of extreme caution about sending U.S. troops into combat. For example, Kerrey opposed the invasion of Panama. And he has said he does not want his son to confront the same decisions he did when he was a young man. Kerrey's background gives him great authority and what some have called a bulletproof vest on issues of war, peace and patriotism. And he is outspoken on all three. The political outcry over flag-burning was a recent example. Kerrey skewered President Bush for leading the charge for a constitutional amendment to protect the flag. ``The president chose the path of least resistance and greatest political gain,'' he said. Kerrey himself initially jumped on the same bandwagon, but changed his view after reading Supreme Court opinions on the subject. Referring along the way to philosopher John Stuart Mill and ``the smell of my own burning flesh'' on a Vietnam battlefield, Kerrey concluded that America ``does not need our government to protect us from those who burn a flag.'' It was a characteristic reversal. ``One of his hallmarks is that he always reserves the right to change his mind,'' said Sen. James Exon, D-Neb. ``He is one of the few men that I've ever heard say that as often as he does. I don't think that means he's not dedicated to his beliefs. But he always keeps an open mind.'' Which is one reason 1990 is probably too early to predict what Kerrey will do in 1992. Another is Kerrey's disregard for schedules and rulebooks and sticking to an advance plan. ``One of the things that made him a marvelous combat officer was his ability to sense changes in field conditions and adapt to them,'' said Richard D Herman, a longtime friend who is editorial page editor of the Lincoln Journal. Kerrey can be incredibly blunt, but he also has been accused of vagueness, of New Age-speak, of rhetoric that loses its bearings. Nebraska Republicans contend he isn't straight with constituents on where he stands. ``People think he's telling them what they want to hear,'' Riffel said. ``He can say a lot, it sounds like a lot of substance, but when you dissect it, you look at it and you say, `What did he say?''' Riffel speculates, wistfully, that Kerrey's Senate record will unmask him as a liberal and prove his undoing in Nebraska. But most observers believe Nebraskans already know Kerrey and his views. They may not always agree with him, but his appeal seems to transcend mundane political realities like votes and vetoes. People are drawn to him _ a guy who tells fellow amputees about the great leg-maker he found; who reads books and drinks beer and goes to movies; who celebrated his election to the Senate by singing a long, tragic ballad about mutilated young war veterans. ``He's a remarkable man,'' said Harvard psychiatrist and author Robert Coles, who has met with Kerrey and corresponds with him. ``He hasn't let politics go to his head _ yet. We're all praying for him.''

DOC.HEAD: Survivor Leads Search for Bodies of 1970 Riot Victims
DOC.TEXT: Adam Gotner, badly wounded, survived that bloody day when police opened fire on people in the street. Twenty years later, Solidarity runs the government and he leads a search for secretly buried bodies. Dec. 17, 1970 is etched in Polish memory as a day of slaughter. At 6 a.m., Gotner and many others were walking to their jobs at the Paris Commune shipyard. Tanks and police were posted at the shipyard gates. Suddenly, the police began shooting. Gotner, then 25, felt something hit his shoulder and saw his jacket turning red. He thought of running at the tanks, ``but I realized it would be instant suicide,'' and retreated. ``All this time, for several minutes, I could hear the shooting continuing, and then it seemed I was stepping on people,'' he said. ``I had the impression I was stepping on bodies. The whole street had been covered with people going to work. In my mind, there were at least 500 dead.'' Long afterward, Gotner realized most were not dead, but either wounded or sprawling for cover. The communist authorities had declared the port and shipyard closed because of unrest over government-imposed increases in food prices, but had not told the workers. Police may have thought the men intended to occupy the shipyard. Official accounts said 45 Baltic port and shipyard workers were killed that day, 28 of them in Gdynia and Gdansk. Many Poles believe the number was much higher. A committee led by Gotner is trying to determine how many died in Gdynia, which means digging for bodies. Two excavations have yielded no conclusive results. A macabre legend grew around the ``December events'' and the authorities contributed to it by collecting bodies and burying them hastily at night, often with no relatives present. Tombstones erected later were allowed to say only that the person honored had died a ``tragic death.'' No mention of the Gdynia killings was permitted in the state-controlled press. Attempts to investigate were blocked even in 1980-81, Solidarity's first brief experience of legal existence. Censorship was eased enough to allow Andrzej Wajda to make the acclaimed movie ``Man of Iron,'' in which the 1970 Gdynia killings are portrayed as central to the rise of Solidarity a decade later. Gotner survived five bullet wounds in the chest, eventually became a Solidarity activist in Gdynia and organized a civic committee this year to build a new monument to the victims in front of City Hall. Soon after it was formed, his committee came under public pressure to investigate the killings. With the Communist Party out of power, city officials agreed. On a sunny April day at the Witominski Cemetery, gravediggers lifted the coffin of Jadwiga Sikorska from a sandy hillside and probed a little deeper. They found two sets of bones wrapped in cloth. One was too old to be from 1970; the other did not appear old enough. A representative of the prosecutor's office was present and the remains were taken to a forensic laboratory for analysis. Mrs. Sikorska's son, Jerzy, had noticed bones in the earth when he buried his mother in March and told the committee. Earlier, 70 volunteers dug up a 60-foot stretch of path in another part of the cemetery where witnesses had reported signs of newly dug graves immediately after the 1970 shootings. No bodies were found. Experts confirmed part of the path had been dug up about 20 years ago, but only to a depth of about four feet. They said there was no evidence the soil had been disturbed below that depth for hundreds of years. ``There were several hypotheses, and mine is that they were preparing to bury bodies there and then decided not to because of personnel changes in the government,'' Gotner said in an interview at his modest apartment overlooking the shipyard. He is a slender, articulate man with dark, curly hair salted with gray, and is cautious in expressing opinions about the outcome of his search. When pressed, Gotner said: ``I think it may turn out to be true that five or 10 more people were killed than has been reported That conclusion would not be popular. ``Alhave heard gossip that the fact that we have noanything proves we are on the side of the authorities,'' he said. Several people claimed to have seen secret burials. Three witnesses who appeared reliable, including a militiaman, claim to have seen out 200 bodies. Gortner notever, that ``no one is coming to us and asking us to find somebody,'' despite pppeals for information. Whether the victims were more or fewer, Gotner said, ``we want to find the truth. alf-truths continue to exist if we want to build the future.'' He removed his shirt, revealing scars on the upper chest and a very deep ein his back. ``If I had known I had five bullets in me, I would have died of fright,'' he said, and laughed. The laughter gone, Gotner said: ``Doing this is my responsibility to the who died at that time. I rememwhen I was walking and I saw someone falling down. I wanted to to help him then, but I could not.''

DOC.HEAD: Missouri Dilemmas Make Life-and-Death Cases for U.S. Supreme Court
DOC.TEXT: Nancy Cruzan lies comatose in a southwestern Missouri hospital bed. Steven Goodwin, a federal prisoner in Springfield, wants to impregnate his wife by artificial insemination. Heath Wilkins sits on Death Row in Potosi, fighting execution for a murder he committed at age 16. These three court cases, all from Missouri, have reached the U.S. Supreme Court or are headed that way. Along with the high court's rulings last July on abortion and in April on school desegregation, they have thrust Missouri into the legal limelight to an extent perhaps unmatched by any other state today. Doctors say Cruzan, 32, in a coma since a 1983 car accident, could live an additional 30 years with no hope of recovery. Her parents want to remove her feeding tube so she can die as they believe she would want. The Missouri Supreme Court refused to allow it, and now the U.S. Supreme Court is deciding the issue in its first right-to-die case. The decision is expected by July. Wilkins, 21, also known as inmate number CP47, spends his days with 69 other Missouri death row convicts at the Potosi Correctional Center while he fights to get the courts to overturn his death sentence. At least one argument no longer is open to him. Last year, the Supreme Court used his case to rule that states could execute killers who commit their crimes at age 16. That's how old Wilkins was when he walked into a Kansas City-area liquor store in 1985 and killed a clerk during a robbery. In the abortion case, the Supreme Court last July voted 5-4 to restore key provisions of a restrictive Missouri law, allowing it and all other states to ban any public employee from helping perform an abortion and to ban abortions in all public hospitals. The court also ruled that states may require doctors to determine whether a 20-week-old fetus was capable of surviving outside the womb. The high court recently used a Kansas City case to say federal judges may order local officials to raise property taxes to pay for desegregation of public schools. Judges, however, can't impose tax increases themselves, the justices said. The judicial pipeline from Missouri to Washington remains wide open. Goodwin, 32, serving 14 years on drug charges at the U.S. Medical Center for Federal Prisoners in Springfield, wants to impregnate his wife by artificial insemination. The federal Bureau of Prisons has refused to allow it. ``All we are asking for is a clean container and a swift messenger,'' said Goodwin's attorney, Ronald Kuby of New York. Goodwin's appeal is before the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, the last stop before the Supreme Court. Observers suggest Missouri's sudden surge to the legal forefront is a combination of timing, coincidence, the court's growing conservatism and the tendency of the Missouri Legislature to pass laws that invite challenge. ``We have been at the right place at the right time,'' said Missouri Attorney General William Webster, ``and we have a Supreme Court that is interested in hearing the issues. And that combination has permitted Missouri to be aggressive.'' He said the court seems more willing to consider cases that have not been fully litigated in the federal circuits around the country. The Cruzan case is an example. ``Twenty years ago, it is very doubtful they would have ever reached out and said, `We're interested.' From the federal case law, it's a brand new issue,'' Webster said. He said the court took the Wilkins case, along with a Kentucky case involving a 17-year-old, after the justices in 1988 overturned the death sentence for a 15-year-old in an Oklahoma case. They said the death penalty is a constitutional punishment for murderers who committed their crimes at age 16 but not for killers younger than that. ``I think it was an attempt to draw the line,'' Webster said. As for abortion, Webster, who personally argued the case before the justices, said the court chose Missouri over three other cases. ``I think there was little doubt the new court was interested in revisiting the issue of abortion,'' he said. ``Arguably ours was the narrowest of the four. The court took this as a tentative step rather than a full-tilt reversal'' of its 1973 decision legalizing abortion. Beyond the laws are those challenging them in the courts, beginning the process that ends at the Supreme Court. State Rep. Jim Barnes, who sponsored the bill that became the state's challenged 1986 abortion law, says whenever laws are made, there are those ready to fight them. ``Missourians tend to make conservative laws which are ripe for challenge,'' said Barnes, a Democrat. ``Diversity generates conflicts and conflicts create court cases.'' Joyce Armstrong, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union's eastern Missouri office, agrees many Missouri laws lend themselves to legal challenge. The ACLU represented Reproductive Health Services Inc. of St. Louis, which filed the original lawsuit in the abortion case. ``It was lobbied very hard by the anti-abortion groups,'' she said of the Missouri Legislature. ``They felt Missouri was a likely state legislature that would pass such a restrictive law.''
