DOC.HEAD: Spread of Zebra Mussels Inland Feared After Lake Superior Discovery
DOC.TEXT: Scientists say the zebra mussel will spread to inland waters following the first confirmed sightings in Lake Superior. ``This isn't going to just affect anglers,'' said Dennis Pratt, western Lake Superior fisheries manager for the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources. ``This one's going to affect industry, boaters ... and the ecosystem is going to take it on the chin.'' Discovery in March of the mussel in the Twin Ports of Duluth and Superior, Wis., proves the pest is established in all the Great Lakes, scientists say. The invader brought via the St. Lawrence Seaway in the ballast of European freighters was found last month on eight of 26 St. Louis River buoys inspected. Experts say the half-inch, barnacle-like shellfish multiply so fast that colonies of millions may turn up soon. They can clog water valves, foul city water systems and pollute beaches. ``They have a two-year reproductive cycle. I think you'll start seeing them next year in big numbers,'' Pratt said. And once they're here, there's almost nothing that can be done to stop them, Pratt said. Zebra mussels have caused millions of dollars in damage in Lake Erie and Lake St. Clair. Great Lakes environmental officials say virtually all the hard surfaces in the two lakes are covered with zebra mussel beds at least an inch thick. The creatures also have accumulated two inches thick and clogged water intakes at five Cleveland Electric Illumination Co. power plants. Monroe, Mich., was forced to close its water plant for three days when zebra mussels were so thick on intake pipes they slowed water flow. Dead zebra mussels can give off offensive quantities of methane gas and foul city water supplies. Environmentally, it's feared huge colonies of zebra mussels on rocks and shoals will disrupt fish spawning, especially walleye and lake trout. They also are believed to increase the spread of parasites damaging to fish and waterfowl. A bill moving through Congress asks for $40 million to help combat the mussels. The mussels' total economic damage in the Great Lakes could hit $5 billion by the turn of the century, a congressional study said. The mussels apparently have few natural enemies, and it is unlikely they'll be food for humans because they're so small and carry parasites. Scientists on the lower Great Lakes are experimenting with ultrasound vibrations to keep the mussels away. Chlorination also seems to help, as does electric shock and speeding the water flow.
DOC.HEAD: Chemists' Laboratory-Created Molecule Makes, Stores Energy
DOC.TEXT: Arizona State University scientists said they have have created a molecule which converts light into energy almost as efficiently as the natural process of photosynthesis and stores it the way a battery would. The development one day could lead to new methods of harvesting solar energy, the chemists said. ``Nobody's going to put the kind of devices we're making now on their roof and start harvesting energy,'' said Devens Gust, a leader of the team from the university's Photosynthesis Research Center. He said silicon solar cells already in use were much more practical for such purposes, but the microscopic ASU device may be suited to drive chemical reactions. The researchers published the details of their work in the April 13 issue of the journal Science. Gust said the researchers call the device a ``pentad molecule'' because of its five active parts. A critical factor in its success is its ability to change light into electrically charged chemicals and store the energy, he said. He said the molecule does that by separating the positively and negatively charged parts of atoms and holding them about one-billionth of a centimeter apart at opposite ends of the ladder-like molecule. The synthetic molecule can capture and store 83 percent as much energy as its natural counterparts, Gust said. Mark Wrighton, chairman of the chemistry department at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said efficient molecular electronic components could radically increase the speed and capability of computers. Gust said one problem with using the molecule in consumer electronics is its size. ``The traditional approach to electronics really has been a materials approach,'' Gust said. ``You start out with something such as bulk silicon. Then you devise ways to make devices from that bulk silicon that are smaller and smaller.'' Using the molecular-electronics approach, he said, ``You design the device at the molecular level. Then you try to figure out ways to incorporate these molecular-sized devices into large, macroscopic electronic circuits.'' Such applications may be years away, Gust said.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for May 7

DOC.TEXT: In a surprising development, American General Corp. put itself up for sale in an auction expected to fetch $7 billion for the nation's fourth largest insurance company. The company's stock price jumped sharply after the announcement Wednesday at American General's annual shareholders meeting, where the anticipated event had been a showdown with hostile suitor Torchmark Corp. Harold S. Hook, American General's chairman, said the company decided to put itself up for auction because it was vulnerable to a possible takeover at a discount price and wanted to realize the maximum value for its stockholders.

President Bush, prodded by Western allies, proposed to drop restrictions on sales of sophisticated computers and an array of high-technology products to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. The move disclosed Wednesday would eliminate 30 categories of goods and technologies from a list of 120 restricted items, while curbs on 13 others would be eased.

The Treasury Department plans to borrow $30.5 billion from the public next week in a series of debt auctions to replenish the government's coffers. The Treasury said Wednesday it plans to sell $10.5 billion in three-year notes, $10 billion in 10-year notes and $10 billion in 30-year bonds next week in one of its regular quarterly auctions to refinance the national debt.

In a sign of improved economic activity, the government said its chief forecasting gauge surged in March to the largest gain in more than a year. The Commerce Department reported Wednesday that its Index of Leading Economic Indicators rose 0.9 percent in March, following a 1 percent decline in February and the steepest rise since a 1.6 percent gain in June 1988. In a separate report baed on a survey of economic conditions by regions, the Federal Reserve said economic growth continued slowly in April with little sign of upward pressure on industrial prices.

Orders to factories for manufactured goods rose again in March, the government said in a report analysts interpreted as another sign the industrial sector is recovering from months of weakness. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that orders for both durable and non-durable goods rose 3.8 percent in March, to a seasonally adjusted $240.4 billion, after advancing 1.8 percent in February. Orders had fallen 5.5 percent in January, the worst decline in 16 years.

The two German states agreed on a treaty for merging their economies after West Germany promised to give elderly East Germans more financial protection from the throes of the free market. The tentative agreement reached Wednesday still has to be approved by the parliaments of both countries, but would settle major differences between the two Germanys over how to assess the high costs of unification. It clears the way for a full merger of their economies by July 2, when the West German mark will become the official currency of East Germany.

Defense spending cuts and a sharp drop in demand for automotive components reduced first-quarter profits by 13 percent for General Motors Corp.'s defense and electronics subsidiary. Also Wednesday, GM's Electronic Data Systems Corp. subsidiary reported a 10.6 percent increase in first-quarter profits and the General Motors Acceptance Corp. financial subsidiary said its profits during the period fell 5.6 percent.

U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills expects ``gravely diminished prosperity for all'' if stalled trade talks involving almost 100 nations collapse. Hills' warning Wednesday came at the start of three days of negotiations with trade ministers from Japan, the 12-nation European Economic Community and Canada. The talks, involving almost 100 nations, are designed to lower a variety of barriers to trade in agriculture, textiles and other manufactured goods and services such as banking and investment.

In a key ruling on insider trading, an appeals court overturned the conviction of a broker who bought Waldbaum supermarket stock after learning about the company's imminent sale from a Waldbaum family member. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said Wednesday it could find no evidence that former Gruntal & Co. broker Robert Chestman knew the information about the 1986 sale of the supermarket chain was confidential. The ruling narrows the definition of insider trading to exclude a lengthy chain of tipsters, which defense lawyers in the case had labeled ``family gossip.''

The stock market staged a moderate advance Wednesday as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 20.72 to 2,689.64. The dollar ended mostly higher in New York following a mixed performance overseas. Bond prices finished little changed. Soybean futures prices resumed their 3-month-old rally; grain futures rose sharply; oil, copper and precious metal futures fell and most livestock and meat futures advanced.

DOC.HEAD: American General Puts Itself Up For Sale
DOC.TEXT: American General Corp. stunned suitor Torchmark Corp. by putting itself up for sale, and analysts said a foreign buyer is more likely to come up with the $7 billion needed to buy the nation's fourth-largest insurer. American General surprised shareholders by announcing the decision at their annual meeting Wednesday, just after telling them that they expected to beat back a proxy challenge from Torchmark for control of the company. The announcement sent the company's stock soaring $7.50 to close at $47.62{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange as 7.1 million shares traded hands in composite trading. ``My feeling all along was that something was going to happen,'' said Ronald Frank, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York. ``I did not anticipate that it would be something as drastic as a sale.'' ``I had expected (American General) to win the proxy fight and to continue to mount a defense,'' said James Ramenda with Burlington Partners in Avon, Conn. Torchmark officials welcomed the move and expressed confidence that they would be able to discuss a merger proposal with American General. ``Based on today's announcement, regardless of the proxy vote, we intend to make another proposal to combine Torchmark with American General,'' Torchmark Chairman Ron Richey said. Ramenda, however, said opening the bidding may make it more difficult for Torchmark to win. ``This announcement suggests (American General directors) have taken a philosophy of anyone but Torchmark,'' Ramenda said. ``Torchmark did not have a strong cash offer and I don't think they have a lot more cash to put on the table. They are going to be looking for a stronger cash offer,'' he said, adding that Torchmark may need a partner to make a successful bid. Torchmark made an unsolicited cash and stock offer of $50 a share, or $6.34 billion, in March, but withdrew the offer and opted instead to wage a proxy fight to elect five of its own nominees to American General's 15-member board. Torchmark also urged shareholders to approve two resolutions calling for American General to hire an investment banking firm and appoint a committee of independent directors to evaluate acquisition proposals. The Birmingham, Ala.-based company, best known for its Liberty National Mutual Insurance subsidiary, is much smaller than its target. Torchmark has assets of $5 billion compared with $32 billion for American General, which has subsidiaries operating in 50 states and Canada. Frank said he did not think Torchmark had a ``great deal of room to increase their bid. At around $50 to $55 a share, that's a pretty full price from the standpoint of making the economics work.'' At $55 a share, American General would fetch about $7 billion. Chairman Harold S. Hook said American General was vulnerable to a possible takeover at a discount price and therefore decided to offer itself for sale to realize the maximum value for stockholders. ``We are confident we elected our slate of directors,'' Hook said to loud applause from 650 shareholders attending the meeting. ``I wish that was the end of the story,'' he added before announcing the decision to seek a buyer. The decision was made at a Tuesday evening board meeting, Hook said. If the company isn't sold in one piece, the board would be prepared to sell operating subsidiaries separately, he added. Analysts expect the company to be sold to a single buyer, though. Hebert Goodfriend with Prudential Bache Research in New York said several companies are interested in American General. He would not disclose any names but said, ``I can say there are more foreign companies than domestic.'' ``My guess is that a lot of Japanese or European companies have a long-term plan to invest in this country. This company is just too big a company to ignore. It's such a big opportunity and it is friendly,'' Ramenda said. There has been foreign interest in the U.S. insurance industry recently. Axa-Midi Assurances of France sought to buy Farmers Insurance Group Inc. of Los Angeles but failed to win regulatory approval. That failure triggered the collapse of Sir James Goldsmith's $22 billion bid for BAT Industries PLC of Britain, Farmers' current owner. American General would be willing to accept offers from foreign investors, Hook said. Torchmark's bid ``made a lot of other people aware that we were vulnerable,'' he said, but American General had not sought a ``white knight'' to rescue it from Torchmark. Asked if Torchmark's original offer was adequate, Hook said, ``it would appear in meeting financial requirements, that they could always get a partner or two.'' Hook said he expects about 50 potential bidders initially. First Boston Corp. will lead the company's selling effort. The outcome of the proxy vote will be released in about two weeks because every proxy must be counted by hand.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Takes to Radio for Summer Ad Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc. unveiled a new summer advertising campaign that ignores a strike by its drivers just as the bus company agreed to go back to the bargaining table for the first time in six weeks. The campaign drops Greyhound's 30-year-old slogan of ``leave the driving to us'' and uses a new jingle touting bus travel as ``a window seat on America.'' The operator of the only nationwide bus system also announced here Wednesday a reduced fare program for some Northeast and Midwest markets, where business has been slow to recover since 6,500 drivers and some 3,000 clerical and maintenance workers walked out March 2. Separately, the company and union said they would resume negotiations Saturday in Washington. They would be the first talks since March 18. ``We've got some good things happening here. They're hellbent on getting a contract,'' Bernard E. DeLury, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, said at a Washington news conference after meeting with both sides. Greyhound spokeswoman Liz Hale said that although the company has been operating reduced schedules during the strike, recent expansions have restored service to about 86.9 percent of pre-strike locations. Further expansions are planned as the busy summer traveling season approaches. ``The strike has not hampered our ability to bring back service to most markets that we were serving before the strike started, so most of our passengers are finding that they can go to their destinations,'' she said. About 3.5 million passengers have ridden Greyhound since the strike began. In recent days, loads have been running between 53 percent and 58 percent of last year's levels, the company said. Union officials have disputed Greyhound's figures on restored service, putting it at about 20 percent of pre-strike levels. The union claims Greyhound faces a mounting cash crunch. The company, created through a 1987 leveraged buyout, has a $9 million interest payment due May 15. Greyhound has said it will be able to make the payment. Ms. Hale, citing company policy, would not disclose the cost of the ad campaign. Greyhound's past owners have used television campaigns, but Ms. Hale said the current owners have used radio exclusively because ``it fits our demographics.'' Greyhound says its passengers tend to be students or from low-income families. The campaign, which debuts Monday and is to run through August, features three versions of a jingle. The ads will run on nationwide networks serving more than 3,000 stations and in 11 large metropolitan areas. The jingle, in gospel, rock and blues renditions, urges travelers to ``take a window seat on America, take a Greyhound cruise, don't need a lot of money to be traveling in style.'' The reduced fare promotion puts a $99 cap on one-way fares with no advance purchase requirements. The fare is good Friday through June 13 and includes Chicago plus Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and Vermont. Greyhound also lowered round trip fares in a dozen New England markets. The promotion is the second to target the Northeast since the strike. During the Easter travel period, Greyhound offered free tickets in some markets if buses did not run on time. Wages and the question of whether replacement drivers will be given permanent jobs over strikers will be the top issues in this weekend's talks, Greyhound Vice President Anthony P. Lannie predicted at the Washington news conference. The company walked out of negotiations in Tucson, Ariz., on March 18 because of the shootings and bomb threats against buses and terminals nationwide. Since then, the Dallas-based company has refused to resume negotiations until a week passed without incident. That deadline passed on Monday. The company is ``satisfied that the violence is behind us ... we're anxious to move forward with negotiations,'' Lannie said, noting that it has been 10 days since a shooting or bomb threat occurred. Edward M. Strait, president of the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, told the news conference the union has condemned the violence and urged strikers who know the responsible parties to turn them in. The union has been willing to resume negotiations all along, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Military Cuts Hurt GM Hughes Earnings; GMAC Down, EDS Up
DOC.TEXT: First-quarter earnings for General Motors Corp.'s military and electronics subsidiary dropped 13 percent mainly because of cuts in Pentagon orders and auto production, the company says. GM Hughes Electronics Corp. on Wednesday reported a profit of $182.8 million, or 46 cents per GM Class H share, compared with $210.1 million, or 51 cents a share, during the first quarter of last year. First-quarter revenue dropped to $2.02 billion from $2.03 billion. Also Wednesday, GM's computer services subsidiary, Electronic Data Systems Corp., reported a 10.6 percent first-quarter earnings increase. Its General Motors Acceptance Corp. financial subsidiary reported profits dropped 5.6 percent during the period. GM plans to report overall first quarter earnings today. GM Hughes is in the process of shrinking its dependence on military contracts to 60 percent of its business from the current 80 percent. Company Chairman Robert J. Schultz said three of its groups _ space and communications, training and support systems and industrial electronics _ should make the switch by year's end. Like other U.S. automakers, GM drastically cut car and truck production in January in a successful effort to reduce new-vehicle inventories. The reduction resulted in fewer orders from GM Hughes for electronic components. GMAC said its profit decline stemmed from lower financing income and earnings from insurance underwriting, which offset lower overall borrowing costs. GMAC earned $336 million during the quarter compared with $356 million a year earlier. GMAC has no common stock outstanding. EDS said it earned $109.8 million, or 46 cents per GM Class E share, compared with $100 million, or 41 cents a share, during the first quarter of last year. First-quarter revenue rose to $1.42 billion from $1.29 billion. The amount of EDS's non-GM business in the first quarter rose to 46 percent from 44 percent a year ago, reflecting a continuing strategy of reducing reliance on the parent company for business. During the quarter, EDS signed an agreement worth about $4 billion over 10 years with Texas Air Corp. calling for joint ownership of Texas Air's computer airline reservations system. EDS also signed a seven-year, $45 million contract with the U.S. Small Business Administration to provide processing services for loans, applications and congressional inquiries. The company also signed new business in the financial service industry and with state governments.

DOC.HEAD: USX To Seek Cause of Sparkling Dust
DOC.TEXT: The streets of this western Pennsylvanie community sparkle, but not because they're paved with gold. USX Corp., which owns the Edgar Thomson Works in Braddock, on Wednesday said it would investigate the cause of coatings of sparkling dust on sidewalks and streets. The dust damaged the paint on three nuns' cars at the Good Shepherd Church. ``People have complained of damage to their cars and other painted surfaces,'' said Ronald Chleboski, deputy director of the county's Air Pollution Control Bureau. The dust concentrations exceed Pennsylvania standards, Chleboski said. The steel mill is most likely responsible for the dust levels, because they were reduced 44 percent during a steelworkers' strike in 1986 and 1987, he said. The dust has appeared several mornings a week during the past three months, said Monsignor Charles Owen Rice, a member of the Allegheny County Board of Health. USX's steel division will start a study of the dust within a month and report to the health board within five months, said Richard Dworek, director of environmental controls in the steel division.

DOC.HEAD: Bill to Merge SEC-CFTC to Get Airing
DOC.TEXT: The debate continues over what federal regulatory agency should oversee financial products that cross the line between securities and futures. Reps. Dennis Eckart, D-Ohio, and Dan Glickman, D-Kan., have sponsored a bill that would merge the feuding Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission into a single Markets and Trading Commission. Glickman was slated to explain the bill in testimony before a House subcommittee today. The idea has some high-powered opposition, though. On Wednesday, Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan said he was ``uncomfortable'' with the idea of concentrating regulatory authority into single agency. There have been calls for either merging the two agencies or giving the SEC authority over stock index futures, financial products that allow investors to speculate in the stock market without having to buy the underlying stocks. Currently, they are regulated by the CFTC. ``One choice with which I feel uncomfortable is the concentration of regulatory authority in a single agency,'' Greenspan said in a luncheon speech to a joint conference of the CFTC and the Futures Industry Institute. ``I am concerned that the costs could well outweigh the benefits from a simpler decision-making process,'' the head of the nation's top economic policy-making body said. Earlier Wednesday, CFTC Chairman Wendy Gramm said Wall Street jealousy was behind the push to give the rival SEC some or all of her agency's jurisdiction. ``There are two motives,'' Gramm said in the keynote speech. ``First, the SEC wants more regulatory power.'' She added that ``some on Wall Street want to turn back the clock to an earlier time'' because ``the securities sector is jealous of the performace and market share of the futures market.'' She continued: ``Rather than compete directly with financially innovative firms and products or respond to a fast-changing economic landscape, they, under the umbrella of the SEC, want to regain better times simply by grabbing the success of the futures market.'' An off-and-on feud between the SEC, which regulates stocks and bonds, and the CFTC, which oversees the futures industry, has been escalating recently over who should have jurisdiction over ``hybrid'' financial products such as stock index futures. Gramm said effort that should be spent on market reform ``is being sidetracked by this unproductive, time-consuming and competitively damaging turf fight.'' ``The debate over jurisdiction has heated up unquestionably,'' said Greenspan, ``the outcome could affect the long-term health of our markets, including the ability of domestic markets to maintain their role as a leader in creating innovative products.'' Hybrid products have elements of both securities and futures contracts. A federal appeals court has said the CFTC has authority over anything with the slightest element of a futures contract. That has prompted SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden to complain that the split regulatory authority is driving financial innovation out of the United States and letting foreign markets trade in copycat hybrid products. But Gramm said splitting off stock index futures from CFTC jurisdiction would only hurt the overall futures market. ``Eliminating this exclusive jurisdiction could result in regulatory chaos by allowing futures, which all have the same economic purpose, to be regulated under multiple and different regulatory systems,'' she said in one of her sharpest criticisms of attempts to limit CFTC authority.

DOC.HEAD: Smirnoff Vodka, Exiled by Russian Revolution, Returns to Homeland
DOC.TEXT: Smirnoff, the one-time vodka of the czars banished during the Bolshevik Revolution, is back in the U.S.S.R. with a distinctly American flavor. Heublein Inc. has taken advantage of easing East-West trade restraints to ship Smirnoff back to the Soviet Union, where it was first distilled in the 1800s, said Vivian Brooks, Heublein's director of public relations. ``Smirnoff has really reached the point where it represents all that is chic and fashionable about America,'' Brooks said. The Farmington-based liquor and wine company has been bottling vodka under the Smirnoff name in the United States for more than 50 years, acquiring the formula from Russian exiles in the 1930s. Peter Smirnoff first distilled his vodka in 1818 in Moscow, Brooks said, and through the next century became the official supplier of vodka and liqueurs to the court of Imperial Russia. In 1917, as the Bolsheviks took control of the government, Moscow's businesses and industries were taken over by the Red Army and Vladimir Smirnoff, then running the family distillery, was jailed and sentenced to death as a symbol of czarist oppression. Smirnoff was rescued by the White Army and made his way to France, where in the early 1930s, he sold the family formula to Rudolph ly bought the Smirnoff formula and rights for Heublein in 1939.

DOC.HEAD: Henley Subsidiaries To Split in December
DOC.TEXT: The Henley Group Inc., a holding company for businesses spun off from Allied-Signal Inc., said it would spin off its two largest subsidiaries to shareholders. The conglomerate plans to spin off Burr Ridge, Ill.-based Pneumo Abex, an aerospace systems manufacturer, and Pittsburgh-based Fisher Scientific Group, a laboratory equipment manufacturer. The restructuring is designed to raise the total value of Henley's investment, Michael Dingman, chairman and chief executive officer, said Wednesday in a statement from the group's Hampton headquarters. Shares in the companies will be spun off to existing Henley shareholders in the third quarter, subject to the approval of those shareholders. The distribution of shares is expected to be non-taxable, Henley said. Before the spin off, Henley will boost Pneumo Abex's equity and reduce its $1 billion debt. The actions will leave the subsidiary with assets of more than $1 billion and annual sales of about $700 million. To raise equity, Henley will buy Pneumo Abex's braking materials business for its fair market value, cancel some of Pneumo Abex's debts held by Henley and contribute Henley debentures to the subsidiary. Henley also will contribute 2 million Intel Corp. shares to Pneumo Abex and the same amount to Fisher, and will receive warrants to buy 15 percent of each company's stock. Fisher has assets of approximately $600 million and annual sales of about $900 million. Henley will file for Security and Exchanges Commission approval and hold a special meeting of shareholders to consider and the spinoffs later this year. After the spinoffs, Henley will consist primarily of the Pneumo Abex braking-materials business, an 82 percent stake in Cape Horn Methanol Ltd., which produces methanol from natural gas in Chile, and Henley's remaining 14.7 million shares of Itel stock. The move is the latest in a series of spinoffs that began in 1986 when Henley was formed by Allied-Signal to spin off 35 businesses. Henley in turn has made many of those businesses into separate public companies. ``We'll have smaller units serving individual markets that are better understood and valued by shareholders, rather than having them remain part of a large, diversified company,'' company spokesman Norman Ritter said. ``Markets tend to undervalue conglomerates because they are harder to understand.'' Pneumo Abex has operations worldwide. Fisher Group's largest operations include Fisher Scientific Co. of Pittsburgh, and the Instrumentation Laboratory of Lexington, Mass.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Find a Cure for the Night Shift Blues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Bleary-eyed workers of the night, take heart: Scientists have found a way to help you get a decent day's sleep. A simple combination of bright light at night and total darkness during the day can help night-shift workers quickly adapt to their upside-down hours, researchers found. The approach appears to be the first quick, practical cure for the night-shift blues, the on-the-job sleepiness and daytime insomnia that plague many of the nation's 7 million night workers. The principal developer, Dr. Charles A. Czeisler of Boston's Brigham and Women's Hospital, said more testing needs to be done before employers start installing new lights. But if the approach matches its early promise, it should readjust people's biological rhythms in just two nights so they stay awake when their bodies ordinarily want to sleep. ``They certainly have made a breakthrough in understanding the effect of light in humans,'' said Dr. Mary Carskadon of Brown University. ``Their evidence is very powerful. There needs to be more trials in the field to determine the efficacy in a broader sense, but I think that what they've done really gives us a guidepost to pursuing this research.'' The technique works this way: People moving to the night shift reported to work _ in this case, a hospital lab _ at midnight and spent the next eight hours sitting at a desk. While they worked, a bank of lights 4 feet away shined with 16 cool-white 40-watt bulbs. Then they drove home, pulled down blackout shades in their bedrooms and stayed in total darkness from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. After just two days, the time on their internal clocks shifted dramatically so they felt fresh and awake when they ordinarily would have been asleep. ``It's very important in critical jobs to make sure that people are alert on the night shift,'' said Czeisler. ``We collected data on 4,000 shift workers and found that 56 percent reported nodding off at least once a week. These include people driving front-end loaders, running nuclear power plants, policemen and chemical workers.'' Czeisler described the results of his group's experimental use of the approach in eight young men in a report in today's New England Journal of Medicine. Scientists read the time on people's internal clocks by checking their temperatures. Ordinarily, people's temperatures hit their lowest ebb in the wee hours, and this is when they are least alert if they happen to be awake. During the studies, a comparison group worked at night under regular lights and slept with ordinary window shades pulled. After a week, their temperatures continued to reach their low point during the early morning. In contrast, those who got the light-dark treatment noticed an immediate improvement in their alertness and performance. ``Our subjects said it was startling how much better they felt at night,'' said Czeisler. ``It was no longer an ordeal to stay up all night.'' Those getting the treatment were able to sleep two hours longer a day than the comparison group. Tests also showed dramatic shifts in when their bodies made hormones and produced urine. The work provides new clues about the effect of light signals that travel along nerves from the eyes to the brain's hypothalamus, the metronome that keeps all the body's functions running on time. Dr. Thomas Roth of Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit called the work ``a tremendous leap forward.'' But before employers try to put his findings to work, Czeisler said, more study needs to be done to simplify the necessary light array, test the approach on older people and women and see how it works on larger groups.

DOC.HEAD: White House Announces More High-Tech Trade With East Bloc and Soviets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Representatives of Congress and business are criticizing President Bush's proposal to drop restrictions on sales of sophisticated computers and high-technology products to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. ``We think this helps us have a more realistic trade approach,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said when the plan was announced Wednesday. But Bush's proposal, made after prodding by Western allies, was attacked from two sides: for going too far, and not going far enough. ``I think this is another rebuff to the people of Lithuania,'' who are being squeezed in an economic blockade from Moscow, said Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y. ``Soviet intransigence in Lithuania should not be rewarded.'' But Herb Linnen, a spokesman for AT&T, said, ``We see it as a start and a hopeful sign but we don't think the proposal goes far enough.'' He pointed out that it would not allow Poland, which has purchased AT&T equipment, to acquire digital communications capabilities common in the United States. The move would eliminate 30 categories of goods and technologies from a list of 120 restricted items, while curbs on 13 others would be eased. ``Careful study indicates that most of the goods and technologies that we currently control to Eastern Europe and Soviet destinations are of low strategic value and should be decontrolled,'' Fitzwater said. In addition to computers, the affected products include telecommunications equipment such as cellular communications systems, satellite ground stations, microwave systems and fiber optics equipment, and precision-grade machine tools. For 40 years, the United States and its allies have imposed strict export curbs on high technology sales to Warsaw Pact nations and China to prevent them from buying equipment that could be used to produce weapons. But pressure has been building to relax the controls as a result of changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Businessmen throughout the West have also argued that much of the restricted equipment has been readily available to the East on world markets. Fitzwater acknowledged some Western allies favor a more liberalized approach than Bush has recommended, and predicted a mixed reaction for the proposal in Congress. Fitzwater said Bush's proposal was unanimously endorsed by U.S. security agencies, as well as the Pentagon and State Department.

DOC.HEAD: Meeting Aims to Break Stalemate Over Trade Pact
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires, may be led
DOC.TEXT: Top trade officials from three continents are holding what are described as freewheeling discussions aimed at breaking a stalemate in the most ambitious round of global trade talks ever undertaken. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills, leader of the American delegation, warned that failure of the free-trade talks could sentence all countries of the world to ``gravely diminished prosperity.'' The talks, which began with a dinner Wednesday and conclude Friday, were being held at a posh country club and resort in the heart of California wine country. They involve Japan, European countries and Canada, along with the United States. Hills, who set the agenda for the meeting, told reporters that rather than have the delegations read position papers, she had drawn up a detailed set of questions she hoped would prompt an exchange of ideas on how to resolve their differences. ``I don't want to have a script read to me,'' she said, adding that the informal talks were meant to be ``more freewheeling than structured.'' The Bush administration has made successful completion of the multinational talks its top trade priority. It hopes that freer world trade will expand overseas sales by American farmers and businesses and thus reduce the huge U.S. trade deficit. The trade talks, which involve close to 100 countries, began in Uruguay in 1986 and are being conducted under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT. While many believe the GATT rules governing trade are badly in need of modernization, the differences over how to accomplish this are so great there is fear the talks could fail. The administration is pushing to scrap costly agricultural subsidies, predicting such a move would boost U.S. farm sales by $11 billion annually. This effort is opposed by the 12-nation European Community, which wants to protect its smaller-sized farms. The United States would also like to see tougher safeguards enacted to prevent patent and trademark piracy, which costs American companies $60 billion annually. However, Third World countries, such as India, are objecting to this proposal. Developing countries also take issue with another American aim to expand GATT rules to cover trade in services such as banking and insurance. Developing nations see huge multinational companies as a threat to their infant service industries. Hills said the industrial countries had to keep promoting the idea that open markets would expand investment in Third World countries and lead to greater prosperity. Speaking to a group of business writers in San Francisco on Wednesday before the trade talks opened, she called the negotiations ``the last, best chance this century to create the trading rules we so sorely need for the next century.'' Hills painted failure of the talks in stark terms of diminished living standards for both industrial and developing countries. ``Down one path lie open markets, expanded trade, economic growth and prosperity,'' she said. ``Down the other lie closed markets, nations turned inward and gravely diminished prosperity for all.'' Hills said she was hopeful the three days of discussions would provide enough guidance to allow lower-level negotiators to draft a preliminary text at a July 23 bargaining session in Geneva, Switzerland. That, in turn, could serve as a basis for clearing up as many issues as possible before the scheduled final round of discussions Dec. 3-7 in Brussels. The trade talks are also on the agenda for the seven-nation economic summit to be held in Houston in July. Hills said she believed it would be very helpful for Bush and the other world leaders to ``give a political push'' to the negotiating effort.

DOC.HEAD: Unocal Affiliate Buys Texas Oil, Gas Company
DOC.TEXT: A Unocal Corp. affiliate agreed to buy Prairie Holding Co., which produces and explores for oil and natural gas in Texas and Louisiana, in a deal that values Prairie at $336 million. Union Exploration Partners Ltd. will pay $252 million in cash and assume $84 million in debt and liabilities of Prairie, a subsidiary of Placer Dome Inc., the gold mining outfit based in Vancouver, British Columbia. The purchase should be completed by the end of July, Unocal said Wednesday. Unocal Chairman and Chief Executive Richard J. Stegemeier said Prairie's reserves and exploration potential fit well with Unocal Exploration Partner's operations in east Texas and Louisiana. The deal gives Unocal more than 20,000 acres of promising exploratory lands, he said. ``In addition, (Prairie) has varying interests in three gas processing plants,'' Segemeier said. Unocal Exploration Partners is a Texas oil and gas limited partnership 95 percent owned by Unocal and its Union Oil Co. of California.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Icahn, America West Discussing Domestic Route Deal
DOC.TEXT: TWA Chairman Carl Icahn says he has been negotiating for several weeks with Phoenix-based America West Airlines to have the smaller carrier take over many of TWA's domestic operations, including its hub in St. Louis, according to published reports. The St. Louis Post-Dispatch said in today's editions that Icahn and officials of the TWA pilots' and machinists' unions met Tuesday with America West President Mike Conway at Icahn's Mt. Kisko, N.Y., offices. Icahn said in an interview Wednesday that the discussions with America West constitute a contingency plan in case he is unable to get concessions from the unions. Most TWA employees are union members; America West is non-union. Icahn said several ``hypothetical'' deals were discussed at the meeting. ``They would not be purchasing anything _ we would not be getting any cash,'' Icahn said of the possible deals under discussion. Instead, he said, the non-union airline simply would ``take over'' many of TWA's domestic operations, resulting in a reduction in operating costs. Union officials, however, said they did not know what to make of the proposals, calling them ``quite whacky.'' ``We walked out of there shaking our heads,'' said Tim Connolly, of the International Association of Machinists. Marty Whalen, a staff attorney for America West, declined to comment on the discussions. Conway was unavailable for comment. Icahn has been seeking salary and work-rule concessions from TWA's unions, saying that he needs the concessions in order to buy or lease new planes to expand TWA. The carrier lost $300 million last year. ``We're at a crossroads,'' said Icahn, who noted that he has cash to purchase new airplanes. ``On one hand, we cannot buy them unless we get the salary cuts. Otherwise, it is ridiculous to buy more planes just to lose more money.'' Connolly said the meeting was intended to ``pressure the pilots.'' Icahn denied the charge. ``The alternative is to just bleed to death'' he said. ``And that is an alternative that we will not take. I hope the choice is that we grow _ but if we must, we will shrink.''

DOC.HEAD: Share Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices declined in early trading as a technical rally appeared to have run its course. The market opened higher on the back of firm share prices overnight on Wall Street. But futures-related selling drew the London market down by late morning, dealers said. The market, which has been supported in recent sessions by gains in stock index futures, was expected to drift lower during afternoon trading unless Wall Street steps in to lend fresh support. At midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 6.3 points or 0.3 percent at 2131.3. Volume was a modest 255.9 million shares.

DOC.NOTE: $adv06
For release Sunday May 6
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Data Interchange
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to show that one stage of the process hasn't been introduced yet but is planned.
DOC.TEXT: Here's how the electronic data interchange system at apparel maker Levi Strauss & Co. works: _Levi's pre-tickets its jeans and other items with tags containing bar codes similar to those used in supermarkets. _At a retail store, electronic scanners at the checkout record the information contained on the tags. The store's computer records the fact that an item has been sold. Using the information, the computer can automatically reorder goods from Levi's. _As orders are shipped by Levi's, the company's distribution center generates packing slips and sends them electronically to the store's computer. The store now knows what is coming and when to expect it. _Stores receive pre-ticketed Levi's products in boxes printed with a bar code on the side. This bar code is cross-referenced to the electronic packing slip number. When stores scan the bar code they eliminate the need to count the merchandise by hand, and the goods can be sent directly to the store shelves. _Under an improvement in the system to be introduced soon, Levi's computers will automatically reorder denim and other supplies needed to make more jeans to replace those shipped.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday May 6

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 44.59 points over the past three sessions, added 10.13 to 2,699.77 in the first half hour today. DOC.HEAD: GM, Ford Post First-Quarter Earnings Declines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with GM earnings, picks up 5th graf: Revenues for ...
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. today reported its first-quarter profit fell 54 percent and Ford Motor Co.'s earnings plunged 69 percent, both due to slumping U.S. sales and production cuts. Both companies' overseas earnings were hurt by economic uncertainty in Brazil, while Ford also suffered from strikes in Great Britain. The earnings declines were less than had been anticipated on Wall Street. Combined, the Big Three automakers reported this week that they earned $1.29 billion for the quarter, down 64 percent from the year-ago period. Big Three revenue during the period fell 11 percent to $61.27 billion. GM said it earned $710 million, or $1.02 a share, on revenues of $30.11 billion during the quarter, compared with a $1.55 billion profit, or $2.37 a share, on revenues of $33.24 billion in the year-ago period. GM Chairman Roger Smith and President Robert Stempel said the company improved efficiency at its North American operations despite production cuts and incentives, which in March included first-time rebates on minivans. Ford said first-quarter earnings for its financing arm, Ford Motor Credit Co., rose 14 percent to $115.9 million. Overall, Ford said it earned $506.2 million, or $1.10 a share, during the first three months of this year compared with $1.64 billion, or $3.44 a share, during the same time last year. Revenues for the quarter fell 9 percent to $23.6 billion, from $25.87 billion in 1989. On Tuesday, Chrysler Corp. reported a $71 million first-quarter profit. Though earnings were down 80 percent from year-ago levels, the performance was still far better than analysts had expected. Ford said it earned $160 million from its U.S. operations during the quarter, down 80 percent from last year largely because of a 26 percent reduction in car and truck production during the quarter, most of which occurred in January. GM and Ford have relied on earnings from their overseas operations to compensate for sagging performance in North America. Chrysler has little presence overseas. Ford said today that the economic problems in Brazil, where Ford and West German automaker Volkswagen AG operate the joint venture Autolatina, may continue to hurt the company's earnings. The company also said its share of the U.S. car market slipped to 21.8 percent, down half a percentage point from where it was at the end of last year. In recent years, Ford's market share has increased slightly while those of GM and Chrysler have slipped in the face of intense competition from Japanese automakers. Ford Chairman Harold Poling and President Philip Benton said the company believed its market share will increase as its 1991 models become more available. Ford's new Escort subcompact, among the best-selling cars of the past decade, went on sale April 26. Ford's cash reserves stood at $3.9 billion on March 31, down from $5.7 billion at the end of last year. The company's capital spending for plant improvements, equipment and other matters, amounted to $1.6 billion during the three-month period. Each of the Big Three automakers severely cut production in January, temporarily laying off thousands of workers, and added new incentives in a two-pronged effort to deflate new-vehicle inventories which had ballooned to more than 90 selling days worth at the end of December. The strategy worked, and the automakers entered spring with inventories in the 65-day range, considered good for that time of year. But the production cuts and incentive costs ate away at first-quarter profits.

DOC.HEAD: Contractors Say Trump Is Behind On Bills; His Aides Say Delays Routine
Precede NEW YORK
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to change attribution to officials and to newspaper that reported it first. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `The Taj...'. ADDS two grafs to add report on shipyard purchase; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Contractors have asked state officials for help in getting bills paid by Donald Trump's new Taj Mahal Casino Resort. However, the state Casino Control Commission has yet to receive a formal complaint to refer to the state Division of Gaming Enforcement, said commission spokesman Tom Flynn. The Philadelphia Inquirer reported Wednesday that the 1,250-room, $1 billion casino hotel owes $35 million to about 100 contractors. Trump aides insisted it was routine to hold up payments amid disputes over incomplete or inadequate work or invoice inflation. Last week Forbes magazine reported Trump's net worth was $500 million rather than the oft-bandied $1.5 billion. The report led contractors to speculate Trump was in a financial squeeze, which he and his aides denied. Contractors ``do this every time they want to bring pressure and they want to get paid,'' Edward Tracy, president of Trump Hotel Corp., told the Daily News in New York. The Taj Mahal, which opened April 2, released unofficial figures Wednesday showing it took in $34.2 million from gamblers last month. That tops the Atlantic City record of $32.8 million set by Caesars Hotel Casino in July 1989. The Mirage in Las Vegas, which competes for the same high rollers, took in $40 million in December, its opening month. Analysts have estimated Trump needs to gross $1 million a day at the Taj Mahal. His April take worked out to about $1.18 million a day, and was affected by huge crowds of curiosity-seekers and problems with new slot machines. In a separate venture, Trump paid $5 million for Amels Holland, a 90-employee shipyard near Amsterdam, Netherlands, to ensure it completes his new 420-foot yacht, New York Newsday reported today. Trump and the yard's owners had gone into arbitration over his contention that they lacked the financial resources to finish the job. Newsday reported the $5 million price that Trump paid to buy the yard was about one-fifth of its value.

DOC.HEAD: BMW, Rolls Royce Announce Joint Jet Engine Unit
DOC.TEXT: BMW said today it plans to re-enter the jet aircraft engine business after an absence of 30 years through a joint venture with Britain's Rolls-Royce PLC. Bayerische Motoren Werke AG said it will acquire an aerospace technology line of Kloekner-Humboldt-Deutz AG and then merge the business into a joint venture with Rolls-Royce. The West German luxury car maker said its move back into aircraft engines reflects the company's desire to expand into new but related industrial areas. BMW said it will control 50.5 percent of the joint venture; Rolls Royce will own the remainder of the venture, which will be based in Oberursel, West Germany. The joint venture will develop, manufacture and market jet engines of up to 20,000 pounds of thrust, which power small civilian and military jets capable of carrying up to about 100 passengers. The new venture will be called BMW-Rolls Royce and will ``collaborate'' with Rolls Royce's own Tay and Trent jet engine programs, the British company said in a separate statement. A BMW spokesman said the KHD aerospace unit _ KHD Luftfahrttechnik GmbH and based just outside Frankfurt in Oberursel _ has annual sales of about $98 million and employs about 900 people. Munich-based BMW built aircraft engines before World War II, and by the end of the conflict was producing turbines for what was then the newly developed jet airplane, BMW said. However, BMW left the aircraft engine business in 1959 by selling its operations to the big West German engineering group Man AG, which later merged the operations with Daimler-Benz AG. Daimler earlier this year agreed to link up its civilian jet engine operations with those of the Pratt & Whitney engine subsidiary of United Technologies Corp. of the United States. Meanwhile, one of the world's largest producers of jet engines, General Electric Co., has filed suit against Daimler's agreement with Pratt & Whitney, charging it violates a joint engine development accord between GE and Daimler.

DOC.HEAD: NFU Call for Greater Controls at Odds With Yeutter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 7, Yeutter said, to insert comma after agricultural committees; also moving general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The National Farmers Union is in town this week to lobby Congress for tighter federal management of the nation's agriculture. But the NFU's bid for higher price support loan rates and ``sound supply management measures'' as part of the 1990 farm bill being drafted on Capitol Hill doesn't ring just right for Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. As NFU members were making their points known in House and Senate offices on Wednesday, Yeutter was telling a rival organization _ the American Farm Bureau Fdderation _ that advocates of bills to boost farm program benefits ignore budget realities. ``Maybe these big, high numbers make good campaign material back home, but the day of reckoning is coming,'' he said. Some 1990 farm bill amendments have been approved or are under consideration by congressional subcommittees that exceed limits set by Capitol Hill and Bush administration budget-cutters. Recent examples include action to sweeten programs for sugar, cotton and rice. Other commodities, including soybeans, wheat and feed grains, would be affected by supports or payments being tied to costs of production. Yeutter said these proposals will be eliminated or watered down by the full congressional agricultural committees, during floor debate or in conference meetings to settle differences between the House and Senate versions. The subcommittees are ``living in a dream world'' and will have to be dragged back to reality by the crunch on federal spending, he said. Yeutter mentioned ``two-tier'' dairy price support proposals, which he said would contradict U.S. objectives to liberalize world trade. He also told Farm Bureau leaders that he is ``not going to back off at all'' on the administration's proposal for more flexibility in the 1990 farm bill. The administration wants the measure, which will be a blueprint for U.S. farm policy over the next five years, to allow farmers more leeuay in deciding the mix of crops they plant on their base acreages. ``I don't know of a single farmer who wouldn't like to have more flexibility in his operation,'' Yeutter said. But NFU President Leland Swenson says higher farm program loan rates and good supply management would stimulatd commodity markets and stabilize prices at the farm and consumer levels. ``As long as we're in a position where we're able to produce more than we can consumer and export, we have to have programs in place that stabilize supply levels around the demand for the products,'' he said. The NFU is proposing a bushel-based program in which each year's needs would be estimated to determine the amount of farm production required. The plan calls for ``disincentives'' to avoid excess production. A two-tier dairy program also is supported by the NFU. Farmers would get a specified price support for a certain amount of production, with penalthes for overproduction.

Please, no loud noises. The corn is taking an afternoon nap. On warm, drx afternoons, corn ``takes a photosynthesis siesta,'' says the Agriculture Department. And that slows its growth. Plant physiologist James A. Bunce of the department's Agricultural Research Service said the photosynthetic rate dpops a total of about 30 percent on warm, dry afternoons under normal growing conditions. Bunce found the photosynthesis slump in laboratory studies and confirmed it in under field conditions, the agency reported Wednesday. ``As soon as the humidity directly around the leaves drops, the leaves dry out slightly and the rate of photosynthesis drops, even if the soil around the roots of the plant is wet,'' he said. Bunce said it should be possible to find corn varieties that react less to humidity decreases, or to breed the potential into commercial varieties. That would allow corn to sleep less and grow more.

The value of U.S. poultry production in 1989 rose to a record of more than $15 billion, up 20 percent from 1988, according to al annual report by the Agriculture Department. Broilers accounted for $8.78 billion; eggs, $3.85 billion; turkeys, $2.24 billion; and othep chickens, $139.9 million. In the case of broilers and turkeys, prices and output increased from 1988. Egg prices rose while production declined, and the prices of other chickens increases while total output dropped. Arkansas continued as the top broiler state with an estimated production value of $1.47 billion last year, followed by Georgia, $1.25 billion; Alabama, $1.13 billion; North Carolina, $848 million; and Mississippi, $593.8 million. Other broiler producers in the top 10 included: Texas, $482.7 million; Delaware, $458.5 million; Maryland, $448.9 million; California, $360.6 million; and Pennsylvania, $203.2 million.

DOC.NOTE: $adv07
For release Monday May 7
DOC.HEAD: Malaysia, the Reluctant Economic Dragon, Prospers
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad doesn't like the idea, but booming Malaysia may soon exit the Third World and join the ranks of newly industrialized countries. Its newly industrialized neighbors in Asia _ South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore _ are known as the region's ``economic dragons.'' Despite robust growth, Malaysia remains a reluctant dragon. Tiny Malaysia has evolved from a simple producer of tropical crops into an emerging economic force that manufactures products ranging from cars to computer chips. Its central bank forecasts growth of more than 8 percent in 1990, for the third consecutive year. Foreign businessmen and other analysts say Malaysia is competitive in Southeast Asia in the quality and cost of labor, infrastructure, repatriation of profits, attitude toward foreign investment, overall cost of doing business and political stability. So why the reluctance? A key reason is official fear that developed countries will classify Malaysia as a so-called newly developed country or NIC, which could mean an end to trading concessions that have enabled Malaysian exporters to do so well. The government also fears trade retaliation from the United States and other rich powers, who could demand environmental and human right standards they deem acceptable to developed countries. Mahathir has described the label ``newly industrializing country'' as an arbitrary Western notion applied by the developed world that may curb economic growth in developing nations. A country risks penalties as a NIC when it industrializes and its citizens attain a higher standard of living, he said. Trading privileges, such as reduced tariffs under the Generalized System of Preferences, are taken away, quotas are slapped on exports and the domestic currency increases in value, making it harder for exporters to do business. ``The chances are that these countries will languish in their NIC status and never become fully developed,'' Mahathir said, because their competitiveness and access to markets is curtailed. ``We are interested in growing but they can keep the title and what goes with it,'' Mahathir said. ``It is just that we do not like categorization and labels aimed at limiting our future growth.'' He said the human rights record of a designated NIC is examined ``and invariably found wanting.'' Malaysia already has been criticized by foreign labor groups for its policy toward union organizing. In 1988, for example, the AFL-CIO sought unsuccessfully to have Malaysia's preferential trading status with the United States canceled. The U.S. labor group contended that Malaysian electronics workers only could join in-house unions. In addition, Malaysia has been criticized for years for the indiscriminate logging of its tropical rain forest. Mahathir says the critics are ill-informed or self-serving. ``The thinning of the ozone layer is blamed on logging of tropical forests. The fact that the burning of fossil fuels and release of CFCs (chloro-fluorocarbons) into the atmosphere occur largely in the rich countries are significantly ignored,'' he told an international conference in October. Mahathir concedes that his country will one day be recognized as an NIC, regardless of his wishes. Based on recent performance, that day may be approaching fast. Manufacturing investment last year increased 57.9 percent to the equivalent of $7.44 billion, said Trade and Industry Minister Rafidah Aziz. Foreign investment rose 30.8 percent last year to $4.97 billion, while domestic investment climbed 110 percent to $3.37 billion. Even without manufacturing, Malaysia has long been recognized as one of the luckier developing lands with a balanced array of resources. A leading exporter of natural rubber, palm oil and tin, it is also an important source of cocoa, pepper, tropical hardwoods, crude oil and natural gas. Industry was introduced in the 1960s with small assembly plants and processing of some crops. Motor vehicles were assembled from completely knocked down kits. Export-oriented manufacturing started in the 1970s, led by semiconductor companies. About 100,000 people are employed in electronics, the driving force behind the changeover from a commodity producer to a manufacturing power. Malaysia is now the biggest exporter of semiconductor devices and the third largest producer, after Japan and the United States. Members of the Malaysian-American Electronics Industry group, which represents 15 U.S. firms, have about 40,000 workers in 18 plants. The United States is a leading foreign investor in Malaysia. Domestic companies with U.S. participation had assets totaling $6 billion at the end of 1988. A large number of them are U.S.-owned. End adv for Monday May 7

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Ministers Agree to Cut Production
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADs with 3 new grafs to UPDATE with oil prices lower following word of agreement. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, The countries...
DOC.TEXT: OPEC ministers agreed today to cut current crude production by 1.45 million barrels a day in an effort to push oil prices back up to $18 a barrel, the organization's president said. All 13 members of the cartel would contributing to the reduction, OPEC President Sadek Boussena said at a news conference. However, oil prices dropped following the cartel's announcement, in apparent skepticism that much had been accomplished. The June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, was down 35 cents at $18.33 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange in late morning trading. The countries that have been pumping above their quotas agreed to return to their ceilings, Boussena said without identifying the violators. The United Arab Emirates, which analysts have said is one chronic overproducer, agreed to cut its output by 200,000 barrels a day, Boussena said. The agreement, reached on the second day of an emergency session, will be in effect until the end of July, Boussena said. The cartel will postpone its midyear session for a month to July 25, when it will decide its output and pricing policy for the rest of the year, he said. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries pumped 23.5 million barrels a day in April, Boussena said, above the cartel's official ceiling of 22.1 million barrels. ``For the time being, we decided to have a freeze-time for three months, said Boussena, who also serves as Algeria's oil minister. Though he provide a breakdown of the agreed cutbacks, he noted that ``the most would be provided from countries who will go back to their quotas.'' Once production is back in line, Boussena said ``OPEC is going to withdraw a big quantity from the market. We hope prices will restore'' to $18 a barrel, which was the price members agreed upon last November. The overproduction has created an oil surplus just when demand traditionally eases off in the second quarter, bringing oil prices well below OPEC's current minimum reference price of $18 a barrel. North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude oil, was trading at a spot price of $16.65 a barrel in London this afternoon, down about 15 cents from late Wednesday. The average price of a basket of seven crudes monitored by OPEC stood at $15.37 per 42-gallon barrel last week, down from $17.12 a barrel in the first week of April. ``Usually they act when they are in trouble or about to be in trouble, and that's where they are now,'' said Paul Mlotok, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Co. who was observing the meeting. ``It's clear they need to cut output by at least one million barrels a day if they want the markets to move up.'' The glut has serious implications for OPEC, Mlotok said. ``A few months of being several dollars below where they want to be costs them a lot of money,'' he said. But Mlotok said he doesn't expect a repeat of the 1986 collapse when oil prices fell below $10 a barrel. ``There is a tendency to see this as a management problem rather than a problem of oil collapsing. They are dealing with swings in seasonal demand,'' Mlotok said. The situation will improve for OPEC in the third quarter when demand begins to increase seasonally, he said.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 44.59 points over the past three sessions, added 12.84 to 2,702.48 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. The prospect of that heavy load of new supply has been weighing down bond prices and pushing up long-term interest rates for some time. Now, however, analysts say those worries appear to be easing somewhat. DOC.HEAD: Bush ``Very High On'' Suggested Replacement at Bailout Agency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he is ``very high on'' Federal Reserve regulator William Taylor to replace L. William Seidman as boss of the administration's savings and loan bailout. Seidman told him today he ``enthusiastically supports'' Taylor, director of bank supervision at the Federal Reserve Board, Bush said at a news conference. ``He suggested the name of Bill Taylor, who we're very high on to take his responsibilities,'' the president said. Taylor is on leave from his Federal Reserve job and is serving temporarily as the chief staff officer of an administration-led panel which oversees the work of Seidman's bailout agency, the Resolution Trust Corp. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Tuesday that Bush would not resist a move by Seidman, 69, to leave before the October 1991 expiration of his term as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the RTC. The FDIC manages deposit insurance funds for banks and S&Ls and the RTC conducts the administration's thrift bailout. However, Bush denied a newspaper report that he suggested Seidman leave. ``Hey listen, I haven't told you I'm anxious to see Bill Seidman leave. ... He's done a good job,'' said Bush. ``It's his initiative with me. ... I think Seidman has conducted himself with extraordinary grace and great ability,'' he said. Taylor was approached by the administration earlier this year for the job of director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision, which regulates solvent S&Ls. He turned that offer down. The job of FDIC and RTC chairman may prove more attractive. Once appointed, the chairman serves independently and cannot be removed by the president. Also, the job is not subject to government salary restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Rise; Soybeans, Corn Decline In Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures rose slightly while corn and soybean futures retreated in early trading this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade. The mixed early action follows a strong rally across the board on Wednesday that was partly attributed to the Agriculture Department's decision to target China for sales of 2 million metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. Expectations for more export bonus offers helped support the wheat market this morning. But gains were limited by a bearish 1990 U.S. wheat crop estimate by the private analytical firm Sparks Commodities Inc. Sparks pegged the total harvest at 2.7 billion bushels compared with last year's harvest of just over 2 billion bushels. ``Sparks certainly took a bold step up in current trade talk of what the wheat crop is expected to be in 1990,'' said Richard Feltes, director of commodity research for the large trading company Refco Inc. The USDA will release its first 1990 wheat crop estimate next Thursday. Soybean and corn futures slipped amid forecasts for beneficial rain in the Midwest. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent to 2} cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.75 a bushel; corn futures were 1{ cents to 2} cents lower with May at $2.85{ a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2{ cents lower with May at $1.67{ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 4} cents lower with May at $6.32 a bushel. Cattle futures were higher while pork futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .15 cent to .35 cent higher with June at 73.95 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .08 cent to .48 cent higher with May at 83.20 cents a pound; hogs were .47 cent lower to .13 cent higher with June at 63.40 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .32 cent lower to .53 cent higher with May at 69.45 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mostly higher on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Court Overturns Broker Conviction, Limiting Insider Prosecutions
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court has placed limits on who can be prosecuted for insider trading, overturning the conviction of a stockbroker who traded on fourth-hand information about the pending takeover of Waldbaum Inc. The decision Wednesday by the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals also guts a key Securities and Exchange Commission regulation used to prosecute anyone who trades on misappropriated information about a takeover. The court unanimously said it found no evidence that former stockbroker Robert Chestman knew that information about the 1986 sale of the supermarket chain, which he received down a chain of family members, was confidential. ``After passing through several family channels, it cannot be said that the information was confidential to any degree or was any more than family gossip,'' the court said. More important, securities experts said, was a 2-1 decision that guts Rule 14e-3 of the Securities Exchange Act, which makes it a crime to trade on inside information about a takeover even if the trading doesn't violate a fiduciary duty to a company. The rule has been used frequently to prosecute insider trading cases involving takeovers in the 1980s. The appeals court ruling essentially means the government will have to prove the defendant knew the information was ``stolen.'' Insider trading lacks a statutory definition but generally refers to buying or selling securities on the basis of confidential, nonpublic information. The Chestman case had expanded securities law interpretation to encompass disclosure of secrets down a chain, and hinged on whether Chestman had a fiduciary dury to Waldbaum Inc. No prior criminal case had involved confidential information passed among family members. Chestman, who began serving his two-year prison sentence last June, was released from a minimum-security prison in Allenwood, Pa., Wednesday evening and returned to his Long Island home, Chestman attorney Elkan Abramowitz said. The U.S. attorney's office was reviewing the ruling and had not decided on whether to appeal to the Supreme Court or for an appellate court rehearing, spokeswoman Deborah Corley said. According to testimony at Chestman's trial, Ira Waldbaum agreed in 1986 to sell the grocery business founded by his grandfather in 1921 to the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co. _ better known as A&P _ for $50 a share, or $28.7 million. He told his sister, Shirley Witkin, about the deal, stressing that the information had to remain confidential until it was announced publicly. Witkin informed her daughter, Susan Loeb, who in turn told her husband, Keith. Keith Loeb then told Chestman, who bought 11,000 shares of Waldbaum Inc. for about $25 each, making overnight profits of $250,000 for himself and several clients, including Loeb. The Securities and Exchange Commission, alerted to the trading by routine post-merger stock market surveillance, filed civil charges. Loeb cooperated with investigators. Chestman was charged criminally and convicted by a jury in May 1989 on 31 counts. The civil charges still are pending. Chestman's attorneys said he had decided to serve the prison term before his appeal was decided because he felt he couldn't get a job until the case was behind him.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am is unavailable.

DOC.HEAD: Brush With History: Copies of Masterpieces Entering Art Market
LaserPhoto pursuing
DOC.TEXT: Even the Louvre's curators would envy the masterpieces in the gallery next door to the lunch counter advertising a grilled cheese special. Van Gogh's ``Les Iris'' is around the corner from a few Monet landscapes at the storefront gallery in Fort Lauderdale. Across the room, works from the Italian Renaissance and the early American Hudson River School share the same wall. They're all fakes. They're all for sale. ``A forger? Yes, we're expert forgers you could say. But we make no attempt to deceive. We don't pretend to sell original works. We sell reproductions,'' said Ernest Thomas Cummins, president of Heritage House Trading Group Ltd. ``We have all the thrill of being a forger, but no risk.'' With prices for original art rising into the tens of millions, some art lovers are turning to high-quality copies done by expert artists. In addition, some museums confronting skyrocketing insurance premiums are considering stashing the authentic pieces and displaying a reproduction, said Cummins. No major U.S. art museum is known to be displaying reproductions in place of originals. Such a practice would raise questions about why people visit museums in the first place. But museum security has become a growing concern. Last month, a woman in Amsterdam sprayed a Rembrandt with an acid solution and caused minor damage. In March, thieves dressed as police officers robbed 11 paintings and other objects from Boston's Gardner Museum. Bids for paintings have climbed at auction houses. In 1987, Australian investor Alan Bond paid a record $53.9 million for ``Les Iris.'' At Fort Lauderdale-based Heritage House, prices run from about $1,000 to $10,000 for the paintings of paintings, depending on the size and complexity of the original, said Cummins, 34, a founder of the upscale Robb Report magazine. Heritage House, which started producing the repainted masters in late 1987, also has opened a shop in Carmel, Calif. The Heritage House works are full paintings, rather than photographs or prints. ``We deal with people who want to live with great art, not just visit it,'' he said. A telephone call usually begins the three- to four-month process of making a reproduction. Heritage House advertises in art and leisure publications. A small classified in The Wall Street Journal recently brought in dozens of inquiries, said Cummins. ``We get all kinds of calls,'' he said. ``Some people want specific paintings or copies of originals they already have to put in a second home. On the other hand, we get calls from people saying, `Can you do something with a dog?''' Once a commitment is made, Cummins contacts one of the nearly 200 European artists used by the gallery. In Europe, where copying masterpieces is a centuries-old craft, specially trained painters often use the pigments and brushes typical of the period of the original. A completed painting is then placed in a frame closely resembling its era. Sometimes, the gallery purchases 17th century furniture to use the wood for frames, said Cummins. The final step is the antiquing process using chemicals and natural heat and humidity. ``We can make special types of cracks from little spider-web types to long splits,'' said Cummins. To guard against misrepresentations, the canvases and frames are stamped and the paintings contain markings only visible under an ultraviolet light. ``We're working in techniques that have been handed down for centuries,'' said Cummins. ``The master copier hands down his knowledge to the apprentices and so on. There is nothing new to what we are doing.'' Only recently, however, has the demand for near-perfect reproductions reached beyond a handful of collectors. Several European galleries now specialize in copies of priceless musuem works. Parisian gallery owner Daniel Delamere has gained status in the art world for selling repoductions and promising never to copy the same work again. Although Delamere bills his so-called one-of-a-kind reproductions as an investment that could appreciate in value, Cummins said Heritage House works are merely decorations. ``People want our paintings because they love art and appreciate a real painting as opposed to a lithograph or something,'' he said. Thomas Hoving, editor of Connoisseur magazine and former director of New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, said there may be a limited market for quality reproductions, but he knows of no major U.S. museum displaying copies. ``Some people may want these paintings in their home. I do not see any market for museums,'' he said. But even known forgeries are finding a niche among art auctioneers. Last month in London, Bonhams gallery put on the block 30 paintings by the late master forger Elmyr de Hury. Nearby, the British Museum's exhibit ``Fake? The Art of Deception'' features nearly 600 skillful imitations. International copyright laws prohibit commericial copies of artists' works until 50 years after their death. Heritage House also does not attempt reproductions of watercolors and multi-media works, said Cummins. Cummins closely guards the identities of his copiers, claiming many fear public disclosure would drop the prices for their original pieces and draw ridicule from peers. ``It's a very sensitive subject and most would prefer to simply keep it a secret,'' he said. Still, some of the artists' eccentricities cannot be hidden. ``We have some artists who walk around in the clothes of the period they are painting in,'' said Cummins. ``Sometimes we get letters from them written in an archaic style that you can barely understand. It's a strange business.''
