DOC.HEAD: Texas Air Posts $107 Million Loss
DOC.TEXT: Texas Air Corp., parent of faltering Eastern Air Lines and Continental Airlines, said Thursday it lost $107.1 million in the year's first quarter. The loss, amounting to $2.80 per share on revenues of $1.86 billion, compares with a loss of $255.53 million, or the equivalent of $6.56 per share, on revenues of $1.88 billion during the year-ago period. Eastern, which has been operating under bankruptcy court protection since employees struck in March 1989, recorded a net loss $136.5 million on revenues of $557.2 million before a $7.8 million charge for dividends payable to its preferred stockholders. A year ago Miami-based Eastern lost $255.2 million on revenues of $620.6 million before a $10.4 million charge for dividends payable to its preferred shareholders. On April 18, a federal bankruptcy judge seized control of Eastern partly because of what he called the parent company's mismanagement of the airline. The carrier is now run by a court-appointed trustee. Under generally accepting accounting principles, Eastern's operating results will be excluded from Texas Air's future reported operating results beginning April 19. Earlier this week, Houston-based Continental Airlines reported first-quarter earnings of $21.3 million vs. a loss of $16.5 million in the same period a year ago. Revenues for the quarter were $1.27 billion, up slightly from $1.24 billion the previous year. Houston-based Texas Air also owns System One Holdings.

DOC.HEAD: Fleet Announces $98 Million First-Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: Fleet@Norstar Financial Group was the darling among big New England banks, but Thursday it announced that the region's slumping economy had caught up and left it with a $98 million first-quarter loss. Fleet had been the only of the so-called super-regional banks in New England that had weathered the financial storm, but analysts said the loss showed that even a well-run bank was not immune to the severe downturn. ``This is Fleet@Norstar, a really good, well-managed bank,'' said Gerard Cassidy of Tucker Anthony & R.L. Day. ``You don't like to see these numbers for a good bank. ... It just supports our thinking that the New England economy is extremely weak.'' An increase in non-performing assets _ to $928 million _ was the underlying cause of the loss, Fleet's first since 1974. And most of that, $552 million, was in commercial real estate, which has hurt other New England banks. Just a month ago Fleet had predicted non-performing assets would total a record $600 million but noted that figure could go higher based on the results of a joint supervisory review by state and federal regulators. Chief Financial Officer John W. Flynn said regulators required more assets be included in that category than Fleet had anticipated. ``Of the $928 million, $412 million of those assets are performing assets right now, (in the sense that) they either are truly current or less than 90 days past due,'' Flynn said. Non-performing loans of $653 million, up $319 million, were the largest part of the problem. Real estate on which Fleet has foreclosed rose $80 million to $275 million. Fleet stressed that although it has some problem areas, its underlying assets are strong and it expects to return to profitability in the second quarter. Analysts were quick to agree with management's assessment. ``Their veil of invincibility has been pierced,'' said James J. McDermott Jr. of Keefe Bruyette & Woods. ``But it's an exciting company with strong capital ... and should chart its way through these difficult times.'' As with other regional banks, the biggest problem was with commercial real estate, mostly in the hard-pressed New England market. In fact, the company's lead bank outside the region, Albany, N.Y.-based Norstar Bank, earned a profit of $17 million, up $2 million. Although Flynn would not discuss other specific banks, he said Fleet does not anticipate the problems such companies as the struggling Bank of New England Corp. have experienced. ``Numerically our nonperforming assets are lower than others in the region,'' he said. ``Our equity capital is higher than others in the region and over the last two years our earnings have been substantially higher. Obviously, we believe we are far more diversified than almost anybody in the country.'' Cassidy agreed, noting that Fleet is insulated by non-banking income like mortgage banking subsidiaries and student loan processing centers which are less influenced by regional economic downturns. ``Long term, these guys are going to be survivors and in fact they're going to be expanding and they're going to be taking advantage of the opportunities over the next 12 to 15 months,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Employees Worry, Skeptics Scoff at Proposed Deal
DOC.TEXT: A proposed deal that would give expansion-minded America West Airlines Inc. all of Trans World Airlines' domestic operations drew a large dose of skepticism Thursday from employees and analysts. TWA Chairman Carl Icahn said he had been negotiating for several weeks with the smaller, non-union airline based in Phoenix and brought the carrier's president, Mike Conway, to a meeting of pilot and machinist union representatives this week. Under one scenario, Icahn said he would give America West the domestic operations to reduce operating costs. He did not say whether the growing airline would have to assume any debt as part of the deal. TWA, headquartered in Mt. Kisco, N.Y., lost $300 million last year and had to pay $366 million in interest on debts of $2.5 billion. The large debt has been a stumbling block in finding a buyer. ``This is just a big mess,'' said Herb Johnson, president of the machinists' union. ``One minute, out the blue, Icahn says he wants to buy Pan American, and then the next minute he wants to sell us to a non-union airline. This guy is a schizophrenic.'' Johnson characterized the deal as Icahn's the latest negotiating ploy. Rumors swept through the airline's main repair facility in Kansas City and causing people to go ``absolutely wild with speculation,'' he added. Johnson said workers were afraid that they would lose their seniority, their benefits and possibly their jobs if they were to work for a non-union carrier. America West spokesman Marty Whalen declined to comment on the deal Thursday. ``We don't comment on speculative matters,'' he said. America West, a fast-growing airline founded in 1983, has hubs in Phoenix and Las Vegas and flies 92 airplanes to 59 cities throughout the United States and Canada. Last year, the airline achieved ``major airline'' status when it topped $1 billion in gross revenues for the first time. Although pilots and mechanics believe a deal with a non-union carrier would be disastrous for TWA, analyst Charles Mancuso of Moody's Investor Services in New York said he didn't see any winner in the deal, except maybe Icahn. ``It just strikes me as odd. I don't see what advantage America West would gain from taking on debt, old planes and a union workforce, but in this business everybody's willing to talk to everybody,'' Mancuso said. Kent Scott, head of the TWA pilots' union, agreed and said he's not going to take the deal seriously until he gets more in-depth information. Scott has been talking with Icahn for months about work-rule and salary concessions. Icahn has said he needs concessions from the pilots before he'll modernize TWA's fleet, one of the oldest in the industry. ``This seems to me to be more like a scare tactic. Icahn's saying `Why don't you just give me my concessions instead of losing everything with this deal?''' Scott said. ``That's how he proposed it: `This is your last chance to get on board. I'm going to do this deal with or without you.' I don't want to pull the tiger's tail, but I don't think he can do it without us,'' Scott said.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Retreat; Late Sell-Off In Wheat
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade with wheat prices falling late in the session following a private forecast for a bumper crop of winter wheat. Soybean futures posted fairly steep losses; corn was down modestly from Wednesday's close. Wheat trading turned into a tug-of-war between bullish traders who expect the Agriculture Department to target more countries for sales of subsidized U.S. wheat and bearish forces inspired by a surprisingly high wheat-crop forecast by Sparks Commodities Inc., a private crop statistics firm in Memphis, Tenn. Sparks pegged the total 1990 U.S. wheat harvest at 2.7 billion bushels compared with last year's harvest of just over 2 billion bushels. The USDA will release its first 1990 wheat crop estimate on Thursday. After reading reports of the Sparks number, ``at first I thought they were wrong or I was wrong or something because it seemed so high,'' said Susan Leighty, grains analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. She noted the Sparks number predicts record-high yields from the maturing winter wheat crop. Leighty said she expects a total wheat harvest of 2.5 billion bushels. Forecasts for beneficial rain in the Midwest weighed on the corn and soybean markets, which gave up much of the gains posted Wednesday. At the close, wheat futures were { cent lower to 2{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.73 a bushel; corn was 1{ cents to 2{ cents lower with May at at $2.85{ a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2} cents lower with May at $1.66{ a bushel; soybeans were 6 cents to 8} cents lower with May at $6.30{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Rates Up
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on 52-week Treasury bills rose in Thursday's action to the highest level in nearly a year. The Treasury Department sold $10.04 billion of the bills at an average discount rate of 8.05 percent, up from 7.72 percent at the last auction on April 5. The rates were the highest since last June 1, when the one-year bills sold for 8.18 percent. The new discount rate understates the actual return to investors _ 8.70 percent with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,186.10.

DOC.HEAD: Germany's KHD To Sell U.S. Farm Equipment Subsidiary
With AM-BMW-Rolls Venture, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The West German machinery maker Kloekner-Humboldt-Deutz AG said Thursday it agreed to spin off its Deutz-Allis Corp. farm machinery subsidiary to the U.S. division's management and an unidentified ``financial group.'' Financial details and the identity of the U.S. financial group were not disclosed. KHD acquired Deutz-Allis in 1985. The Atlanta, Ga.-based farm equipment maker had sales of $307 million last year. The company operates a sales and service network through 700 dealers in the United States and Canada. It also makes crop harvesting combines at a complex in Independence, Mo. Since 1987, KHD said, Deutz-Allis has followed a strategy of operating in niches of the tractor market to avoid the negative impact of the fiercely competitive farm equipment industry. The U.S. company has been unprofitable in recent years. But ``through consequent restructuring measures,'' Deutz-Allis has been able to narrow it $80 million loss in 1987 to about $8.8 million last year, KHD said. KHD, which has had financial difficulties, said the sale of Deutz-Allis ``ends an unprofitable and risky involvement in the U.S. farm equipment market.'' KHD, which also confirmed Thursday it was selling its aerospace technology subsidiary to Bayerische Motoren Werke AG (BMW), said it now will concentrate on its farm equipment business in Europe and North Africa, and on its motors and industrial machinery activities in the United States. KHD said it has shed operations that had about $388 million in annual sales since 1988. Also Thursday, KHD reported a pre-tax operating profit worldwide last year of about $23 million, compared with a 1988 loss of about $101 million. It was its first operating profit in three years, KHD said.

DOC.HEAD: Fall For Sixth Straight Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 509 money market mutual funds fell $2.14 billion in the latest week to $385.72 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. It was the sixth straight week of decline in asset funds and followed an $840 million decline the previous week. That drop originally was reported as $816.6 million but the Washington-based mutual fund trade group revised it. The funds' assets hit a record high $392.14 billion in the week ended March 21. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 246 general purpose funds fell $912.6 million to $132.70 billion, assets of 102 broker-dealer funds fell $2.94 billion to $160.70 billion, and assets of 161 institutional funds rose $1.71 billion to $92.32 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.67 percent from 7.69 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.68 percent from 7.69 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was unchanged at 44 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts was 6.24 percent as of Wednesday, unchanged from a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, was unchanged at 5.05 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.99 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, up from 7.95 percent the previous week. Yields were 8.13 percent on 1-year CDs, up from 8.08 percent; 8.16 percent on 2{-year CDs, up from 8.10 percent; and 8.21 percent on 5-year CDs, up from 8.14 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Chairman on Iranian Scheme: `Take Best Deal You Can'
DOC.TEXT: Ashland Oil Co. ex-chairman Orin Atkins told an associate to ``take the best deal you can'' in a scheme to sell confidential documents to Iran's national oil company, evidence presented at a trial Thursday showed. Atkins didn't know the July 1988 meeting with Roy Furmark, a former Ashland consultant, was being secretly videotaped because Furmark had agreed to cooperate with investigators. The tape was played during Atkins' testimony at the trial of Charles Barnett, a Palm Beach, Fla., attorney charged with joining the plan to sell the documents to the Iranian company for use in a lawsuit against Ashland. Atkins said he was arrested at La Guardia Airport about two hours after the meeting in Furmark's New York office. Atkins pleaded guilty to charges in the case last September and agreed to testify against Barnett. At the meeting, Furmark told Atkins the Iranians had agreed to pay up to $800,000 for the confidential documents Atkins had obtained from Ashland in 1982, after he resigned as chairman but still was employed as a consultant. They decided their Iranian contact would receive $200,000, Furmark would get 60 percent of the remainder and Atkins would split the other 40 percent with Barnett. The Ashland papers dealt with the 1979 sale of $283 million of crude oil from the Iranians to a subsidiary of the Kentucky oil concern Ashland Overseas Trading Ltd. Iran sued Ashland in 1985 for not paying for the oil, and Ashland settled the case last year by agreeing to pay $325 million. On the videotape, Atkins urged Furmark to close the deal, saying he needed money for attorneys' fees in unidentified litigation involving Ashland and because he recently had invested heavily in a coal project. ``I'd like to get something going because quite frankly, I am pretty well damned close to tapped out,'' he said. Later in the conversation, he said, ``Take the best deal you can.'' Atkins also expressed concern about keeping the transaction secret. He suggested the money be deposited into a Swiss bank and then perhaps funneled through a Venezuelan oil concession he owned. When Furmark said the Iranians were interested in getting more documents and possibly consulting help, Atkins replied, ``We may be able to. ... Don't do anything on it till we see something more than we have seen.'' The videotape showed only Atkins, who sat slouched in a chair for the 20-minute meeting. As he got up to leave, he said, ``Let's get us some money and go have a drink, ... do something practical.'' Atkins testified he never received any money from the Iranians. Furmark, who also will testify at Barnett's trial, pleaded guilty in the scheme in March. He admitted showing some of the documents to representatives of the Iranian company at a meeting in London. Atkins faces up to 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine when sentenced later this year for conspiracy and wire fraud.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Post Reports Decline
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Post Co. reported a 6 percent decline in first-quarter earnings Thursday, attributing the weaker results to lower advertising sales at three major divisions. Earnings declined to $39 million, or $3.16 per share, for the first three months of 1990, compared with $41.5 million, or $3.22 per share, for the same quarter of last year. First quarter revenues declined marginally to $340.97 million from $341.88 million. The company said newspaper division revenue remained the same for the quarter, despite a 6 percent decline in advertising inches at The Washington Post, the company's flagship newspaper. Revenues for Newsweek magazine fell 5 percent and broadcast division revenues fell 8 percent. The cable television division, however, reported an 11 percent revenue increase for the quarter, while revenues from other businesses were up 17 percent, the company said. The company also reported sharply higher earnings at Cowles Media Co., in which the Post has a 29 percent interest. Earnings at the Post's newsprint affiliates, however, were lower. During the quarter, the company said it repurchased 253,120 Class B common shares. Since the buy-back program started in 1987, a total of 642,547 shares have been repurchased. The company said the buyback has had no significant effect on the earnings-per-share calculation.

DOC.HEAD: Colt Industries Changes Name to Coltec
DOC.TEXT: Colt Industries Inc., which recently sold its gun division, said Thursday it has changed its name to Coltec Industries Inc. to reflect its new emphasis. The company, based in New York, sold its Colt Firearms Division in March to a group composed of the state of Connecticut, plant managers, workers and private investors. Connecticut said it would invest up to $25 million from state pension funds for a 47 percent stake in the division, which is based in Hartford. Coltec was left with operations in three areas: aerospace and government work, automotive and industrial. The company had 1989 revenue of $1.52 billion, excluding income from the firearms division. Among products made by the remaining divisions are aircraft landing gear and flight control systems; components for aircraft gas turbine engines; automotive replacement parts, fuel system components and transmission controls; truck and bus parts; industrial seals and gaskets; bearings; gas and air compressor parts; metal cutting and forming tools; and electrical transformers.

DOC.HEAD: BMW and Rolls-Royce To Make Aircraft Engines Under Joint Venture
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `BMW said ...' to DELETE incorrect reference that Rolls-Royce is a luxury carmaker; CORRECTS style throughout to Rolls-Royce.
DOC.TEXT: BMW, the West German maker of luxury cars, said Thursday it is entering an aircraft engine joint venture with Britain's Rolls-Royce PLC, returning to a business BMW left 31 years ago. Bayerische Motoren Werke AG said it would acquire an aerospace technology line of Kloekner-Humboldt-Deutz AG (KHD) and then merge the company into a joint venture with Rolls-Royce. BMW said the return to aircraft engines reflects the company's desire to expand into new, though related, industrial areas. The company declined to disclose details of the planned transactions. Rolls-Royce described the deal as both partners acquiring the KHD aerospace unit jointly. BMW said it will control 50.5 percent of the aircraft engine venture, which will be based in Oberursel, just outside Frankfurt. The British aircraft engine maker will own the remainder. The joint venture will develop, manufacture and market jet engines of up to 20,000 pounds of thrust, which power small civilian and military jets capable of carrying up to about 100 passengers. The venture, called BMW-Rolls-Royce, will collaborate with Rolls-Royce's own Tay and Trent jet engine programs, the British company said in a separate press statement. But it said it would not merge any of its existing engine operations into the venture. ``BMW-Rolls-Royce will then commence the design and development of new engines of less than 20,000 pounds of thrust to meet emerging airframe and re-engining requirements in the 75-seater-plus (aircraft) class,'' Rolls-Royce said. A BMW spokesman said that the KHD aerospace unit, which is called KHD Luftfahrttechnik GmbH and located in Oberursel, has about $98 million a year in sales and employs about 900 people. George Shapiro, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. in New York, said the venture appears to be an attempt by Rolls-Royce to boost its position in the aircraft engine industry. ``I've always looked at Rolls-Royce as kind of the weak third-party player,'' he said. General Electric Co. and the Pratt & Whitney division of United Technologies Corp. each hold 40 percent to 45 percent of the worldwide engine market, while Rolls-Royce has a 15 percent to 20 percent share, he said. The new venture will be geared up for strong growth over the next five to 10 years, BMW officials said, declining to project sales targets. European aerospace industry sources suggested that the joint venture could aim for as much as the equivalent of $595 million in yearly sales within the next decade. To reach that goal, however, the two parent companies probably would have to invest as much as 1 billion marks, or about $595 million, in expansion, the experts added. BMW built aircraft engines through World War II, and by the end of the war it produced turbines for the newly developed jet airplane. The Munich-based company left the aircraft engine business in 1959, selling its operations to the big West German engineering group MAN AG, which later merged them with Daimler-Benz AG. The Rolls-Royce-BMW venture follows an industry trend toward joint engine operations. Daimler-Benz earlier this year agreed to link up its civilian jet engine operations with those of the Pratt & Whitney. General Electric has filed a lawsuit challenging Daimler's agreement with Pratt & Whitney, charging it violates a joint engine development accord between GE and Daimler.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rang up a moderate gain Thursday, extending a rally that began at the start of the week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 6.53 to 2,696.17, bringing its gain over the past four sessions to 51.12 points. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 901 up, 557 down and 520 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 145.57 million shares, against 141.61 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 178.17 million shares. In the past couple of days traders' expectations seem to have brightened a little as they look ahead to next week's quarterly sale of bonds and notes by the government. Late Wednesday the Treasury announced plans to offer a record $30.5 billion in securities over the three days of the auctions. The prospect of that heavy load of new supply has been weighing down bond prices and pushing up long-term interest rates for some time. Now, however, analysts say those worries appear to be easing somewhat. Before the Treasury refunding, investors will face the monthly report Friday morning from the Labor Department on the employment situation for April. If Wall Street estimates are on target, the data will show strong gains in payroll employment, renforcing recent evidence that the pace of business activity has picked up of late. N.V. Philips tumbled 2~ to 17[ in active trading. The Netherlands-based electronics company posted a surprisingly sharp decline in profits for the first quarter. Halliburton, by contrast, gained } to 44~. On Wednesday the company reported higher first-quarter earnings. Fleet-Norstar Financial climbed { to 19\. The company, which had a $98.11 million loss in the first quarter, said it expected to return to profitability in the April-June period. Oracle Systems, the most active issue in the over-the-counter market, gained 1] to 17\ as the company cited an improved profit outlook for the fiscal year that ends May 31. Among single-country investment funds, which were strong for the second straight session, Germany Fund rose 1[ to 15]; Austria Fund 1[ to 15[; Korea Fund 1| to 21[; Portugal Fund 1[ to 14, and Jakarta Fund } to 14[. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $10.37 billion, or 0.32 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .63 to 183.97. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.31 to 391.12, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 1.09 at 335.57. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 1.86 to 425.44. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 344.97, up .74.

DOC.HEAD: Union, Tribune Co. Officials Face Off at Annual Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Union leaders from the New York Daily News brought their battle with the parent Tribune Co. to the media giant's annual meeting Thursday, predicting the newspaper would collapse in six months unless its decaying printing plant is replaced. But company officials reiterated their commitment to first bring costs under control at the newspaper before investing in new equipment. Stanton Cook, Tribune Co.'s chairman and chief executive officer, told stockholders that 1989 was a record year for the company, with earnings of more than $242 million. But he said the company would not pour money into the Daily News until ``excessive operational costs'' are eliminated. ``It would be a mistake to underestimate our resolve,'' said Cook. ``The advertisers deserve it, and the shareholders deserve it.'' But George McDonald, head of the Allied Printing Trades Council, which represents 10 Daily News unions in contract negotiations with the company, said corporate officials had it backwards. The unions would make concessions, he said, but not until Tribune Co. agreed to substantial investments at what he called the ``Dickens-like'' plant. ``Unless the investments are made now, the News won't be around in six months,'' McDonald said. ``Let's stop this charade and settle this at the bargaining table.'' His remarks prompted applause from shareholders. Both sides acknowledge that the tough contract talks are crucial to the paper's survival. And both agree the company needs to spend about $500 million on new color presses and a new plant. But company officials have said they want to trim $50 million to $70 million from the Daily News' annual operating costs before investing in new equipment and buildings. Company officials said they want to eliminate unneeded employees in the Daily News' pressroom and drivers unions. Employees representatives say the company wants either to destroy the unions or close the newspaper. McDonald said company officials promised to buy a new plant and presses during a 1986 labor dispute that saw unions give up $30 million in concessions, and he accused Cook of breaking that promise. Cook denied the company or any of its officials promised new plants in 1986, saying no one was authorized to make such a promise and that all commitments made have been met. Meanwhile, Chicago Tribune employees picketed outside the First Chicago Building, where the shareholders meeting was held, and at the Tribune building to show support for their colleagues in New York. Roy Schrode, a 19-year Chicago Tribune pressman, said the company has tried to break the unions at the Chicago Tribune and would try to do the same at the Daily News. Cook, 65, also announced during the meeting that he would step down as Tribune Co.'s chief executive officer and publisher of the Chicago Tribune in August, while remaining chairman of the parent company. Charles Brumback, Tribune Co.'s president and chief operating officer, will become chief executive officer of the Tribune Co. John Madigan, president and chief executive officer of the Chicago Tribune Co., which publishes the paper, will assume Cook's publishing duties at the paper. In addition to its newspapers, Tribune Co. is engaged in publishing, broadcasting, entertainment production and newsprint manufacturing.

DOC.HEAD: Big Three Earnings Dip; Not As Much as Expected
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf to CORRECT that Brazil froze most savings
DOC.TEXT: Profits fell by 54 percent at General Motors Corp. and by 69 percent at Ford Motor Co. in the first quarter due to U.S. production slowdowns and problems with overseas operations, the companies said Thursday. The figures, combined with Chrysler Corp.'s 80 percent drop in first quarter net income, meant an overall 64 percent profit drop for the Big Three automakers during the period. But the results were not as bad as the 75 percent profit decline that analysts had expected for the companies, which are struggling with soft markets and intensified competition from foreign-based automakers. The Big Three earned a combined $1.29 billion in the quarter, down from $3.54 billion in the year-earlier period. Big Three revenue during the period fell 11 percent to $61.27 billion. GM said it earned $710 million, or $1.02 per common share, on revenue of $30.11 billion during the quarter. That compared with a $1.55 billion profit, or $2.37 a share, on revenue of $33.24 billion in the year-earlier period. Ford said it made $506.2 million, or $1.10 a share, during the first three months of this year compared with $1.64 billion, or $3.44 a share, during the same time last year. Ford's revenue fell 9 percent in the quarter, to $23.6 billion from $25.87 billion a year earlier. Through the end of the first quarter, Big Three car and truck sales were 3.6 percent behind last year's pace. By the end of April, sales for Big Three-North American made vehicles were 6.1 percent behind last year's pace. Economic uncertainty in Brazil, where Ford and GM have large presences, dented both companies' overseas earnings, which in past years have shored up sagging North American profits. Strikes in the United Kingdom further hurt Ford's earnings from its overseas operations. David McCammon, Ford's Finance vice president, said Thursday he expected the problems in Brazil to continue affecting the company's earnings in the coming months. Ford and West Germany's Volkswagen AG are linked in the Autolatina joint venture in Brazil. ``I think we are going to see a material drag on Ford's earnings from Brazil in the second quarter largely because there has been no production there since the 15th of March,'' said analyst John Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody & Co. On that day, Ford shut its Autolatina plant after the government froze most savings in an attempt halt runaway inflation. The plant is back in operation, but it will take time to return production to pre-shutdown levels. Kirnan and David Healy, of Barclays-BZW in New York, said cost-cutting programs, especially at Chrysler, softened the impact of severe production cuts in January and costs of incentives throughout the period. McCammon said Ford spent about $1,000 in incentives for each car and light truck it sold during the quarter. In April, he said, that cost rose to about $1,200 per vehicle and predicted the cost would drop back to about $1,000 this month. GM and Chrysler decline to say how much they spent on incentives. The combination of incentives and first-quarter production cuts, which resulted in temporary layoffs of thousands of workers, shrunk dealer new-vehicle stocks, putting them in better shape now than they were at the end of last year. Inventories at the end of March were in the 65-selling-day range, considered good for this time of year and below the 90-day levels at the end of last year. But the production cuts and incentive costs chewed up profits, the automakers said. ``It's almost like the auto industry was going through its own inventory recession in the first quarter, and in a sense it's coming out of its own, self-created recession in the second quarter,'' Healy said. McCammon said Ford planned on running its assembly plants at 110 percent of total capacity during the second quarter, meaning 10 percent of the cars and trucks Ford builds during this quarter will be built on overtime. GM plans to close its Lakewood assembly plant in Atlanta sometime late in the second quarter or early in the third quarter. Chrysler plans to shut its St. Louis car plant in September. GM's subsidiaries reported first quarter results on Wednesday. Profits fell by 13 percent for the GM Hughes defense and aerospace unit, fell 5.6 percent for the General Motors Acceptance Corp. subsidiary and rose by 10.6 percent for the Electronic Data Systems Corp. business.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Fall Despite OPEC Pact
DOC.TEXT: Oil futures prices fell sharply Thursday on the New York Mercantile Exchange despite an OPEC agreement to cut the cartel's total crude-oil output by 1.45 million barrels a day. Analysts said the decline in prices signaled the return of traders who had taken to the sidelines during the emergency OPEC meeting in Geneva and who see little ope in the near term for an easing of the crude oil glut. On other commodity markets, grain and soybean futures settled mostly lower; copper futures fell; precious metals advanced; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 37 cents to 74 cents lower in New York with the contract for delivery in June at $17.99 a barrel. Heating oil finished 1.33 cents to 1.86 cents lower with June at 50 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.27 cents to 1.52 cents lower with June at 59.68 cents a gallon. The 13 ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries unanimously agreed to the production cut Thursday in an effort to help maintain cash oil prices at a minimum of $18 a barrel. OPEC pumped 23.5 million barrels a day in April, said OPEC President Sadek Boussena, well above the cartel's self-imposed ceiling is 22.1 million barrels. Overproduction of crude, especially by chronic quota cheaters Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, has been blamed for the oil glut at a time when demand traditionally eases off in the second quarter. Jim Ritterbusch, energy analyst for PaineWebber Inc., called the OPEC agreement ``too little, too late.'' He said it would be six to eight weeks before the cuts are reflected in supplies at U.S. ports. ``By that time, we're liable to be inundated with the stuff,'' he said. Grain and soybean futures ended mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade with wheat prices falling late in the session following a private forecast for a bumper U.S. wheat crop. Soybean futures posted fairly steep losses; corn was down modestly from Wednesday's close. Wheat trading turned into a tug-of-war between bullish traders who expect the Agriculture Department to target more countries for sales of subsidized U.S. wheat and bearish forces inspired by a surprisingly high wheat-crop forecast by Sparks Commodities Inc., a private crop statistics firm in Memphis, Tenn. Sparks pegged the total 1990 U.S. wheat harvest at 2.7 billion bushels compared with last year's harvest of just over 2 billion bushels. The USDA will release its first 1990 wheat crop estimate on Thursday. Forecasts for beneficial rain in the Midwest weighed on the corn and soybean markets, which gave up much of Wednesday's gains. Wheat futures settled 1 cent lower to 2 cents higher with May at $3.72{ a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 3 cents lower with May at at $2.85{ a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2 cents lower with May at $1.66{ a bushel; soybeans were 5 cents to 8{ cents lower with May at $6.29} a bushel. Copper futures fell moderately on New York's Commodity Exchange despite the refusal by employees of the Southern Peru Copper Corp. to obey a government order imediately to end a strike that began March 12. Copper futures settled .70 cent to 1.10 cents higher with May at $1.202 a pound. Precious metals rose modestly in quiet trading on the Commodity Exchange. Gold futures finished $1.70 to $2.10 higher with June at $373.70 a troy ounce; silver was 0.8 cent to 1 cent higher with May at $4.998 a troy ounce. Cattle futures rose sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in line with firm cash markets. The June contract set a new life-of-contract high of 74.35 cents a pound. Pork futures finished mixed amid profit-taking after recent sharp gains. Live cattle settled .10 cent to .70 cent higher with June at 74.30 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent to .95 cent higher with May at 83.67 cents a pound; live hogs were .35 cent lower to .55 cent higher with June at 63.85 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .62 cent lower to .10 cent higher with May at 69.67 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: M1 Down, M2 Up, M3 Down
DOC.TEXT: The broadest measure of the nation's money supply fell $8 billion in the week ended April 23, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M3 declined to a seasonally adjusted $4,073.6 billion from a revised $4,081.6 billion the previous week. A narrower measure, M2, rose $1.2 billion to a seasonally adjusted $3,278.6 billion from a revised $3,277.4 billion the previous week. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, fell to a seasonally adjusted $805.6 billion from a revised $810.4 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The growth rate in M2 over the past 13 weeks was 6.3 percent, within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The growth rate in M3 over the past 13 weeks was 3 percent, below the Fed's target range of 3.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $282 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $229 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $305.1 billion in the two-week period ended Wednesday, down from $306.2 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed against other major foreign currencies Thursday as many traders stayed on the sidelines awaiting results from British elections and Friday's release of U.S. employment figures. Gold prices advanced modestly. Britons voted in local elections Thursday in the first comprehensive test of the Conservative Party's popularity since Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, now in deep political trouble, won a third term in 1987. The outcome of the balloting could affect the British pound, which declined Thursday. It fell in New York to $1.6410 from $1.6425 late Wednesday. Sterling also lost ground in London, dropping to $1.6425 from $1.6435 late Wednesday. Traders played it safe while waiting for the results, which were expected Thursday night, analysts said. The market also was cautious in advance of the employment figures, especially changes in the non-farm payroll, an indicator of U.S. economic strength. Robert Ryan, senior trader with Bank of New York Co., said the market was looking for a non-farm payroll increase of 150,000 to 200,000. A lower number could set off fears of a recession and send the dollar lower, he said. Markets in Japan were closed Thursday for the Constitution Day holiday. In London, the dollar traded at 158.10 yen, down from Wednesday's close in Tokyo of 158.55 yen. In New York, the dollar rose to 158.045 yen from late Wednesday's 158.015. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.6828 West German marks, down from 1.6848; 1.4550 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.6450 French francs, down from 5.6530; 1,233.25 Italian lire, down from 1,234.75; 1.16625 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16715. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Wednesday's late rates included: 1.6817 West German marks, down from 1.6823; 1.4540 Swiss francs, up from 1.4535; 5.6315 French francs, down from 5.6425; 1.8910 Dutch guilders, unchanged; 1,232.50 Italian lire, up from 1,232.25, and 1.1669 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1672. Gold rose $1.90 a troy ounce to $371.40 on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $371.30, up $1.60. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $370.65 a troy ounce, from $369.25 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $370.25, from $368.85. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.91 to close at a bid $370.07. Silver rose 1 cent to $4.998 on the Commodity Exchange. Earlier, silver rose in London to a late bid price of $5.04 a troy ounce from $5.02 late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Shrinking Market Means Cutbacks For Defense Contractor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to reflect closing stock price Thursday.
DOC.TEXT: The trouble seems to keep coming for the world's largest defense contractor. The market for McDonnell Douglas Corp.'s defense aircraft continues shrinking, 3,000 workers in its commercial aircraft division are about to be laid off and now workers at the company's largest union are talking about striking. McDonnell Douglas' stock, which reached a high of $95 a share last year, also is taking a beating. The shares have dropped more than 20 percent since the end of last year and closed at $47.62{ Thursday. ``We know it's a bad time for the company,'' said Cassell Williams, president of District 837 of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which will take a strike vote Sunday. ``But what's a good time for a strike? Whenever you have to.'' Reflecting the defense industry's woes, the company posted a $2 million overall profit in the first quarter but lost money in its transport aircraft business. Government work provides about two-thirds of McDonnell Douglas' $15 billion in annual sales. Among the programs targeted for cuts by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney are McDonnell Douglas' F-15 Eagle fighter and C-17 Air Force cargo plane. In an attempt to rebound, the company is banking heavily on the booming world market for commercial jets, which has strengthened as more world markets have opened to unrestricted travel. Chairman John McDonnell recently announced that the company planned to expand its commercial sales in the United States, Asia and Europe over the next five years. ``Fortunately, they've got the capability to shift emphasis and it makes sense that they do it,'' said industry analyst Paul Nisbet of Prudential-Bache in New York. ``But they're going to have to run like hell to stay in the race.'' McDonnell Douglas controls about 15 percent to 20 percent of the world commercial aircraft market, compared with Boeing Co.'s 60 percent share. A commercial jet-oriented expansion will rely on a turnaround at Douglas Aircraft, the Long Beach, Calif.-based subsidiary that makes passenger airliners and the C-17 cargo plane. Douglas Aircraft lost $222 million last year and $84 million in the first three months of this year. Last week the company announced it was laying off 3,000 of the more than 45,000 workers in Long Beach as a cost-cutting measure. Officials said the layoffs were unrelated to Cheney's announcement the previous day that he wants to reduce the size of the C-17 program by 43 percent. In addition to cost problems, Douglas Aircraft has been plagued by efficiency problems. The company is having trouble meeting construction deadlines, a problem blamed mostly on cramped operations. The C-17 in particular has been a problem, with costs nearing the company's bid ceiling. McDonnell Douglas will have to absorb the costs for every dollar over its bid for the C-17, which is scheduled for its first prototype flight in mid-1991. ``The C-17 is not out of the woods yet,'' said industry analyst Lawrence Harris of Bateman, Eichler, Hill, Richards in Los Angeles. Harris said McDonnell Douglas' helicopter division also has been a disappointment, with writeoffs the last three quarters on the AH-64 Apache and related problems. At the annual shareholder meeting last week, McDonnell pleaded for patience, saying the company needed more time to turn Douglas Aircraft around. He described McDonnell Douglas as a ``strong company with weak financial results.'' Still, McDonnell projects the company will gain a larger market share than it has had for the last five years or so through increased commercial aircraft sales. McDonnell Douglas introduced its MD-11 jet transport last year and McDonnell says the company will pursue joint ventures with Japanese companies developing high-speed commercial transports. Analysts agree that the company probably will rebound, but say the aerospace industry works in fairly long cycles. ``We are at bottom,'' McDonnell said. ``But we really see it as a long-term investment. McDonnell Douglas can and will be a major beneficiary of world change.'' In the more immediate future, there are pressing labor problems. A 29-man bargaining committee for McDonnell Douglas' machinists and aerospace workers union voted unanimously Wednesday to reject the company's final contract offer, only hours after receiving the proposal. District 837 represents 11,850 of McDonnell Douglas' 12,800 unionized workers and its contract expires on Sunday. The union must give the company a seven-day notice, but picketing and a work stoppage could start next Sunday. ``We haven't lost any money here,'' said Williams, the union president. ``Their financial problems are caused by problems in other locations, mainly California. They're trying to put Douglas Aircraft on our backs.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Calls Executive `Wacko' After Information-Swapping Charges
DOC.TEXT: It was just another congressional subcomittee hearing, droning on about market regulation, until Rep. Norman Lent, R-N.Y., called one of the witnesses a ``wacko.'' Then the hearing Thursday on a bill to merge the Securities and Exchange Commission with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission took off in a burst of charges and countercharges. Lent took exception to remarks by James Coxon, manager of a $60 billion CIGNA Corp. fund, who maintained that employees at some top Wall Street firms exchanged information about trading strategies and customer orders. Coxon, testifying before the finance subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, said individuals at the firms were able to trade ahead of major market trends and the firms' customers. The practice of trading with advance knowledge of incoming customer orders is known as front running. It is illegal in the securities and commodity futures markets, but front-running between the markets is unregulated because neither the SEC nor the CFTC has authority over the other's markets. He said that aside from the information exchanges by what he called ``clubs,'' he had no evidence of illegal activity and had not made a formal complaint to the SEC or CFTC. Subcommittee member Jim Cooper, D-Tenn., complained that nary an eyebrow was raised after what he termed Coxon's ``bombshell'' allegations. Then Lent spoke up: ``I didn't react to that statement (because) I didn't put much credence in it. So when people start mouthing off about secret cabals and clubs, I figure it's just another wacko in the room.'' Cooper countered: ``I don't think the CIGNA insurance company hires wackos to manage $60 billion of assets and it seems to me that the weighty charge is entitled to some sort of reasoned response, perhaps even an investigation.'' Lent later he was sorry for using the term ``wacko'' but continued to criticize Coxon's remarks. He questioned Coxon heatedly about whether he thought he was breaking the law and if he had reported it to anyone. Coxon said he gave a copy of a speech in which he outlined the activities described to the subcommittee to an SEC official late last year. SEC spokeswoman Mary McCue confirmed that an associate director in the division of market regulation had received the speech. The agency neither confirms nor denies investigations, but McCue said: ``We are aware of Mr. Coxon's concerns.'' Edward I. O'Brien, president of the Securities Industry Association, denied the existence of activities described by Coxon. ``I don't know if he is a wacko or not, but his allegations were very unfocused,'' O'Brien said. ``He didn't exactly make the case that there was a violation of any securities law and if so, what it was.'' Coxon is a former principal at Morgan Stanley & Co. and later a fund manager for Harvard Management, which oversees Harvard University's investments. He said stock-index futures _ which let investors speculate on the performance of a large group of stocks without buying the underlying stocks _ ``are used by a smaller group that has determined how to `game' the system and benefit from volatility that is excessive, unnecessary and perhaps induced.'' In prepared remarks he read to the committee, Coxon said: ``Certain Wall Street firms seem prepared to foul their own nests, by forming clubs to share proprietary customer information.'' Coxon said he did not know if sharing proprietary information was continuing. ``As a former member of this club, I assure you that it's very highly organized. It shares information and indeed the intelligence gathering that takes place would make the CIA look like a Sunday school,'' Coxon told Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., the subcommittee chairman. ``Essentially the gaming takes place by knowing the entire order books of the major houses in the securities industries. I'm not saying those houses knowingly participate in the club,'' he said. Coxon indicated it was more accurate to say those who exchanged the information worked ``at'' their firm rather than ``for'' it.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Rise on Refunding Announcement, Employment Figure
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices rose Thursday after the government announced details of its quarterly refunding auction and a report indicated April's jobless rate may be higher than originally expected. The closely watched 30-year bond advanced 7-16 point, or about $4.37 for each $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which falls when the price rises, eased to 8.97 percent from 9.01 percent late Wednesday. The Treasury said late Wednesday it would sell a record $30.5 billion in new debt at its May 8-10 auction, about $500 million more than the previous record set in February. But bond traders had been concerned that as much as $35 billion in new notes and bonds would be sold, glutting the market and depressing the value of existing debt securities. ``The uncertainty of what would be announced has been removed,'' said William Veronda, a fixed-income specialist at Financial Programs Inc., a Denver investment firm. ``It was only a relatively modest increase.'' The quarterly refunding auctions are critical to bond investors because they set the background for a range of interest rates that help determine the value of bonds as well as the pace of economic growth. Low demand for new Treasury debt forces the government to raise yields to attract buyers, which can push interest rates up elsewhere. High demand eases the pressure on yields and can help ease or stabilize interest rates. Bond prices also were boosted by a government report Thursday that the level of initial unemployment claims rose a good deal in week ended April 21, said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Government Securities Inc. The report caused some economists to revise upward their estimate of April's unemployment figures, due out Friday. Signs of a weaker economy, such as a higher jobless rate, tend to support bond prices because they could prompt the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates. Also Thursday, the Treasury sold $10.04 billion of one-year bills at an average discount rate of 8.05 percent, up from 7.72 percent at the last auction on April 5. The rates were the highest since last June 1, when the one-year bills sold for 8.18 percent. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term securities rose [ point to \ point, intermediate maturities rose 9-32 point to 13-32 point, and long-term issues rose 13-32 point to 7-16 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point equals a $10 change in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 3.50 to 1,130.60. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds was at 89 3-16, up 3-16 point. The average yield to maturity edged down to 7.72 percent from 7.74 percent late Wednesday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 8.11 percent as the discount fell 4 basis points to 7.85 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 8.41 percent as the discount fell 3 basis points to 7.97 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 8.58 percent as the discount fell 1 basis point to 7.99 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 3-16 percent, up from 6{ percent late Wednesday. The 6{ percent rate was abnormally low due to technicalities in settling bond trades.

DOC.HEAD: Federated Withdrawing Offer to Sell Bloomingdale's
DOC.TEXT: Federated Department Stores Inc. said Thursday it had withdrawn its offer to sell its Bloomingdale's chain, one of the company's most valuable properties. ``Market circumstances _ as well as Federated's own financial status _ have changed significantly since we offered Bloomingdale's for sale,'' Allen Questrom, Federated's chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement. Federated spokeswoman Carol Sanger said, ``The reason for selling it, which was, in part, to raise cash, no longer exists.'' Thursday's announcement had been expected for some time. The retailer first announced its intention to sell Bloomingdale's in September 1989 when the company announced it was unable to meet its debt payments. Federated and its sister retailing company, Allied Stores Corp. filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization in January, listing $7.7 billion in debt, much of it accumulated when Toronto-based Campeau Corp. bought Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988 in leveraged buyouts. Since the original Bloomingdale's announcement, Federated has obtained more operating cash plus debtor-in-possession financing approved by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. Federated did not reveal how many offers it had received for Bloomingdale's nor any details of those offers. Bloomingdale's operates 17 stores in New York, Florida, Illinois, Massachusetts, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Texas, Virginia and Connecticut. An 18th store is being built in Palm Beach, Fla., and is to open late this year.

DOC.HEAD: Cigna Earnings Drop for First Quarter 1990
DOC.TEXT: Cigna Corp. said its earnings fell by half in the first three months of the year, partly because of big claims resulting from severe winter storms in Europe. The big insurance company said Thursday profits fell to $42 million or 54 cents a share from $85 million or $1.02 a share in the first quarter of 1989. Net income for the 1989 quarter included $13 million from operations that have been sold or discontinued. ``Our first-quarter 1990 results reflect unusually severe winter storms in Europe, which reduced earnings by $34 million after-tax. Results were also affected by continued inadequate property and casualty pricing,'' said Wilson H. Taylor, chairman and chief executive officer. The company's property and casualty division lost $24 million in the latest period, compared with income of $42 million in 1989. ``Our Employee Life and Health Benefits businesses continued to improve, led by non-indemnity health-care operations (HMOs) which reported a profit of $7 million, an improvement of over $20 million from last year's first quarter,'' Taylor said. ``In addition, the group pension and individual financial services businesses reported strong results and were in line with our expectations for the first quarter,'' he said. ``Assuming a normal level of catastrophes, I expect overall earnings for the remainder of the year to be better than in 1989. I also anticipate earnings growth beyond 1990, assuming price improvements in the casualty market,'' he said. Consolidated revenues from continuing operations rose 6 percent in the first quarter to $3.9 billion from $3.7 billion in 1989. Assets at the end of the first quarter were $60.2 billion, up from $57.8 billion at the end of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Ministers Remain at Odds in California Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 7 grafs to UPDATE with comments from Hills, Deukmejian
DOC.TEXT: Trade negotiators reported no major breakthroughs Thursday in their effort to resolve disagreements that threaten to derail an ambitious effort to reform the global trading system. Trade ministers from the United States, Japan, the 12-nation European Community and Canada held a second day of discussions behind closed doors at a resort in the California wine country. The United States is seeking to boost export opportunities for American farmers and business by getting agreement to eliminate expensive farm export subsidies, to eliminate barriers to trade in services and to toughen restrictions on copyright and trademark piracy. A U.S. trade official, briefing reporters on condition that his name not be used, said there was some progress toward better defining the areas of disagreement but no success at resolving the major disputes. The biggest fight involves the American effort to end trade-distorting agricultural subsidies, something the European Community opposes. The talks were scheduled to conclude after a final bargaining session on Friday. The Bush adminisration has made the negotiations its top trade priority, insisting that expanded export opportunities will help significantly reduce America's huge trade deficit. The discussions, which are being conducted under the auspices of the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, began in Uruguay in 1986. Trade Representative Carla Hills, who is leading the U.S. team, said she was optimistic differences can be narrowed. But many fear that unless there are significant compromises soon, the four-year effort will end unsuccessfully at the final bargaining session Dec. 3-7 in Brussels. Hills and the other trade ministers hoped the California talks would provide the guidance for lower-level negotiators to put together a tentative agreement in many of the areas during a July bargaining session in Geneva. ``There has to be substantial agreeement by July,'' said Canadian Trade Minister John Crosbie, who warned that failure of the GATT talks would result in an ``international trade shambles.'' The European Community is strongly resisting American demands for a total phase-out of agricultural subsidies, arguing it must protect its small farms. Third World countries are fighting the proposals to clamp down on copyright piracy and break down barriers to trade in services, arguing the developing world needs to protect its infant industries against huge multinational companies. The administration claims copyright and trademark piracy costs U.S. companies $60 billion annually. In addition to pushing its proposals in the GATT talks, the administration is being forced to battle special interest groups in the United States that stand to lose trade protections as well. Legislation has been introduced in Congress to retain textile industry barriers against foreign imports. Peanut growers and sugar producers who benefit from special subsidies that limit foreign competition are also working to build congressional opposition. Hills has countered that American farm groups stand to gain much more than they will lose through eliminating other countries' barriers. She said exports of U.S. farm products could rise by $11 billion annually _ an amount equal to $3,400 for every American farmer. Speaking to reporters after Thursday's session, Hills said working groups would examine a number of issues in the hope of narrowing differences further before the start of Friday's final session. ``We made constructive progress,'' she said of the talks so far. Crosbie put the chances for ultimate success at better than 50-50 because ``the consequences of failure are so horrific.'' But the Canadian trade minister said progress at this stage was measured by very small steps in a number of areas. ``You can't put your finger on any specific thing and say it is a great leap forward,'' he said. Republican Gov. George Deukmejian of California, addressing a luncheon for the trade ministers, defended the administration's free-trade policies, saying that competition was good for American industry and consumers. ``From agriculture and aerospace to electronics and entertainment, (Californians) have created markets worldwide,'' he said. ``We engage the competition abroad and welcome it at home, for trade stimulates innovation and delivers better products at lower prices.''

DOC.HEAD: Failed Defense Effort Cost $106 Million
DOC.TEXT: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. said it spent nearly $107 million in the first quarter in its failed attempt to fend off a takeover bid from Georgia-Pacific Corp. Non-recurring expenses for its defense efforts totalled $106.9 million from Jan. 1 to March 8, the company said Thursday in disclosing its first quarter results. The expenses caused the company to post a loss of $57.3 million in the period, equivalent to $1.03 a share. Before the expenses, Great Northern had operating income of $87.8 million on sales of $710.5 million. The company reported its earnings in two parts, divided by results before and after March 8, when Georgia-Pacific completed its $5 billion takeover. The deal created the nation's largest forest products company. From March 9 to March 31, Great Northern lost $14 million or 25 cents a share. It had operating income of $18.3 million on sales of $242.5 million in the period. For all of the first three months, Great Northern lost $71.3 million on sales of $953 million, compared with net income of $93.3 million on sales of $976.8 million in the first quarter of 1989. Operating income fell to $106.1 million from $191.8 million.

DOC.HEAD: Fuji Heavy Industries Buys All of Subaru
DOC.TEXT: Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd. of Japan said Thursday it agreed to acquire the 50.5 percent stake outstanding of its U.S. importer, Subaru of America Inc., for more than $400 million. The deal should be completed by September. Fuji holds the other 49.5 percent of Subaru. The outstanding shares are held mostly by individuals and some large institutional investors, Subaru spokesman Dan Dalton said. By virtue of its public holdings, Subaru had been the only seller of foreign automobiles to report U.S. earnings figures. After the deal is complete, the company will not have to issue U.S. earnings reports. The other Japan-based U.S. automakers are wholly owned subsidiaries and not required to report on their American operations. Subaru joined with Isuzu Motors Ltd. of Japan in a joint manufacturing venture in Lafayette, Ind. Production of Subaru cars and Isuzu trucks began in September. In addition to Subaru cars, Fuji Heavy Industries produces aircraft and aircraft parts, engines and other machinery.

DOC.HEAD: Genentech Says SEC Mounts Inquiry into Pre-Merger Stock Trades
DOC.TEXT: Genentech Inc. revealed Thursday that the Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating trading in its stock just before a proposed merger with Roche Holdings Inc. was announced. Genentech, a San Francisco-based biotechnology concern, revealed the SEC inquiry in a filing of its merger proxy with the agency. The SEC, as a matter of policy, neither confirms nor denies the existence of an investigation. In the filing, Genentech said it understands the inquiry is focusing on ``certain communications between the wife of G. Kirk Raab,'' Genentech's president, and a member of her family before the merger agreement was announced. The filing did not disclose who was involved in the questioned trades but said they involved ``persons other than Mrs. Raab.'' According to the document, a routine filing required under SEC disclosure rules, Genentech said it and the Raabs have cooperated with the investigation and the company said it does not believe either it or the Raabs is under investigation. Under the merger agreement, which must be ratified by shareholders at the company's annual meeting June 8, Roche will pay $492 million for control of 60 percent of Genentech.

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Up This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 228,228 cars and light trucks this week, up from last week's 227,875, Ward's Automotive Reports said. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 242,038 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said Thursday. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 136,600 cars this week, compared with 137,562 a week ago and 153,062 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 91,628, compared with last week's 90,313 and last year's 88,976. Canadian automakers were to build 26,560 cars this week, up from 23,995 a week ago and up from last year's 21,974. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 26,560, compared with 23,995 a week ago and 21,974 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Fed: Farm Debt Estimated at 11-Year Low
DOC.TEXT: Farm debt declined for a sixth straight year in 1989 to an 11-year low and the quality of farm loans improved, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago estimates. Most analysts expect the downward trend in debt to halt this year, though, Fed economist Gary Benjamin said. Benjamin estimated total farm debt declined nearly 2 percent in 1989 to $135.6 billion from $138.4 billion a year earlier. He based the figure on recent reports from major farm lending institutions and a preliminary U.S. Department of Agriculture assessment of farm loans held by all other lenders. Commercial banks are the largest source of loans to farmers, accounting for a third of all farm debt. The total for 1989 includes approximately $74.3 billion in farm loans secured by real estate, a drop of 3 percent from 1988. The remaining $61.3 billion in loans primarily reflected borrowing for farm operations and equipment and was down less than 1 percent from the previous year. Compared to 1983 peaks, both real estate and non-real estate loans were down about 30 percent, Benjamin said in an Agricultural Letter published by the Chicago Fed. ``While the 1980s marked a decade during which farm debt fell substantially following a period of widespread financial distress, most analysts are looking for a modest upturn in farm debt this year,'' Benjamin said. ``Reflecting the painful lessons learned during the financial distress of a few years ago, both lenders and farm borrowers remain cautious with respect to new borrowings. ``Prospects for another year of strong net cash farm earnings, particularly in the Midwest, suggest that repayments on existing farm debts will remain favorable and that many farmers will continue to rely heavily on internally generated funds to cover new expenditures. At the same time, however, prospects for further but modest gains in farmland values and farm operating expenses, coupled with the continuing rebound in expenditures for farm machinery and equipment, imply farm loan demand will be somewhat stronger this year,'' Benjamin said. He also reported that the quality of loans on the books of commercial lenders improved last year. For banks, such improvements are reflected in smaller charges against earnings for bad loans and a drop in the proportion of delinquent loans. Net charge-offs of farm loans by banks nationwide last year declined to less than $100 million from $140 million in 1989 and an annual average of $1.2 billion from 1984-86.

DOC.HEAD: No U.S. Recession, Pickup in third World, Hope for Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-6 pvs, `Japan should ... next year' with 5 grafs to show forecast for industrial countries is below last fall's forecast.
DOC.TEXT: No recession is in sight for the United States and other industrial countries, things are looking up in the Third World and eastern Europe could become a source of dynamism for the world, the International Monetary Fund said Thursday. The fund projected a rosy future in its semi-annual ``World Economic Outlook,'' provided governments carry out the kind of policies it wants to see _ lower budget deficits, balanced world trade, privatization of government-owned business. It predicts world production will grow 2.25 percent this year and accelerate to a 3 percent growth rate in 1991. That would match last year's rate but still be behind the 4 percent growth posted in 1988. The industrialized countries should grow by 2.7 percent this year, the fund predicts. That is down slightly from its forecast last fall of 2.9 percent growth. Japan should lead the growth parade of the major industrial countries with a 4.4 percent rate this year and 4.2 percent in 1991. For 1990 West Germany should be in second place at 3.5 percent but yield that position to France and Canada in 1991, which are expected to grow 3.1 percent that year. Officials warned, however, that their figures could not take full account of German unification. German forecasts expect that to be a sharp spur to growth. The United States, the world's biggest economy, is expected to lag behind with a 1.7 percent growth rate this year and 2.3 percent next year. The latest 1990 forecasts for the United States and Japan are down from last fall, when the fund predicted growth of 2.1 percent and 4.7 percent, respectively. The forecast of 3.5 percent growth for West Germany this year is up from last fall's prediction of 3.0 percent, however. The fund classes only 22 countries among its 152 members as industrial. It lumps east Asian ``tigers'' like South Korea with laggards in Africa and Latin America as developing countries. The report forecast their production will rise 3 percent this year, 4.5 percent next year. By 1995 the growth rate for these countries should be at the 5 percent level last seen in the 1970s. ``The increase in growth projected for these countries rests heavily on the assumption that adjustment policies are successful in bringing down inflation and improving the climate for domestic savings and investment,'' the report said. But it saw little scope for Africa to recoup its losses of income in the 1980s. Leaders in both Africa and Latin American often speak of the 1980s as a ``lost decade.'' The fund's rosiest forecast was for Asia _ 5.7 percent growth next year, despite a downward revision for China. It also predicted a marked improvement in growth rates for eastern Europe, though the uncertainties of recent changes and those to come made it wary of exact projections. ``With their relatively skilled work forces, the countries of eastern Europe could emerge as a source of dynamism for Europe and, to a lesser extent, for the world economy,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: State Awards Unemployment Benefit Eligibility To Strikers
DOC.TEXT: Pennsylvania has offered unemployment benefits to striking Greyhound Lines Inc. bus drivers and mechanics, a move company officials claimed made the state the first in the nation to do so. Labor Secretary Harris Wofford announced the payments, which will affect about 300 Pennsylvania strikers, at the AFL-CIO's state convention in Pittsburgh Thursday. The benefits, which would total $288 a week for a claimant with two dependents, will be paid retroactive to March 2, when the strike began. The benefits last up to 26 weeks, Wofford said. ``Now we're ready to stay out for another six months,'' said Dick Erath of Pittsburgh, who wore a Greyhound driver's uniform as he marched with hundreds of AFL-CIO members during a downtown Pittsburgh demonstration. Wofford's announcement was met with a standing ovation at the convention, which has drawn more than 2,000 labor leaders to Pittsburgh. Until now, unemployment benefits have been awarded only on an individual basis, according to Greyhound spokeswoman Elizabeth Hale. The company plans to appeal the benefits, she said. ``Nobody has been locked out,'' Ms. Hale said. ``The strike was called by the union.'' Under Pennsylvania law, employees are eligible to collect the benefits when their unemployment results from a lockout _ the refusal by an employer to allow employees to come to work. The state Labor Department ruled Greyhound imposed new contract terms on the workers despite an offer by Amalgamated Transit Union members to continue working under terms of an expired pact during negotiations. Greyhound has hired 2,754 replacement drivers to run its buses along with 539 union drivers who have crossed picket lines. The union represents 6,300 drivers and 3,000 maintenance and office workers. Negotiations are scheduled to resume Saturday in the offices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service in Washington D.C. The bargaining session would be the first since March 18, when the company broke off talks blaming violence associated with the strike.
Eds: Japan's financial markets are closed for a national holiday Friday.
